review: Star Wars feeling reborn! Great game. Old as the Bible, but still like to play it from time to time. The expansions gives room to install mods. The Mods are insane. Love them. Some are buggy unfortunately and the galactic campaign gets slow, but this is the price of making new mods with old based games. Still, it is a game that gives you the Star Was feeling and worth having in collection.

I saw an add for this game when I was really young and begged my parents for it. They got me the box version for Christmas that year and the Forces of Corruption expansion box edition that Easter to my surprise. It was my first introduction to strategy games and will probably forever be my favorite game with the extensive modding community out there for it still to this day. Before the servers went down originally I would play this game's MP everyday after school for probably 6 years and who know's how many time's I've played the 3 campaigns back then lol. The game offers a lot of replayability and I would recommend it to anyone looking for looking for individual battles, galactic domination, or story based campaigns set in a Star Wars universe. It would be amazing to see a modern iteration of this game.

One of the best Star Wars RTS games, it has a lot of replayability in Galactic Conquest mode or online with the friends. Let's not even mention the fact that there are countless mods for it in the workshop that adds extra spice to the game.
Playing with or against friends is also fun, especially out-witting them in Galactic Conquest.
It's horribly imbalanced yet you can't stop playing. It's the most weirdly addictive RTS since C&C Generals, and I say that with the highest of praise.

The best Star Wars RTS ever and one of the best Star Wars game overall.  It also comes with [i]The Forces of Corruption[/i] Expansion. Great campaign, gameplay and space battles are particularly awesome.

The vanilla game is pretty fun (yes the graphics may not be the most impressive but the gameplay is still pretty fun).  In terms of audio, it sounds like a Star Wars game, enough said (the game makes the rather bold choice not to use too much of John Williams' soundtrack but the soundtrack is actually quite solid). 

In terms of gameplay itself, starting of simple,you have basic skirmish mode which is typical for most RTSs. Nothing too much to explain here. Where the game really shines is the Campaign and Galactic Conquest mode. 

For campaign, you pick either the Rebels or Empire (or in Forces of Corruption, the Zahn Consortium) and play through a story based campaign with objectives. It's essentially meant as a tutorial or beginner friendly Galactic Conquest mode but it's still great fun where you (for the Rebels and Empire) play basically from the founding of the Rebellion right up to the Battle of Yavin. 

The main Galactic Conquest mode is essentially the campaign but no hand holding and open ended. This is probably how you will spend most of your time playing the game. Like the campaign, it's split between the empire management and recruiting units on the Galactic map and then the remainder is spent fighting actual battles. 

In terms of the battles itself, the space battles are definitely more fun than ground with the ability to target capital ship subsystems, stop retreats into hyperspace (as the Empire), use ion cannons (as the rebels) and more. Ground isn't bad, it's just less fun compared to space. That being said, it hella satisfying bringing down 5 AT-ATs from orbit and setting them on the rebel base or watching Darth Vader tank an entire rebel army. 

Last but certainly not least, this game is pretty replayable as is but it would be criminal not to mention the fantastic modding community for this game which is still very active. With some mods literally turning the game into a new one from enhancements to the base game to changing the era or even universe of the game, there's plenty to do once you're done with vanilla. It's also pretty easy to install mods thanks to Steam Workshop.

One of my favorite space-based RTS games. Base game is so-so, especially being from 2006, but with mods it really shines. My personal favorite mods are Thrawn's Revenge and Empire at War Remake. They're both pretty good mods with good developers behind them. Galactic Conquest can be a good time-killer, and individual Skirmish matches can be a good quick-fix. Land Combat is pretty meh, and the pathfinding AI can be pretty abysmal (both in space and on land) sometimes, but again, its a pretty solid game with mods.
RTS at its best.  Finally a single player campaign that lives up to its genre. And a killer price to match.
Excellent rts game, lots of amazing custom content too.

The game is fun, it has a dynamic combat system, even if some of it is based on a rock, paper, scissors system. The game has many systems outside of ground and Space combat, even if that is the bulk of it, which make the downtime between combat entertaining in its own right. The galactic campaigns are fun and allow for many choices to the made, strategies to use, and even order of the entire conquest to be decided. 

The main downsides are this is an older game whose graphics are aging, however, this does not take away from gameplay or the creativity of players. As this game as a large and active modding communities with many large scale mods to be used.

I cannot recommend this game enough. It is one of my favorites of all time and something I always fallback on when I have time to kill and don't know what else to play. This is one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played. It may take a little getting used to, as strategy is a big part of this game. Strategy and conquest. I will also admit that I have never once won a game as the Rebel Alliance. I have tried, but it's just never happened. I do somewhat like the difficulty behind the Rebels as it ties in with the actual movies stating the Empire is basically crushing the Rebellion at every turn, but it's also somewhat annoying.

The Empire on the other hand is like a dream come true. You nearly cannot be stopped as the Empire. If you want to throw a ton of AT-ATs down at the Rebels, go right ahead, just beware of Snow Speeders. If you wanna dominate space battles with Darth Vader's Super Star Destroyer, go right ahead. It's the best ship in the entire game. If you want to just say forget it and use the Death Star to destroy the galaxy, you can do that too!

The mods for this game also make it a grand experience.

The Doctor's In-Depth Review of Star Wars: Empire At War


So, I've played empire at war for almost 100 hours so it's about time I do a review. I've only had for a small amount of time, but within that time, I've had a lot of fun! I received the game for approximately £5 so bare that in mind while reading this review. All of the modes were played in Single player, see further down for multiplayer review.

In case your not sure what Star Wars: Empire at War (and it's additional "Forces of Corruption™" content) is, it is a tactical space and ground battle game within the Star Wars galaxy. There's 3 mains modes.

The first mode is Campaign, where you either follow the harsh fist of the Galactic Empire, the hopeful revolt of the Rebellion or the fierce Criminal Underworld*, as you attempt to capture the galaxy against the powerful opposing forces; depending on your current team. You follow a (weak) story-line and follow orders to best achieve galactic conquest. They have some unique missions, such as the opening breakout for the Zann Consortium* or the attack on the pirate base with Boba Fett. But most of the story is just capturing as many planets with some story behind it. But overall a less demanding story-line can still be fun due to the extremely entertaining game play.
*All Zann Consortium References can only be accessed with additional content, already added within the Empire at War: Gold Pack.

The second, most common, mode is Galactic Conquest. Galactic conquest is the main means on the game and follows the same game play as the campaign and some key features of it is used in the third mode. Galactic Conquest is where you start of with a few planets owned by you, either the Empire, Rebellion or Zann Consortium; where'd you then build up your fleet and ground forces and set off into other planets, pillaging them and ruling over them. Once a new planet is captured you'd then use it to upgrade your fleet with better space stations, building mines (to create more money), or to add more variations of bases. This is only three things you can do among MANY other things. You'd then meet the Opposing side, also attempting to take over planets to create a stronger army. Where you'd then fight until only you stand and you are the only leader on the galaxy. Galactic Conquest does take a while to finish depending on the map but is highly replayable due to the many maps, different tactics and different sides you can use.

Unlike Galactic Conquest (GC)', the third mode, Skirmish is a lot shorter and can end between 7min-20min depending on skill level. Skirmish strictly takes the ground and space battles from them and makes them into a game mode within itself. Where you play against an AI in a 1v1 space or ground combat. For this review I will be using the Space Skirmish as an example but can easily be translated to ground combat (e.g. Space station = Base) . Each side has one space station and goes to find mines across the map to capture to gain an income, where you then spend it on upgrading your station, purchasing more troops to defend those mines or giving tech upgrades to make your side stronger in specific ways. Once your side is strong enough you can attack the other space station to win the match. It's a simple game mode that is amazing to play with or without friends!

Multiplayer Empire at War is EVEN better! You and your friends can all play together to fight against each other or AI in skirmish, 1v1 in an intense battle of Campaign or just mess around in the lobby. Multiplayer in Empire at War will keep you playing for weeks, months, (possibly) years longer! You don't even need to have steam friends, you can find constantly active lobbies in Multiplayer just waiting for you to join.

Beside from the default game, the strongest part of the game is not the game itself, but the mods. Mods are the biggest reason EAW has such an active player base. From Thrawn's Revenge to Republic at War, mods can keep you going for years. Mods are multiplayer friendly-ish (they can bug out occasionally) They are amazingly entertaining. They have two game modes to choose from, Skirmish and Conquest. Mods have new ships, new maps, new field commands and so much more! Due to there being a large modding community for Star Wars: Empire at War, there are lots of mods to choose from, and more coming out, even though this game is over a decade old.

Another amazing thing about Star Wars: Empire at War is that the base game is very low specs, you don't need a geforce PC, decked out with water cooling and LEDs that can power the hubble telescope, a laptop from 2006 works fine. (Tried and tested by yours truly.) Mods might get laggy depending on the quality of the entities. The main thing to look out for is the "pop cap" or population capacity. if the population capacity reaches too high on space battles the higher the chance it'll lag.

A Review of the Galactic Empire
The Galactic Empire is mine, and the majority of my friend's, favourite choice. it's amazing to see a star destroyer emerge out of hyperspace out of the dark vacuum of space, accompanied with 2 others as they deploy the tie fighters, bombers and interceptors to crush the rebellion. The empire starts of just like the rebels with an equal amount of planets (varying on which map you use). They have such unique ships as the Interdictor-class Star Destroyer capable of stopping the opposing forces from retreating or sending in reinforcements. The other unique space vessel they have is, of course, the Death Star. Capable of destroying any space station, ship or planet with a single blow. So the power of the Empire can get to your head, but it's fun, and generally the easiest team to get a grip on.

A Review of the Rebel Alliance
The Rebel Alliance is a lot more self controlled compared to the Empire's way of conquering. While the Empire has large destroyers capable of carrying how many tie fighters, The rebel alliance has to purchase each squadron separately allowing you to control the amount of forces going into one area at once. The rebels are generally a lot weaker than the empire, but with the use of the many heroes given to you early game, such as Luke Skywalker or Han Solo, you are able to conquer the skies, but are more even on the ground, still needing support from heroes, that easily sway the tides of battles. They also have the ability to scout ahead using C3-PO and R2-D2 and steal blueprints for more ships and tech upgrades among other things. The rebels are harder to understand but can be used effectively in certain situations if used correctly.

A Review of the Criminal Underworld/Zann Consortium
I know a lot less about them but have recently used them in preparation for this review and also because i was bored. The main strength of the Underworld is that they have the ability to make planets corrupt, allowing them to create an income off other planets including the opposing force(s). If they would like to go around a planet to invade someone. They would have to corrupt the blocking planet, then bribe them to pass through. They also have powerful ships that can deal lots of damage but work best in numbers.

In conclusion, this is one of the best star wars game to date and is worth getting if it's on sale, I feel as if £15.49 (or what ever currency it is for you) is too much, but if you like space, tactics and star wars then get this as soon as you have the money! I can't recommend this enough. I've literally written this huge review for it due to my love and respect for a game made in 2006. And you've got to realise, there's gotta be a reason it's worth this much money (that's still not that much) for a game almost 15 years old. (by the time I'm writing this)

TL;DR: This game is really fun in single player and multiplayer and the mods are perfect to change the entire experience. Also game = very good.

One of the best Star Wars games I have ever played.  It especially pairs well with the free mods Thrawn's Revenge, Fall of the Republic, Legacy at War, and Empire at War Remake.

My review is mostly focused on the Thrawn's Revenge mod: 

Amazing game. Get the Thrawn's Revenge mod from the workshop if you want a modern star wars strategy game. I have hit 200 hours in a little over 2 months of playing on and off, and I will probably hit 1000 sometime next year. I can't get enough, and the team behind Thrawn's Revenge are completely overhauling the mod constantly to make it extremely fun to play consistently. 

The campaign is amazing in TR. It is much more complex than the base game campaign, while not being too complicated that new players might be put off. This is my first ever strategy game, and I immediately got into it and understood the gameplay and mechanics. Very easy to learn, and very rewarding to master. 

The skirmish mode is great as well. Me and my friends have put dozens of hours into playing skirmish mode together against each other and against bots. It is a very fun experience overall. The only problem is many maps from TR will cause the entire lobby to get a desynchronization error and make you restart your entire match. With some people, I will play 90% of games with no problems, but some friends I cannot even play a full match without being desynced. If you are having desync problems, try Bespin or Shameless Ad. Those usually do not cause many problems for me. 

I cannot recommend this game enough.
I cant add the fucking mods!!!

Truly an amazing game. Here's how I think of it.

Graphics: 7/10 
The graphics can be changed with certain mods such as Empire at War Remake: Galactic Civil War (highly recommend this mod) but overall in the vanilla version, graphics are pretty average for 2006. The graphics almost remind me of Age of Mythology.

Space Gameplay: 10/10
Space gameplay is simply amazing, best thing in the game. I can't define how spectacular the battles are when a star destroyer goes up against an MC-80 or a massive group of TIEs against a bunch of X-Wings. The only thing that I might change is the population limit, it's kind of small.

Land Gameplay: 6/10
For a game that is solely based on Space-to-land combat, they require more emphasis on land battles for sure. Land battles are very average for a game and don't really do anything different. The major problem is that you can't place buildings ANYWHERE on the map except where they are already made (or where the turret pads are). I never really do land battles because of these reasons.

Music/Sound: 10/10
Sounds are pretty standard, but the scores are incredible! The theme of the Zann Consortium is simply incredible in the expansion. The rest of the sound is pretty well done for the age of the game, but the dialogue in the campaign is a bit off.

Story: 9/10

I am an old school strategy buff and love the AOE genre and the like. I LOVE steam that has these old titles and can still get them for my new rig. This has got to be by far and away my favorite star wars game to play. It has all of the elements of the saga, music score and the like. The graphics are not too bad ( being realistic at 1900x680) for a title over 15 years old. But it has the best of real time strategy basics without having to figure out who needs to be hired to dump the trash and fix the broken injector nozzle on my xwing.. I hate   micromanaging logistics of the newer titles! Also a good time to jump in and out of without having to catch the learning curve again.

I first got this game on disk. Years later, when I first got steam, I saw that this game was for sale, and I bought it as soon as I had the money. Empire at War is a game accessible to anyone, being understandable to a 9 year old on easy difficulty, and can still be a challenge on hard difficulty. There is background to each thing in the game without it feeling bloated, no units ever become obsolete, and every planet has a different layout and strategy. Admitttedly, the ground combat can be a bit of a slog early on, and it never becomes as fun as the space combat, but it still has substance and depth. The gameplay might not be hard enough for hardcore strategy game players, but it is enough to make people want to give strategy games a try, at least.

I used to play this all the time when I was younger. I found a cd for the game for $5 at some secondhand store. I finally found it on steam, and I can enjoy it all over again.

Star Wars: Empire at War is a RTS which places you in full scale galactic combat. You can try comply with the plot of the films, and bring the republic to their knees, or you can become the empire and stretch your cruel and oppressive regime galaxy-wide. Or, better yet, you can use the Forces of Corruption DLC to put yourself in the shoes of a edgy pirate whose troops are definitely not wildly overpowered. Every day- Ingame, this isn't EA- credits are added to your balance. You can use it to fortify planets or build both space and land troops to continue conquering.

The battles are diverse as well, dozens of different maps with strategic gameplay elements and ability for your ships which can turn the tide of battle. The battles still remain fresh for me, even after countless hundreds of hours. And, while the AI can make extremely faulty calls, at times, it is still fun to play against if you have no friends. Also, like me. The ships are well balanced, and you can try to strategically siege the enemy's weakpoints, or you can build an army of 75 x-wing squadrons and outpace the enemy at the cost of only loyal citizens lives. There's also land combat.

I membered playing this as a small child, it's probably what got me into rts in the first place, with the modern modding community and the grand campaign for both Rebels and Empire, plus the expansion bringing in a new campaign  with a new faction and mechanics. I recommend this game to anybody that likes these older rts games, and as a an ex-fan of star wars, I was saddened to know that this game was de-cannonized by Disney.

[h1]A Star Wars classic from a more civilized age.[/h1]

[b]10 / 10[/b]
[i]Would buy again, multiple times over.[/i]

Empire at War is a unique twist on the RTS genre that incorporates many beloved features found in other classic Star Wars games. It takes place in the original Star Wars Expanded Universe continuity canon, what more can I say.

[i]Pros and Cons at the bottom[/i]

The galactic conquest mode can be a relaxing empire builder at easier difficulties. Against harder opponents however, it can be grueling and last for days, requiring quick planning and proper strategies as you fight to dominate the galaxy and eliminate your opponent.

Its skirmish mode is faster paced and focused on strategical map awareness. Even against all odds, the tides can turn easily with implementation of wiser strategies and level thinking.

The expansion, Forces of Corruption adds a criminal faction with a neat feature called corruption. Some may find it annoying to face this faction in multiplayer, but I like it. It adds another layer of strategy to the game.

I remember playing it and modding it well before I had Steam and still play it to this day.
Some of my fondest memories with it are of sitting down and having a tense galactic conquest match with a friend over the better portion of a day.

With a very active modding community this game has many possibilities for different play styles and strategies. It is a very easy game to tweak with the excellent use of XML files if you want to have your own hand at it or further customize an existing mod to you and your friends' liking in multiplayer.

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Inexpensive
-Engaging gameplay
-Lots of mods
-Active multiplayer
-Strategy matters
-Great addition to the EU lore

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Unfortunate game breaking multiplayer de-syncs occasionally, as with many other RTS games, this is a possibility.
-Poor performance in bigger Conquests for multi core machines. There are workarounds, and good single core performance helps.

[b]Tips:[/b]
-Run in windowed mode
-Don't Alt-Tab while loading anything
-For multi core processors, use task manager to make game run in real time (priority) on a single core (affinity)
-save often (every 5 to 15 minutes) for long multiplayer matches in case of de-sync

[i]Regards, Anky[/i]

play first with the vanilla game to get a hang of the basic mechanics, then start delving into the gigantic list of mods, best of which being things like AOTR, empire at war RE, Thrawns revenge, clone wars submod, and republic at war, all work a little differently

Empire At War is one of those games where you can truly have fun whilst being challenged strategically.

 Single Player alone allows for a large variety of gameplay that can easily take up hours (even days) of time, in this game that is in no way bad I assure you. 
Even against the AI at its easiest, a strong challenge is presented. Since playing the game, I myself have become much better versed in both Space and Land combat strategy. 

I have not yet experienced Multiplayer in this game, so I cannot comment on it. However, if the game handles anything like how it does in Single Player then I have very little doubt that you would have an amazing time.

I bought this game during the May 4th Star Wars sale so I am much more inclined to feel that what I got was worth the money, but after experiencing the game I would be just as willing to pay the standard full price of the game. 

In terms of the Steam Workshop, mods such as Thrawn's Revenge and Fall of The Republic offer a much more diverse experience as opposed to the limitations of the base game which only provides The Galactic Civil War Era (but is in no way any less fun I assure you) 

Fall of The Republic: Adds an amazing Clone Wars based experience to the game and is completely free. It adds its own unit variants and acts as its own separate game in the subsection Forces of Corruption. I have very little experience in downloading mods but the process for Fall of The Republic through using Steam Workshop was extremely easy and I recommend it. It does take its toll in term of CPU (Central Processing Unit) loads and If you don't have a gaming PC then definitely stick to the smaller scale battles. 

Thrawn's Revenge: Does not add AS much but is certainly worth the download regardless, it doesn't take as big of a toll on the CPU as Fall of The Republic and is no less fun. It adds a much more immersive experience onto the base game (still using Forces of Corruption).

Overall if I were to give this game a rating out of 10 parsecs
9/10
The reason it isn't an initial 10/10 is because the base game does not come with Clone Wars content, but with Fall of The Republic added on it is an immediate 10. 

I hope my review helps you, and I also hope enjoy the game if you purchase it!

Incredible game. Of course after 15 odd years the graphics are severely outdated, however you will be hard pressed to find a better RTS. Its unique blend of Space & Ground combat (which don't happen at the same time this isn't Rome 2) has attracted a significant modding community that, even after all this time is still coming up with new mods as well as constantly improving old ones. This is despite the fact that, as I understand, this is an incredibly difficult game to mod. With my disc version I have no doubt my actual game play time easily exceeds 1000 if not 2000 hours. There are only 2 truly disappointing things about this game.
1) We never got the cliffhanger resolved (i.e. sequel)
2) There is no sequel

Played this game for about 4 years now, and I can safely say this is the best Star Wars game and RTS I've ever played. The space battles in this game are almost cinematic, and the control of each unit you have is total. Galactic conquest mode is always super fun and replayable. The base game itself is fun but gets a bit repetitive sometimes, but the potential EaW has through its mods are unreal. Real shame this game isn't as well known among Star Wars fans as KOTOR or Battlefront.

This is the Star Wars RTS you’re looking for. In spite of its age, you can hardly find a better RTS that incorporates the better functions and aspects of the genre. Commanding units is a simple and fluid action most of the time, managing whether you want in-depth control of each battle or auto-completing is a button-click away, building units and defenses is easy and upgrades are fun to unlock and control, and the overall strategy is adaptable (from being just “kill the enemy everywhere” to “I need these particular planets as a frontline and these for their buffs and...”). I originally had vanilla but appreciate what the Gold pack offers and believe it’s very much worth buying and playing.

This game is a bit of a classic. Don't be fooled by what Steam says about my playtime, back when this first came out, it was an obsession for me. I've got hundreds and hundreds of hours in this game. I would love a modern remaster, but the game still does hold up pretty well. It suffers a bit from the same issues most early 3D RTS games suffer from, like weird pathing issues, bad AI, and slow pace compared to direct predecessors like CnC and Starcraft. But it's certainly worth playing in singleplayer.

Multiplayer is a completely different story. The game is not balanced, and I question if it was ever intended to be. Each faction has something that they're overwhelmingly good at doing, and it makes multiplayer games completely not fun. They went for a Starcraft-inspired asymmetrical system with the three factions, but, in my opinion, failed miserably. I tried finding a mod that would help deal with balance issues, but was unsuccessful.

I doubt this'll ever get remastered, but it's definitely a dream of mine. Update the engine and rebalance everything, and you'll have a perfect 10/10. As it stands, I give it a solid 8/10, 9/10 for nostalgia.

CLASSIC.

Star Wars is a franchise that lends itself to many genres due to its content and themes. Real Time Strategy seems like a natural fit, after all it has War in the name and RTS games tend to focus around conflict. However we have something truly special with this game, in fact I’ve come to love many other RTS games over the years but none have ever replaced this game as my absolute favorite RTS.

This game by default has two diverse and unique factions with a third added on later as DLC forming a truly unique trinity of gameplay with each group bringing their own playstyle and mechanics. Each team has unique hero’s and units and technology to make them feel grounded in the Star Wars universe but also balanced in regards to gameplay.

The foucus for the game is essentially controlling the vast Star Wars universe and all your favorite planets are included for you to conquer, liberate or extort. Controlling hyperlanes and systems to gain resources to help you expand your factions dominance across the stars.

Invading a planet consist of two phases the first being space combat. This is the most enjoyable aspect of the game by far. You’ll never grow tired of bringing a star Destroyer out from hyper space to attack an enemy fleet or watching X-Wings fly in formation to intercept Tie Fighters so your Y-Wings can pull off a bombing run on an imperial cruiser. It really captures the feeling of the Star Wars universe and it’s truly enjoyable to engage in combat with other ships as your target individual components on them from Engines to Hanger Bays to disrupt the enemy in different ways.

The second phase is ground battle which for most hasn’t been the most enjoyable when compared to the games space battles but I think it’s truly an enjoyable part of the experience, each battlefield is unique and designed around the planet you are invading or defending and offers everything from difficult terrain or maybe native inhabitants to help or fight against you. Slowly conquer different command points to call in reinforcements and secure the area entirely. The unites like with space range and differe with each faction bringing different gameplay mechanics and strategies to the player.

Both of these phases also allow you to enjoy everything in a cinematic mode that mimics the films so you can enjoy your AT-ATs as they stomp around planet side or maybe get a good look at Boba Fett’s Slave 1 unleashing a Sonic Imploder into a group of A-Wings, so satisfying by the way.

Different campaigns add more of a narrative drive experience while Galactic Conquest is your Sand-Box to the Star Wars galaxy. 

Couple all that with the sound design of an E-11 or AT-ST walking around with the beautiful Star Wars Score we have come to love and you really have yourself a complete package for not only one of the best RTS games Avalible but also one of the best Star Wars Games ever made.

All in all it’s a fantastic game with a great community that loves and supports it. Some Mods for this game completely change it into a Clone Wars game and some just add more units to enhance the experience, the range is very impressive and shows just how much the community enjoys this game.

If you love Star Wars and RTS games you have no reason not to own this game. 
But this is just my opinion, regardless I hope you give this classic a chance.

This is easily one of my favorite Star Wars games, and games in general. Great graphics, although they are a bit dated after all this time. The game play really makes me feel like I'm in one of those movies. The units are great, as are the special abilities for units. Taking control of planets in space and land give you the ability to build Space Stations (in space obviously), as well as ground structures. These allow you to build individual units on each planet. The more planets you hold, the stronger you get, and the more units you can make (there's a unit cap, which I HATE). 

You can control some of your favorite SW characters in battle, from Luke and Han, to Vader and The Emperor. Each with their own special abilities. 

The addition of The Zann Consoritum in the Forces Of Corruption expansion allows you to build all new ships, production buildings (ground) and units.

Now for the bad part. The Zann Consortium is EXTREMELY OVERPOWERED! I mean it's just absurd. They have units called "Defilers" corrupt planets, Corrupting a planet gives you certain bonuses, such as providing a one time bonus to credits, access to bonus units, etc. But the thing that REALLY bugs me, is that after Zann has corrupted a planet, they can send a Defiler to blow up your ground buildings. And they can create as many as they want, as fast as they want, and just keep doing this over and over. Now, you CAN use certain units of your own to REMOVE the corruption. But sometimes that has consequences. One mode of corruption is called "Corrupt Militia", which is fine in itself, BUT, if you use your unit to "Remove Corruption", it causes ALL YOUR UNITS to vacate the planet. That being said, there are only a few planets where that is an option, and if you're quick, you can just put troops back on the planet, and in orbit, to reclaim it. But you still lose all your ground base buildings that you've built, and your space station. Which then have to be rebuilt. But keep in mind, there is NO COOL DOWN on the production of Defilers, if they can afford it, they can pump them out like clones. No other faction has the ability to corrupt, or to blow up ground buildings. Which makes Zann Consortium EXTREMELY OP'd. 

Well, despite all that, I still love the game. Although If you want to play as Empire or Rebellion, I'd suggest playing the BASE GAME, not the expansion. But the base game is missing a number of units that Forces Of Corruption has, for the Rebels and Empire. Hope this helps you decided whether to buy this, this is my first review on Steam, so I tried to put as much into it as I could think of. Have fun.

Star Wars Empire at War last and only expansion pack Forces of Corruption was released 14 years ago, and yet it is still the best and only practical Star Wars RTS/Strategy game. It's truly amazing how modders are still active and keep the game feeling fresh, most notably Thrawn's Revenge, Fall of the Republic, Republic at War, Awakening of the Rebellion , ReMake etc. 

As an old game, it has faults too. This game was optimized for single core CPUs and as such it is not optimized for multithreaded CPUs and it can run pretty badly occasionally, but most of the time it runs great. Vanilla EaW and FoC are imo worth playing only if you wish to run through the campaigns, which are fun (despite Zann campaign being a bit annoying at some parts, lore and gameplay -wise). After that, pick your favourite Star Wars era, download a mod for it and game on

PS. Old school EaW players remember the save game bug which caused you not being able to save, amazingly that was fixed by a dev patch 11 years after release in 2017, which also restored multiplayer. Petroglyph team is truly awesome and maybe we'll get that sequel in the future, which failed to materialise back in the day.

Positives:
Base building on the planets from the star wars series is fun.  The expansion pack gives a bit more customization options and I enjoy that.
Star wars (duh)
Each faction plays very different from one another (rebels vs empire vs zann consortium)
Galactic conquest is a fun experience and a rather simplistic version of games such as Stellaris and other 4x strategy
Skirmish is a good time if you have friends that also have the game.  The base building mechanics in space and land are unique in skirmish vs conquest
Natives on each of the planets provide a unique twist to encounters

Negatives:
Balancing issues - Zann consortium is overpowered at times and very annoying
Graphics definitely feel a little dated now, but it runs great

Summary: Fantastic game if you're a fan of star wars, battles, and base building.  For instance, if you enjoy games such as Total War, Civ, Stellaris + Star Wars, this is an easy purchase.  It's a bit dated now but it is probably the best star wars game I've played outside of Knights of the Old Republic.

P.s. my steam hours on this game do not represent the time I spent on this game wayyyy back in the day (we're talking hundreds if not thousands of hours)

Old game, but still popular with over 1k generally playing it at all times on the evenings. Probably because there really ain't any official new Star Wars RTS on the market, and definitely not any as good. 

Disney's management of Star Wars is questionable (they are garbage imo, or rather EA is garbage since we are talking about games here), but I respect the revival of BFII and EaW multiplayer a lot. If you didn't know, they released a update to fix the broken multiplayer function caused by Gamespy closing about a year ago. A wonderful thing, and they added Steam Workshop which allows easy access to mods which this game is not short of. Previously Moddb was the main site for mods and still is very active. Due to this revival I do have -one small amount of respect for Disney, and I hold Petroyglyph in high regard and sincerely hope they get to make a new "EaW II" some day which they have showed interest in.

The game
A extremely fun SW RTS game with no equal. The graphics may not be up to today's standards but the gameplay is as good as ever. Fight battles on land and space. Either in small single-game skirmishes, or in the Galactic Conquest where you fight over the entire (or a part) of the Galaxy with or without other objectives and goals. The game also comes with 3 campaigns: Empire, Rebels and Connsortium. The third only being in FoC, so you can't start the Empire or Rebel compaign in FoC. Likewise you cant start the Connsortium campaign in EaW.  

The units are fun and you can find most of the vehicles and troops found in the original trilogy with other fun additions for a even larger amount of variety, balance and enjoyment. Rebel/Stormtrooper infantry, AT-ATs, AT-STs, Speeders, Hoovercraft, Snow Speeders and of course Hero units. Equiped with unique abilities, enhanced weapons or even lightsabers and the force. How, or if to use these is entirely up to you.

In all seriousness this game defined my childhood along with Starcraft and it's still gaining fans, the mods are truly keeping it alive and the game is absolutely fantastic and has great replay value.

I'm blown away that the support for this amazing game has returned. This is not only one of the best stratagy games I've ever played, its also the only game I know of that allows RTS combat in both space born engagements and land engagements. Not to mention it has a pretty good campaign in both the DLC (which is more or less a totaly new game) Forces of Corruption, and the base game Empire at War. The Forces of Corruption DLC campaign follows the story of Tybr Zann a underworld consortium leader and Empire at War, the story of the Rebellion through episodes 4 to 6 (and a bit before episode 4). 

TLDR : Its a fantastic game that now has mutliplayer and workshop mods. Its totally worth the price and I own both the actual box set from 2008 and the steam version. I have sunk countless hours into the base game and more than I wish to admit into the countless mods produced by the community.

[h1] One of the best grand strategy games to date, an absolute classic. Empire At War is all about expanding your influence throughout the galaxy. System by system, build up your infrastructure, planetary forces, and space forces. Easy to pick up and highly replayable. [/h1]

[h1] Galactic Conquest [/h1]
Central to the Empire At War experience, Galactic Conquest is all about expanding your influence throughout the galaxy. Choose from several Galactic Conquest scenarios, tweak the settings to your liking, and hop right in. Core gameplay then revolves around upgrading your systems in the form of space and planetary structures, building up your forces, and attacking/defending systems. Each faction has its own pool of unique units with their own strengths and weaknesses, with factions unlocking more powerful units as a session progresses through the acquisition of technology.

When two opposing forces meet in the space of a system or on the planet of a system, a battle occurs. Battles are tactical in nature and pit you and whatever units you brought with you against whatever the enemy has on hand. When battling on planets, you will vie over strategic points across the landscape that increase the maximum units you can have at once when captured, as well as resource points. If you are defending, you must defeat the enemy and protect your structures. If you are attacking, you must defeat the enemy and destroy their structures. Battles in space typically offer more freedom of movement for obvious reasons (though also featuring their own unique "terrain" in the form of asteroid fields and nebulae). Just like planetary battles, you must defeat the enemy while also attacking/defending structures and resource points.

[h1] Skirmish [/h1]
Skirmish allows you to engage in singular battles of your specification. Choose from numerous battle maps of the planetary and space variety, tweak the settings to your liking, choose a faction, and have at it. Each faction starts with an approximately equal advantage and has access to essentially every unit and technology in the game.

[h1] Accessibility [/h1]
Empire At War strikes a dashing balance between simplicity and complexity that many grand strategy games fail to accomplish. The UI is not overwhelming nor are the statistics overbearing. Empire At War is easy to pick up, but offers a surprising amount of depth for those seeking true mastery of the game.

Multiplayer is supported for both Galactic Conquest and Skirmish.

[h1] Modding [/h1]
With Steam Workshop support, this game has never been more customizable. Browse a bountiful collection of mods to enhance and expand your experience with Empire At War.

Been playing this game for years and its very easy to get the hang off but difficult to master. Balance between the three factions is fine in skirmish with each approaching combat very differently but in galactic conquest without mods its very unbalanced with the consortium being stupidly powerful and flat out annoying in the hands of the a.i and the empire dominating in space combat once you get the second death star and the executor ssd you have to physically try to lose otherwise you steamroll everything, this leaves the rebels as the weaker of the 3 factions because they dont have the military might of the empire or the control over the galaxy that the consortium do.

As a few reviews have said this game becomes a whole different beast with mods and while the base game is very fun and great it is improved with mods, my fave one being republic at war which changes the factions to the republic and the separatists, i would honestly reccommend buying this for the vast amount of mods you can try alone but play the base game first as the ai is abit easy in the base game and most mods tend to improve on the ai


Sidenote as i feel its worth a mention but the pathfinding for the larger ships in space battles is honestly terrible at times so be wary you may have to path courses for ships manually and hope the pathfinding doesnt hurt itself tying to follow your orders.

Great star wars strategy game that incorporates ground and space battles. The modding community is absolutely fantastic even for an older game keeps this game feeling like new and still very much alive. It covers many of the star wars eras and it just has that unique charm to it.

Game is okay for the most part.  The campaigns starts can be a little long in the tooth.  The ground combat overall tends to be frustrating, as it can feel a bit "rock, paper, scissors".  However where this game comes into its own, and for the very reason i keep playing it is due to the space combat.  It is the golden gem in this game.  Anyone wanting it for this reason NEEDS to think about buying this game!

This game is (for its time) one of the best strategy games I've ever played, it's simple interface and low learning curve makes it super easy to get into, star wars fan or not many could find enjoyment out of this title. Lore knowledge isn't a requirement but does help with knowing the units/heroes but again, low learning curve makes that a non essential thing. There's a campaign for both the base game and expansion, galactic conquest which is a mode that features varying amounts of planets to conquer both space and land, there's many ways to go about playing. Forces of corruption adds in a ton of new units, mechanics, heroes and locations. And finally with this game being older it's got a huge library of fleshed out mods that will keep the game fresh even after hundreds of hours of gameplay.

Don't let my steam hours fool you, I bought this game on disc back when it first released and probably have a couple thousand hours logged over the years which also goes to show that it was worth buying again on steam years later to keep playing it.

This game is the best Star Wars strategy game by far. With an active modding community and a combat system that is simple to understand, this game is perfect for any fan of the Star Wars Saga. I am not saying that the vanilla version of this game does not have flaws, but the majority of these flaws are fixed by the modding community. Some personal favorite mods that I recommend playing once you have gotten the hang of the game include Awakening of the Rebellion, The Clone Wars Mod (if you are a fan of the TV show), Republic at War, and the Canon Mod. They are all fun and they all fix some gameplay elements that were lacking in the game. Also, there is working multiplayer in this game, so you can play with your friends. Overall, this is a great game!

This is the defenitive star wars RTS. In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#143 out of 555)... it's time for Star Wars: Empire at War.

It's a Star Wars-themed RTS, with unique mechanics, what's not to love? Okay, okay: the ground combat is pretty dull. But everything else? Awesome. Arguably the best space RTS since Homeworld 2. And have you seen some of the mods out there? Incredible. Absolutely incredible.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

Classic game from the 00's. I played the heck out of it when I was a kid, and it's still a ton of fun. The graphics do show their age by now, but they don't look terrible by any means, plus the modding community is very strong and has many upgraded models, special effects, and even whole new campaigns based on the Prequels and Sequels. It's a bit too easy to win on lower difficulty, and higher difficulty feels like you're being beaten with a hammer until you develop a sound military strategy, but the core game is solid, with varying modes of play to suit your tastes. I'd recommend it to anyone who loves Star Wars and wants to conquer the galaxy and restore order as the evil Galactic Empire, or would like to unshackle the chains of oppression as the struggling Rebel Alliance!

The Vanilla game alone is very addicting, and the story in the game tells a very engaging tale of Tyber Zann and is quest to basically take over the galaxy as the Empire collapses. You could play this for hours in the base game. BUT, the modding community is where the game really shines now. Years ago I would say the contrary, but now with Fall of the Republic, Thrawns Revenge, Rise of the Rebellion, and more, the game became something you could play entire, hundred hour campaigns with. The only flaws I can give the game really is that the AI could get annoying in attacking the same system over and over again, and in the base game Defilers are so annoying, corruption is a pain in the ass to deal with at a point, but these usually arent problems in the mods. GET. THIS. GAME.

This game is amazing EVEN for its age, which at times clearly shows. If there was any one way to describe the game it would be Modular. This. Game. Has. MODS. and dear god do are there a lot of them, good or bad you have a good chance to find something you like. Like legends? Play the Thrawns Revenge mod and play as an imperial splinter faction or a desperate Rebellion/New Republic. Fan of the CloneWars? Animated show or Prequels movies, doesn't matter! We got em all. I know at one point I have played the base game, but it's been so long with so many amazing mods such as EaW: Remake with 2018 graphics and a complete overhaul of the game, or Fall of the Republic and Clone Wars 4.0 or Republic at war that I've fallen down the rabbit hole, and I DON'T want out.

And not only does this game receive a massive amount of fan support, but it's technically a 2 for 1 deal even without sales or discounts. The game features 2 core modes of game play: Space and Ground combat, and with ground combat the ships you have in orbit matter (at least some of the time). I won't go into detail because its 5 in the morning and there are plenty of guides and other comments that go into way more detail than I care to since I'm probably going to bed, waking up at 12 mid-day, having dessert for morning food (I can't remember the word wtf) and getting pimp slapped for the heck of it... but at least this game is fantastic. If I could give more than a 10/10 this comment would be too long and wouldn't fit on the screen. Buy this game, on discount or such who cares. It's worth every penny ESPECIALLY the FoC (Forces of Corruption) DLC that most mods use to format with. Buy, play it, slowly rub your elbows against it, I'm not too picky ( video the elbows though, I have the urge to splurge) and goodnight from some random moron who at 756 hours played still hasn't gotten his fill of Star Wars RTS. God i need a life.

This review is based off the modded and unmodded experience of SWEaW.

The base game itself - great at the time, good story in the campaign, excellent Galactic Conquest mode, Skirmish is eh, but you get some units in it you can't access in the GC. For it's time, 8/10, now it's a 2/10, the graphics are poor, gameplay options are limited, it just didn't hold up well.

Now the mods, the mods bring this game back to a 7/10, there are so many options and themes, it's fantastic. The units are more diverse and the gameplay functions have changed. I love it, but unfortunately it does get quite boring after 10 or so hours of gameplay, and you will rarely ever finish a Galactic Conquest as the game becomes monotonous. 

It's good fun, and you'd definitely enjoy it and get alot of good gameplay hours out of it if you haven't already played the title.

This game is busted. Balance is terrible, AI cheats, and it is a total, unabashed blast to play.
It's age makes it a little rough around the edges, but all told, it's still fun in SP, MP, and has a thriving mod community. I can't say I'd buy it for full price, but then again I've paid far more at this point then I should have. Played it since it came out, played it til the disk went bald, twice, and bought the expansion when that released too. Now here we are in 2020 and I've done gone bought it again. Even today it holds up as a sort of RTS straight-man for the gang. Unblemished, unassuming, and solid.

If you run lots of infantry, look out for maulers. 9/10

Whereas the game itself has aged relatively well and has seen its fair share of instabilities and bugs, the community that was behind this game has helped iron out as many bugs as they could to keep this special niche of a game afloat. That, added onto by the vast Workshop capabilities developed just for this game to spice up the entire experience makes Star Wars Empire at War (especially with Forces of Corruption) allows this game to deliver something truly unique.

Whereas the vanilla may be fairly limited and may grow a little stale over time, the Workshop Mod community is more than capable of adding the right type of spice to your gaming experience. Be it via Legends, or Canon additions to the gameplay; sometimes a mix of both (of which the resulting lineups give mixed balance issues) and in some cases, reworking the gameplay system so that the way the game is played is changed altogether.

Is it a perfect game? No, very few games manage to strike all the boxes on the checklist to be perfect, but is it the best in its class that I know of? Yes, definitely. I would recommend this game in a heartbeat. Even if I've dropped it for a while, when that wish comes around I'll come back time and time again to give this game another go with something new.

In my opinion, a big part of what made many old LucasArts games like Battlefront II, Knights of the Old Republic, and Republic Commando so beloved in the eyes of fans is that the developer's vision for what they wanted these games to be wasn't far off from fan's fantasies of what those type of Star Wars games should look like. The shared vision between developers and fans is the bedrock of their acclaim and has enabled these games to stand the test of time.

Empire at War is no different. You want a real time strategy Star Wars game? How about one where you take control of either the Empire or the Rebel Alliance and wage a galaxy spanning conflict in space and planetside where you have to build your fleets and armies from the ground up and are able to directly take command in each and every battle? Might sound a bit long winded when I explain it, but it's also something you might've dreamed of as a child that you never really thought could be real. Turns out it's been around for almost 15 years now, and on top of all of that, the game has developed a strong modding community intent on taking that vision to the next level.

It's not all sunshine and rainbows though. Land battles are frustrating and tedious compared to their orbital counterparts and the frustratingly low unit cap in the base game feels incredibly limiting. Even though the unit cap was likely a necessary concession for the game to run on the hardware of its day, it's one of the few signs of this game's age that's apparent in its design. Fortunately, many mods remove the unit cap and allow you to bypass land battles entirely so you can focus on the space combat that this game just absolutely nails.

Alright, that's enough from me. If you're a fan of Star Wars and like RTS games at least a little bit, you should play Empire at War.

Cons: 

for a 2006 game:

-Interface is 0/10, was it done in 1990s?

-Animations are 0/10 You know the ships here they don't move, '"breathe" if you will when idle, land mode animations are beyond gay, especially infantry ones. Shame, Dawn of War was made in 2004 and has million times better animations.

-Forces of Corruption music is disgusting and there is no option to separate it from the John Williams' original.

-The whole "Syndicate" shit is so lame and unbalanced! 

-"Superweapons" are a joke!

-In skirmish mode the players of each team must choose the same faction.

-Units are unbalanced, especially the rebel "capital ship destroyer" fish-ship mc30 with its stupid radial blast ability, Rebel ships are much stronger than the imperial ones because of the shields and their ability to boost them, and torpedo launchers, also imperials don't have "capital ship destroyer".

Pros: 

-Multiplayer servers still work.

-In the original game's space battles the music very well fits into the gameplay.

-When you play 4 vs 4, the scale of  space battle somewhat resembles the space battles from the movies.

-In skirmish mode the players of each team share the same space station.

-Only requires ~4 gb of disk space.

What is should have been: the variety of units from FoC in the original game, without FoC music, without land battles, space only. Syndicate as a faction is unneeded.

Star Wars Empire at War is one of the best Star Wars RTS games. It is an interesting change from past games such as STAR WARS Rebellion and STAR WARS Galactic Battlegrounds.
Star Wars fans will love this game a lot. It has a familiar and accurate galaxy map, with planetary bonuses which make sense. Some of the included planets are also surprising.

The graphics are quite good. Turn up the resolution and detail and it does look nice for a 2006 game. Even if you turn the graphics and resolution down, the game still looks nice and runs great even on older machines. 
The soundtrack is also top notch, and the voice acting isn't bad considering they didn't get any of the original actors.

The single player campaigns were interesting, but there is not much difficulty as strategy can be fairly basic. The AI of this game is not great and easily defeatable in my opinion, but it's not retarded and it's not frustrating, which is a good balance overall. The online play was also nice, but the online design could have been better and there was some lag.

This game makes for both ground-based and space-based warfare, and there are 3 categories of gameplay: galactic, space, and ground. 

Galactic is easy and intuitive, and while there are options that you might rather have, there is little to complain about in what's there.

Space is really fun and way better than the space battles in SW Galactic Battlegrounds. Some people might wish they could do more specific stuff, but there's enough strategy for it to be interesting and fun, and the cool feature of targeting fire to certain critical points is immersive. 

Land is very different from most traditional RTS games. You have to capture reinforcement points so that you can bring in troops from your fleet. You don't create units, you bring in units you made on the galactic map. You can build a few structures like turrets, but only at certain specific points. It is still fun and tactical to play, even if it's a bit rudimentary and is lacking all the options of normal RTS games. 

These 3 types of gameplay create a unique experience, which befits a scenario of galactic conquest with pre-made space fleets. None of them are spectacular, but they all mesh in such a way that the minor lackings of each type don't matter, because each is just a part of a whole galactic war. You make units on planets you conquered in the galactic map, and make buildings on them to create specific unit. You command your resources and unit distribution from these bases, and the space and land battles are merely specific tactical confrontations. 

Everything makes sense and blends well as a galactic war, which makes the gameplay varied and intriguing, continuous, and galaxy spanning, and it's a fantastic immersive experience for great fun.
This game is amazing and both strategy fans and Star Wars fans will love it.

Get. This. Game. It's on sale right now for a little bit longer, and goes on sale occasionally, so you can pick it up for fairly cheap. If you don't read past this point, know that the mods for this game on the Steam workshop are amazing (I specifically enjoy the Empire at War Expanded mods Thrawn's Revenge and Fall of the Republic so kudos to that mod team) and easily make this game worth the price tag.

The game itself is designed well as a RTS with both high level strategy and low level control of units in battles. It came out in 2006, and the base game shows that age in terms of graphics, UI, and keybindings. If you want to play through the galactic civil war experienced in the original trilogy, the base game will bring all the nostalgia and the expansion, Force of Corruption (included in the Gold Pack here on Steam) is a Legends story involving a third faction the Zann Consortium (Scum and Villainy). It has Galactic Conquest where you take over the galaxy system by system, buiding your army/fleet in a RTS/4X style game. The game also features a skirmish mode that allows you go up against the AI or other players on both Land and Space.

I don't really play the base game though. The Steam Workshop has a number of great mods available that redesign the game, add new mechanics, units, heroes, and more to play out all your favorite Star Wars scenarios. I highly recommend anyone thinking about buying this game to do so and check out the mods available if the base game doesn't appeal to you. Many of the mods also completely overhaul and upgrade the graphics and textures, so if the original graphics are the only reason you're not buying it, then these mods will solve that problem.

I've been coming back to this game on and off since it came out in the mid-2000s, this game is a product of the golden age of RTS games, where everybody was constantly churning out new strategy clones introducing new concepts/features. This one was way ahead of its time, and its aged decently despite obviously being a bit older. The Grand Campaign is really what shines. think Total War meets Age of Empires. Plenty of mods to keep the game relevant. If EA is listening, this one deserves a sequel.
Good clean rts

A classic from while I grew up made available for new systems and with mod support through the workshop? How could I not recommend it? I would spend days after school or during the summer playing it by myself and always having fun doing so. I remember the hardpoint system for bigger ships being one of the biggest features that never failed to please, and it was so satisfying to destroy them and watch chunks of ships fall off or see that weapon feature disappear from the ship completely, with the engines always being a main target if you wanted to keep them from escaping or slowing them down.

The only problem I've had is the 3rd faction that appears in the Forces of Corruption expansion, the Consortium, when it comes to the galactic conquest mode. The faction is the main feature of the expansion, but the units can easily become overpowered and wipe all of yours out quickly. I also didn't like that you couldn't turn them off in GC, but if you gun for them first you can get rid of them, but make sure you have a strategy for how to take them out first.

Only other downside I had with the game is a lack of a built-in mapmaker/level designer, not even a separate exe for one (that I ever found, anyway). This didn't hinder the experience, but I feel it would have just made it even better.

But overall, great game, it can definitely scratch a Star Wars RTS itch, it has multiplayer again with Steam, and there's plenty of mods to keep you busy for a while.

Made an honest, 32 hour effort (normal difficulty), to like this game. Tried playing various game modes, across several top rated mods, but the problems are probably too deep to fix. Conceptually, it has a lot of promise: integrating a strategic conquest perspective with tactical space and land battles. The game drips with Star Wars theme and is quite immersive. Unfortunately, the gameplay just fell short for me. 

The strategic layer runs in real time, which would be fine if it were possible to issue every type of command while the game is paused. Lore and realism aside, it's frustrating not to have more information about enemy planets and forces. Without that information, there are few interesting strategic decisions. Every game I can think of in this space (e.g., the Total War series, Paradox games) provides more visibility of the opposition. The campaign quickly descends into a series of rapid fire attacks by the AI, ruining the strategic aspect of the gameplay.

The land battles are fun enough to play but mostly uncompelling. The forces of nature (cyclones, rancors) and the involvement of the indigenous population are interesting ideas but ultimately miss their mark.

The space battles are fun to watch but not fun to play, at least for me. The pace is too fast to make interesting decisions. Once the engagement starts, I feel like I lose all agency, and everything descends into chaos. When I win I feel like it was luck. I've watched players on Youtube execute battles flawlessly, but I was unable to develop that skill. 

From the other reviews, I'm definitely in the minority. Maybe not enough of a Star Wars fan.

basicly there are 3 games in one,  a galactic conquest mode, where you manage and conquer planets, a ground combat mode and a space fleet combat mode.
in  campaign or galactic conquest mode you manage everything and can decide weather to fight land or space battles, with the troops/ships you have on a specific planet to defend when the enemy attack

I have so many hours in this game. Only say's I have 100 hours, but i used to play the retail version on disk. Got it back in 2012, and have been playing ever since! So i can firmly say it is easily one of the best games i own! A brilliant Star Wars game, and a brilliant RTS in general!  With an interesting Campaigns in both versions of the game, and Galactic Conquest that offers so much replayability, and that's even without mods! The modability is practically endless. From changing the game to a different period in Star Wars history, or changing it to a different Sci-Fi genre as a whole. What's even better is its on Steam workshop! So its a one click install for most mods! Back on the retail version, even after the steam version added mods i had to put up with manually installing mods. I still see people to this day not knowing how to do that, which is mind boggling to me as it was completely normal for so long.

But to summarise: Amazing game! Loads of replayability! Endless Mods! Perfect for any Star Wars fan, and i believe any RTS fan will also get a good kick out of it!

Now this game on its own is not the best. I know hasn't started as the best review for a game that I would recommend. However, its not the base game that makes this game so amazing; it is the modding community behind it. It is simply the best star wars strategy out there. For such a cheap price and the fact that mods are completely free. it is definitely worth the price tag. plus with mods you can play in almost all the era of star wars that you know and love. You can play as the old republic in the old republic mod, you can play in the clone wars with amazing mods like Republic at War and Fall of the Republic. You can play in the Galactic Civil War with THE most beautiful mod you will ever in The Remake Mod, and my all time favourite mod for this game Awakening of The Rebellion. You can continue through with the New Republic and after the Battle of Endor with Thrawns Revenge. Furthermore to top it of if you want all of these eras to collide then you can play the yoden mod with ridiculously large computer breaking ships.

This game is a nice game with a special place. It doesn't have the graphics or controls of Homeworld because it is different. You start off as either the Empire, Rebel Alliance or Zann Consortium (Pirate Empire) you then build up your faction in diverse scenarios. The thing that really makes this game exeptional is the modding comunity. Take Thrawn's Revenge for example it's been going on for nearly 14 years or AotR which is a great Empire vs Rebels mod. You can play from the Clone Wars to after Endor. If you want a fun time with your friends as long as you know some lore Yodemod will give you a laugh.

This game was off the wall for its time and I still play it. Its basically like a really good command and conquer in space. The New easy steam modding api and multiplayer breathes new life into it. I recommend Thrawn's revenge, awakening of the rebellion, and Galaxy of the dead.

Ah yes, Empire at War. An extremely old game, yet satisfying nonetheless. I mean, Jesus, it's almost as old as I am. However, despite its age and poor graphics, playing it is incredibly satisfying. As someone that sucks at rts games, winning a battle, as petty as it may sound to those with greater experience in the genre, is incredibly rewarding, especially when I have no casualties. Now, in the case of modding, the Workshop provides some decent options. Unreliable and prone to crashing, yes, but very fun nonetheless. Would I recommend buying EAW without FOC? No. Mainly because of FOC being required for some mods, but also because it's pretty cheap. With FOC, then by all means, pick it up, despite its clunkiness and 2000s feel.

Empire At War is by far one of my favorite games that i've ever played. I have replayed the original campaigns DOZENS of times and have logged HUNDREDS of hours into mod game play. This is definitely in my top 5 games that i play.

If you aren't sure about buying this game; Just keep in mind that while the base game is a bit old, it still looks fantastic for a game that came out in 2006.

That's not even including the mods that bring the game into the modern era graphically. 

Another thing to keep in mind is that Petroglyph, the game developers, have been watching the community for this game grow for YEARS, even after they had to shut down the multiplayer. (Which they have brought back in 2019 I believe?)

All in all, this is a fantastic game that i recommened to all RTS fans as well as anyone who is trying to find a starter RTS to get into.
A great real time strategy game that makes the franchise proud, it can be difficult to watch the old cutscenes and animation but the gameplay really holds up and stands the test of time.

While the base game is slightly lacking, as it is a older game, it is very appealing for someone who just wants to sit back and lead the Imperials to grand victory. Or perhaps lead the hopeful rebellion to the end of all this madness. With it's little story characters and holocron characters the base game makes up something very neat. The FoC expansion in itself is that but much more expanded. A new story adding a new faction, cool units, a whole new selection of naval units and ground forces. A new type of play style going from the rebels high shields and powerful star fighters and the Empires many fighter squadrons and carriers to a more. . . complex style of game play. While I believe the Consortium at the start are always super broken af, and that they can easily win a game within 30 minutes; they are still a very interesting economy and strat based faction. For those who just love star wars, RTS games, and modded adventures, then I HIGHLY suggest you play this.

It's really not the best game ever, but if you like the old Star Wars EU, you'll probably like it.

It's got a strong modding community as well, that is somehow still active over a decade later. If you enjoy modding, it can be a lot of fun to mod as well. I myself used to mod it for fun years ago.

I really like the game play that this game delivers, capitalizing on the fact that the Rebels are much smaller, and in ways weaker than the Empire so they rely on stealing, and sending small raid fleets to planets, bypassing the Empire navy there blockading the planet. As for the Empire, they mostly rely on their sheer strength and mass attack to overwhelm the Rebels with small factors in their advantage, such as their frigates and capital ships having a hanger that replenishes fighters and bombers that get destroyed in the battle, as long as the hanger is still functional. As for the campaign, it is very difficult and slow  moving on normal difficulty, at least for me, and suggest experimenting with different tactics for different situations for actually committing to trying to beat it. The graphics can easily be taken care of with a mod, and you can add multiple other mods that can keep this game more enjoyable.

One of, if not THE most fun Star Wars games I have ever played. Endless replayability, great wide spanning space battles and strategy. My only real gripe is that the ground combat can be a bit of a slog on longer campaigns. The base game and Forces of Corruption is fantastic by itself, but an extremely dedicated modding community keeps this game fresh and improves the experience drastically. For fans of the EU, Thrawn's Revenge converts the game and eras to from right after endor, all the way up till just before the Vong arrive. It isn't boring because it is old.
But the imbalance of the game make it lost all the fun.

Rebel is very easy to play.
They have fast moving infantry and heroes.
So capturing building and area is easier than Empire.
They have vehicle that can deal high AoE damage.
Wiping out Empire soldiers is easy task.
Their hero ,Chewbacca ,can steal ANY vehicle from Empire side.
That include the AT-AT walker you would have to go through trouble to create one if you're Empire.
They can steal it in a heart beat ,and use it to defense their base by placing it beside repairing bay.
That AT-AT walker almost become immortal.
(And can crush ANY Sith lord trying to attack your base)

Empire ,have slow walking Storm Troopers.
Their vehicle will keep getting stolen by the Barbaric Fur ball.
The Sith lords ,are Melee with slow movement.
Not to mention their skills are close range.
Darth Vader got a skill to crush enemy vehicle (Single target).
But it will take some time to completely destroy the targeted vehicle.
And in that period ,he's a sitting duck.... or standing duck. Your call.
He also has this skill to kill enemy infantry around him immediately.
But the range isn't wide to kill so many in a single use. 
....Did I mentioned Rebel are fast walking and Sith are slow walker?
Trying to catch retreating enemy into the skill range is not an easy task.

Without his skills ,he'll slowly attack enemy one by one.
In case that the enemy is willing to let him attack them.
If they run ,he won't be able to kill a single person.

You would expect that our OH SO POWERFUL Sith Lords can deflect laser like in the movie.
In this game ,they'll take most of the shot with their body instead of their light saber.

Old School Games only

Cause this game is awesome, but with dated graphics I feel only old school may enjoy :)
But really I've seen so much worse...... so please download give it a try!!!!! ;)

The main game is fairly average in many of its aspects. It is quite obvious that this game is 15 years old, the AI doesnt really work that well, the story is bland, however the gameplay is okay enough. It is fun to exert your power across the galaxy as the Empire, which provides an easy way for new players to have fun, while the Rebellion is a lot more of a challenge.

If you are looking for a good RTS, this isnt it. the game is incredibly simple and doesnt require all that much in terms of troop management, clicks/second, or strategy on the same scale as Age of Empires or Starcraft.

It is a fun Star Wars game to spend 40hrs on and I'd recommend it if it is on sale
