Star Wars: Empire at War is fucking amazing and I come back to it every few years because it's not only the best Star Wars RTS ever made, but pretty far up there in terms of RTS quality in general. The only "bad" part is the expansion, and I'll get to that later.

To keep it basic, the game has three components: The Space battles, the Land battles, and, if you're playing Galactic Conquest, the galaxy where you can build individual units.

Space battles are fucking awesome. The combat is rock-paper-scissors and you can target the individual components of ships and pieces will actually get blown off of them as it takes damage. You have these huge fleet movements with tons of ships shooting away at each other and fighters zipping around and blowing stuff up and it all looks visually amazing, there's even a button that lets you enter a dynamic camera mode that will zoom between units you have selected so you can literally see what it's like for individual fighters in a dogfight or take an overhead above a frigate you have that's shooting other frigates.

Land battles are also okay, but not quite as standout amazing as space battles. The combat on land is also rock-paper-scissors except the balance is kinda fucked in a few ways, and it only gets worse with the expansions. Counters here are more based on a traditional RTS rather than purely counter-based, where just because a unit is a counter doesn't mean it's effective, it means it is cost-effective. To show this with an example, the Empire can build suicide-bombing tanks that can run over infantry, and sure anti-tank infantry can blow them up, but if they're not careful these tanks will get right into their infantry blob and re-enact the Tiannenmen Square Massacre. Higher-tier units are also insanely overpowered, and Rebels in general don't really get any basic unit that can remotely be on equal footing with AT-ATs which are not only incredibly powerful against pretty much everything but can also poop out two squads of stormtroopers each for free. The whole game is really kinda slated in favor of the Empire except for very early-game because Rebels get basically the same units except better versions up until mid-late game.

Galactic Conquest is pretty awesome. You capture planets, earn credits by building stuff on those planets, build structures to make units, defend planets, research technology, and crush your opponents. Additionally, another cool thing that this system has is that individual planets almost always have planet bonuses for owning them. These are usually quite powerful and can be anything from making your infantry have more health, to making your tanks reflect blasters, or even to giving you the ability to create exclusive units on that planet that can be built nowhere else, or in the case of space, you can only build capital ships like Imperial Star Destroyers or Mon-Calamari Cruisers on certain planets, giving some places extra strategic value for your unit composition. It's a really interesting, fun system and I like it a lot. 



And now for the jank. I kinda love the Forces of Corruption expansion but it has a ton of huge issues that break the game. To start with the Consortium faction is busted out the fucking ass so bad that if you try to play them in multiplayer people will kick you from the game. Literally every unit these guys have is horrifically fucking busted in every way, a big example being THEIR BASIC INFANTRY getting one cheap, simple upgrade called Disruptors that lets them KILL EVERYTHING incredibly easily and regardless of unit counters or type. You can kill fucking AT-ATs with 2 units of these things let alone squads. They also get shit like the Canderous Assault Tanks and Destroyer Droids that are so fucking busted that you can quite literally just never lose a single planet once you unlock them in Galactic Conquest by just spamming them. They counter everything, produce quickly and in large numbers from the garrison system and are FAST and capture points meaning that nowhere is safe from these things. In space the Consortium is even more ridiculously busted with their bombers being so strong that they just win against the fighters and corvettes of every other faction, the things that are supposed to counter said bombers. Also they, uniquely, use a weapon type called mass drivers that are basically old-fashioned bullets and they PIERCE SHIELDS meaning that they legitimately fucking break the game if you get enough ships that have these things. It doesn't even stop there, pretty much every single one of their units in space has an ability that is very nearly game-breaking up to their capital ships, one of which, while cool as hell, is literally a giant railgun which has projectiles that pierce shields completely and do stupid amounts of damage, and the other one is more powerful than a Star Destroyer but thankfully doesn't spawn infinite fighters like that thing does. In Galactic Conquest they're even worse. The Consortium is a crime syndicate so they can corrupt local officials on planets and spread corruption that gives them full vision of everything that is built on that planet including free passage at an incredibly light credit cost, but the actual benefits for corrupting things can be anything from gaining technology (such as the previously mentioned disruptors) to removing the local/loyalist population that will help some factions on planets. Also the thing that gets income for every other faction, mining stations, are unbuildable by the Consortium, and instead they can build Palaces that are mining stations but stronger except they're a required building and are limited to 1 per planet, meaning their average income per planet is WAY higher than any other faction and they don't have to compromise being able to defend it like everybody else does since they HAVE to take the palace to build anything else. The Forces of Corruption campaign is awesome though I definitely recommend it.

Star Wars: Empire at War is a fun if rather simplistic RTS. It has an Imperial and an Alliance campaign in the base game, with a third faction being available to play as in the expansion. You play both land and space battles, moving from one objective to the next as you try to capture spawn points, similar to Company of Heroes. It's enjoyable, but I'll admit it gets repetitive. My favorite thing to do is play Skirmish battles as the Empire so I can use Star Destroyers, because Star Destroyers are the best Star Wars ships, don't @ me. There's also a fun Empire campaign level where you're just playing Palpatine going around zapping everyone. Generally I guess the Empire is more fun to play, is the point I'm making, and is arguably easier too, which makes sense. It's not one of the best Star Wars games out there, or one of the best strategy games/RTS's out there, but it's decent at both, so it's worth trying out if you like either of those things.

[h1]Both a Classic RTS & a Classic Star Wars Game // Recommended for any fan of either[/h1]

+ Galactic map naviation & planet upgrades add a layer of depth that makes this more than your typical RTS title
+ Different factions have unique qualities that help each to stand out & prevent the game from feeling too stagnant
+ Graphics are certainly dated & uninspired, but holds up better than most games from the time of release
+ Healthy modding community if one feels the inclination

- Lackluster & general incompetent AI
- Visuals don't appear too bad for the time of release, but they only hold up so well to modern eyes

Wow just wow. For a game that came out almost 14 years now, It's amazing.  the amount of different types of units is great, even better if you use the force of corruption DLC. The game also includes a tech system. The way it works is different on both sides as the empire has to build research station and then spend about 1000 to 8000 depending on what level you are on, and just like that you get all of the level's tech. The rebels rely on stealing the empires tech. surprisingly the rebels can actually go beyond the empire in tech , which of course is weird. but if it wasn't like that, the empire would win easily as the rebels are a little weaker then them until you get to tech 4 when you unlock the mon calamari cruiser to build ( needs level 4 space station and can only be build on some planets just like the imperiel star destroyer).  It will take about 15 to 40 hours to get to a point where you can manage the fleet.
Even thought its an old game it still has some very good mods available.

This game, as you can tell, has taken alot of my free time that i have for gaming. Why you may ask? It's simple, the mods. This game as it is, is old. It's a great old RTS Classic star wars title, but it does feel lacking in some areas due to it's age. The modding community for this game is kind enough to fix some of those issues. More than that, some of these mods feel like a whole fricking sequel to the game itself. If you like old school RTS games, of the likes of homeworld and star wars rebellion, you'll probably like this game. And it's wonderful community, which has made so many mods, it's not even funny. From the clone wars, to the era after the galactic civil war, to even the old republic era, this game has PLENTY of mods to choose from. May i suggest a few: Thrawn's revenge,  Awakening of the rebellion, Fall of the republic, The clone wars mod, The Yoden mod. Those are but a few mods to choose from. The base game plays like any other RTS, build bases, defend them,  assault the enemy bases, and throw in a tad bit of 4x with planets being where you do so. Would recommend.

Empire at War is one of a handful of RTS games set in the Star Wars universe, and is to my knowledge is the most recent [side note: imagine if Westwood Studios was still around to make one of their own. Damn you, EA.].
As an RTS game, Empire at War is pretty good out of the box. There are two battle modes: space and land. Of the two, space battles are definitely much more enjoyable. These modes can be played in either skirmish mode or galactic conquest. For those unsure of what that is, think of Total War but real time instead of turn based: at the macro level, you manage your faction, building units and structures, and using the units you construct you defend your planets and conquer your enemies in battles you can either personally command or auto resolve. 
The base game also includes campaigns for both the Empire and the Rebels. 
This version comes with the Forces of Corruption expansion, which adds a third faction, the Consortium, and a new campaign where you play as them, as well as more maps and more units for the existing factions. 
Story wise, the base game is set prior to the Battle of Yavin, and the expansion is set after it, going from the immediate aftermath of it to after the Battle of Endor. The game also uses (and takes place in) the pre-Disney Expanded Universe.

Empire at War is a good game out of the box, but what makes it worth getting is the massive and still quite active mod scene. Numerous mods, some of which are VERY high quality, exist. From simple mods that add a unit or two to total conversions that move the game to other points in the Star Wars timeline and even into other universes to a straight up rework of the entire game, there is no shortage of fan generated content to support this game, even 14 years after its initial release. 

Strongly recommended for anyone who likes both Star Wars and RTS games.

Ah, the early 2000's. At time when RTS ruled supreme. This game is a somewhat niche little gem, that has got a lot of good things going for it.

First of all, I have played a lot of different strategy games. From Rise of Nations, Age of Empires, Rise of Legends, Command & Conquer, Age of Mythology, Dawn of War, Company of Heroes, Cossacks to the Total War franchise and Europa Universalis, Victoria, Crusader Kings, Hearts of Iron, Stellaris (Okay I think you catch the drift). My point being, I know a good RTS game when I play one. And this is it. By God, has this game aged well.

Now mind you, it is from 2006, and I actually think that is Forces of Corruption. If I recall correctly, the basegame is actually from 2004... So the graphics, well they are not fantastic. They hold up well enough for its age I would say though, and graphics are not everything.

My favourite part about this game is galactic conquest and space battles. Galactic conquest is much like a Star Wars version of the total war campaign setup. You build armies and fleets, manage different planets, invade and defend. Simple, and fun. Much simpler than say, Europa Universalis, but that's okay.

Space battles are epic in scale and Star Wars-esque as all hell. Epic lasers firing about.... Just too epic. Not much to say.
Land battles are okay enough, enough that I enjoy it, but it doesn't hold a candle to the space battles in my opinion.

Another great thing about this game, is that it has a load of great mods. Especially the Republic at War, Clone Wars, and Empire at War: Remake mods are good takers!

This game isn't perfect, but a game doesn't have to be perfect to be awesome. And this game is indeed awesome. Just buy it :)

P.S. We really REALLY need a sequel to this. A Star Wars strategy game? That's just an idea that is too awesome not to expand further upon!

The base game is a fun old game that I've played for years with space tactical combat that feels very true to EU canon and realism, but not without flaws.  For one, the AI is just too stupid to ever provide a challenge, though perhaps that can be rectified via mods.  More importantly though, the balance is very much only balanced "from a certain point of view", which makes PvP kind of broken.  Essentially Rebellion utterly dominates in some areas and Empire utterly dominates in others, leading to a theoretical overall balance but imbalance in specifics.  In general, the Empire rules space and the Rebellion rules the land, but then the Empire gets the death star and just blows up the land(and you'll never kill the death star if it's protected by Executor), and that's why Empire wins just about every time my brother and me play.  Again, hoping for good mods to fix it, and my brother is actually working on some.

But then there's the expansion, which certainly adds some fun EU material like Nightsisters and Thrawn, but it also adds a faction called The Zann Consortion, which is basically Black Sun only for some reason they didn't want to actually use Black Sun, and somehow this criminal organization is more powerful than either the Empire or the Rebellion(how THAT would have existed without us hearing about it before is anyone's guess), and this faction is basically a terrible Mary Sue of a faction.  Any coolness it has just comes from being overpowered, and god is it overpowered, totally ruining any semblance of balance.  You could basically completely disable their units' special abilities and they'd still win 2 to 1 against rebellion or empire, and that's only the beginning.

Still comes recommended from me, but I'll admit that may largely be nostalgia and my massive Star Wars obsession, but I do think that if it can be balanced it would be a playable game even today.

An absolute classic game, period. I honestly would consider this amazing if I hated Star Wars. Yes, the game is quite old and some mechanics are bad, etc. Overall, though, this game is good as is AND has one of the better modding communities out there (the Thrawn's Revenge mod is amazing); plus, it's pretty cheap. A must have for Star Wars and RTS gamers.

Pros:
Simply amazing space battle mechanics (vanilla is a bit boring in terms of ships at this point, but it's been a while)
Pretty okay graphics, all things considered
Easy to run on potatos (if you're okay with terrible graphics, which you should be if you play on a potato)
Lots of good mods
Easy to jump into casually
Multiplayer pvp is good

Cons:
Without the DLC, this game isn't that good. But you can't actually buy it standalone (I don't think). The only issue with that is you can't play the vanilla campaign (as the empire) with the good mechanics of the DLC (unless you use mods).
There are some lore issues with models and such (but this is a video game so that's expected)
Multiplayer player vs ai is a downside*

Here or there:
Ground combat is...I really can't say. It can be dull and grinding (if playing a campaign) but can also be engaging and tough. It really depends. Just expect a bit of a slog when it comes to ground forces. Many mods remedy this, but, obviously, I can't count that when it comes to a review. The mechanics are pretty good and the maps are actually quite good but the gameplay can be lacking. I think they are trying to both simulate an invasion and have traditional rts mechanics (fog of war, etc), along with the limits of the tech of the day, and it comes out feeling a bit less of good rts and good invasion.

*In a MP galactic conquest, planets not controlled by a player are ai controlled. To take these over, you have to, obviously, invade them. However, the game can't let one player have a battle against the ai while the other just sits there so it forces you into auto-resolve. This can be a fun killer because the auto-resolve mechanic tends to always yield greater casualties and lower success chances than when you fight it manually. I've lost fleets (and thus games) in MP simply because I got a bad roll.

Star wars Empire at war is an RTS strategy game.
Due to the games' release in 2006, the graphics are slightly outdated but work perfectly.
Space battles are entertaining and work well.
Ground battles are okay. They work but could do with some improvement.

If the graphics are too poor for you, there are 2 mods I recommend from the steam workshop.
1- Star wars Expanded: Thrawn's Revenge. Which is a good expansion to the game but this requires the Forces of corruption expansion pack to function.

2- Star wars Empire at war Remake: Galactic Civil War. This is a graphical improvement mod which adds both new maps and units. It functions well but also requires the Forces of corruption expansion pack to work.

Both mods should run smoothly but frame rates do get choppy in large battles.


Apart from mods, the base game is fun featuring 2 campaigns (a third included in the F.O.C expansion). These add story to the game and are very fun. There is a galactic conquest mode, which is similar to campaign but without a story to follow and objectives to meet.
Alternatively there is is the skirmish mode which directly drops you into a ground battle where you explore the map, create units and research upgrades to gain the upper hand in combat. 

Overall, I highly recommend this game due to how fun it is to play.

I was in high school when EAW originally came out. Always waited for a sequel (which never came). Luckily, the modding community has not only given us fans sequel worthy content, hours of game play, more and varied units, cleaner looking battles and an overall refurbished and remastered gaming experience. If you haven't played this before, even if you're new to trying the original/vanilla game for the first time... you are in for a great treat. 
If you're skeptical or unsure on getting the game, then I recommend checking out youtube channel TheXPGamers. His playthroughs, seasonal campaigns, test runs of mods and general knowledge of patches and mod authors is extensive, entertaining and worth looking into. He also has a discord and twitch service to check out for more videos and community input. 
My personal experience: I am by no means a great player, but I love the game too damn much to set it down. It sucks you in; the vanilla game is (at the very least) canon and follows the original movies (episodes 4-6) and is amazing. My recommendation is this: get the original, play it, and then check out the mods once you've beaten the original and expansion. 

Long live the Empire!!

Overall I like this game. It's a game I used to play a lot when I was a kid, and I like coming back to the game every now and then just to absorb the nostalgia. However, it's not a perfect game, and it's definitely not my favorite game from my childhood.

pros:
- nostalgic af
- first few hours of gameplay are addicting
- forces of corruption is even better than the base game
- mods available for this game are pretty good

cons:
- the game is only capable of using ONE core in your cpu. This means the game will still lag out even if you have a really good cpu that can do a million other things at once.
- if you play on easy, the game becomes too easy and repetitive after a certain point
- if you play on medium or hard, EVERY battle becomes tedious because the enemies become bullet sponges with larger armies that invade you more often. Because the enemy invades so much more, it becomes harder to get anything else done. I've always wanted to fight Darth Vader's Executor or the death star because it's fun to face a big ship and slowly destroy it, but as far as I know the empire will only build these on hard mode. :( Personally, I think the higher difficulties should've just increased the rate of credits that your enemies obtained. I have no problem destroying entire imperial fleets as long as every f***ing ship doesn't take another army to destroy. I think it'd be more fun just to mow through entire armadas. 

7/10 Still a pretty good game.

Ok so edit. I have a modern PC. The computer I am using has 5 times the Ram and 6 times the graphics capability of the used walmart laptop I played this game on. the save and load times on this game are entirely too long. Id rather lose a save file (which I've never had a problem with) then take 5 minutes to save. 


Clunky glitchy, god awful. I Have 550 hours on this game. maybe a hundred of those were me being too tired to shut down the game properly at 4 am and just letting it idle.
No other RTS has given me this experience. The defense on multiple fronts, the ever pressing need for better weapons, the heartbreak that fills me when one of my capital ships detonate, all hands lost. it is just amazing. I've played maybe a half a dozen mods, conquered the galaxy repeatedly using various factions. its all just so darn good.
if you are a strategy nut, this game is a must. if you are a casual player who wants something they can come back to and play this is a must. if you enjoy the modding scene, this is a must.


Tips: don't auto resolve with ships in orbit, tech up before going on the offensive, build mines only on planets with a 50 or higher base income, and set a timer so you dont accidently play all night.
MODS: most mods can be installed by creating a mods folder in ypur corruption folder, and then click and dragging the mod you downloaded into the mods folder. took a few tries but i got it down, some mods are weird, but not usually worth the extra effort. uninstall mod by clicking and dragging the file out of the folder. i just saved mod authors like 60 comments with that i swear to god.
 MODS, as witnessed by moi
Republic At War (RAW) while well polished visually, it is unbalanced. Republic easy campaign is 20 hours at the least. Cis Hard campaign was 8. i kid you not this mod is not balance wise. 2019 update: Raw runs alot slower on older computers now, They added 2 early game medium cruisers to the republic side but both ships are still outmatched by basic sep ships)
Clone wars mod is like the 2008 series. crashes occasionally, but better than RAW
Clone wars sub-mod has great Land combat just like the 2003 cartoon, but space battles are meh.
Thrawns Revenge is pretty epic and very unique. exact opposite of RAW really. Very well balanced, but the visuals are not as good. granted unlike RAW this game isnt advertised as finished and gets a new beta in febuary of 2017
Rise of the Mandalorians is both interesting, stable, and pretty to look at. also has the BEST turrets on ships unlike in vanilla and many other mods (again, RAW) 
The Alliance and Battlefront mods seem like dumpsters, with so much content from so many creators that they lack stability. Alliance also has an annoying change to the way the camera works in space that ruins the top down atmosphere. overwrites your data folder for vanilla, thus requiring a load of fiddling to uninstall.
Awakening of the Rebellion runs ridiculously slowly on the piece of dirt i'm typing this on, however it makes the game slow paced and every purchase counts. If you ever wondered how warlords in third world countries wage war, AOR has you covered (apologies to the AOR staff for mistaking their mod with others.) 
Ultimate Corruption feels like an expansion. it balances ship strength and fighter complement by class (light cruiser, cruiser, heavy cruiser, battlecruiser) allowing for you to pick and choose what you like. adds loads of new ships, makes stations awesome, and utterly destroys x wings. 

in closing, this game is ok vanilla, but fan made content shines it to a gleam.

Still a solid piece of 4X RTS as it was 14 years ago.

If you don't mind slightly aged graphics, the game is still rich with satysfying gameplay and ton of neat details that will please not only STAR WARS fans, but any keen observer. 

Details like, for example, the infantry uniforms and weapons look different - depending on the climate of the planet that they are fighting on. Indigenous populations and creatures, raging from seemingly useless ewoks to mighty rancors that can smash a T2B tank to pieces.

All of the iconic characters from the old star wars trilogy are there - Darth Vader, Han Solo, Boba Fett.. All the famous planets such as Tatooine, with it's vicious great maw or Geonosis with swarms of it's insectoid inhabitants.

Along with "Forces of Corruption" expansion, that adds new faction, ton of new units and few new game mechanics (garrisoning infantry in bunkers, mobile build pads, manual placing of buildings and forces on the planetary maps) it makes a complete treat for any old-school RTS players and Star Wars fans out there.

The game is a worth while play to a strategy mind set to operate a low spec space command and ground control what has limits on the ground; the mods-(workshop) what go with it, are just great add on's to the game and get a better worth value on it to be recommended to play in own hours or with friends in my opinion

Empire at War remains the best strategy title for Star Wars. The nostalgia is what immerses the player in the conflict but it is the polished gameplay that holds this title as one of the best the SW universe has resulted in.
The real-time empire map gives a sense of urgency and awareness of time, keeping the pressure on.
Asymmetric forces give replayability, and encourage diverse strategies for either side.
The ground forces is always described as lacking and in this I would agree. 
I would also love to see some ownership over units - perhaps similar to Star Wars Force Commander, where a troop gains experience, or even be upgraded from battle to battle and less cannon fodder - your own Rogue Squadron, veterans of galactic conquest from start to finish. 
The Mod community is still wildly active and releasing some of the best content to be found anywhere.

Would I recommend this? Only if you are a fan of Star Wars, Fleet Simulators, Battlefield Simulators, or RTS games. In other words, yes.
The Mods that the amazing community have created allow you to play as the Empire, the Republic, the New Republic, a variety of Criminal or Warlord factions (after the Battle of Endor), and more. There is a bit of a learning curve to this game if you are new to it. Even after 100+ hrs, I am learning each time I play. Watch some videos, get in there and play (remember - learn from your mistakes, but mistakes WILL be made. Sometimes the AI is a strategic genius, others... well, not so much)

My dad bought me this game back in 2007 for our 2002, windows XP ran PC. It ran at about 10 fps and i had no idea how to correctly play the game because I was 6 years old. But 13 years later at the age of 19. I still get the childhood joy and nostalgia of Mon Cal cruisers and Star destroyers clashing in a battle to the death, Imperial walkers charging in on a heavily defended rebel base, or blowing away planets with the Death Star. This game still hold up even in vanilla version and is my favorite game of all time.

So many design-flaws and odd choices - I want to like it, tried using the best mods...but the core gameplay is just so broken that one walks away from each game-session angry or frustrated, even if one wins.

And how the creators behind the C&C universe can make one of the worst land-battle 'mini-games' ever is amazing...the only thing in this game of remotely any interest is the space-battles, and even they are severely lacking.

This game would have been so much more fun if it was turn-based on the galactical map (to avoid the A.I. attack-spamming the player to stop them from doing anything, as it breaks ones input to start build-queues), had an economy that has a better oversight (rarely worried about money, more likely to zip around the map to start building units at most every planet, to keep the spam of units up) and a gameplay that wasn't rewarding just massing up on units and forcing forward with little to no tactics...

Amazing game, must have for all star wars and rts fans.
While the ground combat is lackluster and can easily become frustrating, the space combat and the galactic conquests modes make up for it enormously.
Add to the mix the extensive mod support and there's fun for hundreds and hundreds of hours.
Using mods you can go back to the old republic, and fight as the sith empire, mandalorians or old republic.
You can go to the clone wars, and fight off the cis as the republic or liberate systems for your consortium.
go into the (now legends) future, and fight as the new republic or the imperial remnant, among others.
But the mods don't just end here.
New units and balance to the civil war, improved graphics, enhanced gameplay...
Want other sci fi universes into the game? You can! Halo? Check! Stargate? Check! star trek? Check! All of them in a single mod? Double check!

As of the 28/12/19, there are a few mods to be on the lookout for: Disney trilogy mod and yuuzhan vong mod, for example.

Just by it

It is said that one should keep one's allies within view, and one's enemies within reach.

A valid statement. One must be able to read an ally's strengths, so as to determine how to best use them. One must similarly be able to read his enemy's weaknesses, so as to determine how to best defeat him.

But what of friends?
There is no accepted answer, perhaps true friendship is so exceedingly rare. But I had formulated my own.
A friend need not be kept within sight or within reach. A friend must be allowed the freedom to find and follow his own path. If one is fortunate, those paths will for a time join. 

But if paths separate, it is comforting to know that a friend still graces the universe with his skills, and his viewpoint, and his present. 

For if one is remembered by a friend, one is never truly gone.

Star Wars Empire at War is, in my opinion, one of the best Star Wars games ever made.

Made before EA took over you can really feel that the game was made by developers that really loved what they were doing. The space battles was way beyond their time unmatched by any games at the time. Even though the Land Battles are lacking, the feel of star wars remains in every part.

The main reason to buy this game is the super dedicated modding community that still produces mods to this day. Mods such as the Remake mod, Thrawn's revange and Awakening of the rebbelion really makes the game feel fresh even after almost two decades.

8/10
best rts
VERY GOOD FOR AN OLD GAME

[i]A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.... this great real-time strategy Game of STAR WARS was made and let me tell you it's probably still one of the best Space Strategy Games around. Of course the graphics are pretty outdated but you can fix that easily with some mods from the steam workshop. The battle atmosphere and the variety of units are still awesome and worth being taken a look at.[/i]

[u]Singleplayer:[/u]
You can play the story of the Rebellion & of the Empire and a free game with the whole galaxy open to you.
Though the lore doesn't go too much in depth it's still fun and if you want more, there's also mods for that. ;)
The atmosphere of the Ground and Space Battles is very convincingly taking you straight into the fight and it's all about your tactical knowledge. On top of that you'll have to manage your planets.

[u]Multiplayer:[/u]
The Game might be old but there are still quite a lot of people playing it online, so you can easily play matches with others or your friends!
There are all the possibilities offered you might wish for in a real STAR WARS Battle in the several online modes.

[h1]Abilities & Miscellaneous[/h1]
You can upgrade your planets and your space stations after your wish. All the special characters such as Darth Vader or Boba Fett have their own special abilities which makes the battle even more exciting and unpredictable! Use your units skills wisely and you might also win seemingly hopeless situations. There are a lot of mods you can download to maximize your gameplay content and to enjoy the Game even longer..


[b]If you're just looking for a strategy game it might not be worth the full price for you, but if you like the space theme and STAR WARS this Game is a must have in your library.[/b]

[i][b]May the force be with you.[/b][/i]


 ~ NightPhilipp

When this game first came out over 10 years ago, I loved it.  played the full campaign a few times on both sides, enjoyed the FOC expansion.  And then got Bored.
the first game lacked a lot of depth to it that should have been there.  FOC expansion improved on that a great deal, but it still wasn't enough.  SO I enjoyed it as much as I could for about a year, then shelved it.

Then I read about the Mods ebing made for this game.  And the Mods truly revitalised this game for me.  The mods truly maketh this game a very new experience.
The biggest draw card for this game has always been the space combat.  Ground combat is a bit more lack lustre, but you just learn to run with it.

In time I hope a new and very modern version of this game shall one day be released.  but until then its the modding community at large that will continue to keep this game lurching on its feet, and continue to keep this game worthy of a close look at for casual realtime space and empire management (lite) gameplay.

A game that has never been replicated and never needs to be replicated, because mods.

Whoever had the simple idea of developing a Star Wars RTS with both space and land battles and then combining both in a Galactic Conquest mode which forces you to first gain space superiority over a planet, then land forces and invade the ground was a pretty big genius in 2006. The base games have plenty of flaws, from balancing issues to braindead AI, but this game was always just a template upon which modders could impose their will.

Therefore, here my recommended list of mods for this game, because thats the way it is really meant to be played:

1. Thrawn's Revenge. By far the most polished and well balanced EaW mod out there. It also introduces some new gameplay elements. This mod covers the Star Wars Legends timeline past Episode 6 all the way to 20-30 years after it. If you desire to play in the Rebel vs. Empire era of the base game, this is unfortunately not the mod for you. The devs are also currently developing a Clone Wars Era side-mod, which I know will be held to the same high standard, so look out for that if you care about sequel stuff.

2. Awakening of the Rebellion. If you DO desire to play the Rebel vs. Empire era, this is a mod you can check out, but be careful, it SIGNIFICANTLY changes the gameplay compared to the base game. There is 4 times the buildings and 6 times the units and trust me, you will get overwhelmed. Also lacks polish compared to Thrawn's Revenge.

3. Empire at War Remake. This mod is actually in alpha stages and only found on moddb.com, but it looks incredibly promising. Unlike the other two mods above it adheres more closely to the base games except well, it look absolutely stunning. Every unit is replaced by an incredibly highly detailed model, all the way down to animated turbolaser turrets! Gameplay is also slowed down significantly from the base games, with a Star Destroyer truly being able to take a minute-long pounding, just like a 1,6km long warship should be able to.

4. Republic at War. A mod I had a personal (albeit small, only helped with the german translation of some unit texts) hand in. If you need a Clone Wars fix, you can get it here, although similar to the base game it is a bit unbalanced and the AI is pretty bad. 

Overall the modding scene for this game is what really made it survive all the way into 2019 and its one of the best modding scenes of all time. Judged by itself its an okay-ish 6/10, pretty much only held up by its uniqueness, but with enabling this modding scene I have to bump it up to a [b]8/10[/b].

While a strange game to get used to, I think this is a great real time strategy game. It is difficult, managing both planets space and ground bases, as well as maintaining your fleet and armies on the ground, spying on your enemies, and defending against those who would seek to crush you. I would recommend this game to others, at least to give it a shot. It has many good elements but it can be frustrating and confusing to get used to. You can grit your teeth and learn the hard way like many do and figure it out as you go, or take the easy route and look for instructions or take the tutorial. I do not think people should shy away from it because its different, I think people should at least give this game a shot and see what it has to offer.

Great game. The base game on its own is great with something stuff being a bit broken. For example, as I played the base game, multiple times I had airspeeders killed while trying to tow cable my AT-ATs. This resulted in my AT-ATs being unable to move but be able to fire and perform their abilities. And dear god, the AI spamming Acclimators is actual pain. However, mods greatly improve the game. They add more diversity to a game that is already great on its own. I'd definitely recommend Republic at War since it adds new aspects to the game, for example, the additional garrison research can save a level 2 space station from destruction which usually took a small fleet in order to protect it. Overall would definitely recommend, with the gold pack making it worth the money, more so during sales, in which I bought this for 7.99.

kill the WOOKIES

I'm a massive sucker for big space battles, probably due to Star Wars being my favourite franchise, so this game is great for me - it does both of those EXTREMELY well. There's a great amount of depth to the individual battles, with ships ranging from fighters to corvettes all the way up to capital ships all serving a purpose. What I particularly like is that the doctrines you see established in the films and expanded universe are all represented in the balancing of the different factions - the Rebellion relies on hit and run tactics and stays invested in things like fighters to try and take on Star Destroyers and stations. Inversely, the Empire follows the Tarkin Doctrine to a tee, pushing for heavily armed and shielded capital ships, but having more fragile and less effective single fighters.

This asymmetric strategy extends to the campaigns as well - in your efforts to conquer or liberate the galaxy, you'll gain new technologies and units through different means depending on your faction. The Alliance needs to be opportunistic and daring to win victories, while the Empire will quickly build up big fleets to try and encircle and trap the smaller Rebel forces.

With all of this said, the game does show its age from time to time - while lasers and turbolasers cut satisfyingly through space, some of the textures and models look a little outdated, and the other particles leave a fair bit to be desired. WITH THAT SAID, the Empire At War Remake mod is an excellent remedy to all of this - bringing the game up to a modern standard, and making engagements large and small a spectacle. Small balance tweaks are brought with the mod too, creating bigger opportunities for technologies like Ion Cannons to help a smaller fleet take on a larger one if they play it right.

At the end of the day, I can't recommend this game enough, especially with EaW-R installed. For the cheap prices you see it for on here, easily worth the buy.

This game is the one I keep coming back to. It never gets old, the gameplay is incredible, and it's workshop is a land of endless opportunities. A must have for all Star Wars fans, or RTS fans in general.

Vanilla: Honestly, it isn't the best. There are only 2 factions playable and fewer units than in Forces Of Corruption.

Modded Vanilla: A lot better than vanilla. You can have some great mods, even rivaling some of the better FOC ones.

Forces of Corruption: All around good. More units, more mods, another faction, new heroes, and a super star destroyer.

Modded FOC: The best. Some of the greatest mods are of FOC. This includes Thrawn's Revenge, Republic At War, Battlefront Commander, and others. This is recommended by me for the best experience.

All in all, an amazing game with one of the best workshops I've seen on the steam platform.

Honestly one of the best RTS games out there (IMO). 

-INTRODUCTION-
This game was my childhood (in addition to Battlefront 1 and 2), and so of course there is some level of bias at play here, but the game is just fantastic. For a game that is more than 13 years old it still holds up to other RTS games (WITH MODS, i will speak of that in a little bit). 
I mean just the idea of the game is fantastic enough in itself, that you have an entire galaxy to play with, you choose your own faction and build fleets and armies, how you must establish control of the space above the planet before you can launch your own ground invasion, and with huge both space and land battles with the biggest dreadnoughts to the smallest individual fighter. In addition, the hardpoint system, not seen in many games before this rises the gameplay to another level, making battles even more strategic as you can target and destroy specific points of the ships like hangars, engines, guns and shields. 

-POSITIVES, NEGATIVES- 
Now that sounds all well and good, but how is the game really. Well for starters, the game was made in 2006, so the graphics are nothing to write home about, in fact they can look quite horrible at times (and that is putting it bluntly). The AI is alright, although you'll find that the unit AI can often mess up your thoroughly planned and impeccably perfect plans and strategies. The space battles are phenomenal, and it is probably the main part of this game, and definitely the most well executed gamemode. 
On the other hand, we have ground battles, the most tedious part of this game. They can be awesome, cool, and you will definitely have some battles you'll never forget, but with the weak AI, at points large maps and after a while boring gameplay, it is probably the weakest part of the game. Now let's move to the main reason for why you should buy this game.

-MODING-
With the addition of the Forces Of Corruption DLC, Petroglyph games introduced modding support, which is probably the only reason why the game is still alive.
Due to the game's great core gameplay and frankly just the idea of the game, the community has made a TON of just out-right mindblowing mods. Some of the many out there are the Clone Wars mod, which introduces an entire new era, (the clone wars :] ), and two new factions, a new galaxy and TONS of new maps, it is honestly a completely new game. Another amazing mod is the newly released Thrawns Revenge, a complete rework of the game, introducing multiple factions and an amazing new lighting engine, putting the graphics to modern standards. If you cant handle the early 2000s graphics, this is the mod for you. This mod also fixes a ton of problems from the main game, like ships being able to shoot at longer ranges, fixing the ground battles and making the AI seemingly a lot more complex and capable. 

-CONCLUSION-
Just fRICking buy it.

The best Star Wars RTS with plenty of its own unique flair as an RTS.

No, this isn't a Star Wars mod, though there are an abundance of purely excellent SW mods of awesome RTS games. This is a fun, immersive Star Wars experience. It's not perfect, but once you get the hang of the Rock, Paper, Scissors system and how certain units can dominate even the most terrifying ones, it's a blast. Space combat is absolute perfection.

My suggested mods for the Forces of Corruption expansion, they just make things even more enjoyable:
- Thrawn's Revenge (All Legends Eras played through an AWESOME campaign. Beautiful graphics remake)
- Lord Link's Model ReRig Pack (changes next to nothing from Vanilla FoC, simply makes the Eclipse buildable...for if you've played the campaign and wish you could use it in Galactic Conquest)
-z3r0x mod (What can I say? This is just fun. Adds a ton of planets from Legends and Canon, TONS of Legends ships, CIS droid armies and fleets for the Underworld, fixes the unbalanced Rebellion by giving them tons of Capital Ships so they can actually take on the Empire/Underworld; this mod even has a Galactic Conquest match with no Consortium for those of you who get sick of the Za-brokenn Consortium. Also, you can build the Eclipse! My only complaint is suddenly almost every ship type can only be built on certain planets: case in point, Death Star II can only be buildable over Endor, but aside from the sometimes annoying chore of finding which of the 68 planets can build Tie Fighters or B-Wings, this mod is amazing. Five stars for enjoyment, playablility {it doesn't crash and doesn't feel unfinished as so many mods do})

SWEAW is my second most played game on Steam as of now, but let me first say that I've been playing the game since it's release in 2006 and there is no other game besides the 2001 reason I learned about modding and game scripting- Star Trek Bridge Commander- than this game, Star Wars Empire at War- that I am always coming back to. SWEAW is an amazing, authentic Star Wars experience and my personal favorite Star Wars game ever, and it flat out would be the best if it weren't for KOTOR or the Jedi Knight games. This game has that perfect mixology of elements that make a game infinitely replayable to me- Lots of content, realistic gameplay, and mod support. SWEAW without mods has near perfect gameplay, and while parts of the game do have their caveats- including the less polished ground gameplay- the game only improves greatly with a very active mod community. Just check out the Remake mod for this game, you will be blown away by the content and graphics fidelity closer to the new Battlefront games than the original release.

So let's get into it, why do I like this game so much? Let's star with graphics. The game in 2006 looked fantastic, especially the textures and modelling on larger ships in space. Today though they are serviceable but are much better with mods. Even without them though Star Destroyers look accurate and break apart satisfyingly and there's a good amount of PEW PEW to be had. Performance is decent for a game this old, even with breathtaking graphics in mods it still chugs along at a playable framerate with hundreds of units on the screen. Gameplay is really good. The best mode is the space skirmishes or the galactic map with the ground combat disabled with a script file. Unfortunately the ground combat isn't great as units don't follow pathing or directions correctly, and there's just something off and unfinished feeling with that mode. If you really enjoy Star Wars ground combat, this is usable but the Star Wars mod for Men at War is better. The real highlight of the game is the awesome space combat. While AI isn't the smartest thing ever it works pretty well and it can be a real treat to watch your favorite ships slug it out. Maps are more simple and battles take place in 2 dimensions but there's something really satisfying about being able to build a queue of ships and hyperspace them in anywhere when you need them.

There's a huge amount of replayability in this game as with most RTS games but this one is really worth the price tag. Mod support alone is massive and adds an incredible amount of content and missing units to the already large amount of ships and fighters in the base game and expansion. Modding is fully supported and since the game was updated to work with Steam workshop and Steam multiplayer it really has breathed a new life into the game. There's not just some skins and maps here, but full conversion mods available. There's no grind here as all the content is included in the purchase of the game and single expansion pack part of this Gold edition- I know right? You actually get all the content from the get go with your money!

Audio is decent for the time with a good selection of Star Wars theme music and lots of explosions and PEW PEW sounds, along with some good voice-overs. Controls are as expected in a RTS game, they work. Story outside of the galactic campaign's objectives are basically non-existent, but that really doesn't take away from the game as this is more of a 'you make the decisions and story' game through your own gameplay. It's fantastic for recreating your favorite canon and what-if scenarios especially with the included map editor.

I highly recommend this game and it should be a part of any Star Wars fan's library and anyone who enjoys a great RTS game with lots of potential. Grab this game at the next Steam sale if you haven't already!

My buddy Daequan showed me this game on a fine summer afternoon and I feel in love with it immediately. I've only registered 3 hours on it, but I can say with utmost honesty that this is my favorite game.

This game's main content is good, but the real meat and potatoes of this game comes from its incredible mod support. The sheer breadth of content one can gain from this game's mods is nothing short of amazing. One could play all the traditional Star Wars eras and the Expanded Universe content with the right mods. If you're a Star Wars fan wanting to test out your abilities to command the battlefront, look no further than Star Wars: Empire at War!

Apologies for this primitive review, as this is my very first one.
  To begin, the best thing I can adamantly say about this game is the space battles. They are crown jewel of the game, very fun and engaging, although frustrating and repetitive at times due to several unbalances. *Cough* Zann Consortiun *Cough*
 Other than that, the game also has land battles, which to my very enlightened opinion, they are very frustrating, unfun, unbalanced, and an overall a bad time. It also doesn't help that the games visuals don't hold up very well. 
  Now on to the campaign/galactic conquest. For the most part, a good experience. Simply due to the fact that Space battles take the majority of battles in the campaign. Ground battles are there, but suffer from the problems I has listed before. The story in of its self isn't very good, as it doesn't make much sense when placed in the lore, (i.e., Rebels attacking Wayland) but the game offers some good fun.
 Overall, the game gets an eight out of ten, a good game in my personal opinion. It also has some amazing mods which I highly recommend,  Thrawn's Revenge being one of them.

I love this strategy game.  Immersion in the Star Wars EU that allows you to be the Galactic Commander and be engrossed in the game.  For the Vanilla mode i.e. original Forces of Corruption is the best version to play.  The Zann Consortium main playthrough is excellent.  For Galactic conquest the Zann Consortium has a tough start but is smooth sailing afterward.  Fighting against the Zann Consortium is tough as the Rebellion or Empire but it is doable.  Honestly a bit of luck is involved too lol.  I enjoy the challenge.

The mods are where the game shines.  I recommend the Republic at War mod for the Original Empire at War and the Thrawn's Revenge mod.  Republic at War fixes the issues with the Empire at War mode and lets you play in the Clone Wars.  Thrawn's Revenge is tough with a balanced playthrough and more traditional  RTS elements.  Great for those who want balance and a large universe.

While this game is on the older side of games, it is still a very fun and replayable game. This game has some pros and cons. 

Pros: 
Unique concept - only starwars RTS of its type
Impressive voice acting
Adequate visual effects
Adequate hero mechanics
Immersive space battles

Cons:
Unimpressive land battles
Poor unit models
Lack of unique side missions
Lack of unit diversity

I would recommend to any RTS player to buy this game, but play only one campaign on vanilla. Download all three of the following mods: Imperial Civil War: Thrawn's Revenge (ICW), Awakening of the Rebellion (AoR), and Republic at War (The Clone Wars is an acceptable alternative for those who liked the TV series). These mods add a gigantic amount of content. AoR adds a bunch of unique missions, amazing unit models, and moving parts like turrets, flaps, etc. ICW is a mod for fans of Star Wars Legends, with extensive focus on the warlord factions and their characters. ICW has a unique progression system based on the Legends lore, wherein all the technology progression is based on historical eras, each era characterized by the leader of the Empire or its remnants. Republic at War is more of the movie perspective of the clone wars, with Venators and Lucrehulks a plenty, unique models for named Republic Army units, (212th Attack Battalion, 41st Siege Battalion, 327th Star Corps, etc) and unique models for the Jedi generals that lead them.

SW:EAW (GP) is a fantastic game. After losing and winning several campaigns and skirmishes, I can say I really like this game.

Gameplay: 9.5/10

The AI has a few issues, namely moving units inefficiently and spamming units. This takes a toll on your computer after about twenty minutes into a skirmish match, if it lasts that long. The AI loves to spam Acclamators, Assault Frigates Mk. II's, and Mon Calamari Cruisers. This does make for interesting battles, though. They put you on your toes at times and may really draw your attention for hours on end.

Graphics: 8/10

This game is over ten years old, and has held up okay. Some minor graphic glitches here and there, but otherwise, it looks great, and mods easily fix this issue.

Singleplayer: 9/10

As stated in the gameplay section, the AI has a few issues, but otherwise is a great experience. I do singeplayer to test my fleets, mostly.

Multiplayer: 8/10

Desyncs are commonplace in multiplayer, which sucks during campaigns. I'd recommend saving every five-or-so minutes if you can while in a campaign. Otherwise, multiplayer is great.

Modding: 10/10

The Steam Workshop and external websites make this game even better. Mods like RaW, Yodenmod, and many more mods make the game even more fun and refreshing. Of my 68 hours at time of review, probably 85% of those hours are from modded play. 

Overall, I'd say this game is 100% worth $20. This game is one of the best Star Wars games out there.
Love this game after all these years it still holds up and the mod community makes this game a must have for any star wars fan. this is hands down one of the best star wars games ever.

This is probably one of the better Star Wars games you can buy, mostly for the modding scene. I've recently been playing the fantastic Thrawn's Revenge mod that has added a lot of depth to the game, and future updates to this mod are adding even more elements of grand strategy with planetary influence and elections. The base game is pretty good on its own, and I recommend playing it before starting mods, but I definitely recommend this game.

Steam (at the time of writing this) only shows 44 hours of playtime, however that is because for the past 9 years I have been playing on my disk copy, and doing some estimations with my brother I am probably closer to about 2000 hours since I originally bought it. Modded or otherwise EaW is incredibly fun and engaging, and despite trying other RTS games similar, I keep finding myself back here. Sad to have to buy it again, but I am very glad its here. EaW will be a cult classic for sure.

I mean its star wars first, and the ability to control naval action in this universe is fantastic. simplistic yet still in depth enough to formulate multiple strategies and with the addition of a third faction, allows for even more tactical strategies. The single player campaigns give you a sense of urgency without seeming too overpowered or impossible to win unless on a low difficulty. Would recommend for anybody who enjoys real time strategy games. I bought this game long ago and just got around to playing it and man was I missing out! What a great game with some fantastic mods that make it look/play even better. The vanilla alone was sweet, but the Remake mod just made it even sweeter. 

Usually I'm playing WWII RTS games or Space 4X and have yet to get into a Space RTS and this was a pleasant surprise. I'm not a huge Star Wars fan so I have a lot to learn about the pieces and what they can all do, but it's been fairly easy to pick up without any help.

Really enjoying the upgrades and strategy that goes along with some of the pieces like the MDU's with shields, learning how that all worked has helped tremendously with strategy. I did have a crash recently in a 3+ hour long game during a super weapon firing with the Remake mod, but otherwise things have been smooth.

I haven't even ventured into the space fights yet, can't wait to check that out. It's well worth the $ for sure, even if you're not into Star Wars, it's a fantastic strategy game and the graphics are (especially with the Remake mod) are damn good for how old this game is, especially considering so many 2019 games are going retro with their graphics anyway. This looks better than some of those types of games.

Just get it, you'll be glad you did!

To sum this game up:
Pros
+ Very nostalgic
+ Gives you a chance to command those massive space battles from the movies
+ You can decide the outcome of the war, for all those Empire fans who were disappointed when they somehow lost to the Rebel scum
+ Unique Units
+ Cool in-game functions such as orbital bombardment or commando raids
+ Amazing soundtrack
+ Modding community is amazing
+ Perfect length for Galactic conquest
+ Enemy AI is actually competent 
+ Technology/Research system is very cool as it represents the gear for it's appropriate time period

Cons
- Friendly AI can act pretty dumb from time to time

I would highly recommend this game. I am in partial to star wars so I will try no to be bias because of that.

HUD: simple but effective and easy to pick up. It makes you feel like a commander actually observing battles take place.

AI: Some times the AI has occasional bugs I have found and exploited but I do often remember the AI being very competitive and challenging during skirmish battles.

The story: it is built off of the good-ol' star wars EU stories. It makes you feel like you are actually taking part in something larger than a simple skywalker story. It feels like an actual campaign is what I am trying to say.

Gameplay: load times seem spotty and weird but that pales into comparison with how the game plays. Some things that I thoroughly enjoyed would be; Space battles and the special units used. Weak against/strong against unit index is a great way to base unit compatibility. The perks and special abilities that units have are simple, straight forward, and fun to use. Each ability is useful in its own way which is nice compared to other games I have played. I have played a few other RTS games that each unit has way too many abilities and they do not really explain well what they do. 

Another fun note that I want to put is the cinematic camera. I feel as though all RTS enthusiasts some times like to just watch their massive army absolutely demolish the enemy. Props to the devs for adding a big button that takes away the HUD and all distractions so you can just watch. 

I am trying to include things that I did not like but it is hard because this is an absolute gem. I would say that some heroes are ANNOYING AF. Han and Chewie can seriously get bent. I understand how each faction lacks in areas where as others they excel in though. Bottom line is that some heroes are OP and you can cheese the enemy to oblivion but I would not have it any other way.

I love this game, and pretty much everything about it, as someone who LOVES Star Wars and sci fi in general this is like a dream. I cant say much about the visuals other than that they convey what this game is trying to deliver really well. The game play is top notch, I love the satisfying feeling of having a capital ship ready and when it almost looks like you have lost BAM, they are screwed. The strategic elements feel, well strategic and what you decide to attack matters, if they are trying to get away, take out their engines, if the're shields are too annoying then take out the generator. There's a million ways to play this game, the soundtrack keeps you playing the game, its not incredible but its perfect for a Star Wars game.
         Personally the game shines through mods, unfortunately the 'This belongs in a museum' computer I have cant handle some mods, but it usually works, I suggest the cannon timeline mod, it adds so much and feels great to play. I give Empire at war and Forces of Corruption a 9/10, its one of the last remaining decent Star Wars games with an actual fanbase, (I'm looking at you EA) So if you want to spend your money on a star wars strategy game, this is the one to spend it on it on. 

Note: I wrote this a while ago, I have more games, am older and have less time to play, yet I am still active in this game.

I really recommend this to Star Wars fans out there. You can really do so much with this game. My favorite part is the Forces of Corruption expansion, all of the ships in the Zann Consortium are SUPER cool. I would pick the Consortium over the Empire and Rebellion any day! Nonetheless, if you are a SW fan, you really should get this game because it's amazing. The mods are awesome too, there's so many and it changes the game in a very interesting way. If you choose to get it, I assure you, it won't be a mistake because again; it's super amazing and fun. I get lost into for hours at a time due to the extreme enjoyment I get out of playing it.

This game is a masterpiece of epic proportions. The base game is challenging and very rewarding. The modding community for this game is still extremely active even to this day. Major mods are still having major updates at the time of this review. The multiplayer runs well and the AI is challenging. I feel that space battles and mods are this games greatest strengths.

Just a ton of fun even if the RTS elements of the game are a little bit weaker than most other games.  The biggest hold backs for the base game (there are many, many mods out there that address these problems so if you feel like playing those, then this game is near flawless) is the limited number of units that can be on a map at a time.  On the ground, this is no issue since it would suck to be bouncing around thousands of units while lasers fly all about but then there are the space battles.  They do feel like you are leading a rather formidable armada into battle but only to a point.  Sure, you can have a huge death stack of units meeting  another fleet and slowly but surely warp in new ships whenever some fall, but you never get a Return of the Jedi feel of large fleets smashing into each other.  Other than that, the sound is amazing, the game still looks good for being nearly 10 years old, the AI is rather competent (except on Easy where they will routinely abandon planets to go attack with 44 X-Wings into a fleet of Star Destroyers covered by a picket of corvettes) and the campaign is actually fun oddly enough.  Worth 20 and it is an absolute steal when on sell.

This game is fun and was inventive for its time. The idea that trained units don't arrive directly onto the battle unless deployed via hyperdrive jump or off map dropship is still blowing me away to this day. Not only that, but the Workshop support for this Steam release adds a few more years to this game's replayability by letting you play it in new and interesting ways, such as turning back the clock to the Clone Wars era or incorporating the zombies from the Star Wars book "Death Troopers". I highly recommend that RTS players give this classic a try!

Though outdated and sadly in need of a new and updated version. Star wars Empire at War Forces of Corruption is a good game for its time. However it is a gleaming diamond in the ruff when you consider the mods made for the game and the very active developers working on these  customization's. Its a beautiful work of art what many of these mod developers have achieved with this platform and it will likely remain a beautiful favorite of mine, for time and time again of invasions of the star wars galaxy. This is not a game for people who don't like strategy and painstaking amounts of time wasted. It is however a very competitive game and you will continue to explore new strategies as time goes on as ultimately this will decide your Empire and rebellion, or even Republic or Confederacies fate. Only you can decide, will you take the path of the real story or will you change its history altogether?

Very solid game. I recommend the Remake Mod (find it on moddb) and the Thrawn's Revenge/ Imperial Civil War mod, which is on steam, after you finish the campaigns.

Strategically, try to use your faction's advantages to their fullest. Small rebel ground forces are impossible to stop or detect, and can raid and conquer poorly defended imperial worlds with ease. Imperial fleets are exceedingly powerful, get free fighters with their ships, and need to play mind games with a foe to ensure their many fronts become a liability. Also remember that taking a planet with a helpful ability is just as sound as taking one that you don't want your foes to have.

As Zann, Corruption allows you to move fleets past other planets' defenses, meaning you can ship forces behind enemy lines and exaggerate the too many fronts problems the empire has. Pay close attention to types of corruption, too; some kinds generate massive amounts of money. Use your superiority fighters, shield-ignoring mass drivers, and take care of your superweapons to stay ahead. If the Empire makes the Death Star II, you can permanently kill it with IG-88, and it'll also destroy any planet or fleet the death star is over. Darth Vader in the Executor can easily be ignored, and you should just attempt to take planets it isn't on rather than address it with weaker fleets. Take lots of bombers!


At any rate, I've put countless hours into this game even before I had it on steam. To this day it holds up as one of the best star wars games out there, and certainly the best when it comes to grand strategy.

People say this is a bad rts strategy game with a star wars theme, and they are right, and the game is awesome.
What makes SW:EAW so good for 2019 are the mods, literally no one plays the vanilla game anymore without mods.
PROS:
-very fun gameplay, lots of strategy involved, and in space combat there is probably more strategy than in any other rts scifi game i have ever seen.
-very fun, challenging, but not too hard galactic conquest mode where you conquer the galaxy on a massive scale, there are legit hundreds of things you have to watch out for: tech level, possible locations of enemy large fleets, order of conquering planets and keeping in mind their specialties (which most planets have), sizes, possible defences etc, unit buildings, defending your worlds, and a lot of other things
-with mods like the remake mod, thrawn's revenge, awakening of the rebbelion, yoden mod you can make the game feel like a sequel to the vanilla one, and the best of all: the devs for the listed mods are super active and will update them when they have the time to
CONS:
-bad vanilla graphics, but its saved by the fact the game is from 2005
-the unit lists for the vanilla game are quite limited and not so unique
-needs more legends content

overall, if you are a star wars fan who seeks epic strategy battles, and especially space battles, look no further than this classic

The logged hours is a lie; I've put well over 1000+ hours into this game. As somewhat of an expert, I'll list the pros and cons of getting this, while being as unbiased as I can be with one of my personal favorite games of all time...I'll try, okay?

First off, this is absolutely a Real-Time Strategy (RTS) game first and foremost, and was made back when people actually cared about RTS games. It shows in the gameplay, the strategies you can come up with, and the formation of fleets/garrisons for your space/ground battles. Depending on which version you play, the factions change a bit. If you play the OG Empire at War, you have only the choice between the Empire or Rebellion. If you play the Forces of Corruption expansion, a third faction is added called the Zann Consortium, which helps to make the gameplay a bit less stale and more challenging, though it comes with its own set of problems if you play against the AI as either Empire or Rebellion.

There are two focus points for the game: space and ground combat. Space is where you get the majority of your fun from, as ground combat is a little bit lacking, and defenders have an overwhelming advantage against the poor schmucks on offense. Since my best advice for ground combat is to bring a large compliment of ground troops/vehicles and auto-resolve the conflict to minimize casualties on your side, I'll focus on space combat.

Space combat has several facets to it. Rather than a traditional rock-paper-scissors approach, the developers came up with a unique dynamic between each class of ship, allowing you to mix and match ships to create your ideal fleet composition. You are even able to build individual squadrons of fighters if you feel that the ones provided by your carriers/capital ships are not strong enough/numerous enough. Iconic Star Wars ships such as the Imperial-class Star Destroyer, the Mon Calamari MC80-class Star Cruiser, X-Wings, TIE Fighters and more are included, plus several ships that are not as well-known, but nevertheless fulfill a vital role in fleet composition. You can have as many ships as you are able to build in any single fleet, but there is a limit to how many you are able to deploy onto the battlefield when engaged in combat at any given time. There is also an overall population limit that is determined by the number of planets in your possession, that can also be increased by building and upgrading space stations on those same planets. Both space and ground, in this regard, have set build structure limits for how far you can upgrade space stations (space) and how many ground structures you can have on the planet (ground), usually based off of lore-related reasons (ex: Kessel is less of a planet but more of a planetoid, and does not have a lot of space for ground-based structures. As such, it has very few buildable structures planetside.) This prevents you from building endlessly and dragging the game on forever, something that I'll be covering in a bit.

Naturally everything costs money: ships, troops, vehicles, space stations, etc, so you'll need a stable income. Income is provided via planets in your possession, as well as any complete trade/hyperspace routes you control. Income can be increased on planets via mining facilities. Some planets produce extra income due to outside factors, usually lore-related (ex: Kessel has 2 or 3 ground slots, but due to spice mining has a very high credit production, so dedicating those slots to mining facilities drastically increases the already-high credit production, allowing that planet to produce more credits than another planet may with 3/4/5 build structures). Income is generated on a 'daily' basis: every 'day' that passes deposits credits into your account based off of the total income produced by all of your planets/mining facilities. This income is yours to do with as you please, and will accumulate as 'days' pass if you do not spend any before the end of the next 'day'.

As for in-game time? That's a bit of an issue, and one of the only things really holding this game back. Keep in mind, this was produced around 2006/2007, so there's a limit to what the game can do in terms of extension. The longer the game goes, the more prone it becomes to lagging, crashing, and other system-related issues. Unless you are running an absolute POS computer, this game should run fine for you with no issues until around Day 350. After that, all bets are off. The better your computer, the more likely you are able to push that to Day 400 or even a bit higher, but eventually the built-in system the game runs on will not be able to handle it, and start crashing repeatedly whenever you enter combat, making it unplayable. Again, because this was a game built back during the mid 2000's, it's got some limitations to it. That being said, it shines despite these limitations.

Alright, time for the Pros/Cons List - 

Pros:
-Genuine RTS game
-Based on Star Wars, with references to the lore found all throughout the game.
-Heroes for all factions included. FOC expansion adds new heroes.
-Campaign? It's got a little bit of campaign to go with it, but it's mostly for new players getting started and learning how the mechanics/controls work.
-Flexibility with fleet and garrison customization, allowing for a whole assortment of different playstyles to be utilized.
-Buildable Death Star
-Usable Death Star (yes you can blow up planets with this superweapon in the game, and it's not limited. ANY planet can be a target.)
-Killable Death Star (if you're not the Empire, and want it dead, there are ways to do it, though it'll cost you a Hero. Good news is that the Death Star can't be rebuilt once this option is taken: it's gone for good.)
-Pretty damn good replayability, which is rare nowadays.
-The Modding Community. This game has been out for over a decade, and has a dedicated following of die-hard EAW fans that are, to this day, providing new and exciting mod content that can be used with this game for fresh, fun experiences for those who have already beaten the regular game into the ground and are looking for something new to do with it.

Cons:
-Ground combat is clanky af, and heavily favors defenders. Just slap a large amount of troops/vehicles on the planet you want to take and auto-resolve the headache away.
-Dated graphics. Unless you get a mod pack for them, age has taken its toll. Still a pretty good game visually despite this.
-Dated system. As stated above, the higher that Day count clicks, the more likely you are to encounter in-game issues, nothing of which can be done about it, no matter what type of computer you use.
-Corruption mechanic in FOC. If the AI is given control of the Consortium in FOC, they will spam Corruption on your planets, forcing you to constantly drag your Heroes capable of removing Corruption across the galaxy to cleanse it, as well as costing you credits to purge it from your planets. Failure to do so allows the Consortium free passage through otherwise enemy-controlled territory, and they can send terrorists to blow up your ground bases, weakening your defenses as a result. Can get really annoying really fast for even a hardened veteran.


Overall, I would give this game a SOLID 9.0/10. Despite being aged and having very visible flaws, the fact that it's lasted over a decade and still has a dedicated following of fans that love the game and are willing to spend time and effort to make it even better is, IMHO, a testament to how good this game truly is.

I think my time played says a lot, I rather like this game.
It has a mixture of strategic management and RTS tactical battles in a manner similar to total war, and I would absolutely recommend to any fans of that series or wider genre. Whilst old, this game combines good strategic gameplay with satisfying links to star wars lore. I wasn't particularly a star wars fan when i first started playing, I did so for the strategy, but I have become much more of a star wars fan as a result of my time in game.

Besides the base game and expansion, the continued success of empire at war really comes from the excellent community produced mods. There is something here to satisfy everyone. I personally strongly recommend AOTR above all others, although I would recommend getting a through grasp of the base game first since it adds a lot of depth and a steep learning curve to go with it. New mods are still coming out regularly alongside updates to the big popular classics.

All in all, if you're unsure whether to get this game, grab it on sale and give it a shot, you most likely won't regret it. Oh, and don't worry about running requirements, graphics are in a good spot of being plenty good enough to play the game and but also not so sparkling that they require you to have a decent PC.

This game deserved a sequel, but failing that, what the community has done with it is amazing. Just be aware that it's a 32-bit, single core application, so it [i]will[/i] lag when the action gets crazy unless your machine has very strong individual core performance. Empire at War is an RTS game based in the Star Wars Expanded Universe (At the time Canon). In base game, you can play as the Rebels or the Empire. In Forces of Corruption, you get the opportunity to play as the Criminal Underworld, or as the game calls them, The Zann Consortium (as well as the Rebels and the Empire).

EaW is basically Total War but in Star Wars. You build your fleets and ground armies and defend/attack planets. You can upgrade your tech level, unlocking new ships to build and new units to recruit. You even get to control iconic characters such as; Darth Vader, Darth Sidious/Emperor Palpatine, Admiral Ackbar (His Home One flagship) and Luke Skywalker (In his X-Wing). Other playable "heroes" include; Admiral Piett, Rogue Squadron and Admiral Thrawn.

But the strongest part of EaW is; The Modding Community. With modders like Corey Loses and his team making mods like Thrawn's Revenge and Fall of the Republic (Still not released as of 13th October 2019) the game really is flourishing. They expand on the game and add more mechanics to make a deeper experience. We also have mods like; Republic at War, Empire at War: Remake, Yodenmod and Battlefront Commander that makes the game really enjoyable in multiple playthroughs.

Overall, the game is really fun. The Modding Community really comes in clutch with EaW. But don't get me wrong, Empire at War is good even without mods, but it certainly helps. If you are up for a fun RTS set in Star Wars, pick this up. If you don't enjoy Star Wars, pick it up anyways, its a fun experience.
