If you ever played this when it first came out back in 2006, then you should totally pick it up again. It's classic Star Wars goodness at When Star Wars was really booming. It is not a simple game to jump into if you have no experience with Real Time Strategy games. Heck, I had forgotten or never realized how hard an RTS could be until I bought this. If you like Star Wars, especially Extended Universe Star Wars, then you will enjoy this whether you have had experience with RTS games before or not. Locales, sound design, and all manner of heroes and villains to use from multiple eras. The modding community really gives it some new life, too, as there are some excellent mods out there that expands the game to include more classic, EU, and Disney canons. Plus the fact that it can be played at your own pace adds to its value. Really a top-notch RTS any Star Wars fan can appreciate.

 Ground battles

2016 review: Looks great. Lots of cool mods on the internet. The campaigns are fun, and so is the Consortium campaign. You can use strategy, or spam stuff which is easier. The Consortium is overpowered though. Its super annoying when playing against the Consortium.
       The original Empire at War and the Forces of Corruption (FoC) addon are separate, which you can choose when you start the game. The original has the Rebel and Empire campaigns. FoC has the campaign for the Consortium. You can play single player modes on either version.
        Playing galactic conquest as Rebels or Empire is terrible. Easy difficulty is too easy, Medium is too hard. Both sides will not give you any breathing room. Consortium can go to your planet and take over your level 5 space station just by being there. WTF? Is this a bug? Their military power is around 95%, while yours is around 30% - 60% if you try on easy mode. I have no choice but to do auto-resolve with a very large force when attacking Consortium on land because they spam tanks and long range torpedoes which can wipe out anything you throw at them.
       You can control the super star destroyer, Executor, but only in galactic conquest. The icon looks like Darth Vader. In space, Vader is the Executor. On land Vader is himself ofcourse. You can use the 2nd Death Star which has the ability to destroy any enemy ship, but only in galactic conquest.
New heroes: Luke, Yoda, Garm Bel Iblis and his huge hover tank, the Arc Hammer factory ship, Admiral Thrawn, Dark side witch, IG-88, Bossk, Tyber Zann, Urai. Kyle and Mara are removed.
       Dark troopers phase 1 - 3, new tie fighters, over powered Consortium capitol ships with big guns and stealth (seriously, Consortium capitol ships are OP), mon cal frigate with cluster bombs, ewoks with bombs strapped to them..., rancors, droidekas. Rebels have not changed much because they already have more units than Empire.

There're a multitude of issues with this game currently. Here's but a few:

- Doesn't function - the two top-most game options ('Singleplayer' & 'Tutorial') on the start screen are unclickable. This is replicated for every screen, meaning that although the user can access the 'Multiplayer' tab, they cannot choose either of the options - 'Internet' or LAN.

To fix this bug, go to the the directory in which the game is installed (by default, 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Star Wars Empire at War\GameData') and run the Compatibility Troubleshooter on 'StarWarsG.exe'. That should fix it - if not, manually change the compatibility settings to Windows 7.

- When editing graphical settings an error appears requiring a restart of the game (although most settings that are changed are saved).


However, past the under-the-hood issues due to incompatibility with newer Windows OSs, the game itself is actually very compelling. 

For instance, it is surprisingly realistic regarding its Space Battle mechanics - the use of ion fields and gas clouds that hinder certain abilities of the ships passing through them helps push tactical gameplay over brute force.

Empire at War brings a new genre to Star Wars in the form of a Real Time Strategy game. It mixes many elements that are seen in later games such as Battlefront with its Galactic Conquest. The game is the Red Alert of the Star Wars franchise and it can definitely be a lot of fun to have huge armies from the Star Wars universe fight it out in control of planets within the galaxy that is far far away. The game takes you to many well loved places like Dantooine and Kashyyk in a constant struggle to maintain control over the galaxy. The game is getting pretty old now but it's definitely still playable and able to be enjoyed.

So... yeah this is a complicated game. Personally I enjoy it but there are times where it straight up gives you the finger. if you AREN'T playing the expansion good I hope you enjoy it I do. But for those who choose to venture into the expansion heed my words. With the release of the new faction the Zann consortium they didn't choose to balance it well. in galactic conquest I've had a "bug" (and I say bug because if this is a feature then the devs really fucked) the Zann fleet would hold in orbit above space even when a fleet of mine was positioned above it as well. When you try to move the fleet back it then puts you into combat with consortium's fleet but now your space station is now there's. It feels very cheap that they can just steal your level 5 space station that you sunk time and money into. 

TLDR great game, avoid the expansion

I clicked possitive recommend for Empire at War, but I am actually on the fence about this game. It's fun to play the Empire, but not so fun to play the Rebellion.

Playing the Empire is what a conquest game should be. Build huge fleets, massive armies and conquer orbital systems and planet locals. The problem with the Rebellion is the raid fleets. Often times it's too costly to try and defeat Imperial fleets in orbit of Imperial controlled worlds, especially when there is an orbital ion cannon on that planet's surface. You might win but at a huge cost to your own fleet, and the Rebellion can't afford huge losses like the Empire can. So the Rebels can instead sneak three ground units onto the planet in what's called a "raid fleet". If you make smart use of building turrets and bacta healing stations on the ground, a small raid fleet can liberate a planet from a much larger force. But is it fun? It's much slower and tedious because you have to destroy the Empire's forces little by little. It's not fun playing the Rebellion because unless you're playing  on normal difficulty, you can't afford to throw your forces at the Empire and fight them head on. Instead you must slowly chip away at their larger resources little by little.

The other problem I have is the Rebellion and Empire can't face each other full force in space or ground battles. Each side has a max limit to how many units can enter battle and the rest of your forces can only join as reinforcements as your units are destroyed.

Lastly is the difficulty settings themselves. On "normal" it's much to easy and hard difficulty is much too difficult. I want to like this game because it's so close to being something great. It just doesn't do it for me. Since it's at least somewhat enjoyable to play as the Empire, I give it a positive recommend.

It is surprising that there is only one decent Star Wars strategy game, but here it is. And while this game may not have as advanced mechanics as many other top sci-fi space strategy titles, it definitely provides very immersive experience and very atmospheric battles, filled with units and heroes from the original trilogy (Emperial and Rebels) while having the original soundtrack playing in the background. Unlike many space strategies it also has land battles on the planet surfaces and while the game economy system is somewhat primitive the galactic conquest mode is as enjoyable as much as the skirmish mode, though I myself do prefer the latter. However it should be noted that some game mechanics can only truely manifest themselves in the galactic conquest, such as blowing planets with the Death Star. The FoC expansion provides interesting additional faction and some additional units and abilities. 
What really keeps this game popular is the Republic at War fan-made addon (available in the workshop), which features clone war era factions (Republic clones and Separatist droids) with many interesting units and locations. A perfect way to make a game shine is to make it mod-friendly - something which modern era game makers tend to overlook...

One of my favorite classic games. The campaign is broken by an AI able to bend rules the player cant, allowing it to create massive fleets and ground attack forces almost instantly. When player is near winning, and the fog of war lifts from the whole map, the ai gets that advantage as well, allowing it to use bombing strafe against units and buildings it cannot see. Easy difficulty is rather slow, and extra easy, normal is ridiculously difficult simply from the bent rules giving the ai advantage, hard is unplayable past the first few missions. If they could do some better balancing, and improve pathfinding as well as attackmove, the game would be wonderful to play campaign.

Star Wars Empire at War can quite possibly be the best Star Wars RTS game or even Sci-Fi RTS game of all time and rightfully so. EAW brings about space and ground RTS in a very unique and pleasurable way. not only to Star Wars fans, but fans of RTS games. The game has a massive amount of units to command, great locations and maps to battle on, nice graphics (remember this is an old game) and beautiful music. Gameplay mechanics are very easy to understand and playing it is a joy. 

The main factions of EAW is the Rebellion and the Galactic Empire and another faction, the Zann Consortium, was added in the Forces of Corruption Expansion. You have command of many units from each faction such as your Stormtroopers, X-Wings, ATAT's and such but even some units from the expanded universe of Star Wars such as Tie Defenders and Dark Troopers. Alongside your main forces you have access to Heroes to join you on the field. The heroes are vast and very different from one another. You can have Darth Vader, Obi Wan, Luke and the Emperor, but also other heroes such as Tarkin, Piett and many more. Vehicle Heroes are what make the brute strength of your forces by having an enhanced ATAT or a Star Destroyer commanded by the best Admiral of the Empire or even have Red Squadron take on a multiple squadrons for Tie Fighters. 

The game has a great story which can be played from both sides and a very detailed galactic conquest campaigns which span from certain events in the Galactic Civil War such as the Outer rim, Hoth and the Rebel Uprising to complete domination of the Galaxy. Managing your forces and resources and which battalion should go where will make you feel like a real commander. There are also skirmish modes to create your own battles.

Music is great as it is Star Wars and the graphics are nice and clean, which is great considering how old this game is.The game has two areas of gameplay, On planet and Space. Each one is self explanatory with planet battles involving soldiers and vehicles and space battles involving star ships and capital ships.

But the area where I believe this game excels at is with the units and the amount of detail that was put into them. Soldiers have a cast amount of options and upgrades to them from training in the weather to weapon handling. Vehicles can be damaged and lose access to weapons and must be repaired. Star ships and Capital ships are the main attraction to detail. Each gun on a capital ship is seen and I mean EVERY GUN AND CANNON. You have missile launchers, proton torpedo launchers, concussion laucnhers, batteries, broadside cannons and such, each one firing and each one being able to be destroyed. Bridges, Shied Generators, hangers and such are part of each ship and have their own role to play. A Victory class Star Destroyer for example has around 20 hit points and critical areas which help the ship operate. Damaging its engines will slow it down and not allow it to retreat into hyperspace for example. A nice touch is that all major ships such as Star Destroyers and such have their own name so it adds a form of personality to each ship. 

The amount of lore in this game is just amazing. You will spend more time looking at the units that actually commanding them. If you are Star Wars fan you MUST get this and if you are a fan of RTS you MUST get this. 

Thanks to a great modding community, there are many mods for this game such as the Republic at war mod which converts the game to the clone wars where you can control the clones or the CIS. Mods which add more units and gameplay and better textures are always welcoming and make each playthrough a new and exciting one.

I figured since I had around 175 hours on this game I should be able to give a pretty fair and accurate review. I started playing this game way back in 2008 on the family IMac. Haven’t stopped playing it since haha. I purchased the steam version a few weeks ago after losing the product key for my physical disks. I love the workshop mods and I extremely recommend checking those out if you can! 
Let’s get down to the review though haha. 
This is by far one of the best RTS games I have ever played to date. The fact that it’s also a Star Wars game is a big bonus to me. The game and units are very well made and balanced during gameplay. I love the fact that it has a battle camera for a cinematic experience if you get bored and just want to sit back for a bit. Also love how you can select a unit and follow them via the camera as well (press C with selected unit). Honestly in terms of graphics the game has aged pretty well, you can also download mods that enhance the graphics as well. But I find playing the original very charming as well. 
And honestly for the price you can’t beat it considering that the free workshop mods can give you hundreds of additional hours of story and campaign as well as new units, maps, and planets to explore! This game is a must have for any RTS or Star Wars fan. It’s a pretty basic RTS so it’s definitely good if you’re new to the genre as well. 
Hope this helps!
Thanks

Seems to be an ongoing glitch where if you're in cinematic mode for over 15 minutes and switch back to tactical view, the mouse cursor wont show on the screen. EA and Disney take note; THIS is a Star Wars game done right.

Empire at war is a fun strategy game where you are a supreme commander for the Rebel Alliance, Galactic Empire or the Zann Consortium from the expansion pack Forces of Corruption. The main game mode is Galactic Conquest where the player will pick a conquest map and try to take over the galaxy, kill certain leaders or control key planets depending on the conquest. If I were to pick between the base game or the expansion pack I would pick the expansion pack due to the additions and tweaks to the gameplay that make it more fun. The most glaring flaw with the expansion pack is that the Zann Consortium is overpowered and that it is a crime faction, making it feel like playing Hearts of Iron with the Sicilian Mafia as a playable faction. In my opinion, the best thing about Empire at war is by far the modding community, which had me playing the game for hundreds of hours due to the excitement of looking at which new features, units and graphical improvements from the mods. My three favorite mods (In no particular order) are Thrawn's Revenge, Republic at War and Awakening of the Rebellion. Despite its age, Empire at war is still played due to the creative modding community and is still a game I would recommend buying especially during a Steam Sale.

I have dumped a lot of hours into this game, and I don't regret any of them. If you like RTS you will like this game. 
  
  The shining part of this game is the space battles and the mod support. 
      The core game play is playing as the Empire, Rebel Alliance, or the Zann consortium building your factions army and navy up all while you conquer/Liberate/or corrupt worlds to further your grip on the galaxy. To do this you build different structures on your planets, research or steal new technologies and fight alongside different characters throughout star wars lore. 
        
   Now For modding. 
        The modding community has made amazing strides to make the game better in every way. With mods like Thrawn's revenge that takes you to the days just after the battle of Endor, all the way to just before the Yuuzhan Vong War. 
        Then the Awakening of the Rebellion, a mod that completely reworks the game by adding new units, ships, updated graphics, and a complete rework of the Zann Consortium.
        The Republic at war or RAW for short thrust you right into the clone wars as you battle the droids or clones of that era.
        As well as Clone Wars  a similar mod to the last but following more closely to the TV show by the same name.

One of the only Star Wars RTS games and it doesn't disappoint, it may be showing it's age in some of the graphics now especially on the ground but it's still one of the most fun RTS games I've ever played and it has a huge range of high quality mods to keep you entertained after you complete the campaigns.

Very fun and classic Star Wars game. This game comes with the Forces of Corruption DLC, allowing you to choose between the original experience and the more hectic and diverse gameplay the DLC adds. You will also have access to various mods in the workshop, some of which completely change the game and allow you to experience various setups. Two great mods I recommend are Thrawn's Revenge and Awakening of the Rebellion, though I suggest getting used to the game first. 
My only complaints are some clunkiness and lack of polish in some spots, but the mods generally fix some of these things.

For a game that is quickly approaching 15 years old, I am still amazed at how fun it is to play. They don't quite make them like this anymore, do they?

Anyways, this is the single best Star Wars strategy game that I've ever played; there's something so satisfying about subjugating the galaxy to the Imperial rule with your own fleets and armies. 

The graphics leave a little bit to be desired, but this is just a small blemish on a objectively great game experience. Each faction has its own strengths and weaknesses, giving you the opportunity to strategize your attacks accordingly. 

I highly recommend grabbing this near-masterpiece! (especially when it's on sale around May 4th)

Empire at War, as well as Forces of Corruption, is a lot of fun to play - whether that is the Campaign or in Skirmish. Forces of Corruption adds another interesting faction to play as (the Zann Consortium), as well as new units for both land and space combat as the Empire or Rebellion. Playing in multiplayer is very fun in either of the two. Now that it has Workshop support, mods make the battles much more interesting by adding even more units, heroes, and reworking some of the in-game mechanics.

Notes:
 - Really enjoy the campaigns; if you've played Galactic Conquest on SW Battlefront II (2005), you'll notice some similarities.
 - When playing multiplayer matches with my friends, we do have issues sometimes, of someone's connection being lost randomly; I can't really say concretely if it was a bug in the game though.

Overall, 10/10. Any fan of Star Wars, or even RTSs, should check this game out.

This is one of my all time favourite games, and will likely remain so for a very long time. The main stories are well thought out with effective progression and logical plot points that leave little to no errors or question as to what events lead up to them.
The space battles are fantastic, with open options about how you want them to go. They can be quick some times (e.g. just charge everything you have at the enemy until they fall.) or can be drawn out and result in limited losses by use of sophisticated strategies  (easier in the FoC expansion). However, ground battles tend to be longer in the early game and very one sided in the late game due to the rebel speeders.
The modding community have really done this game a favour, by allowing a massive range of possibilities. Want to pit the old republic against the new republic, then the Yoden mod is perfect.
In my opinion, this is a must have for any star wars fan who enjoys strategy games.

"Hello, there!"

I will leave it to this game's store page to inform you about its details.  This review is more of an opinion/perspective - maybe a piece of the puzzle that will help you decide if you want to get the game.

Considering this game came out a number of years ago, I still find it quite enjoyable.  It's designed fairly well for the era of gaming it comes from.  The interface, learning curve, ability to play and RE-play the game is good.  It has a low level of complexity compared to current strategy games, so you can see this as a positive or negative.

Some of the downsides are:  (1) the "computer players" you face have inconsistent strategies (I wouldn't exactly call the computer-controlled factions "A.I." considering the year this was released) and they have the advantage of doing things rapidly because, well, it's all just executing variables, (2) controlling certain units can be problematic, both in the land and space battles - some follow commands better than others, (3) sometimes units do their own thing despite the instructions they are given.

Back to positive, this game has many of the Expanded Universe details incorporated into the game.  However, a person who doesn't like or understand "Star Wars" may not find the game as enjoyable.  Either way it really depends on whether or not you appreciate the "retro" aspects of the game - to each their own.

Empire at war makes me disappointed, because i know we are not currently getting anything quite like it.

In 2006 as it still is now in 2019, this game is a great romp in the star wars galaxy, play as the Empire or Rebellion (and with FoC the Consortium (pirates essentially)) and build ships, fight in space or on the ground and do your thing.

Now, for what 90% of the people that are considering playing this game these days want to know, are there mods? yes, yes, a lot of them; some of them magnificent.

Some top picks are Awakening of the Rebellion and Thrawn's Revenge: Imperial Civil war as well as the Remake mod that updates the base game to modern graphics among other changes.

Tl;Dr: Good Strategy Game, Space good, Mods good, land battles bad. 8/10

Star Wars is often a series where its video game renditions come in 2 flavors, terrible, or fantastic. On the terrible end of the 
spectrum you find games such as [i] Star Wars Kinect [/i] and [i] Star Wars: The Clone Wars: Republic Heroes [/i], while on the excellent end of the spectrum you tend to find games such as the original [i] Star Wars Battlefront 2 [/i] and the [i] Lego Star Wars [/i] series.

This game falls definitely on the good side of that spectrum.

[The Overall]
This is because Empire at War is very much an excellent strategy game, with its highlights primarily being in the space battles and the modding community which has been around forever.

[Strategy]
The overall grand strategy elements are relatively simple, take the planets until your opponents are gone, but where the game truly shines tends to be in its battles, where tactical minds and proper decision making can make or break a battle at higher difficulties. Space Battles are probably the greatest highlight to be seen in this game, as they are a marvel to both watch and command.

Land battles tend to be where this game catches the most flak, and the flak is well deserved unfortunately. You will usually find yourself slogged down against any opponent when you are playing a land battle, and it is very difficult, even for some mods, to make the land battles entertaining. There are also certain units which are particularly unbalanced in land combat (The Rebel artillery comes to mind) although they aren't 100% broken.

[Graphics]
This is a game made in 2005ish, and looks the part, however there are a multitude of mods on the workshop which usually have graphical improvements as part of it, otherwise if you're not looking to mod it's definitely going to look like an older game.

[Story]
The basegame is incredibly light on story, and the campaigns for both sides are usually just little missions between your conquering of enemy planets, however the FOC expansion is definitely heavier on story in its campaign, and actually offers a pretty decent campaign experience, with unique missions that you wouldn't see in the basegame campaigns.

[Balancing]
The base-game is relatively balanced, I have not heard any particular rumblings about it or found any overpowered units off the top of my head (The Rebel Artillery tends to wipe out units, even ones meant to counter it, relatively quickly but that's it) and every unit tends to have a counterpart on the other side, making both sides feel similar, but also different as each unit gets slight quirks.

The FOC expansion however, introduced the Consortium, which is nearly broken. In the grand campaign they can undergo missions to get useful benefits on the planet. (Turning the locals to their side, getting new units, making money off of killed units in battle) The Consortium units also tend to have a lot more powerful traits when the proper tech is stolen, with bombers that can disappear on radar, fighters launching anti-fighter/corvette buzz droids, a self destructing destroyer, and a ship which can literally just steal the shield off of another ship.

While fun to play as, there's a reason there are several mods to remove the Consortium from the FOC expansion.

[Fun Factor]
I have played this game way too much, and can confirm I very much enjoy it. If you're looking for more than just being a tactician the game is light on much else, but I did find using the Ewok Suicide-Bombers to be very much enjoyable.

[Modding Scene]
If you're looking to escape the Rebels Vs. Empire scene, or just want an expansion, you'll find many mods on the workshop to accommodate your tastes.

The big 2 you will want to look at are: [i] Thrawn's Revenge [/i] and [i] Republic at War [/i], the first takes place in the (now legends) Imperial Civil War, featuring hero permadeath, unique units and campaign requirements, and sometimes even fleets that will try to third-party you. The second sets the game in the Clone Wars and is known for being incredibly hard (Although I believe they've been attempting to balance that) even on easy difficulty.

A couple others I enjoy are [i] The Clone Wars [/i] and [i] Battlefront Commander [/i], The Clone Wars takes more inspiration from the 2008 TV Show, and is probably the best in terms of Land Combat, meanwhile Battlefront Commander is a bit of an amalgamation of different mods that both expands the vanilla game, and also introduces the Clone Wars.

It's up to you on how you want to play this game, modded or unmodded, but you'll definitely find that certain mods can really truly improve the game.

As of getting a new rig, and probably the newish updates to this game, it plays fine. So now I may review it in its entirety.

This game is rather like the original DOW or MOW games in that the vanilla game has some balancing issues. FOC's Zann Consortium is the worst offender of the factions. However, this is not an e-sport, so balance doesn't make or break the experience. I can testify that all factions are still a riot to play as despite the balance though. But the base game is not what gave me over 250 hours in this game.

There exists a HUGE library of mods for this game. Mods like Republic at War, Imperial Civil War, and Awakening of the Rebellion come to mind. These mods not only make the game more in-depth, with many more units for each faction and varied play styles, but also tend to give many new maps, bigger campaigns, and several improvements to gameplay and balance. There also exist mods like 1 credit 1 second for those who just want to show up the filthy rebels' doorstep with 12 Executor SSDs and a Death Star. This modding community is still very vibrant and looks to remain so for quite a while.

So pick this up if you want a good mix of grand strategy and rts or you want to play some Star Wars games from the golden age of the time before EA ruined the landscape.

A simple RTS within the Star Wars Universe. WIth or without the Forces of the Corruption expansion, this game is awesome.

That being said, this game is not without its flaws. It's fairly dated compared to PC RTSs today. 

Campaigns:
-Rebellion: Great, with their Raid ability. Testing one's capability to work with little to take a lot.
-Empire: Awesome. PURELY. MASSIVE. ARMIES. (And fleets). PERIOD.
-Zann Consortium: Interesting, as it puts a spin on the typical 'command & conquer' style. Utilizing unique tech and abilities to make up for the more expensive units.

Multiplayer:
-If you can find another willing play, great. Though, I hear the Consortium is overpowered in multiplayer. ;)

Overall, I give this game a 9/10. Dated, but still enjoyable to new and experienced RTS players, plus.... it's Star Wars, before the Disney/EA catastrophe.

If you've played a Total War Game, this is basically that except for Star Wars.

Now personally I never watched/read any of the star wars media so I know very little about the universe. However, I have always been intruigued by the military history of the Star Wars universe, more specifically the Imperial war machines. I picked up this game with the hopes of seeing some of these machines in action thinking it was an FPS similar to Battlefront 2. To my surprise it was a total-war-esque turn based strategy game. I hopped on the Imperial side and started churning out soldiers and vehicles of war, every time I saw a new unit I googled it to get more information and lore on the thing. Aside from it showing you what various machines are used in the series - from the obscure to the common - it's also a very fun strategy game. You must manage the nation's internal struggles such as the economy and architectural management, aswell as have a formidible army and fleet. You gotta also plan ahead when you attack, because if your fleet gets decimated carrying a large army sent to attack a planet, then not only did you lose a large amount of troops and ships, but it will be a major setback in your future conquests and it leaves the planet the troops originated from wide open to conquest, giving the enemy a vital upper hand. It's a strategy game at it's finest, packed with interesting units and fun gameplay. Would definitely recommend.

One of my favorite games of all time. Back in 2008, I think, I got my hands on a CD containing the game prior to obtaining the steam version, and I played it for a really really long time.
While I personally favor the standard EaW without the FOC-Expansion, I must say that it's pretty much obligatory to buy the DLC - just because of the amount of fantastic mods one gets access to (shoutout to Republic At War).

SW:EAW(FOC) provides you with countless hours of game experience. Wether you want to hone the perfect ground based assault tactics, conquer the entire galaxy in a massive campaign or, simply, just want to experience some good 'ol Star Wars vibes, this game is my go-to for it.
The basis, EAW, is rock-solid, straightforward and very immersive. While other strategy games definitely add more to it with mechanics like harvesting special resources, obtaining diplomatic relationships, customizable units etc. and very well do many aspects even better, to me, SW:EAW sticks out because within it's borders, it allows you a lot of freedom to play around. 

Your primary objective is to get credits by any means necessary, in order to allow you to reinforce your army. Secondly, you are required to expand across the galaxy due to a max. population threshold. In the early stages of a campaign, this measure always creates a certain tension; you never know if your decision to unlock a certain unit, your assault on this specific planet and so on might just bite you in your butt a couple of minutes later.
The different properties of every planet are done in a simple, but, to me, great way.
The battles themselves are fun. Plain and simple. While I do think that in the original, some things might be a bit unbalanced (empire: 1 AT-AT for heavy firepower, 1 AT-AA as anti-air/rocket, SPM-Ats for Anti-Infantry and anything else for suppressive fire/advancing is the meta strategy I came up with to ensure victory in pretty much any cenario), there are still many options for the other fraction to retaliate and even push back your seemingly perfect assault/defense. 

The expansion pack, however, adds enough content that I would pretty much regard it as it's own game.
Honestly, I did not mess around with FOC as much as EAW (since on my original CD, the FOC-Expansion was corrupted, sadly), but it manages to add just the right amount of complexity (corruption, different means of gaining resources, a wonderfully creative concept of expanding your influence across the galaxy via requiring you at several occasions to complete mini-missions) which the original was lacking to make it better in any way - even if it's not as straightforward any longer.
The new units, campagnes and systems are brilliant. Even though the imbalance continues in the DLC (looking at your spaceships, Zann-Empire), personally, I think it's more than manageable - especially if you like a challenge from time to time.



All in all I have to say: I'm not a fan of strategy games, never was, probably never will be. But SW:EAW(FOC) is the exception to the rule. 
I definitely recommend buying, at any price given. Even without the workshops' mods to FOC, it is worth every penny and I never regretted buying. It was a long ride and I'm happy to continue it for even more years.

Awesome game, I used to have this on CD before I got steam, but I would say I've spent at least 500 hours on this game, over a period of 7-8 years. The Game has a lot to offer and I find it incredible that despite being made a fair while ago it still holds up today as a great game.  It's an easy game to understand, it was my first PC game and I never had trouble understanding how to play. I love being the Empire and crushing filthy rebels with my fleet of Star Destroyers, and when that doesn't work, when there's dirt you just can't quite get, there is always the Death Star to help you get those hard to reach places. The multiplayer has been down for a while now but by downloading something like Game Ranger which is what I use, you can still play online. I know there's modding for the game but it's not very clear how to properly install it and I've never gotten it to work. There's a fun campaign for both rebels and empire and also just good old galactic conquest maps and skirmish modes where you can completely decide how you play.

This game still holds up today more than 13 years after launch. It has an engaging campaign and when you're tired of playing through that you can engage in a long drawn out conquest of the entire galaxy or just a quick game trying to take out a small corner of it. Then there is my favorite mode, skirmish mode. It offers infinite replays when you throw in the fact that there are tons of mods available. And it even has multiplayer games, but that was never what I was interested in. If you like RTS games this is sure to please you. If you are a big star wars geek like me, this will satisfy your lore requirements. And there are even mods out there that change the theme entirely into other Sci-Fi worlds too. It's worth buying this game. You will certainly get your moneys worth out of it. I spent thousands of hours playing it when it first came out, and I foresee many thousands more now that I can play it again.

Pros
-Control massive armies of iconic Star Wars units and wreck havoc on enemies
-Galactic Conquest modes provide every strategy fan's need, from unit management to planetary priority.
-Instant Action battles allow you to jump into single battles with up to 8 AI's on 3 different factions
-Vast Modding Community offers a millions of ways to spice up the game, from new maps to new units to entire gameplay overhauls.
-Includes Empire at War, with it's two campaigns that offer a brand new insight into the A New Hope era, and Forces of Corruption which brings in a brand new faction and a brand new campaign that expands the Star Wars universe in ways not often done before.

Cons
-Low Multiplayer community means you'll be stuck against AI most of the time
-Is not quite optimized for stronger hardware, and thus FPS lag and crashes can be frequent.
-Despite vast options to build armies, the old fashion spamming big things usually ends up winning.
-Zann Consorption is significantly overtuned, especially in Galactic Conquest
Very solid rts especially if your into Star Wars

Wonderful game. These types of games aren't my thing, considering that I prefer to be upfront, rather than strategic, and having to heavily micromanage, but this game totally changed all that.

I actively look forward to playing this game often. I realize that I'm not super incredible at it, but when I complete a battle(especially a land battle, considering I'm so shit at them,)  I get really happy, and keep attempting to play more and more.

Losing a planet or battle too, though it can be demoralizing during certain cases, is not that problematic. As you play more, you realize that you can always gain this planet back, and perhaps its best to move your forces elsewhere and find a new strategy in order to defeat the Empire or Zann factions.

Mods are also amazing. Mods like Republic at War and Thrawn's Revenge are amazing, and give us new ways to look at the game, and how to play. I enjoy a game of the mod "Awakening of the Rebellion" as I have to play more tactically and think harder, which as a mod like "Thrawn's Revenge" lets me relax for a little bit, and screw around. 

I highly recommend this game and its DLC, though an old game with problems, its still really amazing, and recommended for all players, regardless of whether your good at these types of games or not.

Classic Star Wars game that has great gameplay and great story line/campaign and has that classic Star Wars feeling. Empire at War itself is amazing but with the Forces of Corruption DLC included, it almost feels like an entire new game by adding in 1 new faction, the Zann Consortium and also adding in different game elements and so on. Overall, the gameplay is excellent, the space battles are amazing but ground battles seem to be a bit basic due to a very limited pop cap and the variety of units. Other than that, Empire at War is a must get for its gameplay, an excellent modding community and basically any computer can run this 13 year old game. Getting mods that change the game completely (such as overhaul mods) make the game feel entirely different.

Yet another pearl in the once mighty crown that was LucasArts, which now lies broken and shattered. It saddens me to see how Star Wars games were once THE standard, they were innovative, interesting, bold, charming. Games like Knights of the Old Republic, Republic Commando, Roque Squadron, the Battlefront series - the Empire at War series. Those games (and many others) are what so many of us had our childhoods built on.

Like a few other SW games, I first played Empire at War thanks to the "Best of PC" collection. As a huge fan of strategy games (Age of Empires, Civilization, Warcraft, Battle for Middle-Earth, Crusader Kings, etc), I was so excited to get the chance to play this game. It did not disappoint. With truly captivating (even to this day) graphics, amazing space battles were every choice you make can determine the outcome of the battle itself, and some pretty gruesome land battles - Empire at War takes the cake as the best Star Wars strategy game out there (sorry Battlegrounds).

I'd encourage everyone to play this game. The FOC expansion was a neat little addition (for me, mainly for the Empire units and Yoda). There are some great mods for this game out there, my favourite being Republic at War (using it to this day).

I've been playing this game for over 10 years now on and off. Most of my time was back on the old discs.  Now that Steam has it combined with the still surprisingly active community of modders, the game continues to breath new life.  The distinctly different ways you have to play for fleet combat, ground combat and the overall empire management on the overworld map all comes together for a fun experience. Definitely worth while, especially if you can pick it up on a sale.

Awesome old game. I'm not sure if it should still be 20$; but, it does go on sale during seasonal sales. There's a large scale galaxy mode (similar to Total War but in space) and just skirmish modes as well. The base factions are balanced (Force of Corruption introduces a new faction that is a bit more op). There's a awesome cinematic camera mode for space battles. A lot of the time once you reach a certain level of firepower you can sit back and watch your fleet just decimate. The mods add a lot to the game, especially as it doesn't receive updates actively. I play a mod to make the game set in the Clone Wars and it just makes the game for me.
Absolutely Beautiful game use to play so much on disc back in the day, This is my favourite RTS game and always will be love this so much i hope you guys can enjoy it as much as i do.

When I first played this game I was a young lad. I was 'garbage' at it however, as the kids these days say. I actually had the CD copy of it. I always found one thing weird about it. Whenever I played it long enough, or tried to boot up the expansion Forces of Corruption, my computer went black and had to be hard rebooted. This was most frustrating. 
I gave the game a rest for a few years however and got back into it a few years ago. So I wanted to try it again now that it was on steam and had multiplayer, but was nervous to try it on a computer of my own. In case the black screen glitch came back again. But I did it, and it worked!
I wondered if it had something to do with the CD copy I owned so I went on the search for it. And one day while searching through my room, I found it! It took some hard work, but I did find it! 
Now it was a pain in the butt to install, between the two separate disks needed for the base game and expansion, but the access codes were the most annoying part. The weird thing however, when I put in the code for the expansion pack, I didn't notice at first or when I was younger was when you enter it in, Jabba the Hutt appears on screen being choked to death by a princess Leia 3D model. This was really weird and not what I was expecting upon entering this game, but I brushed it off. I was far too excited to get caught up in a weird image. George Lucas was a weird guy anyway so I figured he was putting it in as a joke. 
That's when I got hit with so much nostalgia it made me have to pee! I went to the bathroom and was excited to get back to the game, which had loaded in. All I missed was seeing the iconic Petroglyph logo pass by and LucasArts appear as the menu faded in. I was hit with a sweet yellow HUD and a sick rock beat that made me very excited to play the game! So I tried to jump into a match right away. 
When loading it up, I had three team options for skirmish and over a dozen maps, 6 maps for Galactic Conquest, and a unique story mode! So in order to better learn how the game worked, I wanted to try campaign. So I loaded it up and heard a booming voice yell "Everyone, has a price." 
I started off in a prison yard, with the story's pirate hero locked in a cell. No, not Watto or Jabba, but this white haired fellow named Tyber Zann. He was planning a breakout and a bounty hunter was on his way to end his life sent by none other than Jabba himself, but something happened when the hunter arrived. He was a completely naked sprite. This was weird thing to me as the hunter sounded like he was wearing a helmet with a robotic voice, but was just a naked human with very defined features I didn't know were available for 2006 games. It was nice however that I couldn't see anything gross and the hunter wasn't on screen for long. 
After this the game really took off. I got to conquer planets with my fleets and had a string of victories over weaker worlds owned by the crimelord Jabba. After taking him out of the picture and taking over his droid factories, I was moving onto the Empire. Which was odd to me as the Empire was being abnormally quiet to this growing threat. But I did weird find a glitch or an easter egg on the planet Yavin 4 on the land where I was battling on land and the Empire landed and I could see the Death Star 1 in orbit above the planet, but in space it had already been destroyed. It made the mission more challenging, but it was a fun time still facing the Empire and Rebellion in the same battle, something I'd never done before. And seeing them interact was entertaining. 
Back into space, Batropia, a planet I'd never heard of was the location of the next mission. The mission made me feel uncomfortable, we had to kidnap Princess Leia and hold her for ransom. Now I didn't mind the other missions involving slavery or whatnot as it is just random characters and a video game about Star Wars and messed up things happen often here, but why Princess Leia? We had never taken action against the Rebellion previously either. So this was my first battle against the canon protagonists. 
On the planet I found a burnt down forest. And a big rebel base atop it. With dead bears, animals and other animals I hadn't previously seen in any star wars stories or movies. This was also a side of the rebels I hadn't seen before. They were burning the forest and animals alive. All being overseen by the woman I was there to collect, Princess Leia. She was standing atop a float laughing as she watched the wildlife burn. This instantly made my mission make sense. She had to be stopped. We were the good guys in this story. The Rebellion were monsters. I was going to end this planet's suffering. 
I sent in IG-88 first to lay found some fire and cover my larger slower ships as they landed. But instead of IG88 being landed, it was a C3PO model. This was weird as it had IG88's voice, but that was it. There was no R2D2 or anything. Just a gold C3PO droid model. 
I was shaken by this as he had no gun and was quickly killed by the rebellion forces already closing on my landing site. So I tried bringing out Bossk, who again, was not himself. He was instead a womprat. 
"What the hell...." I thought as I paused the game to collect my thoughts.
This game has to be broken or messing with me. Maybe my mind is messing with me. So I unpaused the game and saw the battle was apparently still going on even with me pressing pause! My base was burnt to the ground and the rebels were moving all over my landing zone and Leia was laughing as she pointed to me calling me a failure!
What the heck was going on here?!
So Tyber told me, "we failed, but we will get her on her next route." But as I looked back to the map, the entire planet I was previously on had imploded and turned to a floating cloud of dust on the galactic map. This was insane! They had burnt the planet to a crisp! But why?! That's when I saw the rebellion heading to their home base on Hoth, which had appeared on the map as a Fire Planet, such as Mustafar or Sullust. I was staying as far away as possible from that place. God knows how Hellish that landscape had to be for these sick and twisted Rebels to be here. 
Instead I moved onto the Empire as my target, but the planets on the map had seemingly disappeared.... What the... all that was left was Coruscant and Hoth, then Ryloth, my home base. The other 40 or so planets had all vanished! How could I complete this game when the map kept changing. And my only mission in the log now was "Kill the Emperor."
This was so confusing. Why had it skipped so many steps and done what seems to be an end game mission. But I wanted to beat it and have bragging rights over my friends to say I beat the disk copy of this legendary game so I went on and made a fleet to invade Coruscant. When I got there, there was no space fleet. Where was Piett? Thrawn? Boba Fett? Hell, where was the Death Star 2?! There was nothing at all above it. And on land, with the help of corrupting the local militia, I could only see the emperor alone on the planet. No buildings, no units, just Palpatine. So I invaded. 

To Be Continued....

Introduced to it via a handful of YouTube videos, my initial impression of it was one of equal parts mild interest and underwhelming appearance.

My initial impression could scarcely have been more wrong!
Upon buying the game, and installing a mod or 2, I found myself spending countless hours completely engrossed by it.
Granted the vanilla game, (and Forces of Corruption expansion) while still very playable and enjoyable, DOES leave a lot to be desired... 
But the Empire at War modding community is as robust as it is amazing! With dozens of mods to choose from.. it's a game that has near infinite replay value.
There are simple empire/game tweak mods, as well as full conversion mods that make it feel like an entirely different game.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO ANYONE WHO LIKES/LOVES RTS GAMES, AND/OR STAR WARS!

Ok, I have put enough time into this game to give it a review that I think is pretty fair.

I have like 140 ish hours on here I probably spent 40 on vanilla, 70 On Thrawn's revenge, 20 on Republic at War, and 10 hours on AoTR and TCW mods. 

Vanilla is an experience, play it to learn the game but after beating the campaign or playing some galactic conquest try modding.

Thrawn's Revenge fixes my problems with the game and then some. The mod has no campaign but a 20 something year galactic conquest where you can play as many different Imperial warlord groups, the New Republic, The Empire, and The Hand of Thrawn. Ships are re-balanced, given more guns or fighter bays etc. Ground combat gets a lot of crap for being boring but this mod gives it some life. Getting to use multiple new units like Jedi Knights, many new vehicles and whatever the Hand of Thrawn gets makes teh ground combat ok.
I really think of this mod as a fixed version of EAW's issues, and it is from the New Republic era which is my favorite, so getting to use Wedge in the  [i]Lusankya[/i] or Luke Skywalker and Mara Jade as ground units is really fun.

There is sooo much I need to say, so buy this game, download a mod for whatever Era you like, play it and have a good time!

Edit: I also put 100 hours on this game in like 2 weeks

Star Wars Empire at War isn't just an RTS game with the Star Wars name slapped on it. It truly is ambitous in what it sets out to do but unfortunately it doesn't quite excell at everything it does but it is a great game overall. 

The games core structure isn't played mission by mission on isolated maps like in most RTS campaigns. Instead you take over planets by either epic space battles or not so epic land battles via a huge conquest map filled with planets. 

This large scale map is very similiar to what's in Civilization or Total War games but in this case, when you make decisions on the map, like reinforcing units and building stuff, it all takes place in Real-time just like the battles so it adds a layer of tension not present in the standard TBS style Conquest "Risk" style maps seen in those other two games. You can be attacked at any time when building stuff.

In regards to how the space and land battles flow from this design, it dramatically changes the flow of gameplay that most people are used in RTS's. For instance, whatever land forces you have when you invade another planet that you got by building on planets that you already have conquered is what you will have for that invasion - there's no reinforcements or building more units on that planet's map after you invade.

 So you'll be limited to what you chose to invade with which adds a lot of tension and focus on more tactical play for ground invasions. You cannot just queue up more units from structures on the ground because you have limited resources to work with when you actually assault another planet in order to conquer it whether it's by space or by land. 

When getting to how both space and land battles work in tandem, if a planet has a space fleet of any kind or size guarding it (virtually all planets do), you'll first have to destroy the space fleet otherwise they'll just destroy all of your troop transports carrying your land forces before they land. 

it's a very dynamic element that still hasn't been seen in any modern RTS. 

When it comes to talking about the actual execution of both types of battles, space and land, one is more enjoyable than the other without a doubt. 

While both types of battles are balanced to a great degree, Space battles are more fun to play. They are a spectacle to watch and the gameplay is smooth.

Land battles are janky and not as responsive in comparison to the better executed Space battle.

Despite the fact that you get to see pretty cool hero Units like Darth Vader, Luke Skywalker on the ground duking it out with other well modeled star wars characters and units that we all love, the responsiveness, handling, and just overal feel of combat leaves a lot to be desired. Combat lacks the same punch and impact that the space battles offer and I feel that the units in space battles respond a lot faster to my commands. That's not to say that Land battles are incredibly laggy: they aren't. It's just that they lack the scope and overall polish that space battles do. 

Overall, Star Wars Empire at War has aged rather well, because with the exception of Homeworld Shipbreakers, there has been a drought of good RTS games and if you're looking for a good solo RTS experience, then this game will most likely satisfy you. 

+ Space Battles
+ Galactic Conquest Risk-like Map
+ It's Star Wars
+ Dynamic Flow of Engagement and Battle Structure

- Land Battles need more polishing

Overall I give it an 8.

I love this game because when I was a kid I loved Rebellion (possibly called Supremacy in your region). Not a lot of people shared that opinion but Rebellion did have its fans and there are dozens of us. Dozens!
This is something of a spiritual successor to Rebellion. 
It is not Rebellion. 
There's planetary base building, but that's more just wait for money, wait for build time and then build the next level thing. 
There's a ground based RTS component which I'm pretty sure is just a straight up port of the doomed Star Wars: Force Commander and isn't particularly fun to play. (Especially because the Rebels can pull some straight up bull shit)
But the space RTS. Praise the Maker! It is exquisite. A true delight. The only flaw in Rebellion was the space combat simulator - if someone could put these two things together then you can have all my money. 

The Forces at War expansion adds a lot of fun stuff (like the Executor) but also adds a third faction, The Zann Consortium who are ridiculously overpowered to the point of breaking the game. 

So why am I giving this a positive review? Well because of the space combat for one thing, because I want to see a reboot of Rebellion for another. But worth mentioning is the mod scene for this game. The mods are incredible. Some of them are the equivalent of what War of the Chosen did for X-Com 2. Some of them make it an entirely different game. If the basic premise of Empire at War felt good but you hated the execution (ie me) then there exists a mod which will tickle your fancy. 

PS - remake Rebellion.

I can succesfully say in 1 hour, This is the only strategy game I have 0 clue what im doing. I know the bare, bones, basic controls but theres no "A-move" you have to manually click attack move, then right click. Even then your fleet of ships is inevidibly dead. This doesnt make it a bad game, but I have 0 clue of the controls explaind to me. I will say, for 2006, this looks excellent. 

However, I will give the controls a pass. This isnt your standard Relic RTS, the controls are a bit different and thats my issue. I cant transition into this game like any other RTS with knowlege of what im doing, then learn the armor types, weapon types, etc. Its just "ah yes you press a button and hope for the best" Playing medium AI on Galactic Conquest just yeilds more questions of whats going on. The AI will ram into your bases with a stack of ships whilst you think about "wat do" because you dont know what to do. After 1 hour though I've learned the basic amount of controls to say, succesfully, this game? I dont quite like the ground combat. You call down units from reinforcement points. That's it. Neat but. Still weird. The space combat was neat but it was "whoever presses the power up button the most wins" and most the time the AI slamming my ships with stacks, knowing full well what it was doing, crippled my production. 1 minor slip up, sent me back to the main menu to restart galactic conquest again. Again. Its not a bad game. I full well enjoyed everything in it. But its a very, basic, and entangled RTS. the controls are way different than any other RTS, and I came away still barely knowing what to do. I will revist this game another rainy day and attempt galactic conquest again. And no, Easy AI is for Panzys.

oh and as for game modes you have Skirmish, which pits your pre-built base against the AI's pre-built base. I didnt bother to go further than that. And then you have, ehm. Galactic Conquest. In which you hold, and attack sectors. I was too confused to go forward to learn how to attack more planets, or defend mine better so I just super stacked the standard Imperial Frigate, then swarmed the AI with the frigates ability to increase damage on its main attack, and millions of teensy TIE fighters. I can imagine with a friend this game would be fun. And seeing as its last update according to the console was 2017, and I saw internet games, Im going to go on a limb and say this is a passion project. Maybe not super passion. But the devs still somewhat care about it enough to make it work in 2017.

Also; also. I only have 1 hour in playtime in this. So please take my word with a grain of salt.

[list]
[*]Visuals were amazing at the time and are serviceable by today's standards. 
[*]The RTS components are on three levels. On the galactic scale, you manage the economy, unit construction, and positioning fleets and armies in a real-time environment. Planets have bonuses and strategic bonuses (and their locations). Then there are space battles and land battles. 
[*]There are story campaigns for the Empire, Rebellion, and a third faction in the expansion, known as the Consortium (space pirates).
[*]Instant action allows you to just battle in space or on land, as you destroy the opponent's base or space station. 
[*]In galactic conquest, there is more strategy involved, but it remains accessible. For instance, having bombers over a planet allows you do perform bombing runs in the land battle. There are different maps with different objectives and rules.
[*]There is a focus on macro-management. You command groups of units, rather than individual soliders or tanks. This makes the battles much easier to keep track of and unit stacks much easier to manage on the galactic map. 
[*]You don't have to gather specific resources, unlike other RTS games of its day. Instead you just use credits, which are awarded in many ways. Simple. 
[*]Instead of just targeting an enemy battleship, you can target specific components on the ship itself for a more tactical approach. Knocking out heavier guns or the shield generator first will turn the tide of battles. It also insures no one can just build large amounts of a single type of unit. Everything has a counter and it is all well-balanced. 
[*]Good unit variety without being stale, and without going overboard with too much (unlike Total War).
[*]Good learning curve.
[*]Great mod and community support. 
[/list]

Cons
[list] 
[*]The A.I. is not very good. The only thing the difficulty changes is how fast they get money and how many units they throw at you. On the galactic scale, the A.I. is pretty bad, while in space and on land, the A.I. has better performance. Overall most fun will be had against other players via LAN or online. 
[*]There are more units and weapons in this game than meet the eye, but you have to dive into the XML files to unlock the units that are already in the game. Things like Venator Star Destroyers, V-Wings, hidden additional weapons on various units that are deliberately turned off, etc are already there but were hidden away. 
[*]For people who are devoted to canon, many ships have fewer weapons than they should have, and this is probably because of system limitations and balance. 
[/list]

Star Wars: Empire at War has a much more dynamic rhythm than standard RTS. Its map is focused on conquering planets, blending interesting battles in space and battles within the planets. The speed of this game is very fast, the structure is simpler, due to the fact that you do not need to collect separate resources to create your units, just build the correct building and it automatically generates credits. The three campaigns (Rebel, Empire, and Zann) show the point of view of these two sides of the war (to Rebel and Empire) at a time between Episode III and Episode IV. Zann's campaign is the coolest of the three, the corruption option is very interesting, the story itself is something new and the missions a lot more fun. The whole story is a war story, so the game having been thought of with the full focus on the battles makes perfect sense with what it sets out in both gameplay and script. A recommended for anyone who likes RTS and wants to play something fast and focused on battle.

A Star Wars game from a time before Star Wars was a joke of an IP. Before the dark times. Before Disney-LucasFilm. This game's campaigns tell the story of how the Death Star plans were acquired better than Rogue Wan ever could lmao.

This is prolly my favourite Star Wars game ever. I remember coming home from Middle School back when this game was new and hopping on the computer to play with my friends at school in multiplayer stuff. Either killing eachother or killing the AI. It was good times.

Booted this game up again and it's still just as good 12 years later. I'm someone who really appreciated Star Wars' EU, and some of the vehicles and ships in this game turned out to be some of my favourite pieces of equipment in Star Wars (SPMAT's, Assault Frigate Mark II, The Eclipse, etc). The campaigns are great, dicking around with friends is great, and the game itself plays like butter. It's smooth, easy to learn, extremely interesting and rewarding to succeed in, and at times hilarious to fail in. 

To this day it's still my favourite RTS, even beating out classics like Age of Empires II. And hell some of the mods people have made for this game truly show how creative Star Wars fans can be, as well as their understanding of the Star Wars universe. 

Great game from a much better time. We'll never get memorable classic titles like this for Star Wars ever again. Thankfully it'll always be here for us to enjoy, where Disney-Lucasfilm can't touch it.

Hello! I have played this game alot and have enjoyed it severly! But that won't get you to buy it, will it cause everyone has their own tastes! 

Pros-
Long gameplay, a single galactic conquest could take a couple days with breaks in between.
Multiplayer, since the shutdown of gamespy it's been difficult to play multiplayer but with programs like gameranger you still can and it is VERY enjoyable.
Battles, the battles are VERY fun but can sometimes get repetitive but thanks to the still active modding community and the DLC, this problem is solved.
The tactics and strategy aspect, I, personally, am in LOVE with strategy and tactics and this game is full of it. A corvette cant beat a star destroyer head on but put that corvette in a ambush like position and it might stand a chance!
Star Wars, must I really explain this part?
The unpaid DLC, the DLC is very enjoyable with new units and a new side. Insteading of running around with stormtroopers why not run around with stormtroopers AND giant robots!

Cons
Repeat, this game can get very boring since the gameplay is limited to half a dozen land and space units on each side so it gets boring. But thanks to modding and the DLC it can be fixed.
Modding on steam, its a bit annoying when installing mods on steam because you have to download the mod and find the steam folder and install it there them mess around the launch options. The community(including myself) has been BEGGING for a workshop integration for the game but there has been no luck...
The campaigns,The campaigns are a bit frustrating and boring and the story is trippy.
Unit size, the units are not realistic with its actual canon size. Boba Fett is half as large as an AT-ST, no matter how awesome you think he is.


However the cons are solvable with modding and the game itself is VERY  fun! I definitly recomend this to star wars fans and RTS fans!

One of many great Star Wars games, this game allows you to play the two famous factions in Star Wars, along with one extra in the expansion pack. Battles can be fought either on the planets themselves or in space, and you control many units iconic to the universe. Each faction also have their own way of playing, both on the campaign map and in the battles themselves.

This is definitely a must if you are fond of Star Wars, RTS games or both.

Star Wars: Empire at War is a strategic star wars game that let's you control the forces of either the Empire or the Rebels inside of the star wars galaxy, wielding iconic units, heroes and fighting in both space and land on iconic planets.

The game itself is fun if you like strategy games and I myself have had a lot of fun playing through both of their campaigns. Multiplayer was also added during May so you and your friends can easily make colossal space or lands battles, duking it out and just having a good time.
If you're like me and have no friends(or you only have one that also owns the game) you can launch up a galactic battle against each other, assuming you have the time.

The expansion that follows in this purchase brings in a new faction, new units, a new campaign and a new way of playing through the galaxy.

The new faction represents a criminal faction by the name of the Zann Connsortium. They got their own units and they corrupt the galaxy from piracy, kidnapping and other criminal acts.
Fun!

The game is extremely fun with friends, alone or using one of the many mods that the lovely community keeps on pushing out. Some great, some bad. I'd suggest you check it out.

Star Wars: Empire at War is a real-time strategy game from Petroglyph and published by LucasArts, the best strategy game in Star Wars franchise. Gold Pack also include the expansion pack Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption in one package.

Star Wars: Empire at War takes place before and to the event of Episode IV, to the Battle of Yavin, while the expansion pack, Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption follows the underworld faction Tyber Zann with the Zann Consortium. Of course this is an expanded universe story, now called Star Wars Legends.

Star Wars: Empire at War gameplay is more like map conquest called galaxy conquest since this is the Star Wars galaxy, you start on a galactic map, establishes bases on planets like Coruscant, Tatooine or Naboo, build up armies and galactic fleet, then engage in space or ground battles on map in real epic battles. You get to command the Star Destroyer fleet with the Galactic Empire or squadrons of X-wing with the Rebel Alliance. This game can entertain you for many hours.

While Star Wars: Empire at War has great gameplay, the graphics are somewhat, inadequate for me. Kind of like, ugly, but at least has some detail. The effect are not that great too, except for the Death Star. The performance are great nevertheless.

The one of many greatest thing about this game is that there are many mods out there making this game even more interesting and fun, like Republic at War or Thrawn Revenge, try them.

The downside of this game is with the expansion pack, Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption, it still have many minor bugs that left unfixed. Although the bugs won't hinder your gameplay at all, but it is somewhat annoying.

Very addicting game Star Wars: Empire at War is for strategy fans, you get to fight twice to capture a planet, a space battle and planetary battle. I recommend this.

I don't really write a lot of reviews, but Star Wars: Empire at War is too good to pass up. If you have ever wanted to destroy the galaxy, save the galaxy, or corrupt the galaxy, then this is the game for you. 

Battles in Empire at War are anything but boring (with the exception of land battles, which can be dull at times, however, spamming a planet with troops and using auto-complete fixes the problem). Ships are mostly equal, and while battles are not exactly strategic (in my case), I think they are a star-destroyer load of fun!

Galactic conquest adds a new layer to the game. The varying factories and barracks you can build makes sure you have a tough time beating the rebels, empire, or both. The short skirmishes are somewhat easy, but multiplayer saves the day. I have never won a game of multiplayer skirmish.

Mods add yet another layer to the game. Developers are always attempting to make Empire at War look like a modern game, and mods like Thrawn's Revenge and the Clone Wars mod make sure you never run out of content. I personally check Mod Db every day for updates to the Empire at War Remake mod (looks awesome so far!)

The Empire at War community is always friendly to a new conqueror, and will solve any issue you have :).

Simply stated, 

GET THIS GAME!
If you're looking for a long, enduring battle then this is the game for you. However this game shines in the modding department which will vastly improve you experience

At the moment, I believe this is the best Star Wars strategy game out there. Although there is ground combat, the space combat is where this game shines the brightest. The mechanics at its core are simple and balanced. Most rebel fleets won't win a direct fight against an imperial one, but the rebels have their own little advantages, such as better fighters and faster ships, that a good player can use to win. 
So that's the base game.
After that, you have an amazing amount of mods that not only update, balance and improve the games mechanics, but even add in new eras and updates the game's models. Thrawns Revenge, Republic at War, Awakening of the Rebellion, Ultimate Commander, and the Enhanced Campaign Mod are a few of the best mods out there. Each mods plays and feels so differently they're essentially their own game. If you like RTS games and love Star Wars, this game is a must have.

If you are a Star Wars fan and/or an RTS fan buy this game. This game and its dlc fufills the power trip of taking over the Star Wars galaxy as the classic factions (The rebel alliance and The Empire). The combat itself is split into to halves, space and ground battles. Space battles are what you'd fully expect from the Star Wars universe, X-Wings, Tie-fighters, Corellian Corvettes, Star Destroyers and the Death Star, the best thing is it's all well balanced. Ground battles are slighlty weaker and overall less refined mechanics but overall still a fufilling component of the game. 

The game has aged quite significantly although the core gameplay mechanics stil hold up well today and is virtually bug free. Replayability is encouraged through the use of different factions and different galactic conquest scenarios. Whilst not the most complex strategy game, its core gameplay elements do contain depth and are satisfying to master. 

I couldn't write this review without mentioning the additional lifespan and perigrination offered by a wide variety of overhaul mods, which I've had the pleasure of seeing develop over the years. They cater to all tastes; 
Do you want accurate ship representation, a much deeper economic and battle system? Try Pheonix Rising or Awakening of the Rebellion.
Do you want to play as the Clone Wars factions? Try 'The Clone Wars' or Republic at War.
Do you want crazy? Try ZeroXs mod or Yoden mod
Do you want a legends accurate post-Endor until the Caasmas Crisis galactic conquest scenario, with fully playable Imperial Warlord Factions including the Empire of the Hand? Do you want a comprehensive reskin of the UI, FX, unit models and the galactic map? Try Thrawns Revenge and get addicted to bringing a super star destroyer out of hyperspace right next to an enemy fleet and watching it decimate it. It's literally worth buying the gold pack just to experience this mod and thats no understatement.
Best star wars strategy game ive found. Theres also lots of quality mods to modernize it, updating graphics and adding units and whatnot, but even the base game is solid. Highly recomend

Star Wars Empire at War and Forces of Corruption are two legendary edition to the Star Wars mythos, with modders trying to improve the game over the years, it is far from a bad game.
Gameplay:
The game allows you to play as different factions. The Galactic Empire, The Rebel Alliance, and the Zann Consortium. Each has their strengths and weaknesses. The Rebels have a clear advantage with their fighters and ground units, the Empire has an advantage with their Stardestroyers and larger vessels, and the Zann Consortium has the corruption ability. My advice is to use all your abilities wisely and to remember their strengths and weaknesses. Even if you haven't played this game, you will still find this game fun and challenging.
Graphics:
It's fair to say that graphics have aged well, mainly with the ships. Modders keep improving on the original source material to make the game looking as polished as possible, so you will see these improvements if you look at them. When you look at these ships, with their original look however you'll see some flaws. First, with the ground units with their near-plastic like Rebels and Stormtroopers, I would it was a mistake. These graphics, however, do not affect the overall experience of the game itself. So don't worry about a thing; you'll find this game addictive even with plastic like stormtroopers and ground units.
Story:
There are multiple stories within each faction. The Rebels within the original are almost all in A New Hope, so it takes you inside the movie which cools if you think about it. The Empire, on the other hand, takes you into an alternate scenario which makes sure the Empire destroys the Rebellion and The Death Star is not destroyed. Finally the story of Tyber Zann in Forces of Corruption. Each story is unique to their faction, and when you play these campaign missions you will see that it all connects in the larger Star Wars universe. I personally enjoyed every single one of them; however, in my opinion, the Rebel campaign is the best and most satisfying.
Verdict:
With solid gameplay, amazing graphics within the space combat, and solid stories to top it all off. It is no wonder that Empire at War got so many good reviews. My final score is a whopping 10/10. Even with its flaws, I hope you play this game, and May the force be with you.

Have you ever watched a Star Wars movie and thought to yourself: "Man, these so-called officers are terrible at their jobs, I would do a much better job at commanding the entire army of the Rebellion/Empire"? Yes? Well, I have good news for you, friend!

Empire at war is a marvellous strategy game, with a main story with three different difficulty levels, skirmish mode with dozens of maps either in space or on land, and a Galactic conquest mode that lets you choose your own story with different tech levels, amount of planets and a variety of challenges. In Easy mode you will encounter mostly slight resistance and next to no invasions at all, while in Hard you will be struck with everything they got. 

Sadly, the multiplayer feature is long-since gone (unless ad-hoc), but the AI is so well scripted that you won't have a dull moment fighting off those pesky cruisers and TIE-bombers raiding your space stations. 

[spoiler]And remeber that Obi-Wan is an old man and might not be up for a fight against Vader or the Emperor.[/spoiler]

This game is a beautifle (for it's age), the maps are open and i love the mound of units you can flood the maps with. In this review i will only be discussing the multiplayer and game premice.
