[h1]Overall vote: 7.5
Enjoyable Star Wars themed RTS with interesting campaigns and game modes. [/h1]

Star Wars Empire at War: Gold Edition includes both the original game and the expansion “Forces of Corruption”; set during the Galactic Civil War (the Original Trilogy Era), the game offers three main game modes: Skirmish, Galactic Conquest and Campaign (the first two also available in multiplayer).

Skirmishes are similar to the classical RTS battles, except instead of sending your workers to collect resources, you gain a certain amount every second; this amount can be increased by controlling structures on the map with the infantry units you’re provided at the start of the battle. More and more powerful units can be recruited by researching technologies from your base, which you have to defend to avoid being defeated by the AI or the enemy player.
Skirmishes can be fought both on land and in space; while space skirmishes are truly exciting, giving you the possibility to command powerful ships like Darth Vader’s flagship, the Executor, and attempting very interesting manoeuvres, given the emptiness of space,  I found land skirmishes a bit annoying, for two main factors; the first one is given by the maps layout: most of them are in fact composed by long and tight passages, making manoeuvring large group of units very difficult; meanwhile, the other is caused by the AI behaviour and pathfinding: larger units, like the AT-AT or the Rancor, will have difficult times moving from one positions to another, and most of the time instead of moving they will start spinning endlessly on their position (a subtle reference to the infamous “I’ll try spinning, that’s a good trick” line?), or sometimes stand perfectly still when the enemy is firing at them from a few centimetres away.

The Galactic Conquest mode is instead a two (or three, in the expansion) player mode in which every human player or AI takes the role of one of the three main factions: the Galactic Empire, the Alliance to Restore the Republic, or the Zann Consortium (a criminal syndicate who, sadly, made its only appearance in this game). Each faction starts with a bunch of planets under its control: each planet can host a certain number of structures and troops, and provides resources and abilities to its owner; naturally each faction has its own structures and troops, with more advanced troops unlocked by technological research (also differing between the three factions). The goal of this mode is to control the whole galaxy by eliminating the other factions, fighting both space and land skirmishes on each of their planets. This is the mode I personally enjoyed the most, as it unites elements from RTS and 4X games.

Finally, the three Campaigns (one for each faction) are very similar to Galactic Conquest, with the only difference that, instead of simply conquering the whole galaxy, you have to complete certain missions (basically skirmishes with complex objectives) in order to unlock more planets to conquer. The two campaigns from the base game follow the events of the Galactic Civil war from approximately four or five years before Episode IV, up until the Battle of Yavin (ending of episode IV) from the perspective of the Alliance and the Empire, while the campaign from the expansion narrates the Zann Consortium rise to power in parallel to the Galactic Civil War (definitely the most interesting, and fun, of the three).

At the end of the day, Empire at War is a very enjoyable Star Wars themed RTS (the best of its kind, given the shallow competition), that is definitely recommended to any Star Wars fan, but that not adds any particular innovation to the genre, appearing less appealing to anyone who’s not particularly fond of the saga.

Summary:
SW: Empire at War is a RTS/Grand Strategy game that was released in Mid 2000s. This game is older, but does hold up still pretty well. With the expansion, EAW has 3 factions (Rebellion, Empire, Zahn Consortium) all fighting for control of the galaxy. Each faction has their own strategies, units, and styles of warfare that come with them. There is a galactic conquest mode, skirmish mode, and a campaign for each faction. I personally find the Empire to be the most enjoyable storyline and prefer playing as the empire overall. 

Positives:

1) Galactic Conquest is an amazing addition to the game that does so much for the playability and replayability of the game. In this mode, you are literally fighting Grand Strategy and RTS to rule to galaxy and wipe out the other factions. I love this mode so much and really the reason I keep coming back to this game. 

2) Space battles are extremely fun and were set up amazingly. It looks amazing with lasers and turbolasers shooting everywhere, TIE fighters and X-Wings darting everywhere and engaging in dogfights, missiles going everywhere. It is a spectacle to behold and is at times a nailbiter. Especially when 2 large fleets engage each other or if your either defending or attacking a large space station. Especailly defending when you are fighting a numerically stronger force. Strategy becomes king in those situations and picking the right strategy can definitely help you fight off a numerically larger force no problem. There are also different unit abilities that can bolster or ruin an enemies strategy. For example: creating a 'sqaure formation' as the empire with SDs forming a square with two interdictor cruisers in the middle with Missile jamming fields practically negates one of the Rebeliions deadliest ships and one often used by the Rebel AI. 

3) Fighting on Ground is also just as entertaining. Some battles will literally turn into slug fests. WIth force strentgh being so nearly equal that it comes down to minute decisions rather than some giant strategic sweep. There is a wide array of units to from all sides that make it always a challenging fight. I do believe that the AI likes to spawn artillery though a bit too much. But then again I spawn a ton of AT-ATs to wipe out everything. 

4) The Heroes are strong but not OP. This is a huge plus in my book. They can play a role but don't dictate the battle which is a nice change of pace. 

5) There are so many different factors and strategies to use on teh galactic conquest map to knock out your enemies. For example, the Consortium's bribery is devastating to planetary defense. The Rebels are at disadvantage when it comes to space battles, but they can launch commando raids which can have deadly effect in the right hands. 

6) The battle maps are big enough to have room to play, but small enough to where a battle shouldn't take forever. 

7) Rebellion and Empire are pretty well balanced against each other. I belive the consortium is a bit overpower with thier ships. The aggressor destroyers are a pain to deal with. 

Negatives:

1) Consortium is a touch OP. Aggressor destoryers are have an insanely powerful gun that can smash through ships.

2) The AI has a tendency to spam ships and spam capital ships. So you can end up having to battle over 100 capital ships in one battle potentially. 

3) The AI also likes to attack with a giant fleet. After losing a few ships, retreats. Then like 30 seconds later its right back in the same place doing the same battle. Rinse and repeat that gets kind of annoying after awhile of that same madness again and again. 

4) I wish they had inserted the clone wars into this game. I think that would have been such an amazing expansion or game to play. Fighting empire and republic would have been amazing!

Overall:

I love EAW. Its a childhood classic to me and is still just as fun as it was back then as it is now. There are complaints, but they aren't game breaking. I also believe it could have done more, but that doesn't prevent it from being a good game. I would totally recommend this game. 10/10

Have you ever watched the Star Wars films and wished you could see the galaxy at large?
To see the entire galactic conflict start to finish?
To be able to even alter the history and take the fate of the galaxy into your own hands?
Empire at War is the best, be-all-end-all experience for that. TL;DR at the bottom.
PROS: 
>A large map and unit diversity that makes the galaxy feel alive, even with native units allied to one of the factions
>Many units for both sides, allowing a great deal of strategy
>Campaigns for all 3 playable factions with unique storylines that are well paced and have a good degree of replay value
>Replayability due to how varied the maps are and how many potential combinations of enemies you could think of
>Amazing modding community, which includes many eras of the canon and the extended universe
>Multiplayer servers are now back online, allowing you to play multiplayer without needing a proxy
CONS:
>Zahn Consortium is poorly balanced for the game, corruption and their playstyle leads to some balance issues.
>Graphics are fairly simple. Not a game-breaker but they are definitely old.
>The AI is a known cheater and a bit basic; on higher difficulties they'll often be able to swarm in many more ships than they should be able to produce and seem to always know where your weak point is. However their strategy itself isn't great so if you can survive a massive doomstack, you can probably beat it. 
--------
Overall I think the game is still fun despite the AI being a tad botched, and the multiplayer being introduced once again has let me sink even more time in this game with my friends. Being able to massacre Ewoks, destroy the death star with a surgical strike, and sell gungans into slavery, this game doesn't disappoint and offers an actual competent strategy game for the Star Wars Genre.
--------
TL;DR: The game has some issues with the AI and the graphics are old, but it has a wonderful community, spirit, and depth to it that makes it great for sinking hours into. A solid 8/10.

[h1]EMPIRE AT WAR (WITH CANCER)[/h1]

A real-time strategy and tactical conquest game, Star Wars: Empire at War had me at the cover art. I poured countless hours into this game that aren't logged on Steam. In fact, I think only the long-lost servers of X-Fire (R.I.P.) can really say how much of my life I happily wasted on this game. With that in mind, I have asked myself, "Do I regret all of those lost hours?" The answer is complicated.

It should be noted that both the base Star Wars Empire at War and the expansion Forces of Corruption are included in the Gold Pack. They can be played separately and are almost two completely different games.

[b]PROS[/b]

+ Star Wars! For a hard fan like myself, a video game can be carried purely on the fact that it focuses on the Star Wars universe, and having that instantly recognizable text on the box almost sells itself. More importantly, this is one of the few strategy games of the franchise, and certainly the best one (in my opinion) since Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds. Besides, you gotta admit that the classic sound of TIE Fighters just makes you want to play.

+ Pretty decent and entertaining single-player campaigns for each faction, but no real replay value, at least not for me.

+ The space battle format in my opinion is one the most well-executed in any strategy game. While battle does take place in three dimensions, the player views the battlefield from a top-down perspective. Space battles exclusively take place in orbit of the system's "crown jewel" if you will, and the backgrounds- while a little too distant- are visually pleasing and unique for each system.  Each system is unique in its layout, and there are different "terrains" for each system. These terrain can be home to hazards, such as asteroid fields- which constantly damage a ship- to gas clouds- which obscure ships hiding within from view.

+ All three factions (Galactic Empire, Rebel Alliance, and Zann Consortium) are all completely different from the other and demand fundamentally different strategies to seize victory against each opponent. This demands constant attention to the overall strategy and the tactics needed for every battle change a little each time.

+ The Death Star will be in range in 15 minutes!

+ Good news! This game enjoys extensive modding support. Thus, nearly every neutral and con can simply be modded-out!

[b]NEUTRALS[/b]

0 Can become repetative after a certain point. Normally I would list this as a con, but this only tends to happen towards the late-game in vanilla. If you have mods and a will to carry-on, it shouldn't get too dull.

0 Multiplayer is all but dead. I can't really fault a game as old as this one, though, so I'll squeeze it in here.

0 The graphics haven't aged terribly well in some places, particularly in Empire at War (not so much for Forces of Corruption).

[b]CONS[/b]

- Forces of Corruption is the most unbalanced game I have ever seen in my entire fucking life. Yes, FoC gives the Galactic Empire the Super Star Destroyer and implements the TIE Interceptor as the default fighter (all but matches the A-Wing squadron in a duel), and the Rebel Alliance gets the MC30 (torpedo boat that absolutely ruins the Empire), but the Zann Consortium is NOTORIOUSLY overpowered. I genuinely don't here possess the character limit to describe how bad- nay, HILARIOUS it is. I genuinely recommend that you go see for yourself, just Google "Forces of Corruption unbalanced". Seriously, look it up, it's a good chuckle.

- Multiplayer demanded that you create a new account or some nonsense. It was thoroughly annoying.

- No autosaves, which can bite you and strip away countless hours.

- Multiplayer campaign. This is actually one of the most entertaining games to play a multiplayer campaign on, but there are fundamental faults. First: You MUST do it all in one go, as you cannot save your progress and load it at another time, at least in my experience. From what I've seen, there MAYBE is a fix to this SOMEWHERE out there, but the base game typically makes it nearly impossible without some file manipulation or whatnot. Second: You MUST establish house rules because of the simple fact that if the Rebel Alliance kills the Emperor, the Galactic Empire loses automatically. I once played a game where this twat simply sent Han Solo and Chewbacca to bypass the orbiting fleet (Rebels can do this with a small enough force) on Coruscant and effectively assassinated the Emperor and ended the campaign. Third: Limited to only two players, which is disappointing given that there are three factions in Forces of Corruption. Fourth: Game does crash occasionally, and that means the campaign is over.

[b]TL;DR/CONCLUSION[/b]

Yes, I do regret the number of hours I put into this game. When I strip away my love for Star Wars and strategy games, what's left is an unfinished, poorly-balanced, and shallow game that was sadly abandoned like a blind puppy. Thankfully, the Steam community has taken it under its wing and vastly improved it into the solid beast it always could have been. I'm glad I have it, and I sometimes do come back to it, but I've gotten all that I really want out of it. The only role that it serves is to quench my thirst from time-to-time. But I simply won't be doing much beyond that.

I cannot overstate how amazing Star Wars: Empire At War is. There's a reason there's only one real Star Wars RTS. The moddability and flexibility of the game is astounding- even if you're not impressed with the admittedly wacky balance of the base game, fanmade mod patches or even total conversions like Republic at War, Clone Wars 4.0, Thrawn's Revenge, and Phoenix Rising really breathe life into this old IP, and with Petroglyph writing one last love letter to us fans by adding Steam Workshop compatibility and Steam-hosted multiplayer, old hands at the game such as myself can share our love for this classic with a whole new generation of fans.

A classic for rts lovers

Although the land combat in this game is mediocre (even bad at times) the game truly shines in its space combat. Each ship has systems such as a hanger or the shield generators and they can be destroyed if the enemy can pass your shields. This makes your ships more valuable in a firefight and losing these systems could cost you the battle.

The campaign is interesting enough to keep playing but it's not the main focus of the game. The most fun you'll get out of the game is playing through a galactic conquest or a skirmish with your friends.This game also has a large modding community with some of the best mods i have seen in a game. A couple good ones are: Republic at War, Thrawns Revenge, Yoden Mod, and Awakening of the Rebellion.

I will definitely recommend this to any Star Wars or rts fan
Such a wonderful throwback! I use to play this game all the time! Definitely worth it!

Ignore the 2 hours in-game, I've played both the base game and Forces of Corruption on disc since I was young, even before I had a Steam account.

This RTS is easily one of the best and one of the coolest. There are very few RTSs set in the Star Wars universe, but in my opinion, there doesn't need to be another one after this gem. I admit, I don't play much of the campaign, but that's because of the Galactic Conquest gamemode.
Galactic Conquest is fairly similar to that of Battlefronts 1 and 2 (The originals, obviously) in that you take control of one side or the other or the Zann Consortium in the Forces of Corruption, and conquer planets. In this, however, there are tech levels that allow you to build more and bigger units, including Star Destroyers, Mon Calamari Cruisers, and even the Death Star itself. There is some base building as you must build buildings to either buff your planet or build certain units, requiring players to make tactical decisions on where certain units would be needed for a front. This also applies in space, but on a lesser scale as you must only upgrade the stations. Massive fleets and armies can be built all throughout the galaxy, and features all of the units in the original films and even some from the EU.  Heroes are also included in skirmishes and the Galactic Conquest scenarios, and may change with tech upgrades. For example, in the Forces of Corruption expansion, once a certain tech level is reached, Vader will no longer be in his TIE Advanced, but instead in his Super Star Destroyer. The tech and units in this game are amazing, and it is fantastic seeing the ships and vehicles from the movies and books come to life. 
The gameplay itself is fairly similar to regular RTSs on land, but there are command posts and special buildings that can sometimes be captured on the field. In the GC, there are sometimes indigineous buildings that spawn civilians that'll help or harm your cause. This is not limited to humans, however, as even Jawas, Wampas, and Gungans are in game.
Space is, in my opinion, where this game prospers. Ships actually have hangar bays and spawn fighters or bombers, and all capital ships and stations have hardpoints which have different functions and can individually be damaged. 
Really, I can't sing enough praises for this game. I have spent probably thousands of hours in this game all together and plan to spend even more since workshop support and mods allow me to explore even more units, planets, and heroes and add a bit more of a challenge.

Ignore my steam hours, I originally had this game on PC DVD-ROM and recently bought it on steam for the multiplayer servers. If you like Star Wars and strategy games then this is for you, not the most complex game but satisfying and rewarding space and land battles with the aim to rule the galaxy!! Be aware that this gold pack has 2 games within it: Star Wars Empire at War (original game) and Star Wars Empire at War: Forces of Corruption (sequel). Both games are very similiar with the sequel adding a new playable faction: The Zann Consortium, with their own campaign story, who are a little bit OP, but still good fun. The Empire and Rebelion get a lot of new units in the sequel, but not new campaigns, and some of the maps and gameplay mechanics have been improved, but it is essentially a big expansion of the first game - but hey, they both come together!

I highly recommend this game, with the proviso that it is over 10 years old, so don't expect anything incredible, but very good for some Star Wars themed conquering!!

Classic strategy game(total War style) + RTS combat (both space and ground) + Star Wars + metric tons of fan made high quality mods = Buy it now!

STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack is a RTS game for Star Wars: A New Hope time period.  It worked on Win 10, looked ok, played ok, sounded ok.  I had originally bought and played it on disc when it came out, got this again in the Star Wars Steam bundle. This game looks Dated now, just been upgraded just enough to play on Win 10 and the Steam version provides updated online Multiplayer support.   The devs are the veteran coders from Westwood, who made the Command and Conquer series of games.  The Gold pack has the original Empire At War plus the expansion Forces of Corruption.  

Buy it in the Star Wars Steam bundle, or by itself when on sale.  Might be ok by itself for the right person that likes old RTS games.

When you're in Galactic Conquest, and it's paused, you are unable to move unit formations in a fleet until you unpause it. Just a minor annoyance, not even sure if it's a bug or not.

Honest score: 9/10 Very very fun, especially with mods. Just be weary about any AI's over easy in Galactic Conquest; They'll bombard you with attacks that hold like 30+ infantry or fighters or something mundane to defend against. Also, auto-resolve is horrible, don't trust it. You'll lose waaaaaaaaaay more than you would normally. The way auto-resolve works is dumb, it's a number game; Whoever has more units, will almost always win (the game counts unit points, so 3 or 4 fighters (in a large battle) is equal to a capital ship)

I am one of the biggest Star Wars nerds I know, so when I first played this game several years ago on DVD I was extremely excited.  I loved the gameplay, as it felt like a mix between StarCraft, Supreme Commander, and Total War, and I was enthralled with the amount of nods to Star Wars Legends and the rest of the lore.  Around two years ago, I found the fantastic modding community on ModDB, and installed almost every mod on the site and played through them all.  When Petroglyph started updating this game again, I was so hyped, and the workshop has done wonderful things for the community.

If you want a slightly unbalanced (Consortium OP) RTS experience in the Star Wars Universe with a lot of references and decent gameplay, play the base game.
If you want some of the best experiences I've had in gaming with the huge amount of mods that overhaul, enhance, and make the game better, play any of the ones of the workshop.

I highly recommend!

EARLY DISCLAIMER:
This game is in my favorites folder -I do not hate it, I like it.
BUT... my liking the game is WHY I must leave a negative review.. because there are things wrong with it that were never addressed -or simply made worse with updates (or in the *shudder* sequel game Balance of Power).
The game is playable. The game is enjoyable.
But this alone is not enough for a positive review.


Starting with the first EAW game:
It's fun, and the campaign on each side has its high and low spots (okay, so they have a little timeline issue where the emperor is killing Bothans for leaking secrets to the FIRST Death Star, but ah well).

Space combat is GREAT.... except for a few big issues:
1) missiles and torpedoes. 
They can pass through shields and damage or destroy hardpoints (such as your guns, or shield generators) directly... and once all a ship or station's hardpoints are gone... the ship or station is gone as well. This means that a few Y-Wings can turn an entire space station to dust, because missiles are not considered a special attack, nor are they limited in uses -they are a Y-Wing (or TIE Bomber) main attack.

2) "Vehicle specials".
Perhaps it's a nitpick, but the fact that a Corellian Corvette is "weak to TIE Bombers", but can outrun their torpedoes while blasting the bombers to dust leaves me saying, "this ain't weak to no bombers"

3) You can't choose which vehicles start your fight
You brought in 20 star cruisers, 40 fighters, 40 bombers, and 50 ground vehicles thinking that the ground units would simply be deployed after the fighting.
...nope... they're your first wave of attack against 3 star destroyers and a space station... good luck, commander (oh, and naturally, the AI does not have this problem. As long as they have more than 20-25 units when they attack in space, all their attacking units will be space units)

Left the ground units behind this time?
Good. Now all your fighters drop in at once... against Star Destroyers and space stations (they'l do some damage, yeah, but they will take heavy losses.. kinda wish I'd been able to put in some bombers and cruisers.. you know.. "command the fleet"?)


The single-battle setup has a nitpick issue:
You MUST play as the Empire fighting the rebels, or the rebels fighting the empire. There is no rebels vs rebels or empire vs empire and the limitation is aggravating

The campaign mode issues (AIs don't follow the rules):
In campaign mode, the AI is able to create facilities instantly, instantly create units, and create unitbeyond their tech level. 

It is also able to -while you are playing as the Empire- send in more "sneak attack" units than the player can, and send in units that break the "size limit" the player is restricted to (you want to send in a missile unit? Nope, gotta beat the station first, they're too big to sneak through.. unless you're me.. I can TOTALLY sneak missile units through).

The AI units are also able to have greater range and longer visibility than the player. The number of times I have had a missile unit taken out by another missile unit (despite having destroyed its scout counterparts) is enormous.

...stuff like this annoys me to no end, and it seems popular in RTS games (and the higher the "difficulty", the more rules the AI can break, it seems)


Ground combat:
In general -aside from the issue where the AI has longer range and visibility- can actually be fun... sometimes... though often for me it's tedious more than anything. The whole "landing zone" idea was.. well... to me it was stupid that ONLY infantry could hold the landing zone. You can have 15 AT-STs sitting on the landing zone and keeping all enemy units at bay.. but you WILL NOT have the landing zone... because they are not "infantry". You HAVE to use Stormtroopers... and if you don't.. you can't call in more units... or, if you retreat from battle, you won't SAVE those units, because you don't have possession of the landing zone.. even though the enemy can't get near it because you're at the landing zone.

....oh... and your units can't fire when they first land -so if an enemy unit gets close, you will be torn to shreds before you can move. Don't expect that to hold true for the AI units, though. They can move and fire as soon as they unload.

Then there is the whole idea that "you only need to win in 1 city to capture the planet".
It's a PLANET... there should be more than 1 place you can/need to win to control the ENTIRE planet... but they didn't put that in -and there's a reason for that... the ground combat gets real old REAL quick -especially with what was mentioned above.



Balance of Power:

Balance of Power added in some new units, a new faction, and made some nice changes (like enabling Empire vs Empire fighting in single battle).

Its campaign was decent -if not even cannon in the times of pre-Disney- but you can only play as the pirates -who are way OP in general- which is highly disappointing... you don't get to be the rebels dealing with the second Death Star.. or the Empire dealing with the pirates AND the Rebels.. the Death Star, Vader's Super Star Destroyer.. those are IN the game, but they never show up in the campaign (you do fight a SSD, just not the Executor). You can bypass planets by "corrupting" them, which also has secondary effects (such as preventing units from spawning, losing the planet if you remove the corruption, etc... so much for the BALANCE part of "Balance of Power").

It introduces and uses a host of new ships, including what may possibly be the most OP ship in the game.
You think I mean the Super Star Destroyer?
No.. that one is actually fairly balanced. It's incredibly powerful, yes, but incredibly slow, so large it has back weapons that can't target the same guy as front weapons, and can, in fact, be destroyed by a large contingent of A-Wings.

I'm talking about the Missile Corvette. It's as fast as a reqular Corvette -with the ability to boost its speed- but attacks with missiles, which (as with the previous game) bypass shields.
All you ever need when you play as the Rebellion.. is this ship. 6 of them can take out virtually anything, with hardly ever being touched in return... at least... that's true when the AI uses it... when you use them, you need a few more, because the gunners will suddenly understand that you shoot at where the ship is moving, not where it is now.



So.. the long and the short of it:
It's a fun game. It's a good game to see ships clobbering each other -especially when you hit the spacebar for cinematic view (which, sadly, you cannot control, so the best parts you tend to miss).

However, the balance in units and combat is way off, and the AI is constantly breaking the rules which the player is forced to abide by, which can make the game far less enjoyable than it ought to be.

This game... should.. be.. better. That's why my review is negative.. even though I like playing it and have it in my favorites folder.

To be honest there is alot i could talk about but most reviews have done that already so i'll be quick.

1) Do you want an rts with ground and space combat? If so its good for that, the space and ground combat can be a bit annoying because sometimes the ai just tries to hide though.

2) Are you okay with dumping hours or even days into playing the galactic conquest? If you're going to be playing story or skirmish story might be a few hours or more depending on how fast you go and skirmish should last 30-60 minutes if both sides are trying. Galactic conquest is a gamemode in which you fight for control of the galaxy, or depending on the map set up can be only a few planets (mods can also have their own maps that are different than vanilla maps and might not even have the vanilla maps in the modpack so be ready to adapt your playstyle) which might be very short from a few hours to a few days or weeks.

3) What can i get out of this? Well you have a story campaign for both the empire and the rebellion and zann consortium (pirate organization) however the zann consortium and in the forces of corruption dlc so if you want to play as them or have them ingame you have to load that instead of the base game, plus alot of and to be honest i would say most mods only run with forces of corruption so keep that in mind. Besides that you'll have the story (3 factions with empire and the rebellion stories tying into each other a little and the zann consortium story going a pretty different direction as it *based on what i remember* starts after the second death star has been destroyed) mode and with galactic conquest and skirmish which both can give you lots of enjoyment along side the story and on top of that mod support on steam has been added so using mods in much easier now along with that came multiplayer support back to the game allowing you to play with others!

All in all I love this game and if you enjoy star wars games and real time strategy games alike then i'd say you're going to like STAR WARS: Empire at War ( 10/10 rating in my personal opinion )

The disk version of this game, along with the brilliant "Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds", encompassed most of the childhood that I can still remember. With even several years having passed since its heyday, it remains a classic gem that, for its replayability alone, easily warrants the twenty dollar price tag.

Now that this game is bundled (containing the both original copy and the "Forces of Corruption" expansion that was later developed), mod support has been added to steam, and multiplayer has been restored to the base game, it is undoubtedly one of the most worthwhile purchases I've made on steam.

If you like Star Wars, or you like RTs games get this game, while aged the gameplay experience is still fun, and their are plently of mods you can choose or make your own to spice things up.

Pros: 
- Good campaign - Both EaW and FoC have a campaign that expands on the normal galactic conquest with a series of story events and characters.
- Fun gameplay - Rather simple for an RTS but with lots of subtleties that allow optimum unit usage like the space compass
- Galactic conquest - Hands down why most peple play the game. Controlling bases and fleets on dozens to hundreds of planets (with mods). Only made better with mods that deepen the economics, add additional planets and unique effects, and change the factions and unit rosters.
- Good performance without mods - Mode performance obviously depends on the mod, and the lack of optimization can hurt on lower-end systems.

Cons
- some balance issues in the expansion (can be fixed). Its argued the Consortium is op, mainly because of them making more money then everyone else. Mods exist, and I suggest them.
- expansion removes some depth from galactic conquest (can be fixed)
- Unit control are not precise, as the unit actually needs to turn/bank to get there
- graphics have minor issues in land, or some ship-to-ship clipping in space - somewhat fixed with the new patch adding some communit-made shaders. Clipping is a side-effect of the unit collision system and not fixable.

After playing the physical version of the game on my old PC for years on end as a kid, to playing the digital release now, I can say with the utmost certainty that this is one of the most underrated and overlooked Star Wars games out there. Which is a massive shame, considering it's also probably one of the best. If you like the thought of throwing large space fleets full of some of science fiction's most iconic ships into all-out slugfests with each other, you'll LOVE this game. 10/10.
Ground battles might be a bit middling, but good god the space battles are epic. Best out there by miles.

Before buying it on steam I've already sunk hundreds of hours into Empire At War and Forces of Corruption. Empire at War with or without the expansion is not only the best star wars game I've played but the best strategy game. 

Turn-based macro strategy map with real-time battles like the Total War series, but 10000x better. The 20-25 unit limit and reinforcement system ensure good, strategic battles where even if the Empire throws their entire navy at your one little garrison you can hold them off indefinitely with a solid tactical approach.

Hopefully the steam version will work a little better but the game has always had a lot of bugs, like incessant crashes , and installing the game and getting it running was a serious and painful ordeal. But it was worth it to complete the campaign and a galactic conquest map.

Forces of Corruption had license to create new extended universe content and their character Tyber Zann and his faction "Zann Consortium" really were quite interesting and a lot of fun to play, though a little OP with their corruption mechanic and replaying galactic conquest with Zann becomes tedious as you need to play certain mini-missions to establish corruption.

Even with all of its constant crashing i still give this game a 9.999999/10

Sorry this is an actuall thing that actually happened to me... I digress........

This makes it even more fun when you win as the rebels since its so challenging. This game was never designed to be a competetive RTO considering these facts and especially considering that there "fix" to the OP empire was to add an even more broken faction. 

Thank you disney for adding multiplayer support back in! it even works with mods and that is truly impressive considering the age of some of these mods and the original game as well.

If your going to play the original game i reccomend that you play as the empire and rebellion, not one or the other, because it isnt like LOL. the word "ballance" isnt of interest here. play them both and enjoy the uniqueness of each of these factions. If I had to pick a favorite faction though it would be the empire. Not because of Vader or the Deathstar, although those are kinda awesome too, no no no... The fact that I can Stomp on an entire village of Gungans in the middle of a ground Assault Battle with an A.T.A.T. gives this game a 10/10 Recommendation from me!

On a side note if your looking for a balanced Star Wars RTO then this game might still be your home. there are several mods in the community of this game that thanks to disney are quite easy to install in-game through the workshop. the Republic at War mod changes the factions to be the Grand Army of the Republic and the Confederacy of Independent Systems. 2 factions that were stuck in a stalemate war on a galactic scale for 3 whole movies! the ships are more balanced by far than the original game and it adds more content. Only disadvantage in that pack is the way that the ships move around asteroids. Keep an eye on them and you will know what I mean and want to tear your hair out a little bit as your Venator fleet does 4 360s and then just goes in the other direction.

Another great mod for all you Thrawn Lovers (Myself included) is Thrawns Revenge. this pack has 5 Factions and a whooole bunch of new ships. the game runs smoother, the ships have more hardpoints so the battles are more epic and strategic, and for a mod that has Grand Admiral Fucking Thrawn in one of its factions, everything is quite balanced.

I never even mentioned the skirmish battles in this review. there fun if you have 30 minutes to kill with a friend but dont want to get stuck in a full scale 4 hour galactic war.

CONCLUSION:

PLAY WITH FRIENDS
DONT PLAY THE ORIGINAL GAME OR EXPANSION WITH THE INTENT OF HAVING FAIR GAMEPLAY
TRY THE MODS IF YOU DO WANT FAIR GAMEPLAY, OR IF YOU WANT EVEN MORE CONTENT
KILL THE GUNGANS WITH AN A.T.A.T. WHEN YOU GET THE CHANCE BECAUSE YOU FEEL LIKE YOU HAVE JUST UNLOCKED THE SECRET TO THE GALAXY OR SOME SHIT AND YOU HAVE "UNLIMITED POWAHHHHHHHH!!!!!"

I have (at the time of writing) played this game for 61.2 hours and I can safely say that it is a brilliant game. Over the course of playing, I have played using two different mods as well as the base game. On all of my playthroughs I have enjoyed playing the game, particularly during...

-+-SPACE COMBAT-+-

The Space Combat is a standard RTS, but with several added features. The most important of these features is Hardpoints. Instead of attacking a target with it at full power until the moment it breaks up, you target specific systems, such a Tractor Beams (to prevent the enemies from trapping ships) or Hangar Bays, to stop them from releasing fighters. The next is Unit Abilities. These allow you to perform special actions to give yourself the upper hand in combat. An example of this is the Acclamators's Weapon Boost (Which is shared with most Imperial units). Overall, I really enjoy it.

-+-GROUND COMBAT-+-
I must admit, I do not enjoy the [i]base game[/i] ground combat because there are too few units and it is visually uninteresting (Though I do cut some slack for it being a very old game). Mods, however, greatly improve it, adding better maps and more units. If you are going to be spending alot of time on the ground, I recommend the Cone Wars mod, which makes each unit moveable on it's own, instead of in groups. 

-+-MODS-+-
Start by playing the base game, then ook into mods. Most mods are complete conversions and rely on you knowing the basics of the game. I recommend Clone Wars and Thrawn's Revengem the latter is receiving an update soon and the prior is complete.

-+-VERDICT-+-
STAR WARS: Empire at War is a brilliant game, and I recommend it even if you don't like Star Wars (There are mods that change the setting)

This game is flat out fantastic. I can see why so many people love this game. I have hundreds of hours clocked in, and I've loved every minute of playing this game.

There's nothing like a good strategy game. Star Wars Empire at war was my very first Steam purchase. I had always been looking for a Star Wars game combined with a strategy RTS, and this game was it. 

Gameplay: Outstanding. I love the gameplay in Empire at War. You can get a close up on each planet you control and build things like a space station, a barracks, a shield generator, all the Star Wars land items that changed the galaxy! You can also train stormtroopers, build AT-STs or AT-ATs, or move a hero like Darth Vader to a planet's surface to protect it from invasion while playing as the Empire. You can even build the Death Star and actually destroy planets! As the rebels, you can train rebel troopers, use powerful artillary and missile tanks, and use iconic heros like Luke Skywalker or Obi-Wan Kenobi to guard a planet or fight in space. The space battles are absolutely amazing. Join the Empire and send an armada of star destroyers to crush the rebels, or join the rebels and steal technology from the empire to build memorable vehicles like X-Wings and Mon-Calamari cruisers. In the Forces of Corruption expansion, you can join Typer Zann and build a criminal network to control the galaxy, while also given the option to play as the Rebels or Empire with more units like darktroopers, Super Star Destroyers, Yoda, and Sith Inquisitors. The only weak points in the gameplay are the land battles and the balence in the Forces of Corruption expansion. I've always found land battles to be extremely cliche and boring. They are mostly something you want to get out of the way so you can fight another space battle. They also take a long time and are sometimes extremely difficult to win if the enemy has turbolaser towers, artillary, and a few heroes present on the battlefield. My issue with the balence is that the Consortium is really overpowered. They have cannons called Mass Drivers that fire these metal slugs that penetrate shields. They can take down entire armadas of Mon Calamari Cruisers (known for their powerful sheilds) quite quickly. Overall, the gameplay of Empire at War is one of its strong suits.

Community: The community is great. There are a ton of great mods you can subcribe to on Empire at War's Steam Workshop like Republic at War or Thrawn's Revenge. You can also play against real people online with Empire at War's newly refurbished multiplayer servers! Empire at War also has a very active community in the forums, so if you have a technical issue, it will most likely be answered quickly.

Pricing: Worth full price. I even would go far enough to say that I would still buy it if it were worth $30. 

Performance: There are still a few glitches that Petrolyph's team is working to fix, but none of them are game-breaking. I'd say the only major performace issues I've noticed while playing the game is when using mods, especially Republic at War.

Overall, I'd say that any Star Wars fan/gamer would have a great time playing Empire at War.

This game, while aged, is all that I remember it to be. Conquring the galaxy through epic space battles and impressive land invasions allows players to relive and change the story of Star Wars. Using legendary heroes from the original trilogy and even the extended universe. While it is not a complex RTS, it still provides a reasonably challenging AI for its time. With the reintroduction of multiplayer and the steam workshop allowing for easy to access mods, new life has been poured into this classic game. If you're a fan of Star Wars or even just seeing spectacular space and land battles, get this game.

Utterly repetative, and lacking any real strategy or difficulty.

Honestly, even allowing that its a fairly old title, I cant believe it was ever popular at all aside from the "star wars" part of the game.  Its honestly the only reason I can see this game having any draw.  

The "missions" are pretty much the same thing, every time.  The "campaign map" is nothing but a way to choose the next "mission".  You fly down to a planet, which MIGHT have 'gasp' a different map, that will play out exactly like the map you just played before it.  There is no difficulty, there is no innovation.  You simply choose from a very limited group of units, and overwhelm your opponents position with numbers.  I only put in 15 hours because I literally forced myself to keep playing in hopes something would change.

Avoid it like the plague, please.

The space battles are much better than land battles. What I mean is never do land battles, youll rip your hair out. For a game this old it does seem to still entertain. It is a serious CPU hog so if you have a slower CPU it might trouble you to run. Other than that if you like strategy games and Star Wars youll like this.

Ok, this review may be a bit biased, as this was my very first PC game ever, but lets get into it. I love this game, and I have loved it since I found out about it when I was 7, and when I found out I couldnt get it on my Xbox 360, I was saddened, to say the least. But then, I got my PC, and when I saw this on the steam store page, I knew it had to be my first game. So I bought it, and boy am I glad I did. This games skirmishes and base combat are inferior to other games like Starcraft or Command and Conquer, the primary competitors of its era, but it has one thing over them. Galactic Conquest. Galactic Conquest is the game mode in this game where you control different planets, the different planets all have different advantages, and different incomes to make money to expand your growing empire. You capture different planets with land and space skirmishes, and you only beat the game if either A. You defeat the primary villan/hero. (For the Empire its the Emporer, for the Rebels its Mon Mothma, and for the Consortium its Tyber Zaan) or B. you capture every signle planet in the galaxy, which, on the biggest map is 55 planets, including your own. I could play Galactic Conquest for hours upon hours, I would play the biggest one until I had mastered it, then move onto the next difficulty. And then I had completly mastered the game on the hard difficulty, and just as I started to not play anymore, they revived the multplayer. I got my friend this game for his birthday, he was skeptical at first, as he is a Starcraft player, but he got sucked in, just as I did. And now, we play Galactic Conquest with each other on a weekly basis. And the mods. Dont even get me started on the mods. All I will say is that Republic at War 1.2 is better than the base game, and for anyone who likes the base game, get this. You wont regret it. You wont regret getting the base game either.

This is just thee best game. I have never seen a single bad review on the store page or in the community it is just that good that hardly anyone complains about it. Even though this game is like 10 years old it is still one of my favourite games to date.

Don't let the my game hours fool you, I got the game on disk long before buying it on steam, so in total my hours are more in the hundreds than the tens.
So, about the game:
The base game offer tons of fun for the price you pay, from its campaigns, to skirmish, all the way to the galatic conquest mode, where you can play as one of the three factions in an attempt to conquer everything.
Each factions has completetly different units and heroes as well as different mechanics, especially the Zann Consortium with its corruption mechanic.
This game as some really great mods, mods that add huge amounts of replayability and features.

Would definetly recommend this game for any Star Wars fan or anyone new to Star Wars. The space combat is the best part for me and getting to command all my favourite starships, ground units and heroes/villains makes me feel like a child again, witnessing Star Wars for the first time.

Pros;
- combat mechanics are engaging and focus on critical sections of ships which gives the player a more tactful feel.
- the battle camera is a great way to view the battle from the perspective of your forces.
- galactic conquest takes a story campaign to new heights! 
- the AI isn't fully scripted through GC so anything can happen.

Cons; 
- does take some time to load.
- limited skirmish options.
- mods can make your game better or worse depending on how you look at it.

I give this game an 8.5/10.

In forces of corruption they give you a box while managing your fleet or ground group that allows you put a unit in there to send them first into battle to scout instead of sending in everyone with no control on who comes and who stays back to reinforce.  I apologize I am bad at explaining things but its a very simple difference.  If they took their machanic from forces of corruption and added it to the base game I would give this game a 10/10 but that one thing does have a big effect on my playstyle and annoys the living hell out of me if im honest.  But overall the game is absolutley fantastic and the mods are crazy good!  9/10

STAR WARS: EMPIRE AT WAR (GOLD PACK) FOR THE PC. GAME REVIEW!!!

My experience with this product of a game its very competive with its own economy based income completely different from a comparison point to STARCRAFT 3. Another RTS game like an example Warcraft 3: The Frozen Throne is a follow up comparison through economy and base construction and manuver of units. What made be buy this product was the game trailer from the PS2 game console within the STAR WARS Battlefront 2 extended content or STAR WARS WARFIGHTER also for the PS2. New released RTS games like Company of Heros there are four extended content of the game and it takes considerable amount of data to play and sometimes doesnt run. Empire At War that I experience has no problems and runs smooth. Best RTS with fast economy and unit control. I recommend it been wanting to play for a awhile. Another fact is its very fast in gameplay but I struggle with economy income where you have to find icons with the map of building refinerys to establish a higher income to produce base functions and units. money with the game is very diffcult like any RTS game manage your units very carefully and campaign is very fun follows the movies very precisely.

This is a wonderful game. While it has some balancing issues like almost every other game it is immersive to the star wars universe makes you feel like the grand commander of any of hte factions you choose to play. It runs very well when not in multiplayer, and even there it runs quite well. I loved this game from the minute one of my cousin's firends put me in front of it and not only got the game on disc but rebought it on steam for ease of modding and to give the disc to one of my friends so they could play it.

On top of the base game content Forces of Corruption expands and adds to the level of play while adding an interesting new faction to the mix that base game didn't have. 

Whether you wish to weild the might of the Empire, resotre hope to the Galaxy as the Rebellion, or simply make a profit and corrupt everything as the Zann Consortium this game has something to offer everyone.

As well access to mods using workshop and so on can allow you to add so many different factions and bring this game into whatever setting of the star wars, or even non star wars, universe you like. It has a diverse and extensive mod community due to its variable base edits and most of the mods I have played and looked at both breathtaking and simply running to a great standard.

I love this game and I hope that someone reads this and wants to play it as well.
This game takes it's rightful place as the best Star Wars game since Battlefront. Mod support is a little iffy, but after jumping through a few hoops, all sorts of possiblities open up.

The land battles are shabby at best but the space battles make up for it. When I play the space battles it makes me feel like I'm in the middle of one of the movies. There are a number of mods that greatly enhance the experience as well including but not limited to Thrawn's Revenge which provide alot of replay value.

I really do enjoy this game, and I think it is a good addition to any collection for a fan of RTS games or the Star Wars universe. The game manages to bring the scale and desperation of a galaxy at war to life in a way that even the movies don't, as you attempt to liberate friendly planets with local support or burn down the homes of hostile natives - even when playing as the Rebellion! Despite being a little older now, the title plays exceptionally well, looks decent enough (thankfully there aren't many cut scenes) and has excellent MOD support and additional content with the Forces of Corruption DLC. 

You can even wage war with Admiral Akbar again and pretend The Last Jedi never happened!

A golden oldie for sure, and well worth picking up during the sales!

Strategy, appealing visuals, and that satisfying feeling of playing a nostalgic childhood game. The combat is incredibly satisfying. Something about those thin red lazors blowing up imperial (or rebel, if you've fallen to the dark side) bases and structures puts a smile on my face. With a suprising amount of content and reasonably priced DLC, I would highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to sit down for hours on end and conquer the galaxy. May the force be with you!

Now, if you are currently looking through the reviews and have found my little review, take this to heart before you buy. This game, is not an amazing rts. Dont get me wrong, i love this game to bits, but realisticly, its not that great. The ground combat is...well, its not terrible but compared to the space combat its a joke. If you buy this game, you bought it not becuase you wanted to see darth vader completley destroy an army of infantry (though, you can see that if you want), you play it to watch as your army of only empire capital ships gets completly destoryed by thousands of rebel bombers because you thought you didnt need any anti-fighter ships. You came to watch the rebels snatch victory from insurmoutable odds, obliterating what you once thought to be intimedating star destroyers. You came to laugh with a sick twisted sense of pleasure as you defend the death star before, while the match is playing, you press a button to activate the death star, and watch a rebel planet expload. 
           but, most importantly, you came because this is star wars game. A Star wars rts at that, a very rare breed. So, just remember before you buy, if you wanted to have epic, fun and awesome GROUND BATTLES, you may not want to buy this. However, if you're willing to sloge throught the mediocre ground battles to experience the awesome space battles? Well, then i welcome you- to Star wars: Empire At War. Oh, and btw, mods add a lot of longevity to the game, some mods just make the game better, more then a few that put this game in the clones wars (one focuses more on the cartoon series while the other is more just general clones wars stuff, noramlly stuff in the movies with a couple mentions to the cartoon). If you're a star wars legends fan theres even a mod that puts this game in the entire legends era after the battle of endor, with all kinds of new factions to mess around with. 
TL;DR This is a damn good game with some glaring faults, but if you can put up with them, maybe even get some mods to make the game last longer in your library before you uninstall it, then this is a fine additon to your RTS or Star Wars collection.

i dont know what the heck people are talking about when they praise this game. If you want a review that is actually objective, true, and looks past all the star wars nostalgia then here it is:

Excellent Game! Although there are some pretty serious and crippling bugs that need addressed such as the Empire's Speeder ground unit, and its begging desperation for the desired Clone Wars expansion, the game's content is very relavant and on topic to the starwars franchise. I have played and enjoyed many RTS's (real time strategy games) including Blizzard's Warcraft 3 and Ensemble Studio's Halo Wars (I) and I have to say that Star Wars: empire at war is right there with them with years worth of enjoyment and with a slight brush up and fix on EAW's bugs even has the potential to be better than its competitors. 

Recently EAW has been updated with a new expansion, forces of curruption. While it is exciting to know that the game is getting another look at it, and I may only have put a few hours of investigation into the expansion, my first impression is that it is a BIG mistake. Any type of expansion at all is way out of oder from the needed address of bugs and balancing issues that the original has had for a very long time. Im not trying to be disrepectful in any way of the game creators who I love and thank for making the original game but, for them to put all time and work towards making the new playable side Zahn Consortium with all its unique playing complexities, when all they needed to do was fix the handful of bugs in the original and call it a day. It was alot of aplaudable work im sure, but cronologically went in the wrong direction. If some one is looking at this game, saving up money, and drueling over youtube videos wondering if this game is worth buying? It most deffinitly is, you wont regret your purchase if your a fan of RTS games. "Odds are the Empire's speeder unit will never be repaired" -3CPO, "Don't tell me the odds!" -Han Solo.

Update: 12/13/2017- I given the game a few more hours of play time and I've found that that empire's speeder bike unit work much better and im super excited and happy to see that, also I slightly noticed that the tie tank's self destruct range of effect is 0, deson't really even hurt any enemies, I suggest only using the self destruct ability when attacking building and there are enemies that would destroy the tie tanks otherwise, besides that everything is awesome! Thanks for the fix!

This game was already fantastic on its own, but now that multiplayer has been revived and the game is compatible with Steam Workshop mods, it's easily ten times better. Star Wars fans and fans of RTS in general should absolutely play this game. I have played other games that cost up to $60 or more, compared to the $20 asking price here, and many of them can't even compare to the amount of fun I've had with this. Don't be fooled by the old graphics (especially considering that there are graphic-enhancement mods), this one is absolutely worth purchasing.

Probably the pinnacle of real-time strategy gaming, has a very stimulating storyline that is both easy to follow and understand. Whether you are new to this style of gaming, or a seasoned player, then this game is for you, with the constant threat of invasions from Imperial and Rebel forces (if you decide to play the forces of corruption expansion) as well as developing an army and support fleet to land your own offensives, you'll find it quite the task to adapt yourself to think both offensivley and defensively. I would say for a game as old as it is, the graphics are quite superb (although I'm sure many would sadly disagree) and with the right settings can paint quite a breath-taking and beautiful display.
Fan created mods really make this oldie shine. Pick it up on sale son, EA isn't gonna make a Star Wars strategy ever, so enjoy this goodie. 8/10

I don't know if it was the pressure of early adult life or the demands of college, but I began to experiment with huge ships in my late teens. I began by looking at huge ship magazines in the basement when my parents weren't around. Then one day, my mom came home early and unexpectedly caught me in the act. Both of my parents were furious. They asked me where I go the magazine from and I said I found it and that I thought it only contained articles on small watercraft. As a result, I started to sneak out at night, telling my parents that I was headed to a friend's house to watch Full House, but in reality, I was in the library, reading up on huge ships. As my career developed, I found an apartment that I could afford and I moved out of my parents’ house. My interest in huge ships only grew. My apartment became a center for trafficking huge ship paraphernalia: model huge ships, pictures, of huge ships; life preserves – you name it. Eventually some neighbors complained and the owner of the apartment building had me evicted. By that time, I was so far gone that I didn’t care and I moved into a hostel. It was the perfect place to continue my pursuit of huge ships. The rent was cheap, drifters came and went, everyone minded their own business, and once in a while a new person would come along with scale models of huge ships in Turkey. We had a lot of wild nights and I was having trouble holding down my job. Eventually got fired. One day it dawned on me that if I don't get away from huge ships, I'll end up dead. By pure luck, I ran into a fellow who went through the same thing and he recommend Trimmer's book. Between the book and my support group, I made progress and got back on my feet again. Last night I almost turned left out of the parking lot instead turning right, as I've done routinely for the last 6 months. Turning left would have meant that I was heading to the Port of Baltimore where huge ships are present everywhere: horns blowing, sailors lashing gear to decks, and merchants teasingly gesturing to the gangplanks as they ask passersby if they want to go for a voyage on a great, big, huge ship. I started to imagine the wakes in the bay and the frolicking of tugs as they pull and push these huge ships in and out of the port. There was a burning desire inside of me: my mouth started to salivate; my hands were trembling; and my eyes darted left and right as they searched for an answer. I thought that maybe I could just go to the port and find one or two huge ships and it wouldn't be that big of a deal. Call it a voice in my head, an angel on my shoulder, or Trimmer's book in my glove box, but I turned right and headed home instead. My support group had a meeting last night and I told them about my near stumble. It felt good to tell everyone that I did not fall victim to weakness. I have my beloved support group and my dearest John W. Trimmer to thank for 6 months - huge ship free.

**8/10**
-THE GOOD-

---#%$@ING STAR WARS: Empire at War puts you in the command seat of the immense Galactic Empire, the tennacious Rebel Alliance or, with the Forces of Corruption expansion, the Zahn Consortium; a brutal criminal cartel that dominates the galactic underworld. Games like Battlefront (the original games, not the half-baked EA remakes) let you live the battles and see the struggles of each soldier but Empire at War makes you the commander of entire fleets of Star Destroyers, swarms of X-Wing fighters, or legions of brutal Consortium death-squads. It's difficult to understate how satisfying it is to invest thousands of credits into building your fleet and executing the perfect strategy to take-apart your enemy's most formidable defences. The level of joy I feel when I hear the Imperial March playing in the background as my massive AT-AT walkers crush rebel troops underfoot (literally) is really what makes Empire at War special.
---SCALE: Empire at War gives you the tools, resources, and authority to take-on the entire galaxy in the game's 'Galactic Conquest' gamemode. In Galactic Conquest, you choose between a number of unique scenarios and are given a pre-set loadout of planets, heroes, and resources and one goal: annihilate all opposition and conquer the galaxy. Maps range from small handfuls of worlds to the ENTIRE Star Wars galaxy! On top of all that, each planet includes both space and ground combat and comes with their own unique sets of advantages and disadvantages. For example: Tatooine, the desert world Luke Skywalker grew up on, is prone to sandstorms which significantly reduces the accuracy of rocket weapons. That means any invasion of Tatooine must be planned ahead of time because, if the defenders have tanks or defense lasers, your rocket weapons won't be very effective and you need to get creative.
---THE FACTIONS: It would've been very easy for the developers to simply make the Rebellion, Empire and Consortium factions functionally identical with different reskinned units but that's definately NOT what they did. All three factions have definate strengths and weaknesses that must be taken into account. The Galactic Empire has access to far more resources than the Rebels or Consortium and can create fleets and armies very quickly but they rely on strategy to be used effectively. You can't just charge a fleet of Star Destroyers into a Rebel attack force and expect to win, for instance. The Empire also has another unique advantage over the Rebellion and the Consortium that I'll discuss later. The Rebellion can't engage enemies directly because their units, though able to do significant damage, don't do very well in sustained combat. That means Rebel players must be willing to use hit-and-run tactics to fight their foes. The Rebellion also has the most powerful starfighters in the entire game and good Rebel players learn to use this to their advantage. They also advance themselves by stealing technology from the Empire and Consortium; gaining access to cool and unique units allong the way. By the end-game, the Rebellion ends-up with an extremely flexible fleet that can handle almost any threat. The Zahn Consortium, however, is much more brutal. They rely on the 'Corruption' game mechanic which, by doing special missions, the player can sabotage their enemies, move through their territory unseen, and gain access to powerful new units. Be careful, though, because your enemies can use their charismatic Heroes to purge your corruption! The Consortium relies on it's tough units to beat their foes; their fleet is built to brawl up-close and personal and their ground forces are capable of fielding units that counter even the most powerful enemy units. For example, they can build a Ysalamiri Cage that prevents Force-users from using their powers, and can turn an extremely powerful unit like Darth Vader into a much more managable threat!
---THE DEATH STAR: Yes, you heard me right. The Empire, in Galactic Conquest mode, can build the Death Star. By constructing expensive Research Facilities on various worlds and researching various parts and technologies, the Galactic Empire can build the Death Star (or the Death Star II from Return of the Jedi if you have the Forces of Corruption expansion). Once construction begins, all players get a warning message "DEATH STAR CONSTRUCTION HAS BEGUN" and a 5 minute countdown. "DEATH STAR CONSTRUCTION COMPLETE" heralds the completion of the most powerful unit in the entire game. As you might expect, the Death Star is capable of utterly destroying entire planets. A fleet with the Death Star in it can engage in space battles as usual. However, you will see a graphic on the HUD with a countdown "ENEMY BASE WILL BE IN RANGE IN...MINUTES". Once the countdown is complete, you can pull the lever and watch a demonstration of your fully armed and operational battle station. The resulting blast will completely annihilate any structures, ground forces and heroes stationed on the planet's surface and turns it into a lifeless asteroid field. The Death Star II, from the Forces of Corruption expansion, can even target Capital Ships and Space Stations with the Superlaser and instantly destroy them in one blast (at the expense of a delayed countdown). The Death Star is easily the most powerful unit in the entire game; so powerful that it cannot even be attacked in a regular space battle! It lingers ominously in the background, inching closer and closer to firing range of the planet. Fear not, however! It can be destroyed! If you manage to locate the Death Star, the Rebellion can stage a daring, desperate assault on the Death Star using the Rogue Squadron Hero Unit and destroy it. The Zahn Consortium can send the cunning droid bounty hunter Hero Unit, IG-88, to sabotage it's main reactor and cause it to self-destruct. If destroyed, it CANNOT be rebuilt so use it wisely!
---MODS: Though not as numerous as games like Skyrim and Fallout, Empire at War does have its own modding community (ModDB). While they range in quality from utterly unfinished to out-of-this-goddamn-world, they are fairly easy to install and it even has Steam Workshop support if you're new to modding! I personally recommend the "Thrawn's Revenge" mod, otherwise known as "Imperial Civil War" which totally overhauls all the units and planets in the game to reflect the old Expanded Universe post-Return of the Jedi continuity. It's easilly the best mod out there for Empire at War and it's totally free! *cough* Bethesda Creation Club *cough*

-THE BAD-

---BUGS: As is inevitable with video games, Empire at War does have it's share of bugs. I haven't encountered any game-breaking bugs in my play sessions but I've noticed a few audio and graphical glitches. Nothing huge or game-breaking (you won't see units distend like overcooked pasta or anything like that), just little things that might irk you if you're the kind of person that notices those things often.
---FPS: I've noticed that Empire at War tends to struggle to maintain a stable 60 fps when you zoom out in large space or ground battles (especially on the more graphically intensive maps like the Maw Installation, Taris or Coruscant) but nothing major. Most of the time it's temporary and I haven't had it dip bellow 45 but everybody's computer is different. It's a fairly old game so most people shouldn't have too much of a problem running it.
---GAME BALANCE: None of the game's units are especially powerful (okay, besides the Death Star but that doesn't really count), but there are a few instances where your faction might struggle to compete. For example: I find that the Rebel Alliance tends to struggle more against Zahn Consortium in space because they're so heavily armoured and they have weapons that can penetrate shields (the main source of Rebel Ships toughness). Using their powerful fighers and bombers tends to fix this, though.

Not only is this one of my favorite Star Wars games, it is one of my favorite RTS games. Anyone who is interested in either of these categories should definitely try it. Also a lot of fun since mod support was added.

Star Wars Empire at War and it's expansion Forces of Corruption (included in the Gold Pack) are a must buy for a Star Wars fan looking for a worthy RTS to soak some hours into.
I may not have many hours on my Steam copy, but I assure you I played this all the time on my old PC back when it came out. You could say it was my childhood pc game.
In this game you can play a story campaign of all 3 factions: Empire, Rebellion and the Zann Consortium. The Empire and Rebellion ones take place before and during A New Hope. (You need to run the Empire at War Gold Edtion game to play this) The Consortium campaign takes place after this. (You need to run the Forces of Corruption game to play this) I'm putting this behind it as it's a bit unclear to newer players.

But the game really shines in the next part of the game: Galactic Conquest. This is where you will put most of your hours in. A real-time sandbox campaign with the goal to take over the Star Wars Galaxy. You can do this with the 3 factions listed above. As the Empire you can build the Super Star Destroyer: Executor and the best of all... the Death Star! (Death Star I in EaW and Death Star II in FoC) I really enjoy playing as the Empire with all its technical marvels. But beware even your greatest piece of technological terror has a weakness... and others are desperate to exploit it!
But the conquest works as follows: you have an X amount of starting systems, which you can upgrade with bigger space stations and build bases on to increase income, your army or build it into an impenatrable fortress. To capture a planet one must first destroy the fleet and station in orbit, then you must prepare your troops for a ground assault. After winning both battles the planet is yours! I would get this game for this sandbox experience alone. 

And then there's Skirmish, the mode where you can play on a vast selection of space and ground maps with all the units available in the Galactic Conquest mode (except the big ones like the Executor and Death Stars). Here you start with a space station (in space) or a ground base with pre-built buildings and defences which you can upgrade (on the ground). The focus here is more on epic battles than on base building, you can still put down turrets, repair and healing stations. 
I played this less, but it's still good fun. 

And then you have multiplayer! Yes! Since a few months ago, Disney gave the all-clear to the developers from back in 2006 to release new updates to the game! In the first patch they added Multiplayer which was gone for quite some time after GameSpy got shut down, it's now integrated into Steam! Furthermore they fixed bugs and crashes that were still present in the game. And best of all they made installing mods quicker and easier with the addition of the Steam Workshop! 

And then we come to the final part of this review.. the mods! The mods for this game are amazing, from mods that add new units and maps to enormous overhauls that change the setting from Galactic Civil War to the Clone Wars era! This means that when the base game starts getting old, you can just download a nice mod from the Workshop or Moddb and get a whole new experience! 
I played tons of Republic at War, Phoenix Rising with my CD copy. Now I found new ones like Battlefront Commander and Awakening of the Rebellion. 

So should you get this game? Well I think you know the answer by now. The game is very stable, yes some crashes here and there but thats mostly when playing mods. The game has plenty of content worth of 100s of hours. Great community and modding community with amazing mods. 
I'm grateful to the devs for making this game. If you are a Star Wars fan and like strategy and RTS? Yes get it now! As Darth Vader said many times: "It is your destiny..."

Also, a few sentences that will describe the experience of playing this game:
- We will crush this Rebellion with one swift stroke!
- Everything that has transpired has done so according to my design....
- General, prepare your troops for a surface attack!
- Lord Vader, you may start your landing. The shield will be down in moments.
- It's a TRAP!
- Intensify forward firepower! IT'S TOO LATE! *explodes*
- They came from behind! *explodes*

Ah, Empire at War. Where to start?

It is, as the name helpfully implies, a Star Wars game, an RTS to be specific, released in 2006. The vanilla game having a Rebel and Imperial story campaign, the latter being a what-if? and the former following the old canon before Disney. Both of them are rather easy, the Empire one moreso, and are functionally, in my opinion, little more than extraordinarily long tutorials, mainly prepping the play for Galactic Conquest. The DLC Forces of Corruption adds an entirely new faction, who are functionally a galactic crime syndicate, with their own entirely new campaign as well. The story is signficantly imrpoved from the previous two, and is rather enjoyable overall, as the new faction also has entirely new units, vehicles, and ships.

Cons-wise, the base game is rather outdated graphics wise for obvious reasons. Ground battles are generally repetitive slogs. The AI is as dumb as a sack of braindead kittens, even on higher difficulties. Auto resolve, as in the vein of almost every game to ever have the feature, is bound to only end in heart break. There are also still some bugs and similar hanging around, although I haven't encountered anything truly game breaking. But the biggest issue overall is balancing in Forces of Corruption, as the new faction introduced is hilariously, utterly, and completely overpowered, capable of casually swatting aside either the Empire or Rebels.

However, dont be fooled. It is in of itself one of my favorite games of all time with ease, and I have been playing it for nearly a decade now on numerous computers, and for good reason. The space battles are the highlight of the game, and watching a Star Destroyer swarm obliterate a Rebel fleet is orgasmic. The strategic layer/ galaxy map portion is also strangely enthralling, watching a stack of Star Destroyers build up while you station AT-AT's on literally every planet of value, then some for shits and giggles. And finally, mods. So. Many. Mods. You do yourself a diservice not to play Republic at War, Thrawns Revenge, or EAW Remake, which has updated the graphics in space battles to more than easily match any modern standard for most people.

Overall, it has flaws, but this game is still one the very best Star Wars games out there, and for very good reason. Buy it. Do the tutorial and a few campaigns, maybe a few galactic conquests and skirmishs. Then mod it like its going out of style.

I've owned this game since it came out back in the day, and I've loved every minute of it. It has a fun mix of ground and space combat in the great Star Wars universe, with all the memorable units and characters from the films. It expands this roster with characters from the Star Wars expanded universe (now legends). 

The game has all the things that make it a good game and more, for the community has one of the most passionate modding communities out there, and thanks to the new steam workshop it is easy to install. So if you want to play with stormtroopers, rebels, clones or droids this game can offer it all. And let us not forget all the space ships from the films, or the... Death Star.

This is one of my favorite games, as it offers Star Wars on a galactic stage and you are the one you lead either side to whichever goal they might have, be it galactic peace and stability or freedom for all in the galaxy. 

And now with Disney taking over and actually bringing back multiplayer, we might see more of this game in the future, though that might just be wishful thinking.

So good luck and have fun, and may the force be with you...

This is one of my first reviews on Steam, although I've had this account for many years. If there was one game I would write a review for it would certainly be this one. Being a life-time Star Wars fan this game satisfies every need. I originally played this game on a crappy Windows XP computer in the disc version. Being fairly young at the time this game astounded me. Of course I didn't have a sense of what good graphics were at that time, but (as it does now) that hardly mattered. I could control the whole Galactic Empire?! I could blow up planets with the freaking Death Star?! The list goes on. Years later I bought Civilzation V (another classic) from my local Hastings. It required a Steam account so I went ahead and downloaded it. A year or two later I discovered that my childhood classic : Star Wars Empire at War FOC was on the Steam store. I purchased it as soon as I could. The nostolgia hit me like a brick. Later they fixed the Multiplayer and added a Mod Workshop. Great job Steam staff!
