I used to have the physical two disc copy of this game and regretted getting rid of it – but I found out that Steam carried it and promptly bought it again.  I have always enjoyed Star Wars, but I am not a super fan that loves everything unconditionally.  This game is dated, lacks gameplay variety, and is not really supported on account of it being over 10 years old.  I can easily kill time with it, but it is buggy and lacks the components that new users would want to see in an RTS even if they are willing to overlook the dated appearance of the game and excuse its other quirks.  

Despite its issues, and there are a fair number of them, the game is enjoyable; it has three decent campaign storylines, instant action battles, and custom Galactic Conquests maps.  There is modding available and the mods that still work give the game some variety and help the overall game longevity - if only a little.  The game sounds are all atypical of most Star Wars titles and are not seriously off-putting, your favorite characters appear at some point, and there is a decent selection of planets to conquer as well.

Overall, I enjoy this game – however I would discourage you from paying the full $20.  Even though it contains the game’s only DLC, the decade old duo (Vanilla game + Forces of Corruption) is not worth that much as there are newer triple AAA games with similar User scores going for $20 or less on Steam.  But if you really like Star Wars and/or there is a good sale going on I recommend you give this unique Star Wars RTS a try.

Make no mistake, the core of the game isn't the interplanetary management but the battles. The space battles reign supreme: decide where your big ships should attack, what enemy fighters should your fighters intercept, what critical points in that star destroyer should you focus your firepower first: the shields sounds always like the best option, but those laser turrets are about to destroy your expensive ships, and the hangar is constantly deploying more TIEs and the engine keeps the ship closer to your armada...
There are land battles too, which feel a little easy (there's a heavy limit on the maximun number of deployed troops on both sides).
From the Galactic interface you're deciding when are this battles happening. You construct buildings (factories and mining facilities), you raise armies and move them from planet to planet.

And that's it.
It doesn't have the complexity of Rebellion so it is easy to get the hang of it.
PD: Every singe time I finished a land battle with C-3PO & R2-D2 on it, I tried to separate them from the other troops in order to prepare for another mission, but the droids dissapeared. It happened every time. So after the battle I saved the game and then immediatly reloaded that game. Only way I found to keep my precious droids.

I bought this game because of the promise it held to live up to Star Wars Rebellion (SWR) as a new and improved version with added gameplay and modding capabilities. While I found the graphics to be much better (Early 2000's versus 1990's), the game lacked the depth of SWR. The characters are almost not needed. I won a game without touching them once. The land battles also lack any sort of strategy. The space battles, however, are absolutely beautiful and fun!! I enjoy playing the skirmishes. If this game could be redone with aspects of SWR along with fresh ideas similar to the Total War games, this game would gain an entirely new level. The redeeming aspect of this game is the fact that it is moddible and there are several great mods out there (battlefront commander being my favorite). 

In short, I would reccomend this game to any Star Wars enthusiast like me. There is a lot of interesting info along with the game which I appreciate. Get mods to ensure it is accurate to Star Wars canon, though.

Features: Space battles, Land battles, Zann's Rise To Power (FOC only), Galactic Conquest.
Over 20 maps, both Land and Space. 5 Maps for the Galactic Conquest. Pretty good plot for the 
Zann's Rise To Power. In the EAW (Empire At War, aka the orignal version) all features included above, save for the Zann's Rise To Power. That is replaced with either the Empire Campaign, or the Rebellion Campaign, both with their own plot and over-lapping time-lines. Also, in EAW, health and damage change. More health, and less damage. I warn you... Take the tutorial first. If you're playing FOC, It helps you understand how to play as he Zann Cortium. Hope this helps!

With all the fluff out of the way, the modding community is equally as amazing!
If you ever do consider picking up this game, check out the Clone Wars mod! It's like a whole extra game on-top of the existing purchase!

F*ck yeah! Petroglyph is here to resurrect one of the best RTS games ever.

[h1]Pros and cons![/h1]

[b]PROS:[/b]

-Space battles. Mmmm, the space battles! They're just so amazing. Build turrets here, deploy TIE-fighters there, wait for that f*cking piece of sh*t space station to finish the upgrade...

-Galactic Conquest - A gamemode where the players try to take control of the Galaxy by capturing planets. It's a bit confusing but fun when you get into it.

-Multiplayer is back!

-Modding support!

[b]CONS:[/b]

-Land battles are ok, but not very interesting. In other words, they suck.

-Only three factions: The Rebel Alliance, Galactic Empire and Zann Consortium. I wish there was more.

-The game doesn't have any stuff from the prequels.

[h1]Final score: B for Brilliant[/h1]

Worth playing if you're into RTS, or just Star Wars In general.

I got this game on disc when I was about 9 or 10 "back in the day" and played it for years. Then my best friend got it on steam and we had to do some manual patching wizardry and use third party software to play together. It was still one of the best games we've ever played, despite the headaches getting it working. Now they've updated it out of nowhere with multiplayer and workshop support. SO, allow me to share my experience and a few tips for some of you who may just now be discovering this old RTS masterpiece.

First, a quick overview. You've got the Rebel scum, the Super Pirate scum in the expansion, (admittedly they have some very fun toys such as the OP Driv-I mean Mass Drivers -- we'll get to that...) and everyone's favorite the glorius Galactic Empire. You battle in space and on land with fairly standard base-building RTS mechanics. In space you expand your space station and on the ground you build your structures in predetermined locations. You also capture neutral buildings with various functions in both modes. It's very straightforward. There's a Campaign, [a typical scripted RTS campaign from what I gathered from playing not that much of it] Skirmish, and Galactic Conquest, where you build all your buildings ahead of time from the galaxy screen and then once a battle takes place, you have to work with whatever you built up as your defense and garrison or whatever forces you brought as the attacker. Think Total War games. But still with the neutral buildings and turret emplacements to capture, and production buildings like the barracks will occasionally produce extra units for the defender. (if they built one, of course.)

...That wasn't so quick, but let's move on nonetheless. Here are some tips and general fun stuff about the three factions. This is (almost) all about space combat because I don't care much for the ground combat and avoid it whenever possible. Also some of it only applies to the Forces of Corruption version. It's better. Just play that one. :P

The Rebels have a wide variety of units available bla bla bla here's what you need to know: They have better small stuff. Their fighters and bombers tend to outperform Imperial counterparts. (especially if you micromanage X-Wings -- they can be told to fold and unfold their s-foils for speed or firepower. time it right to crush those Ties.) Their most outstanding unit IMO is the B-Wing. It is INCREDIBLY powerful against fighters and capital ships alike. They use rapid fire lasers and more proton torpedos per run than the actual bombers. They too can lock their s-foils and I suggest you keep them closed because they are very, very fast that way, and their firepower only goes down from *Ridiculous* to *Really Quite Good*.

TEH MIGHTY EMPIRE has STAR DESTROYERS. ...They also have Tie Defenders which are fantastic but are just a bit overshadowed by the B(roken)-Wings. But mainly they have the Victory class and Imperial class late game ships which are just beautiful. ALSO almost every Imperial capital ship (basically just not the interdictor cruisers) comes with a fighter compliment which replenishes throughout combat so long as its hangar bay survives. (did I mantion you can target subsystems of capital ships? You can target subsystems of capital ships.) They get AT-ATs too, which can just shit out Stormtroopers and wreck every other vehicle on the ground. (Yes the Rebels get snowspeeders. Yes they have tow cables.) BUT the BEST PART about the Empire is their Galactic Conquest endgame. At final tech level you can build the Executor (the giant fuck-off star destroyer from ep.5 and ep.6 that crashed into the death star if you're not a nerd) which can spawn INFINITE RANDOM TIE FIGHTERS (one at a time on a cooldown; it's not THAT broken) and THE DEATH STAR 2 WHICH CAN TARGET SHIPS, STATIONS, AND PLANETS. Tired of those pesky ground battles? Did the Rebels sneak in and re-capture the planet you rightfully conquered and oppressed? BLOW IT UP. WIPE OUT THEIR FLEET AND BLOW IT THE FUCK UP. Ten year old me was very happy when I discovered this feature. Can you tell?

The Zann Consortium (the badass pirates who are so badass they kill all the other pirates and think they can rule the galaxy) get all the (really) interesting units and features. Corrupt enemy planets and profit off of them in Galactic Conquest, revive Destroyer Droid production and steamroll enemy infantry, use cloaking technology to sneak into the middle of the enemy fleet and then self destruct them to death, or MASS DRIVERS Here comes the bit on MASS DRIVERS Do you have time to talk about our lord and saviour MASS DRIVERS??? Ahem. The Mass Driver is a weapon type just like Turbolasers and Proton Torpedos. Actually it's both. See, Turbolasers are the big conventional guns that go BANG BANG BANG BANG BANG et-cetera at some speed and pound enemies into dust. Proton Torpedos are big and slow and aren't fired very often, but they IGNORE shields and do ALL THE DAMAGE. Mass drivers are both. Seriously. They don't compromise; they aren't a hybrid. They are the best of both. They go BANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANGBANG STRAIGHT THROUGH SHIELDS AND OBLITERATE EVERYTHING ON THE OTHER SIDE. The guns are equipped in space on the Vengeance class Frigate, their super-capital, (basically their star destroyer or mon calamari cruiser equivalent) and their upgraded space station. On land they are THE BEST DEFENSIVE TURRETS AGAINST EVERYTHING and also are on a tank that also has shields which is the best tank in the game IMO. The DOWNSIDE is... well the Vengeance class doesn't have shields, and all their units are expensive. If you're a turtle player like me, this won't even phase you, but good luck rushing with them.

Well that took FAR too long but I hope someone sees this and at least has a good laugh. By the way, OBVIOUSLY Steam can't display my hundreds of hours with the disk version... you'll just have to take my word for it. ^_^ Cheers.

Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

Don't let my hours on record dissuade you in the idea that my opinion of this game has no merit. At first, I thought perhaps the nostalgia was the reason I would enjoy this game from a decade ago where I would spend every night constantly playing it. I would corrupt planets, conquer planets, and best of all destroy planets. This game was a legend for it's time and to this day remains my favorite strategy game of hands down. Now, in 2017 (over a decade from the original release), this game has been updated to allow myself and others who have always loved it, to continue to play online with friends and other members of this community, even adding mod support. Honestly, one of the most unbelievable things that has come about and is truly a mark of hope in this time of shitty devs. May all creators take note in the hard work that this game has went to thanks to the developers.

With the arrival of the Steam Workshop capability for the game and the resurgence of multiplayer capability, Empire at War has already become an even greater game. In Vanilla EAW + FOC you can command the forces of the First Galactic Empire, or the freedom fighters of the Alliance to Restore the Republic or corrupt and control the galaxy with the Zann Consortium. Additionally, in mods pertaining to the Clone Wars era, you could play as the Galactic Republic or as the Confederacy, or in TOR mods, fight as the Old Republic or as the Sith Empire, and many more options now available to you. The way you play is up to you. The choice is yours to command. In conclusion it is strongly recommended that you buy and play this game. You will not regret it I assure you.

Empire at war gold version comes with 3 campaigns, and a quite a little bit of single player content to play with. Personally I spent around 50 hours playing the base game which already good value for my money. Furthermore it has one of the best modding community, with plenty of excellent mods with add on to an already amazing game.

However, when I bought the game It lacked multiplayer which had been removed common for an old game and mods were difficult to install I could only get one to work, got around 30 hours out of it. Afterwards I thought it would be a game that just sat in my steam library never to be touched again.

To my surprise, multiplayer has brought back by the developer for the game which over a decade. But this was all, along side the release of multiplayer again is steam workshop support allowing us to really easy to get mods installed. Mods I once could never get to work can now run with a few simple clicks.

This shows what amazing developers this game has that are willing to go out of their way to create a experience for the player. 

Personally I think you will enjoy this game, if you love Star Wars or strategy games. For a such cost with so much content, it's basically a steal.

    [*] The Galaxy map looks good.
    [*] There is strategy needed on the Galaxy Map though.
    [*] Space Battles look good.
    [*] Hero's feel like Heros.
    [*] Abilities look neat.
    [*] Voice Acting is good.
[/list]

Lets go over its [i]short commings[/i]
[list]
    [*] Ground battles are usually boring.
    [*] There is no galactic conquest co-op mode.
    [*] WHY ISN'T THERE A GALACTIC CONQUEST CO-OP MODE?
    [*] No faction really feels unique.
[/list]

If there was a Galactic Conquest multiplayer mode this game would be better. It's a solid RTS that holds up today and requires thought about how to play on harder modes and on easier ones its quite the light show, Mods make the game much better and unique but any RTS fan should pick this up because it is fun and looks amazing.

Sorry for the short review but Empire at War doesn't have too many overly complex things or anything thats so bad it requires discussion. Everything it attempts to do it does right. Space Battles feel good and while ground battles take a bit too long they're not unbearable. I simply cannot talk about much because there isn't much to discuss about how good or how bad it is, it does what it tries to do and does it well. I can't talk about the story mode because its a side part of the Galactic Conquest mode which is superior and can be played for hours trying to push through the enemy in gigantic epic battles for control.

I suggest getting this game because its fun, its enjoyable, and throughout my childhood and even now i've spent a few thousand hours playing this game when my dad first introduced it to me when he Pirated it. Now i bought it because i love this game, it still holds up even today.

If you want to see gameplay I would highly recomend TheXPGamers Youtube channel, he uses mods but the gameplay is the same I bought this game after watching his videos. My review is just going to be random thoughts.

Tired of losing AT-ATs to rebel planets filled with pesky airspeeders and OP artillery? Use the Death Star to blow the planet up! 

Everything has a counter but most things aren't hard counters with some exceptions:
-Artillery (on the ground) is a little OP. They one-shot infantry and have huge range and large splash damage. Their laughable health means you can use some fast vehicles to take them out but they can be very annoying to deal with. 

-Infantry take forever to die, except vs artillery. This is something that mods fix but an infantry vs infantry fight lasts a silly amount of time IMO.

-Corvettes are a little too good vs bombers. If there is one in the general vicinity of your bombers they will die in like 2 seconds. The empire has a large supply of bombers but the rebellion has to pay for every squad...

I haven't played the expansion much but in the base game the two factions are very well done. As the empire you just use brute force. Units like the AT-AT and Imperial Star Destroyer have high health and damage but are rather slow. The rebels can do cammando raids and have to be carefull where they strike because they are weaker than the empire but most of their space units are much faster than comparable imperal ships.

Each battle (space or ground) is played out with time paused in the rest of the galaxy so you can really focus on your tactics or just use movie mode to watch the battle. There is no base you have to babysit and unit production is only done in galactic map view between battles. The models aren't very high-resolution but I still enjoy just watching the battle once I know I will win.

The mods out there are also great. Republic at war and Thrawn's Revenge are my favorites. (If you read the extended universe books Thrawn's revenge inclues lots of that stuff). Mods really spice things up but I would recommend playing the base game first. Thrawn's revenge fixes all of my above complaits but the AI isn't very good. Republic at War the Confederacy AI is infamously hard (it will focus fire and retreat damaged ships).

Speaking of AI, the AI in the base game is very competent most of the time, it will often rush you with corvettes to kill off your fighters which is really really annoying but a very effective strategy. It try to only attack you when it has a larger force and it builds up ground defenses on every planet.

It is possible to play multiplayer on GameRanger but I have yet to do it.

I bought the game on sale but I think it is worth full price.

Star Wars tries its hand at strategy. Why not? It's done pretty much everything else including a computer chess game I had as a kid. GIven the wealth of Star Wars lore, vehicles, soldier types, etc., it actually makes perfect sense to have a Star Wars real time strategy game.

In practice, however, I didn't feel like the game had enough of a tutorial, and to someone who wasn't super-skilled at RTS games, throwing the odd space combat/orbit stuff into the mix early on was incredibly confusing for me. I went back and tried it again a while back after I had stopped playing the disc version for a few years and got confused with that, only to get confused again with this version.

I could probably read up a bunch and figure it out, but as any of you with jobs or other games begging for your attention know, it's not worth my time to go research a game I haven't been having any fun with. This was a great idea, but better tutorials would have made this much smoother and make sense to me (hopefully).

This game is amazing. With this great game, you get to live out some of your Star Wars fantasies. Ever wanted to blow up a planet? Congrats, you can do it. Ever wanted to steal an AT-AT with Chewbacca? You can do it. Ever wanted to become the boss of galactic organized crime? You can do that too.

While the Vanilla version does get old after a while (pay no attention to my low play time on Steam, I used to have it on disc and easily have surpassed 1,000 hours), you can always check out the myriad of excellent mods that are available for this game, allowing you to experience the Clone Wars, the Old Republic Era, and the Post-Episode VI Era (the old Expananded Universe one). 

While the graphics are mediocre (I think there are some mods for that too), balance is basically unheard of, and there are a couple of minor bugs, this is still the ultimate Star Wars strategy game, and it definitely deserves a sequel or something. Overall, this game is defintely a 9.5/10. Buy it and you won't regret it. May the Force be with you.

P.S. Make sure you play the expansion version called Forces of Corruption (unless you actually want to play the Empire and Rebellion campaigns, which aren't that great), Steam considers it and the base game to be two seperate entities.

I can't really do a PRO and CON review for this game since i've only played thirty three minutes. But, this game... I've played half the tutorial and I just can't say I like it. In fact, i'm refunding it as I speak.  Its just too complicated for my tastes. But i'm not going to give it a negative review. I mean, this game has a lot of good qualities and content... I just can't morally make it a negative review.

Anyways, the game is obviously a RTS. I know plenty of people who don't like RTS style games, but this one should please those who do like them. Its got all the bases covered in an RTS and its Star Wars! So that's also a plus. And its DLC is sure to take more hours off of your life. But, like I said, its a complicated game. You'll learn that when you play its tutorial.

In the end, this game can please you, or it wont. It didn't please me, but that's my problem. If you enjoy complicated RTS style gameplay and if you enjoy the original Star Wars trilogy then this game is for you.... but buy it when its on sale..

However one of them has discovered a mod that contains the Eclipse Super Star Destroyer that fortunately yet unfortunately only has its axial beam.  I'm dreading it when he figures out how to use it for multiplayer if he can. I'd suggest this game to anyone who is a Star Wars or RTS fan.  I personally give it a solid 10/10.

Hello boys and girls Joker here, this review/guide is primarily made for those that have experienced issues getting this amesome game to run under Windows 7, 8 & 10.. I'm currently using Windows 10 (Windows 7 up intil 4 months ago) but i know it would probably work just the same.

So, let's begin shall we.. 
Let me just say that installing the game caused my system to give me some kind of error message stating that the game installation could not get the required update due to it being locked after not receiving full access etc? (Err, Wot..TILT?!)
Anyway, i figured it out by following a few simple steps! 
Step 1) Remove the contents from your library by first canceling the installation process and afterwards clearing the games cache (the game must be greyed out so to speak).
Step 2) Go over to your Windows Steam folder (Program Files x86, Steam, SteamApps, Common,..) followed by selecting the corresponding Star Wars EAW Gold file and deleting it accordingly.
Step 3) Restart your computer.
Step 4) Start Steam and install the game again, which should now work correctly..
Step 5) Start the game normally. 
Step 6) This next step is a bit tricky and will most likely cause your system to hang/freeze but you can easily fix that by restarting the system once more.. (No worries, just use crtl + alt + del and in case you can't fully use the task manager, simply 'force' the PC to quick restart without actually rebooting it.)
*So, let me discuss (Step 6) a bit further now. You would like to change settings to your personal choosing, so just set the game according to your optimal/automated settings. 
*Do not set the monitor settings to maximum just yet or it will be guarateed to crash (you can do that afterwards).
*Get into the game once more and you'll notice that your settings are now adjusted/adjustable..
In case your system would still crash, just repeat the previous steps and all will be working fine afterwards.
Step 7) Enjoy Star Wars EAW Gold!!! When done correctly give me a thumbs up guys, that's all i'm asking. :)

Now for my short review: 
I still have the original disc copies at home and i must have played both original copies for many, many years..
That's why i decided to buy them on Steam hoping i could still be playing and enjoying them here while using Windows 10. (and This version works perfectly even without the patches i needed "in the good old days" to be able to run the expansion, which i can honestly say is quite awesome)
I must say that i'm really pleased that for me at least it remains the same just the way it was all those years ago.
Therefore i can only recommed it with my own personal thumbs up and an additional score of 8.5/10 in my book!
It's still a great game, so why should i need to say more right?
For those that might still have some doubts, buy it when it's on 75% off sales, it's really worth it and if you think not, just refund it!

Peace out!

So I decided to make a review after I really really made my friend upset. So everyone says the Zann Consortium is horrible to play as and against, but I don't see it that way. After playing only fifteen minutes against my friend I managed to antagonize, defend and annihalate him while he was the empire. But I don't see the Consortium as overpowered as each of the ships have weaknesses that can be easily exploited and if smugglers are used by other factions the crdit amount gathered b the consortium can be dropped from a high amount of around 12,000 to 6,000. Now that is a lot of credits still, but each part of the Consortium requires Credits. Space stations, upgrades, even unlocking abilities of your units requires money. To stop the unlocking of abilities for the Zann Consortium, which without them would get decimated, you have to keep track of planets with Black markets and either stop their heroes or defilers from corrupting the planets. 

The original game itself is nice, but the multiplayer if there are any disconnection issues you immediatly get kicked out due to the games setup (Also you have to use Gameranger for multiplayer) So playing with the Forces fo corruption is beter as you have a timer before disconnecting. 

I also love playing as the Consortium, It was also fun to find out all of the abilities and tactics for the faction, all the while my friend laughing and enjoying the fact that I couldn't find the abilities for my ships and was destroying me. But now he is very very very very unhappy for the fact I can blowup the deathstar with IG-88 for a small sum of 50,000 credits, and I also figured out the abilites for my units, so now he gets really angry. 

I enjoy this game very much. (.....) hates the consortium and agrees with all the online reviews saying its evil and unfair. I just find a sense of FIGURING IT OUT. Yep. Thankyou. Also this probablly isn't a very good review........

I consider Star Wars: Empire at War and its expansion, Forces of Corruption, to be one of the best Star Wars games to date. We've had many excellent games such as Republic Commando, KOTOR, Star Wars Galaxies, etc. but this game lets you command fleets of ships and legions of troops in all out war against the enemy.

However the best part of this game for me is all of the mods that the community has created. Mods like Stargate, EaW Re, Clone Wars, KOTOR era, and so on have really extended the life span of this game for me. 

My only issue with the base game is the unrealistic unit scaling, but thankfully many mods fix this with more Star Wars accurate scaling. Seeing TIE fighters be tiny little dots compared to a Star Destroyer is a sight to see.

Once again, one of the best strategy games that does not receive enough attention. The gameplay never gets old, and you can get stuck playing for hours. It is very unique, as it does not feel like you are playing a copied game.

Star Wars Empire at war is a game that came out in 2006 and for a game that came out over a decade ago, it has aged amazingly. Well, as amazingly as an 11 year old game can. The Forces of Corruption Mod adds the Zhan Consortium to the already 2 existing factions, The Empire and the Rebellion. Already a great game, it really shines when you dip into the huge modding community the game has, Republic at War, Thrawns Revenge and Awakening of the Rebellion are 3 of my favorite mods for the game. They are total conversion games changing the time period of the game adding onto the gameplay experience for the price of a crappy free to play game on steam, free. Overall, even though the game is old it has a huge following and it has aged well, I would recommend it to anyone.

This is going to be a warning more than a review. I played many, many hours of this game as a kid and I bought it on steam because the Forces of Corruption expansion wouldn't install properly on my computer. This game installs and plays but let me warn you: SAVE OFTEN! Do not count on the autosave. I got some PTSD from the steam version after I played some hours in the campaigns. The game has some serious game breaking bugs. You may not get them, you will be lucky to get them 1 out of every 5 times you play the campaign. But when you do, you will want to tear your hair out. The one I got in the steam version (similar stuff happened on the disc version) was when I moved a character to do a mission within the time a scripted sequence was occuring in dialogue (IIRC) and he bugged out inside the planet. I needed him for the next mission but he was stuck in the planet. What's supposed to happen is you get your character back after a small period of time but that didn't happen. The autosave happened right after that so my save file is unplayable. SAVE YOUR GAME.

Edit: I decided to do a retrospective video on the game to provide more information: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0ZUdrCwy0M

The only thing I could ask of this game is that it gets opened on the Steam Workshop so mods could be more accessible and easier to use for this game. Otherwise it is really fun coming up with new plans to conquer the galaxy or corrupt it with the DLC.

Star Wars Empire at War is without a doubt an aging game. It's graphics are slightly poor, however the game easily makes up for this with its outstanding gameplay. The $20 of this game are easily payed back. Even if you aren't having the best experience in the game, the modding community offers many different modifications to enhance your gameplay. Unit files are extremely easy to modify so you can even bend this game to your personal taste.
Pros-
Great Gameplay
Excellent overall storyline (EAW)
Great support from modding community
Several different maps and game modes to choose from

Cons-
Slightly aging graphics

To sum this game up, it is a $20 pack of fun that will keep you playing hours on end!

This game is without a single glimpse of a doubt (if that even makes any sense)my favourite game.I got it when I was just 7 years old.I now have 33 games on my stem library and over 50 games (including my steam games) on my computer, and STAR WARS™ Empire at War is STILL my favourite game(I also have 27 games on my Ipad and 9 on my PS4).In case you are reading reviews to see how good the game is and how it is like, look no further.It is a RTS (Real Time Strategy(which means you are at a birds eye view and control your troops/ships))game which has 3 modes : Land Battles, Space Battles and Galactic Map. So, after having bought this game twice, I finally discovered how to play the Forces of Corruption side of the Gold Pack...through looking at the forums page. It seems that the desktop icon won't get you where you wanna go. Instead, you need to first right click on the game itself in your Library game list, and you should see it there. Once you've played the FoC side of the Gold Pack once, clicking the Play button inside the Library game list will allow you to play either Empire at War or Forces of Corruption. I truly hope this helps someone else, because this is something I was desperate to find out myself. Also, dont let the playtime fool you, I have played this game more then a fair amount before Steam...so much so that my CD no longer works, hence my desperation to play it here.

It seems the multitude of Star Wars games that have been released so far all have been a succes. Personally, I haven't heard much about Empire at War, but I decided to purchase it in the recent sale. I can say I don't regret the purchase one bit, as this game offers extremely well-made RTS gameplay, level design, characters, voice acting and graphics, for its time, being a decade old, this is one of the best Star Wars games I've played along with KOTOR, Republic Commando and Battlefront, it just offers so much perspective in the Star Wars universe and it goes back in time where games were made with passion and love, not only with greed and money in mind. The game is extremely easy to get into, and I highly recommend it to any Star Wars fan looking for a strategy game.

The game appears to have aged well, but it has fatal flaw. You can just sit a few minutes on fast game time and collect all the money you can possibly require. Losing a battle? Not a problem: just extract, build more weaponry with the free money and come back to finish off what you started. Hell, you don't even have to fight the battles; just click "auto-resolve" button and if you've built enough big ships with the free money, you've won!

I only played for 3.5 hours but I don't see any challenge or even goal in the game. Feels like a product made for people who get wet when they hear Star Wars sound effects than a game. So unless you find Darth Vader incessantly saying "I find your lack of faith disturbing" titillating, stay clear of this game.

God, I have so many childhood memories of this game and its expansion. To be honest, Forces of Corruption may as well be it's own game, but yeah here's the review.

GAMEPLAY
I mean, do i even need to say how good it is? Honestly if you are like me and LOVE instant action strategy games, this is THE game for you, even if you dont like star wars. Its easy to learn, somewhat hard to master certain strategies such as bomber-fighter hit and run and defence formations in space and on the ground. It definetly has given me countless hours of replayability.

GRAPHICS
Who cares about this anyway? ITS MOTHERF***ING STAR WARS!

On a serious note, the graphics are actually pretty nice for their time. 

MODDING
Countless amounts of mods are available for this game. personally I play with Absolute Corruption v2.4 for Forces of Corruption. Though, it sadly isnt possible to have multiple mods on at the same time, some Total Conversion are essentially entirely new games. So once you get bored of the base games, look for some mods, they are freaking awesome

The forces of corruption part of Empire at War requires a much different strategy when playing galactic conquest. As the empire you face off against the Rebellion and an Independent faction. That independent faction is very much over powered with their droid Hero IG-88 or something. He can sneak right past all your systems and take out the death star in one go. No warning, just a large boom and everyone on the same system as the death star is dead. Be very careful when using the Death Star. You can't rebuild it, but you also don't loose the game when it dies. You can loose any Hero infinite times and keep playing, but you can't rebuild the death star. I have to say it's disappointing when you've worked hard for it, then it disappears out of the blue. You can't stop IG-88 from blowing it up. It just happens. This is just a warning if you happen to read the reviews on here before you by the game.

An absolutely amazing RTS. In my 8+ years of playing this game I've never found anything that quite matches it.

It's like 'Risk+Age of Empires+Space Battles', and done wonderfully so. Only bad part is that a modern sequel is very unlikely unless the mouse house decides to revive it.

Also wish there was a steam workshop for this, seeing as how there's still a crazyily-active modding community for this game.

10/10, get this game if you enjoy Star Wars or just RTS titles in general.

I've played many RTS title, and this is one of those games (Actually only this game..) that really give me a goosebump on every aspect, like C'mon, huge space fleets battle around the planet orbit with a spectacular sounds that are the same like on the Star Wars movie, and see the battle through a cinematic perspective? 11/10 There are more other pros, just seek them by yourself, it's on sale right now. If you're a star wars fan and loves RTS series, this game worths every penny.

Pros (My opinion): 
-The real "Star Wars" simulation, if you've ever wondered "Is there any star wars game that I can play the whole universe in it, not just playing the jedi and doing some guns/lightsaber fight", this is the game for you.
-Amazing soundtrack 10/10 , feels like when you're watching the movie. 
-The RTS mechanic is not that simple (a Pro for me)
-Land and space battle (Yes, you control the space ship, even those big ships, you control it.)
-Death Star that you can control. 
-Main characters like C3P0, Obi wan, etc.
-Amazing mod communities add a replayable value to this game.
-Two campaigns, plus one with the DLC.
-There's skirmish mode too.
-The RTS mechanic is not dissapointing. (Like you can build a fighter ship that has the ability to "grap-hook attack" to make the AT-ATs fall down) 

Cons: 
-The multiplayer's kinda dead, even though you can still play through Gameranger

A great strategy game for Star Wars fans. From blowing up Alderaan to destroying the Death Star, space battles is where Empire at War thrives the most. The space battles are as good as most sci-fi, strategy games today. The ground battles are enjoyable, but not as enjoyable as games like Age of Empires 1 and 2. The campaigns are alright and do expand on the EU and some missions are really enjoyable. The Galactic Conquest mode is probably the best gamemode for Empire at War because it allows you to build the Death Star as the Empire and yes you can blow up planets. You can also conquer planets from the movies, like Tatooine and Coruscant. The expansion pack even takes the game further, by adding a new faction and allowing the Empre and the Rebellion the ability t build new ships like Darth Vader's Super Star Destroyer (Galactic Conquest only). Also, the mods for Empire at War expand the galaxy even more. Empire at War is a great game for Star Wars and strategy games fans everywhere and I highly reccomend it to anyone reading this.

The only Negative i can think of is that mods can be probelmatic and rage-indusing for beginners because there are sometimes hiccups in installion 

Final verdict 9.9999999/10

One of the best Star Wars games currently on sale, gives access to lots of different units and combat abilities, allowing for epic ground and space battles, well balanced factions, will you take down the Rebelion with the Empire, of liberate the galaxy from the tyranny of the Empire, or even take over the Zann Consortium and corrupt the entire galaxy This game brings real time stratagy to a new level, it is fully modable with lots of mods freely avalible.

This game has both a single player campaign and a galactic conquest with different goals and tech levels, along with the ability to have all three sides fighting in a single player skirmish in a massive 1v1v1 space or land battle.

If you are a Star Wars fan or just love real time strategy games, I would highly recomend this game.

This game is a must for strategy and Star Wars fans, While the base game (and FoC) are great and fun games in their own right, the real reason this stands out is the amazing mods the community has made. Here are two I would highly reccomend.

Republic at War: Puts you in th clone wars era, difficulty is definately raised here, somewhat unbalanced but really doesn't take away from the experience.

Thrawns Revenge: This is my personal favorite for many different reasons, There 5(or 6?) factions and most of them are playable, It adds a metric assload of new units (Both space and ground), its very well balanced and challenging, and it changes up the combat in some neat and good ways.
Godly

This is one of my favorite games ever. The Space combat is hands down the most enjoyable part of this game and it feels like I'm partcipating in a Star Wars space battle. The Ground combat is a very slow and does not feel very natural it is very hard to control anything. While there is alot in the base game and its expansion Forces of Corruption the real fun comes with the insane amount of mods that the community has created for it. They come in many ways for example if you love just the base game but wanted more ships and ground units then getting Absolute corruption which adds countless ships to each side and adds units to ground combat to make it less annoying. However if you want a total conversion then there are two mods I would point to, they are Republic at War and Thrawn's Revenge. They each put the game into different Eras of Star Wars and do very unique things to the game that makes it feel completly different. This is one of the best Star Wars games that you can get right now.

Overall this game is fun to play. I haven't had too much time to play it, but let me explain the pros and cons. I apologize if I forget anything.

Pros:
-Space and ground combat
-Modding community
-Campaigns or simple galactic conquest (I prefer the latter)
-Gungan genocide
-Non-CPU intensive
-Multiple "galaxies" for Galactic Conquest
-Tech advancement (allows for you to properly build up your forces over time)
-Heroes (it's satisfying launching a huge clone invasion on bomis koori 4 and killing darth sidious (mod))
-Can get groups using Ctrl + 1-9

Cons:
-If you don't press "attack move" (basically move but they'll engage targets) they won't engage targets
-You have to micromanage everything
-Stability is a little whacky on newer platforms (I personally have only had the game freeze for a few seconds)
-Graphics are shit
-Can't rotate around the battlefield, which makes some maps (mostly mods) hard to play in
-Multiplayer doesn't work (can probably get it to work using evolve or hamachi)
-Unit prices don't seem realistic
-Can be hard to manage all information
-AI does some dumb shit (attacking high level space stations with ground units in transports)
-Auto resolve always puts the enemy in favor

Overall, really fun game with great mods.

This is, in my humble opinion, the greatest Star Wars strategy game of all time (and the second-best Star Wars game after Star Wars Battlefront II). I'll give you a quick overview and then launch into a more detailed breakdown of the various pros and cons of the game. (And check the bottom of this review for a couple of handy links)

Quick overview; The game is a grand strategy game, based in the Galactic Civil War period (but mods can be used to get the Clone Wars, or the aftermath of the Battle of Endor or pretty much any other time period). There's a campaign for both the Empire and the Rebels (and the Zahn Consortium if you have the gold pack), or skirmish battles (land or space) and Galactic Conquest. The campaigns can take a while, and there's huge replayability with Galactic Conquest and skirmishes... you won't get bored easily! The graphics are the biggest downside, but for a 2005 game they've aged quite well. Land units are undeniably blocky, but the space fights (relatively unaffected by graphic because ships are blocky anyway) look remarkably good for an 11 year old game.

Pros:
The space battles are the jewel in Empire at War's crown. No game before or since had managed to capture the magic of Star Wars space warfare so perfectly. There's even a 'Cinematic' option that hides the HUD and views the battle as if it were a film.

The Galactic map spans the entire galaxy - all the planets from the canon films and many more. All of them have their own beautifully detailed land and space maps, and many have local life (eg. Wookies on Kashyyyk) who aappear on the land battle and, depending on their circumstances, will fight for either the Empire, Rebels or Zahn Consortium.
The game manages to give each faction not only unique units, but also a unique gameplay without giving any one side an insurmountable advantage. For example, obviously the Empire has Star Destroyers to the Rebel Mon Calamari cruisers, but the Empire gains technology by building research labs, and the Rebels gain it by sending R2-D2 and C-3PO to steal it from the Empire. The Zahn Consortium has various criminal methods at their disposal - such as bribery and extortion - to compensate for their weaker spaceships and (debatably) weaker land units.

The campaign is fairly extensive, and the Galactic Conquest means virtually infinite replayability. The skirmish also means you can easily hop straight into a battle without having to build up tech or anything first.

Heroes. Ah, heroes. Both sides have all the main characters from the original triliogy; Lord Vader, Luke, Leia etc, but also have some more minor heroes, such as General Veers and Captain Antilles. There are also a few from the Extended Universe, such as Mara Jade (the Emperor's hand) and the Zahn Consortium have quite a few bounty hunters (IG-88, Bossk etc). Each has unique powers and some have unique disadvantages (the Empire cannot retreat from any battle if they have Grand Moff Tarkin "Evacuate?! In our moment of triumph? etc)

Grand Strategy - the campaign and Galactic conquest have a heavy emphasis on the grand strategic overview. You have a population cap, and you need to decide how your planets will be defended. Will you have huge defenses over a select few worlds and all but ignore the others, risking losing them to even a small enemy force? Will you have only a few infantry on each  planet, relying on your massive fleets to stop any enemy incursions? Each planet also provides a unique bonus, so some  planets will be more valuable than others - while some will be vital because they are on a hyperspace lane and if you can hold that planet nobody can get to your core worlds.

The Death Star. You won't get this until late in the Imperial campaign, but there are few endgames as sadisfying as literally destroying the few planets yet hiding rebel fighters one by one until the Empire reigns supreme over the galaxy.

Cons:
Land battles. They are very 2005, I'm sorry. There's no getting around it. This game has lots going for it, but nobody plays it because of the terrific land battles. They are somewhat like the battles in Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds (remeber that Age of Empires rip-off?). The graphics are forgivable, but the most annoying thing is you can't build your own base. You can only build on pre-designated build pads, which kind of damages the flexibility of the game.  The good news is they are generally skipable, aside from a few campaign battles.

Multiplayer. If that's your thing, I'm sorry, but once again, old age is hurting this game. As of May 31, 2014, online functionality, including network multiplayer and wireless chat is no longer available due to Glu Mobile purchasing GameSpy and shutting down all game servers. Hey, there's still mods being developed, so the community is far from dead.

The gameplay can be a little frustrating at times, and the AI often appears to be nigh-omniscient during Galactic Conquest. But really, is a challenging AI that bad a thing?


Summary:
As you no doubt have figured out, I love this game. To rehash what I said at the start, it is by a long shot the best Star Was RTS out there, and the way games are going these days, it probably will be for a long time to come. The space battles and the 'grand' part of 'grand strategy' really define the greatness of this game.  Buy it. Buy it now. I promise if you're a Star Wars fan (or even if you're just a casual RTS fan) you won't regret it.

To make things simple for myself I'll list things off as pros and cons. I've had a 1000+ hours playing this game, before getting the digital copy, and so I hope it'll help convince you to try this game out.

Pros:
-Easy to learn
-Multiple scenarios and skirmishes 
-Enough units for variety
-Immense amount of mods to extend game's life
-Easily identifiable heroes and villians from the movies
-Graphics great for the time created, decent still.
-Features land and space battles separately, makes you plan accordingly what to bring for both.

Cons:
-Story is short, may leave you a bit unsatisfied if you go too fast
-Tiny community now leaving multiplayer to be almost rare
-If you stayed vanilla, you greatly risk losing interest after maybe a good week's worth at least of gaming.
- Music is kinda repetitive and may make you wanna mute it after a while

Neutral:
-Galactic Conquests can take forever, it's reward being subjective
-As far as RTS games go, it's pretty standard aside from land and space scenarios

TL:DR The game was fantastic when it came out however it did not age well but if you want a good Star Wars RTS this is it.

-The Galactic conquest mode was fantastic for it's time, a real-time X4 type of game in which you have to manage armies, fleets and planets in order to grow and conquer your enemy. Story mode took place pre Episode 4 until the end of Episode 4 (this was before Rogue One and everything got retconned by Disney)

The space battles were great, large ships were split into different hardpoints (weapons, shield generator, engine etc...) so you can focus on which ever target in order to give it a negative effect after it's destroyed. And all the fighters were in dog fights when they approach another squadron of fighters. (However it's hard to tell if you're winning or losing those dog fights.) 

The mods for this game were fantastic, mods that included new races like the CIS and clone troopers, to new ships and units for exisiting factions.

Some maps (ground and space) and special points on them that you must go near to capture them, points like Abandonned Factories, Sensor Pods, Communication Array, turret points, Hutt Palace, etc... each brings an advantage to the owner of the point.

So the issues now:

-For land maps there's a pathing issue with every map, meaning units can get stuck while moving. This is especially true in long skirmish matches.

-RTS games were never visually appealing but there's something off about looking at ground unit models that have triangular shapes. Even Darth Vader looks to funny to take him seriously.

-If the Rebels can reach Tier 3 in a skrimish match it's pretty much game over as their T-4B tanks are juggernauts that can't be beat, even with AT-ATs and Darth Vader. Basically the game is unbalanced at that point.

-There is no online community anymore so unless you have friends to play with, you'll only get this for the single player.

-The AI in the Galactic conquest mode is a bit... silly. They will send a fleet of rebel transports without protection into your Imperial controlled space (space station and whatever ship you have stationned there.) And then will attempt to flee after the map loads. Vindicator cruisers with gravity well generators can prevent them from escaping... meaning they just lost an army because they decided not to bring ships to protect them...

Years later, Empire at War continues to be a great RTS game in general. Three campaigns (across both the standard edtition and Forces of Corruption) and Galactic Conquests give the game a lot of meat for your time. As my first time playing the Forces Of Corruption expansion (didn't have it back then), it was quite fun to take control of a faction that isn't Rebels or Imperials, even if it is slightly unbalanced. FOC also adds new heroes for the old factions, giving a reason to keep playing through Galactic Conquests and the like.

The graphics are arguably the game's worst aspect and the performance isn't always up to snuff when running at double speed (which you'll need because this game suffers from grindy battles quite frequently), but these aren't deal breakers.

If you love Star Wars and the entire franchise, then that is absolutely wonderful; however, this Star Wars RTS game doesn't feel like a true RTS. It lacks that simple enjoyment that you get when playing similiar games like Warcraft, Age of Empires or Total War. It just lacks those features and replaces them with a complete automated system. You can't place your own buildings where you would like them, they are done for you. Getting resources? Automatically done. All you do is upgrade and build troops while conducting a small micro deployment here and there in terms of reinforcements. I've seen far much better with competitors, save your time and money. Just stick with the non-gaming franchise and go watch the movies and collect memorabilia! I didn't enjoy this game and regret buying it!

Luke, did I ever tell you these were your father's droids? We went on wild adventures together for over 3 years in the Clone Wars, and the little one even saved me from a swarm of buzz droids, yet I somehow don't recognize them anymore. They were good friends.
Luke, did I ever tell you that while your father was training on Coruscant, C-3PO served your family (Uncle Owen, Aunt Beru, Grandma Shmi, Grandpa Cliegg) for nearly 10 years? Somehow, your uncle didn't recognize Threepio when he returned to family's service.
Hey Luke, did I ever tell you that all Jedi used to dress like homeless moisture farmers the same as I do, despite that still dressing like a Jedi is no good way to hide from Empire? It was a good robe though.
Come here, Luke, today we will be training with this practice droid while you wear this helmet to blindfold yourself. You would think this was an impromptu training procedure, but no, we did this to younglings all the time and even built them special mini helmets. Right now you are literally worse than a child, Luke, like the ones your father killed with that lightsaber you are holding. He was a good friend.
You must go to Dagobah, Luke, and seek out Yoda, the Jedi Master who trained me — well, actually, he's A Jedi Master who trained me. Before I moved up to Liam Neeson's service, I was one of the 20 younglings who went to Yoda's class every tuesday and thursday back in youngling school inbetween Jedi chemistry class and lunchtime. Nothing remarkable or mystic to our relationship at all. He was just my teacher who handed out droids and youngling-sized helmets to the class. Also, all his deep seemingly spur of the moment lessons and teachings from a true master are all fairly common Jedi sayings that he just butchers with his ghetto way of talking. A good friend, he was.

Having completed all three campaigns and one game of conquest my worst fears are confirmed. EAW is an RTS hybrid that tries to be many things but is tripped by technical issues, bad design decisions and a clear lack of testing. The end result is a game that is mediocre at best and only held together by the magic glue that is Star Wars. Only recommended for fans who are willing to suck on a lollypop made out of pure salt just because it's shaped like Darth Vader's helmet.


+Authentic Star Wars music and sound effects that leave nothing to be desired. Sometimes even the voice acting is surprisingly good
+Graphics seem fairly timeless with some space battle effects still looking pretty sweet
+Space battles are fun most of the time
+Asymmetric factions (Empire has bigger ships with free fighters, Alliance has better fighters that require no carriers etc.)
+Multiple campaigns and conquest mode scenarios
+Dropping the screen filling Executor in the middle of a battle for the first time should make any nerds inner fascist climax immediately

-Doesn't seem to play nice with Win10 and has no borderless window support. If played fullscreen while Alt-Tabing can put your Windows in a state where you have to reboot to get anything done. I recommend running it in a maximized window instead.
-Game breaking bugs include disappearing critical characters, inability to task units to campaign critical missions, disappearing units etc. These issues can be somewhat circumvented with furious saving. [b]Always save to a new file![/b]
-A multitude of UX issues that range from fighters needlessly blocking capital ships from selection to the way save files are handled: latest saves don't always show up first, save files take too much space etc.
-AI blatantly cheats both by its very nature and also seems to gain scripted fleets out of nowhere for the campaigns
-AI sometimes just freezes and does nothing with its ships in battle
-Unit AI is atrocious and does not seem to do any target prioritization whatsoever for any attacks. Pathfinding gets progressively worse with unit size to the point where units like AT-ATs, artillery units and Star Destroyers sometimes require near constant micromanaging so that they move the way you need
-Being unable to assign any movement orders on the galactic map in pause mode makes no sense
-Forces of Corruption doesn't integrate to the main game and is actually a separate game that feels like it was cheaply hacked together in a hurry
-While the original EaW is somewhat balanced, the Consortium faction in FoC is completely out of whack and seems to have the best in almost everything in addition to their frustrating corruption mechanic that requires constant fiddling especially from the opponents
-Ground battles are usually horrendously repetitive and tedious
-Battles can be autoresolved, but the logic for resolving them is completely ludicrous and can lead to massive casualties even if the opponent doesn't actually have any chance of fighting back
-Very limited amount of units and ships in a battle at any given time (for example, you can have 6 Imperial class Star Destroyers if you have almost nothing else) and the rest have to be drip-fed into the battle as reinforcements when previous units are destroyed
-Player can't choose which units enter a battle first in EaW (mostly fixed in FoC though)
-Flying units can't actually fly over many obstacles in ground battles
-Some of the writing and voice acting is very cringeworthy especially in FoC. A few characters also use quotes from the movies to a ridiculous degree even for fanservice
-The Alliance can commit genocide without any issues and can actually get more funds from it

I'm writing this review at the tale end of 2016, I still play this game regularly, and there is a very good reason for that. I am hopeful that with the uptick in Star Wars everything with the new episodic series and the Star Wars Stories series that another Star Wars real time strategy game; until then, Empire at War reigns supreme. To start with, the original Empire at War in this pack, it is an in depth yet user friendly real time strategy game that allows you to build massive fleets and land armies with limits for space and land battles so you don't lose track of your units in battle. The game has three modes; story/campaign, skirmish and galactic conquest. The story allows you to choose the Heroic Rebel Alliance or the Fearsome Galactic Empire through many unique missions that allow you to explore the unsung battles of the galactic civil war. This game mode yields to the Galactic Conquest mode which is very similar to the Campaign but without the special missions and cut scenes. This is my personal favorite mode because it allows you to run through the whole galaxy and conquer it for your favorite faction. In this mode, you have to balance the logistics of limits to your troops, money to pay for new units and for developing conquered planets. You work your way up in the tech tree to unlock the more advanced and powerful units and buildings in the game. The Empire and Rebellion have dramatically different capabilities as well; different enough for their strategies are challenging to master but very well balanced. For example, the rebellion can launch special land invasions on Imperial planets called raids that bypass the orbital fleet and if the rebellion is successful then the empire loses that system no matter how good their orbital defenses are. The Empire on the other hand can build the death star that can of course destroy enemy planets. It must have a fleet to defend it while it gets into range and within a few minutes of a space battle, it can fire and destroy the planet. The balance here is that the rebellion can destroy the death star for an automatic win, regardless of the state of the map so the empire is forced to spend many resources defending the Death Star. The final game mode is the skirmish mode that allows the player to engage in a single land or space battle. All units are purchased from the base or space station unlike the previous modes. This mode is great for a quick battle to learn a map, play with units the way you want or simply cut your teeth on new strategies. Unfortunately, the servers for this game have been off for a long time but you can use game ranger to play with your friends who own the game. With the vanilla game covered, I'll briefly cover Forces of Corruption. This add on adds a completely new faction with its own campaign. The unique thing about this circumstance is that it is in the extended universe and has many non-canon units, characters and missions. The Zann Consortium is a criminal syndicate to rival the Hutt gangs and in the campaign builds itself into a formidable faction in the galaxy. It uses underhanded techniques such as sabotage, piracy and other abilities to advance its tech tree and earn credits in the galactic conquest mode. It uses a mix of different ships to form its fleets all with their own unique roles and powers. They add another player faction to the multiplayer as well and is a DLC that adds serious content to an already wonderful game. Overall, this game is king of Star Wars RTS and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys both.

TLDR: Poor man's Command & Conquer, But still worth playing if picked up in a sale. 

After Initially not particularly enjoying this game and writing a review to reflect this, I decided to continue playing in the hope that this game would improve if i gave it a chance. After a lot of restarts coupled with a lot of trial & error, I finally got to the point where winning a game of galatic conquest seemed viable. 

Now for anyone reading this review, I still contest that this is indeed a poor man's Command & Conquer, It's strategy aspects are about as deep as a puddle, with what is ultimately a glorified game of rock, paper, scissors. 

All games effectively play the same, capture a few systems, build up planetary defences whilst you wait for your credits supply to build up, position ships on key systems to prevent raids and keep building units to defend systems from incursion. then you simply build 2 or 3 fleets, and 1 large ground assault force, attack with the fleet to clear the atmosphere, then land troops and auto resolve, rinse and repeat until you win the war. 

One aspect I did enjoy however, is the very simple idea that destroying the enemy team's mascot ends the game, for example if you destoy the fleet with the emperor abaord a star destroyer it's game over, same with destroying the death star or killing mon-martha.
Played since '06. This game has aged very well.

The ultimate Star Wars strategy game.  Build bases on your planets and prepare to conquer the galaxy!  Participate in massive battles, bring in reinforcements (including your favorite characters like Rogue Squadron and Admiral Piett's Executor), and wipe out your opponent's space defense.  Then send your forced to capture the ground base, bringing it more reinforcements (incluing heroes like Emperor Palpatine and Luke Skywalker), call in bombing runs and bombardments from your crusiers in space, and capture the planet as you please.

Also includes autobattles, in case you get tired of micromanaging every battle.  Each of the factions also plays quite differently, adding even more playable hours to the game.

This is a fantastic, classic RTS game. There is an alarming lack of star wars titles with interactive space and land battles. This game fills the void and with an active modding community its hard to get bored. I reccomend total conversion mods such as "Republic at War", "The Clone Wars", and "Thrawn's Revenge." It does show its age with the AI issues, and the pathfinding on some worlds leaves much to be desired. However, this game is one of my all time favorites  and you would be missing out on a classic.

With the music and the sound of Turbolasers firing as Tie fighters fly around, intercepting the Rebel X-wings, while the Y-wings go after the capital ships, this game is to me pretty much Star Wars ASMR.

Playing this game as the Empire makes me realize how utterly impossible the Rebellion could ever win in the original Trilogy if the Empire were using proper strategies. 

As soon as the Death Star II was constructed, it started blowing up every outer rim planets, space stations, any capital ships (If that stupid idioitd Ackbar put his big-arse ship in the fight, he will be the first to get blownn up before he realized that he's in a trap). By the time the 5th planet was destroyed. I cannot fathom how these stupid rebels can still have the will to fight, they have become "the problem", every planets they planted their bases were blown up, Realistically, any planets will quickly reject these stupid rebels and their hopeless cause, else they risk being annihilated. 

But since this is a game, the Rebels, in their blind persuit to restore their stupid and flawed as fucked "Republic" kept retreating into other outer planets (they didnt even have the balls to take one of the core worlds), this resulted in every outer rim planets being annihilated down to the last planet...and that ONE planet they retreated was ironicially..Korriban, the birth place of the original sith pure-blood.

The Emperor did not wish to destroy this once sacred world, simply ordered the alternative. Every fleet, every military units in every star system in the galaxy were ordered to travel above the orbit of Korriban to show these pathetic rebels who couldn't learn to just get along and admit that the Empire is the new order who actually brought peace, that their cause was a delusion long lost.

Mon Mothma, along with the rest of the remaining rebel heroes and ONLY a single platoon of infantry left (Everyone else had pretty much died or abandoned them) watched the sky as over 70 star destroyers, more than hundreds of AT-AT, AT-ST, Artilleries, thousands of stormtroopers assaulted their last base (Which now cosists of only a barracks and a light factory).

Luke, Obi-Wan and Yoda died in a fight against his royal majesty the Emperor himself, Lord Vader and Boba Fett. The traitors such as Han were being demolished by Colonel Veers's army. Chewiee tried to hijack something but died to TIE-Bomber bombardment, wookies don't win this one.

Finally, Mon Mothma was humiliated when the Emperor added the final insult to injury by ordering a single dismounted Scout Trooper to shoot the barracks she hid inside until it exploded. Finally causing the end to this stupid pointless rebellion that caused over 30 worlds to disappear from the galaxy map when they could have just surrendered ages ago.

While all this happened, Tyber Zann's plan was ultimately foiled because Ryloth, the planet he was on, was thought to be a Rebel world and got blown up along with the planet, the Consortium died long before they even ever got their first capital ship built (Palpatine was getting annoyed these rebels wouldn't give up so he simply ordered the Death Star II to just flew randomly to any non-imperial controlled worlds until the entire galaxy is marked blue)

Personally, I absolutely LOVE Empire at War. While I do have a few quirks about some aspects, such as the mortars/ missile launcher vehicals the Rebels love (every goddamn battle I fight on land has those damned mortars and they really crush all of my nefarious plans!) Aside from that one particular unit, the only other problem that I've been facing is that the screen will move when you don't want it to. Gets pretty annoying when you're trying to get Darth Vader or a battalion of Stormtroopers to a specific location or kill a specific target when the screen's moving all willy nilly. Other than those two quirks, I'd say that this is a very great, well made representation of the Galactic Civil War in the form of a well balanced RTS game. The Rebels stick to hit and run tactics, and can really take any Imperial defenses by surprise early game while the Imps will lead full on invasions against Rebel held worlds and the Consortium.... Eh. Don't care much for a gang of criminals that much. Aside from repurposed CIS Battle Droids, they're really no threat to either faction until late game. I'd rate this game 10/10 for stealing my love for Star Wars back. May the Force be with us all.

This game fits perfectly into the Star Wars genre of games. It's like Battlefront 2 from an rts perspective  which I find to be very cool.  Even if you don't like the whole galactic civil war theme or you want to experiance something from legends, there is a plethora of mods on moddb that covers almost every part of the canon and the eu. Now the price can a bit a high regularly, so I would wait for a sale when it goes down to five dollars. But all in all, I would absolutely recommend this game to any rts fan, or Star Wars fan alike.

Probably one of the best Star Wars games ever made, if you are into Strategy.

Love the space battles, lasers and pew pew of the movies? Check.
Ever wanted to command a fleet of Star Destroyers? Check.
Ever wanted to show the full power of a fully operation battle-station? Check.
Want to lead a ragtag group of Rebels to victory? Check.

While the expansion had a fun story, the 'corruption' mechanic is often debated as to whether it was beneficial or detrimental to the flow of the game. However, the game really shines with MODS.

Want to lead the Republic to victory against the Separatists? Mod for that.
Want to lead the New Republic to victory against the hidden fleets of Thrawn and the Imperial Remnant? Mod for that.

This is, honestly, one of those games that never gets old, but is screaming for a modern re-make and/or sequel.

This is one of the best stradegy games I own. Right up there with Total War: Rome 2 and Age of Empires 3. Why? Because:

1. I am a big Star Wars fan. I have seen all of the Star Wars movies atleast 3 times.

2. It has everything you need and want from a scifi stradegy game: It has space action, land action, different troops that are good for different situations. It actually tells you what the units do. Like in Total War: Rome 2 the game tells you "Yeah, this is a spear unit. Guess what it's good for." Obviously it's good against horses, thats obvious but what about the other units? I don't know what is the best counter for an elephant from 2 000 years ago. But this game, it tells you EXACLY what it's good for. Like saying: "Here, dumbass, look, bomber is good against slow moving targets like this this and this. Also, these things counter it." It tells you 3 units that it's good against and 3 units it's not good against.

3. A great storyline. Sure, it feels rushed at times and forced but the quality voice acting combined with the "I am the most powerful person in the galaxy. Now hold and drag this unit here.", makes it a great experience. It is a both a tutorial and a great story at the same time. Feels like Sly 2 on PS2. Oh the good DLC-free no-microtransactions times...

4. It screams Star Wars. It has rancors, Darh Vader, fitting music, Admiral Ackbar and the Death Star. It has everything you wished from a Star Wars game. (you can also blow up planets with the Death Star! CAN YOU BELIVE IT!?)

5. Okay a few complaints now: The Death Star is the second Death Star, I understand that it looks good, but why isn't it finished? It looks just like the one from Return of the Jedi. But in RoTJ it was not finished. Now I am attacking with an unfinished Death Star and throwing it around the entire galaxy? Come on man, build it first. Also, there is a bug when you destroy a planet that has Han Solo and Chewbacca, the game crashes. The makers, Petroglyph Games still exists so why haven't they fixed this HUGE bug? Come on, the last update was in 2009. Come on. Fix your game before saying good bye.

But overall it is a satisfying experience to any Star Wars fan. If you don't like Star Wars, you can skip this one. There is nothing much to offer to people who don't like Star Wars or scifi.

This game CAN be played multiplayer, through GameRanger or some other external service.

As for the game itself... well. Empire at War, I would say, stands as my favorite Star Wars game, since it combines an infamous franchise with a beloved genre, and their child is beautiful and healthy. That child is Empire at War.

EaW and Forces of Corruption (FoC) are both rather uniform in regards to gameplay. In EaW, you can play as the Rebels or the Empire; same goes for FoC with the addition of a third party of pirates and criminals. The basic premise of the game is in conquering the entire galaxy by force alone; to do so consists of two separate stages: a space assault with fully customizable fleets, and a ground assault on terrestrial defenses. Once both have been met with success, the planet is yours, along with whatever bonuses it provides. Another "hidden" bonus with capturing certain planets is that you can cut off hyperspace lines, or to simplify it, place roadblocks that would prevent your enemy with combining his forces, since he can't pass through planets unless they're either neutral or allied. For races, I suppose, counting Forces of Corruption; you have three different choices that have their own benefits and quirks, but can ultimately be played the same way, or however you'd want them to. 

First up is the Galactic Empire (or just "the Empire"), and no different from the rest of its appearances in Star Wars, the Empire has a fetishistic love for firepower and big guns. The Empire has a VERY strong Navy and Army that deliver a serious wallop at the tradeoff of a considerable cost. Most of their best weaponry is unlocked in the fourth and fifth/final tech tiers, which gives the Rebels and the Zann Consortium plenty of time to strike at leisure.

The Rebel Alliance (or just "the Rebels") don't match the Empire in terms of raw strength, and their tech tier development is dependent on that of the Empire, but what the Rebels offer in exchange is more flexibility and diversity. For example, the Empire's Star Destroyers have automated hangars that automatically deploy TIE fighters/bombers as the battle goes on (unless the hangar is destroyed), but their shield generators are exposed to enemy fire. The Rebels' cruisers have internal shield generators that can't be destroyed (but the shield can still be knocked out), but no hangars - to compensate, you can specifically build whatever bombers and fighters you need, and how many you need; also, you can deploy them whenever and wherever you'd like, as opposed to the Imperials, where you're caught in a waiting game for what could potentially be what you are or are not in need of.

Added in the expansion, the Zann Consortium is what I can only describe as "parasitic", in that the bulk of their strength comes from that of their enemies; allow me to explain. The Zann Consortium has a tech tier that, for the most part, is based on stealing technologies and credits from the Empire and the Rebels, and in certain cases can actually acquire units from those two factions. One of my favorite features of the Zann Consortium is their ability to enslave races on certain planets, meaning you can get Ewok suicide bomber units, where a guy with a whip forces Ewoks out of a burlap sack and they charge at an enemy with a bomb strapped to them. It's extremely easy to play as the Zann Consortium, and they are brutally overpowered (their method of destroying the Death Star whenever it shows up is what can only be described as "cheap and effortless"), though it does take a bit of a learning curve. 

As far as game modes go; both Empire at War and Forces of Corruption share the same modes, of a singleplayer campaign; a single-or-multiplayer Galactic Conquest mode which is the main course of this excellent game; or basic "skirmish" battles that can take place on land or in space, and better units are issued as time goes on. Empire at War contains singleplayer campaigns for the Empire and the Rebels; Forces of Corruption only contains a campaign for the Zann Consortium.

I really like the game, but there are 3 major things that make me mad about the game, the difficulty, the Corruption, and the lack of maps. I will explain the three in this review.

The difficulty has a major jump of difference from normal to hard. Normal being super easy if you can build up and defend yourself for like 50 days and hard being just a pure fucking headache. The Empire and Corruption just team on me on hard and just keep on sending excesively huge armadas just like 5 days in the game. And it's so hard to spam out mining facilities when A. they're being blown up and B. you have to make a shit ton of space units to defend. 

The Corruption is horrifically overpowered. Being able to "Corrupt" plants. After being corrupted, you can either slip through the planet's defences and go to another enemy planet, or blow up ground structures. On hard, the Corruption will pretty much just destroy a building every oppertunity they have. Making it difficult to make an economy because your mining facilities are being blown up. Not to mention the fact that it is QUITE expensive to remove it unless you have a shit ton of planets.

The lack of maps make it just boring to play, they don't even seem to be that well made. Like in Equal Footing all of the factions' worlds were spread out and difficult to defend UNLESS you're Corruption. 

tl;dr unless you like a challenge, (don't play corruption in galactic conquest) You will propubly find some aspects of this game a pain. (Oh and I stupidly pressed "press this if you got this game for free". This is not part of the review.
