- The campaigns are very entertaining and interesting to follow.
- You could always try a quick skirmish battle from the home screen if you're short on time.
- The 'Forces of Corruption' pack has a really good EU story, it's also fun to play as a team other than the empire or rebellion in a GCW Star Wars game.
- Very little lag.
- Very few glitches.
- You actually look at what your/the enemy's troops are good/weak against and use that information to win the battle instead of just aimlsessy making them all charge like hooligans.
- ADAPT, ADAPT, ADAPT!
- Snowspeeders are fun.
- AT-ATs are even more fun.

Now for the cons:
- It's not fun  going against a snowspeeder or AT-AT when you don't have the opposite.
- Not the best graphics, for those who care about it.
- Units may sometimes be unresponsive, especially in space.
- Special abilities don't always work.
- It's sometimes hard to go from right click for move/attack to left click for the special ability.
- Money is very rarely a challenge.
- WHAT?! 4 SHOTS FOR A BLOOMIN' KILL FOR ONE PERSON, WHAT IS THIS?!
- Some beginners may find easy mode feeling medium or hard (EDIT: The first few missions are normally quite hard, the rest rather easy).
- Auto resolve is pretty harsh and unbalanced.
- Most of the times that I tried out the Death Star it crashed (luckily it works for the campaign).

Overall, it's a very good game with its cons being rather minor. The content has kept me up for days  yet I'm still going. It is very addictive and it's hard to just leave among all your other ditched games. It also is probably one of the very few games that is actually tactical, making you adapt to certain situations. 9/10.
Great solid game. I've put in easily 200+ hours. My only complaint is that i wish there were more flexibility in the multiplayer interface.

I've owned this game on disc for a long time and have easily sunk hundreds hours more into it than what I have on Steam.  As a kid the battles of Star Wars were mind blowing.  So, the chance to play an RTS that lets you command all the inconic units of the original trilogy was a dream come true.  This package also includes the Forces of Corruption expansion.  This added the criminal empire of Tyber Zann as a third faction, and added additional units and heroes to the Rebel and Empire factions.  When launching this game, steam will ask you whether you want to launch the original or expansion, so you can pick whichever you prefer at any time.   

For anyone who hasn't played this game, it is primarily a singleplayer game.  The main mode is galactic conquest.  In this mode you control either the Empire, Rebellion or Zann Consortium and are battling for dominance on a galactic map.  Each time fleets clash on the map or a planet is invaded by ground troops you get to fight the battle in real time.  
There are story campaigns for the Rebels and Imperials in the base game, and for Zann in the expansion.  These are basically galactic conquest maps that feature special missions and maps, as well as some basic story in the form of voice acted conversations.  
There's also a skirmish mode that features single battles either on the ground or in space.  In my opinion the skirmish mode is the weakest part of the game, but there may be many who disagree with me.  

Experienced RTS players will probably find this game a bit easy, especially playing as the Zann Consortium.  A patient player with a few units on the ground can sometimes sneak past a max level space station and destroy armies of units on a well entrenched planet, occupying the planet and automatically destroying the space station in orbit.  As the Zann Consortium, I can't tell you how many times I've just sent my five heroes  to occupy planets single handedly.  It's amazing how 5 people can so effectively hold an entire planet.  

But even so, it's undeniable how satisfying it is when you do get those classic Star Wars battles.   Dozens of Imperial Star Destroyers squaring off against Mon Calamari Cruisers over Coruscant.  AT-ATs mulching inferior rebel T2 - B light tanks, only to get tripped by Airspeeders.  Zann or the Rebels bringing a massive fleets only to find themselves locked in battle with a Super Star Destroyer and the Death Star.   NOW WITNESS THE FULL POWER OF THIS FULLY OPERATIONAL...  *ahem*  You can get the idea.  

And keep in mind all that I've said here is just about the base game.  This game is many years old now, and there are truly incredible total conversion mods out there that are even better than the base game.  You owe to yourself, whether you're a noble Rebel leader, an ironfisted Imperial general , or a cutthroat Consortium goon to try this game.   

BUY IT!

This is, overall, one of the greatest RTS games that I have ever played. 
Although, personally I'm not a huge fan of the planetary battles, the space battles are the greatest. Nothing compares to watching Mon Calamari and Imperial Capital Ships line up and slug it out, with X-Wings and TIE Fighters dogfighting up above. The expansion pack is awesome as well, because it goes really deep into the Extended Universe, which most die-hard Star Wars fans like me love. There is also a large number of mods available, plus you can still use multiplayer though Gameranger.

I remember this game rather fondly when I played it when it  first came out a few years back, Playing it now I only have one word, for it: Stale.

It's kinda hard to pin down why, because on paper it all should work. It's a Star Wars game where they add Ground control style combat on land, Star trek Armada Style space combat (which was a pretty good RTS, not AMAZING but it worked) with Hyperspacing mechanics that allow you to reinforce just about anywhere. [strike] Complete with a "Risk" style map ripped from Dawn of War.[/strike] [b]EDIT: I derped, Dark crusade came after this [/b] Sounds great right?

Well it just doesn't play as well as it sounds on paper. Again it's  hard to describe but it all just feels so bland. The units aren't terribly interesting (except some heroes), the textures are plain, yet muddy, and it all feels like they took a lot of concepts that were AMAZING in other RTS games (Ground Control's Dropzone mechanics, CNC Tanks, Company of Heroes' Squads, Dawn of War: Dark Crusade's Risk map, Yes I am aware some of these came after this, but they still did it better) but didn't properly understand WHY those mechanics worked the way they did in those games and thus it ended up watering it all down.

Granted if you are a fan of the Extended Universe before Disney De-canonized it you'll get a kick out of the extra units and characters (Where else will you have Kyle Kataran throw down with Mara Jade?). but all in all, to me it feels very bland and watered down.

Star Wars: Empire at War- Gold Pack is an interesting experience. The base game is enjoyable, the voice acting is good, and the action is very well done. My only issue with the base game is that the AI is mostly defensive and rarely attacks you unless the story requires it. I would prefer if the AI was more aggressive. Where this game truly shines is in Galactic Conquest. You can start off with the Empire, the Rebellion, or the Consortium and fight to assert your dominance on the galaxy. Each faction has unique units and different playstyles while there are a variety of scenarios to choose from that further enhances Galactic Conquest. I do feel the Consortium is over-powered, but they are still beatable.

This will be what could be described as...a "mixed" review. I recommend this game for any star wars fan out there that wants an RTS fix. I can't recommend this game to rts fans. It is a very straight forward and shallow game that basically amounts to having more units than the other side. There are actual strategic elements that are brought in through community mods and add-ons, but the vanilla game is sorely lacking in this area. There is also a steep difficulty curve between the easy and medium modes. Note, I never gave the multiplayer a shot. 

+community support for mods and add ons.
+Star Wars name 
+mixed space and ground combat keeps things interesting
+fun to live the role of stratego for epic space battles

-lack of depth to rts elements
-once all units unlock, the end result becomes foregone
-steep difficulty curve between easy and medium. Easy mode the computer is ridiculously easy. In medium mode, the computer's aggression is turned to 10 and development of a military force is much more time consuming. It becomes a matter of consolidation of resources and base defense.

Oi, I wanted to love this game I really did.  Ok First things first.  Yes it's a big galaxy strategy game of Star wars, you can build fleets and armies, have land and space battles, build star destroyers etc, it's all there.
BUT: When I'm playing it I'm thinking, for every thing the game does well, there's two things that crop up that make me think, 'rebellion did this better six years earlier'.
1)You get limited 'command points' so that the biggest battle you get is about 5 star destroyers... if you have 20, fine, they come in one at a time as reinforcements.
2) Ships repair automatically, so if you cripple a ship in a hit and fade mission, eg, you play as rebels, fly in blast a big star destroyer, fly out then your main fleet comes in just after, literally 1 second can transpire, which represents maybe 1/12 of a galactic day, and that ship will be completely fixed.  So anything you don't destroy is immediately repaired.  That seems like basic logic has gone WAY out the window.
3) You can not sabotage anything, you can only steal technology as the rebels, so usig spec forces or whatever doesn't come into it all.
4) Ground battles are  alittle repetitive, and if for eg, you take over a planet, you can't build defences on the ground level until a battle starts... WHAT THE HELL! So eg you can build BIG things like Ion cannons or shields for the planet, but little 'build pads' for local defences to help you shoot down AT-AT's or whatever can't be built until an invading army arrives... what was my army doing for the six months I held that planet, just standing there? Then they go.. 'oh right, the enemy is landing, maybe we shouldn't have been just giving each other piggy back rides this whole time...'

These might sound niggly as problems, and  they are, but they and a few more I wont mention REALLy pile up to hold the game back from being great. 
The story is paper thin, leads up to the destruction of the 1st death star in star wars 1977.

THE EXPANSION PACK:
In short, it fixes about three little problems, much improved story campaign, you can now sabotage and do things like that BUT ONLY WITH THE NEW TEAM, but the issues above are still largely present.
And when you play games with all 3 teams (ie NOT the campaign) You can see how balance was not an issue for the developers.
The new team, the pirates are SO overpowered and will absolutely cripple the rebs and imps, so play as them or get angry, that's your choices.

So overall, yes I do recommend it, you can see by my hours played that I still gave it a go, and the expansion definitely improves the game enough to give it some reply value. ( I got a MOD with some maps, so I could play the expansion on old maps WITHOUT the new pirate team, thus it wasn't so unabalanced, but could play with the new features, ships etc)

We all know that Rebel terrorists are the greatest threat facing civilized society.  How can we, loyal children of the Empire, ever hope to rise above such subversive filth?  Thankfully, Star Wars: Empire at War exists, as a realistic simulator that readies Imperial cadets for the challenges provided by the drunken, racist Rodian-slayers and effeminate robots that make up the rank and file of the Rebels' immoral affront to civilized society.  Disregard revisionist history; Rebels shoot Greedo first, ask questions later.

Empire at War deftly combines the challenges of space and land combat into a single RTS, with resource managment and allocation of troops around the galaxy being key to whether or not you can repel the vile, fish-headed "Admiral" Ackbar from cruelly dominating and subverting the otherwise good people of the Empire.  

There is an option to play as the Rebels, but no one would ever do so, unless they were a social deviant in need of wholesome Imperial reeducation.

TL:DR - If you're looking for a more casual RTS - This isn't it.

So, I can see how this would be something many people could like. It is Star Wars after all. But after playing for a good 5 hours, I can tell that this is not a Star Wars game that I like. Which is very rare for me. 

My experience with it so far has been pretty horrendous, mainly through seemingly cheating AI mechanics and sudden difficulty spikes. Naturally, I was playing on Easy, and I'm not great at RTS, but I sort of assumed it would be more like C&C where you would have time to build up your forces and then assualt the enemy. Its not like that at all. My experiences come from C&C Red Alert and Generals and I've also played a fair amount of Shogun Total War. My issue I feel is that the time scale of the game literally leaves you behind within 30 seconds. 

In Galactic CQ, I am frequently being raided and out-gunned within the first 5 minutes of play. The AI steam rolls as it doesn't seem to be confined to the amount of actions a human could physically decide upon and take. The AI is so precise and clinical in its processes, that within the first 5 Galactic days, the Rebellion already has amased an economy 5 times greater than my own. I've been through forums and such and there seems to be no real answers about why this game is so different in play style to C&C or Shogun. But I feel its the fact that the AI moves so fast.

Personally I was looking for a more casual Star Wars C&C clone. This is not what this game is, unless you're already good at such game. I feel like I would have enjoyed it more if I had time to learn and not be swept off the game board almost immeditly by huge fleets which can't physically have been created with only a starting credit cap if 5K. Inexperience is also a deciding factor. The tutorials are decent, but they don't really provide you with the load of how much you have to do and organise. Also, the reinforcement mechanic which the player is forced to use, but the AI can happily spawn tanks etc against you... is just broken. 

Also, don't bother playing the expansion. The 3rd faction is so OP that there is literally no point, unless you like seeing all of your "owned" worlds, completely corrupted and leeched within 30 seconds.

Just glad I bought it on sale. If we consider £1 for 1 hour of play-time, I'd say the game at least achieved that.

Imagine Total War scale battles but with Star Wars!  Now take away everything interesting about Total War and add in easily exploitable tactics and lots of spam!

Empire at War may have been "good" a decade ago, when you were younger and thought it looked pretty and thought that Darth Vader was cool, but there's a bit more to a game than the characters in it and how nice it looks.  Like having fucking balance, and not making 95% of the battles boring because of the simplistic, stupid AI and arbitrary, manufactured maps that  slosh together.  The space battles are fun to watch play out, but the game likes to fuck up and you'll have to work around the shitty unit management to get them to do what you want.

In fact, just wait till Creative Assembly makes a Star Wars game, or get a mod for one of their games that does just that.  Because this, this isn't fun.  Playing a shitty game and pretending it's enjoyable because it has the star wars license is not fun.

Sluggish controls, tactical map unit caps, and a real time macrostrategic map of the galaxy make this a pain. Yes, there's a pause button on the galactic map, but you can't do anything while paused like move fleets or build units. It only works on the tactical map. Also, some of the scenario maps seem glitched on tech levels. If you go to advanced settings and reduce the starting tech level while playing on hard, then you start with reduced technology but the computer starts with regular technology. Having X Wings, Y Wings, and basic frigates doesn't really match top of the line Imperial Star Destroyers.

There's also no hold position command. You can tell units to stop, but it's very easy to lure or get lured, especially when units won't respond instantly after being lured. This creates a very annoying situation where rocket infantry wreck light tanks, anti-infantry vehicles wreck light infantry, and aircraft become pointless (although aircraft dominate easily until AA weapons are around). In space, it means fighters and bombers won't withdraw from cruisers, and larger ships that are slightly misoriented beacuse they advanced two inches too far take forever to turn around.

The game really isn't that bad, but it's like they choked it for no good reason and ruined the experience. If the units were responsive, tactical map unit caps didn't exist, the galactic map was turn based instead of real time, and the pause button let you issue orders while paused, then this would be an easy thumbs up. I have no idea why they ruined their own game with arbitrary restrictions.

Like RTS? Like Star Wars? Just like crushing your enemies with giant war machines in both space and planetary battles? If you like any combination of these then you will most likely like this game. You get to control the Rebel Alliance, Galactic Empire, and, if you have the FoC expansion, the Zann Consortium (basically underworld units). Each of these factions plays differently with the Rebels focusing on stronger armies, hit and run attacks, infantry focused armies, and guerrilla style warfare. The Empire uses numbers and brute force (Hint: check what happens when rebel infantry play chicken with your vehicles ) Finally the Zann forces use a mix of subtle corruption type debuffs and overpowered units. There are two main ways to play, skirmish and campaign. The skirmish allows you to do one off battles that are slightly different from the usual ones with resource capturing, and building up your tech in-game. The campaign allows you to play your own war between all of the factions. You manage your troop movements, production, and strategy. There are multiple set ups for how to start, each with a different number and distribution of planets. I prefer the  campaign, but sometimes its fun to just play one battle. 
       I highly recommend the FoC pack as it adds a new faction, new planets, and new units for everyone. Both of the game types (space and ground) are fun, with the space being my favorite. Little tip, some heroes (like Han and Boba Fett) don't just hangout on a transport if you get into a space battle with them, but take part in their own ships as well as on foot in ground fights. Also as your tech level gets higher, make sure you own at least one of the "shipyard" planets so you can build your ultimate capital ships ASAP.

Star wars Empire at war is a real-time strategy game based in the star wars universe. Both factions the rebels and the empire have different units. The rebels can use tactics like sending small groups of 2 units on to the planet to avoid emperial fleets and can steal tech from the empire too. The Empire on the other hand can use brute force to take over systems and build their way up to the death star and blow rebel bases to bits. Each faction has a different metheod for dealling with things. There are neutral factions on certain planets some are allied with rebels or the empire and will be under that factions control in a fight, there are also pirates which will control the neutral systems.

THERE IS NO MULTIPLAYER! ( the servers were closed down ages ago but single player is still there)

The Forces of corruption (FOC) however adds a third faction, the zann consortium, who use corruption which lets them carry out assassination, blackmail and all sorts of dirty under-handed tactics. The consortium hire mercs and buy their techs on black markets. You may notice that the consortium has less units than the empire and rebels BUT they can use piracy to steal the ship types of enemy factions and slavery to capture locals to fight for you.

NOW! there is a major thing you should know. When you enslave ewoks they are forced to wear and explosive vest. Yes in this game you can kiddnape baby ewoks and force them to blow themselfs up for you. like i said dirty under-handed tactics.

The games graphics are... not too good and at times it can run a little poorly. but i feel that the game play (which is heavy on MICRO) makes up for it. the campaign is all about using your heros abilities to over come pearls and complete your objectives. now if you dont like the gameplay or the ewok thing then i can see why you wouldnt like the game.

 But if you think you can look past the graphics, and want to try out being a criminal master mind in the star wars universe and dont mind blowing ewoks to bits then this is the game for you.

Dunno what to put here so have a recipe for Welsh ice cream!

Ingredients

50g plain flour

2 small eggs

50g caster sugar

75g white chocolate

50g milk chocolate

100g dark chocolate

65g butter (unsalted)

Handful of walnuts

Good quality local vanilla ice cream

100g winter berries

Method

Over a bain marie melt the milk chocolate, dark chocolate and 50g of the white chocolate and butter.

Whisk the eggs and sugar until pale and creamy. Slowly mix the flour into the melted chocolate and butter. Fold in the sugar and egg mix. Crush the remaining white chocolate and walnuts and stir into the mix. Pour into a baking tray lined with greaseproof butter. Bake at 180 degrees for 10-15 minutes until the centre is springy.

When cooked leave to cool. Serve sliced into squares with vanilla ice cream and winter berries.

The base game is pretty solid. The campaign can be a bit frustrating, what with the very specific objectives you have to follow to the letter or else you fail. The galactic conquest is more fun in that regard, since you can do basically whatever you want and follow no strategy but your own.
Forces of Corruption... where do I begin? There are the positives, of course. New planets- Mustafar, Utapau, Kamino, Dathomir, and Mandalore, to name a few. New units, spanning the movies and the Expanded Universe (now known as Legends), such as the TIE Defender, the Executor, and Grand Admiral Thrawn. A new campaign and a new faction- the Zann Consortium. New features, like orbital bombardments and using the Death Star II to shoot ships and space stations out of the sky. Basically, it's a lot of fun.
Now the negatives. That new faction? It's overpowered, unbalanced, and overall no fun unless you play as them. Why? They spread "corruption" to your planets, expanding their influence and giving them limited control over your planets. So what does "corruption" let them do? Destroy your buildings. Any and all of them, unceasingly until you remove the corruption. And as soon as you remove it, it's back again. There's no way to defend against it. If that's not bad, they can use IG-88 to hack the Death Star, blowing up whatever planet it's orbiting, any fleets above the planet, and the Death Star itself. Yeah. The Zann Consortium sucks. I recommend getting a mod to remove them from galactic conquest, so you don't have to worry about getting the Death Star, the entirety of one of your best fleets, and the planet you just captured randomly wiped out because "why not?" Other than the overpowered Consortium, it's a fun game, and you should definitely pick it up when it goes on sale.

Star Wars: Empire at War is a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game set in the Star Wars universe. It got an expansion pack which expands the game a lot.

Good things:
-The main game has 2 campaigns, 2 factions, and a lot of planet to play with. Meaning a lot of different ways to win/lose.
-Battles on Foot AND in space. And in the WHOLE FREAKING GALAXY.
-Newcomer friendly. This game got me into strategy, and seeing as how I f*cking love this genre, it's a VERY good thing.
-It's about the Galactic Civil War. Meaning you get to play as DARTH VADER.
-The expansion packs adds a 3rd campagin, faction, and a dozen of planets.
-With the expansion pack, you get to chose your base's layout. This may not seem like a huge thing, but it can be important depending on your playstyle.
-You get to use THE DEATH STAR(s).
-The 3rd Faction has Destroyer Droids. Nuff' said.

Bad things:
-This game's graphics aged REALLY badly.
-It's set in the Galactic Civil War. Meaning you don't get to play as CRISTOPHER LEE (R.I.P.).
-Boba Fett is Empire only. Even with the 3rd Faction.
-The Death Star may make your game crash. (That's not a good thing in case you're wondering)
-If you don't have the Expansion Pack, Luke is Space only. And with the Expansion Pack, he's on foot only.
-The main game has cinematics in case you lose/win. The Expansion Pack doesn't. Because F*ck you.

I loved Galactic Battlegrounds and have enjoyed many others in the same genre, like C&C, AOE, etc.

I feed stupid for saying it, but this was too difficult for me.  The first bit of the tutorial was a breeze, but as soon as the second one started, I was lost.  Drag this there.  Zoom in.  Click that.  I followed what I was told to do, but didn't have much comprehension as to why.  There was too much information given to me in that second tutorial and I was unable to absorb it in order to use that knowledge in-game.

I skipped the rest of the tutorials and started a campaign (on easy) to see how much the information on the second tutorial impinged on the game.  On the second part of the campaign, I was presented with the world map - right there, I was lost.  I dragged R2-D2 onto the planet I was meant to, and did the same for a couple of troops, but when I zoomed in to that planet, it said the battle was starting so onto the ground I went.  Moved right a little while and found a laser turret, quickly followed by more troops than I had.  Didn't last long before I was wiped out.  The commentary said to call for reinforcements but I'd no idea how to do that.

Should I have dragged more troops on before getting to the planet?  I understand that Empire at War can't just be more of the same that was presented in Galactic Battlegrounds, but this was too much of a departure/advancement for me.  I'd far rather be put on the planet and have to build my base before encountering the turret and troops - I could then have built more if needs be.

Given I'm fine with other similar games, I blame the tutorial.  If it was anything like the one in C&C Red Alert 3, it could impart as much new information as it needed to without the user feeling lost.  

I understand I'm in the minority here given 93% of users recommend this - perhaps if I sat with one of them and have them walk me though the basics, I'd have a better chance of enjoying this title, but as it is, I'm sadly deleting it in frustration.

Horribly unbalanced and dated game.

While the graphics may look appealing, even today, the gameplay is an entirely different story. Both on land and space battles, there are units and certain aspects of different factions that you can exploit to garantee a win. 
If you decide to play a conquest game, beware when fighting against the Empire. If they are able to build a death star, it can quickly decimate the areas you control. When defending against it in space, you will have a couple of minutes to try and destroy every last space craft the enemy has, before they'll be able to use the death star to instantly destory your space station or planet, forcing you to lose the battle. 
The Consortium is just as bad. While they have most of the cool and fun to use units, all of their units are designed to ignore your units shields, auto kill any fighters you have, etc. while they have individually shielded structures, and gain bonuses to what really matters (space station wise), hard points.
Most larger ships and space stations have things called 'hard points', such as turbo lasers, ion canons, proton torpedos, engines, and shields. Once destroyed, they can not be recovered. While the Empire and Rebels usually can increase their shield strength or firepower, the Consortium increases the armor on their space stations hardpoints. Why this is so important is because each faction has at least one or two units that can bypass shields, usually missile ships or bombers, so shields aren't entirely important to bolster. Being able to better defend your hard points is a little more effective. 
As for on the ground, both the empire and rebellion have a unit that can fly, a special, unique kind of unit that ignores most rules of combat. Bolstering incredibly high mobility and decent firepower, they can skip the ground combat and go right for the enemies base. With a large enough force, most units wouldn't be able to shoot them down, while you quickly wittle away at their forces and structures. Seriously, they are just that powerful. 
This doesn't mean I hate the concept of this game. Rather, I hate how little thought and care was put into the game. It had the potential to be so much better, and I would love to see someone try and remake the game. 
I strongly recommend not buying the game for more than $6.

Let me state that I have played way more than the 40 hours listed as I bought this on DVD many years ago, but only the Steam version seems to work on Windows 10.  I also will state that I have enjoyed playing this game and I feel that it could be a very good game, if only the dev had put more effort into the base gameplay engine and less effort into the "cinematic" features.  Read More:

Pros:
- Epic feeling space battles with fighters, bombers, cruisers and battleships
- Mod Support!
- Skirmish modes for people who don't want to play a galactic campaign (more 4x games need this)
- Galactic Conquest mode allows you to conquer the galaxy
- Land battles add some variety and breaks inbetween the space battles

Cons:
- Pathfinding ( and by that I mean the complete and total lack thereof ) - I mean seriously, ships refuse to obey basic movement commands, they can't path above or below each other, they can't squeeze between each other (even if 2 ships at the same time should be able to squeeze between), they retreat into the enemy, they face the wrong direction and ignore you when you tell them to turn the right direction, they take the longest possible path to the destination, and they stop before being able to engage the target you just told them to attack.  As for ground pathfinding, units constantly get stuck on terrain and other units, sometimes permanently making them useless for the rest of the combat.
- The Defending side in battles have a massive advantage as they get a station or buildings plus the garrisons (infinitely respawning defenders), possibly a super weapon, and they can get upgrades, because upgrades aren't empire wide for some odd reason.
- Fleet incoming warnings usually don't go off and so randomly you'll get hit by an incoming fleet with no warning even though you have long range sensors and sight on the systems the attack came from.
- You can't give orders while the game is paused, unlike many other strategy games like this.
- Battles are separate from the galactic conquest mode, so they constantly break the flow of conquest.
- Auto-resolve will always cause you to lose way more ( ie. Instead of a victory with no loses if I played it out, auto-resolve gives me a complete loss with no enemies killed), but when you get attacked 3 times every minute, it looks appealing.
- Gravity wells don't prevent the enemy fleet's reinforcements from retreating even though they should be holding right there in hyperspace and should be effected.
- You can't have your entire fleet fight the entire enemy fleet all at once due to pop cap during a battle, although this is probably to limit how much frustration you get from the absolutely terrible pathfinding.
- A criminal empire is by far more powerful than the Empire and the Rebels combined, with only one required money building that also provides a super weapon in orbit, meaning they can fill their planets with massive garrison buildings, they have insanely good ships and no tech level requirements so they can build tech 5 shit at tech 1, and oh yeah they can corrupt the galaxy which gives them money, and buffs including, removing control of planet from the owner if corruption removed, moving past enemy fleets to pretty much anywhere, and gaining vision everywhere.
- Ground combat devolves into artillery catching other artillery off guard with maybe a few spotting units.
- You can't get rid of heroes which take up pop.
- Space maps feel claustrophobic ( Coruscant being one of the worst with my defending ships started facing the wrong way and the enemy could already shoot them while the game was still in the battle start view) while most land maps are too big and slow down the game.

So yeah, while I had fun with the game, it has some issues, so I can't recommend it, primarily due to the complete and total lack of pathfinding.

Terrible.  Before the expansion, Empire at War was a below average strategy/rts game that I went ahead and played sometimes anyway because it managed to pretty faithfully create a Star Wars feel.

Then I bought Gold to get the expansion, even though I didn't enjoy the original very much.  I was thinking I would get some more "hero" characters and maybe the new faction would be nice.  The new faction is not nice.  Almost nothing that comes with the expansion is from Star Wars--most of the hero units you get are characters that I guess came from Expanded Universe or one of the animated series, or maybe created originally for the game.  Whatever they are, new hero units are terrible.  They don't fit with the original character and stand out like a fist-full of sore thumbs.

Why fill my Rebel Alliance hero roster with all these off-brand characters such as "Garm Bel Iblis" when you still haven't added a Princess Leia character?  

The new faction is the worst.  The Zann Consortium--a criminal empire, is made up almost entirely of "Not from Star Wars" units such as Urai Fenn, and Tyber Zahn.  Why not make it Jabba the Hutt's faction and use all the bounty hunters from Empire Strikes Back for the Hero units?  They did include IG-88 and Bossk at least, but overall this faction doesn't feel like it came from Star Wars at all.

The Empire is full of weird characters too.  If this game has moved away from Star Wars, then why the Hell am I playing it?  Not for the gameplay, that's for sure.

Space Battles are kind of fun.  They look good, and feel like Star Wars, at least until the new, wacky Zann Consortium ships show up.  Ground Battles are terrible and have been terrible since the original game was released.  Ground battles are clunky, simplistic, poorly balanced, and just plain not fun.  And now that there is a bunch of Not From Star Wars units running around, I'm just playing a poorly designed, generic sci-fi rts on the ground.

So lame.

The Strategic Game/Empire Management?  Not very good.  Kind of boring--you play it because its Star Wars and it vaguely feels like you are commanding the Empire/Rebellion.  Again, the more the game moves away from actual Star Wars units and feel, the more Im asing myself why I am playing a clunky, poorly designed RTS game.  

The answer is, I'm not.  I'm done with this crappy game and I do not recommend that you buy it.

*ACTUAL REVIEW BELOW*
Empire At War is an RTS  Set in the Star Wars Universe. The game itself has 2 Primary Modes, and several Modes wihin that. The Primary are Galatic Conquest, Similar to the Battlefront Gamemode, and Instan Action, in which you just pick a map and begin. The two of three sub modes apply to the other two, Those two being the Land Battle Mode, where you use various troops, vehicles, and heroes of the Universe to engage an opposing side, either the Rebel scum or the Mighty Empire. Another is Space Battles, a mode where you use Everything from fighters to Star Destroyers to fight your opponent's. 
The gameplay itself is more or less just a simplified RTS; It focus's more on the War and Battle part than building structures, although a basic Unit Upgrade system is in place. The empire has a Slight Advantage in Space Battles in my experience,  as with even basic units, the basic Tactic of Swarm with many troops is efficient enough to win most Encounters. However, having not played much as The Rebel Scum, That may be true for both sides.
The modding community for this game has created a large amount of Mods, with mods in The Clone Wars Era, to the Imperial Remnant Era.
All in all, I enjoy this game, and, despite some small bits being dislikeable, such as the fact the Empire Can eventually just Death Star Planets to death, I give it a 8/10. Some things could have been changed, but asides from that, I Highly reccomend it, as it is a Fleshed out, enjoyable game.

Great game! Best RTS game in my opinion. But it has issues...


***EDIT***
"This review use to be negative i did however find a fix, im not sure how long term it is though. I will now rate it as reccomended, but its up to you to determine if you want to invest in a buggy game"

Pros

It has a great modding community, some great mods like Star Wars the clone wars, Republic at War, Stargate, custom maps, so much more. Modding is very easy as well. It is not workshop modding but your classic digging in the directory modding. However very simple, easy for all ages.

It has great controls. I thought it was going to be extremely complicated and hard to understand, however it is very simple. With mods such as Republic at War and Clone wars, they literally feel like they were built into this game and not added on (if that makes sense) It has a simple interface and point and click controls.

Fun and intense battles. OF course with most games you can easily overwhelm your enemy with enough units but if you put this game on hard mode or even if you believe you are the next great War tactician and download Republic at war and put it on hard. You will need to honestly think and command your units, you will not be able to simply hold the line or overwhelm your enemy (unless you spam 40 Republic Class Venators). None the less for a star wars game you do alot of thinking, you get to control the fate of the star wars universe through your actions.

Galactic Conquest.

Nuff' said? But really it is hands down the best game mode i have ever played. It consumes hours upon hours as you command your fleets to take planet after planet or defend from enemy invasions. Mods only make this experience better. 

There are more pros but i do not want to list them all. Lets get into the reason why i do not like empire at war.


Cons

1.Forces of Corruption

This add-on is very CORRUPTED. When modding or even playing the stand alone game i have ran into countless errors. I have spent up to 4 hours assembling my forces in Galatic Conquest for a dumb Exception error to occur and DELETE ALL MY SAVES. A quick google search and you will see loads of people have this problem. The problem is the updates and patches meant to fix this are already in the steam version so i have no idea why us steam users experience these issues.  These issues have made a 11/10 game into a 6/10 because there is no point in playing when the game deletes your saves or crashes. 


If i ever i find a fix i will reccomend this game. But i will not take out the con as i think people should be ready for alot of bugs.  Really hope i find a soulution. 


Things i have tried

Ram fix (however it says "unable to write to installation path") this occurs for forces of corruption. 
Patch 1.5 (same error as above)
Verified integrity of game cache.
Uninstalled and Reinstalled MODS


FOUND FIX (will update if turns out to be wrong)

If you constantly get an exception error that says to check a log file and you're log file says invalid code pointer (or something like that) then my fix was to go into the corruption folder located inside the empire at war directory and go into the data folder and delete your XML folder.

MAKE A BACKUP IN CASE THIS CAUSES MORE PROBLEMS

So far i have made it to day 111 on GC and no problems. The problem started at day 50-80


DISC SPACE ERROR

For Disc space error i reccomend launching Steam as an admin and then launching FOC or EAW through steam.

Star Wars Empire at War is a gem, perfect for those who are looking for a slow but entertaining real time strategy game that takes place in the Star Wars universe.

Pros:
-Challenging.
-Includes a fun story mode and missions that are separate from the story.
-Moddable.
-Active Community.
-Many locations from the movies and new places to invade.
-Forces of Corruption is an expansion that adds a lot more content.
-Famous heroes can be controlled, including Luke Skywalker, Boba Fett, and Han Solo.
-Battle Camera can allow players view battles in a way seen in the movies.
-The game can be replayed a ton due to Galactic Conquest and Skirmish.

Cons:
-The game can get repetitive without any modifications.
-Without Workshop, modding can become difficult.
-The artificial intelligence is not the best, sure you can be out-smarted by them in your first game but you will learn and there will be no way to lose.
-Ground battles can be annoying, especially when you kill everything but one person is hiding somewhere.

9.8/10
Star Wars Empire at War is nearly perfect and the game is one of the games a true fan of Star Wars must play. I can't say anything about this game, it is just awesome.

Empire at War is probably the Star Wars' most serious foray into the strategy genre, and I hate to say it's mixed at best. While the battlescapes make for some really impressive visuals, the game falls flat on its face on the tactical map.

It's one of the worst I've ever seen in a strategy game. It's real time with a pause, which wouldn't be an issue execpt the game refuses to let you make any meaningful orders while paused. It will only be an hour or so before you started getting bombarded with battle prompts (which you can autoresolve) back-to-back, and it just becomes completely unmanagable as your attention is constantly divided. It seriously plays like a turn-based system that was retooled to realtime at the very last second, and its shows. I cannot understate how frustrating it is to deal with. 

And while the battlescape is fun to play on, it also has issues. Pathfinding for you or the AI is atrocious, and you'll often have to bear ships taking a full minute to turn around when they could have just moved forward. On top of some pretty awful unit balance, battles are always completely lopsided and predictable. 

Do not get this on anything but the cheapest of sales. The cool battles might draw you in, but the game turns into a slog very, very quickly.
If you have ever played this game before you know why this gets a thumbs up. If you have not played this before, my only question is; "why not?!?"

It's been around for more than 8 years, and it's still replayable. This was one of my favorite games when I was 8 years old and even to this day proves that it is a fun game. Sure, the graphics aren't as good as games now, but its replayability and sheer scale make this game a wonderful game.

The original is a surprising rts - simple-looking but deceptively deep and most definitely playable. Excellent job particularly in space battles of capturing the feel of Star Wars. Regrettably, network play is completely inert in this release... one would have hoped some effort to facilitate Steam net play would have been made, but no. Even virtual networks seem to fail to get multiplayer up & running. Forces Of Corruption is exactly that: an imbalanced force that corrupts the integrity of the base game. The new faction itself is horrifically overpowered making Imperials and Rebels alike look feeble. Silly. Ignoring that expansion pack, if Empire At War were ever repaired, it would be worthy.

Oh man, this game was my childhood. I had this game as a little kid and it was fantastic. Unfortunately, I lost the disc for it (as kids do) and couldn't fufill my rebel-quashing dreams anymore. Then I saw the Star Wars bundle on the winter sale a few days ago and couldn't resist. My dreams of galactic conquest and the destruction of rebel insects could continue! 
LONG LIVE THE EMPIRE!

Pros:
-Obliterating scores of Rebel Scum has never been better.
-Graphics on maximum (which any modern computer can easily handle) are not fantastic but do hold up
-Space Battles are so much fun. Commanding fleets of Star Destroyers and Victory class cruisers against Admiral Ackbar and his supporting fleet of Mon Calamari cruisers never gets old
-The AI on hard can actually be a tough challange, and has given me a run for my money on several occaisions. 
-The modding community is still going strong, and there are TONS of mods for this game.
-Playing as Rebel scum can actually be enjoyable.

Cons:
-The third faction, the Zann Consortium, is kinda OP. They have a bunch of units that can directly counter your big strong ones and make you feel kinda useless. This is especially true if you play the Rebels.
-Some unexplainable crashes, but not enough to make the game unplayable
-Ground battles are kinda shit. This can be easily fixed by building a mass of stormtroopers (or Rebel Infantry if you play the Rebel scum) and auto-resolving every ground battle. Can also be fixed by blowing up every planet with the Death Star. 
- Limited Faction choice and few units. This can easily  be fixed by downloading mods for the game. There are mods that expand on the original game, and there are also total conversion mods that turn the game into the Clone Wars, where you can play as the Republic or the Confederation. 

Overall, if you like Star Wars, buying this game is a no-brainer. If you like 4x RTS games, buy it. If you like to get crushed by the Empire or to crush the Rebel cockroaches as the Empire, buy it. And if that isn't enough, you can build the Death Star and win by turning every planet into space dust. BUY IT!

A top notch and well presentable RTS game, as well as an excellent star wars game, Empire at War is a great game for fans of rts and star wars fans, as it does a great job at preserving the elements and aesthetics of the original trilogy and it exapnding further by adding a few features from the Thrawn/Galatic Civil War trilogy with the forces of corruption expansion set.
The space combat of the game alone should be more than enough to attract any space fanatic type of person, ground combat can be boring and can drag on due to the population limit (most units you can have is usually less than 10) and how large some ground maps can be. The game however suffers from a sketchy and out of tune ai, making the game quite unpleasant, espicially during space maps and your own units having a mind of their own and not being able to properly nagivate throughout the map.
Another great selling point of the game is its modding capabilites. The modding community is currently alive and thriving due to the large amount of mods and upcoming mods for the game.

This game is literally perfect, I have around 3000 hours of EaW and FoC as I have played them since release. I just recently bought the steam version so I could play online with other Steam players on Forces of Corruption via GameRanger. If you can get past the slight balance problems and bugs the game has you will enjoy it a lot. 

Pros: 
1. Very cheap $$$ wise.
2. Regular Empire at War is almost perfectly balanced.
3. Both EaW and FoC have a very fun fast-paced Skirmish for Land and Space. 
4. EaW and FoC's Galactic Conquest can give hours of entertainment. 
5. Forces of Corruption has a very fun Campaign.
6. Both EaW and FoC can run on low-end PC's with lower graphic settings while having the ability to look amazing on higher graphic settings. (Graphic enhancement mods exist as well)
7. Both EaW and FoC have countless mods, custom maps and etc that extends the gameplay.
8. Pretty easy game to mod and a good start if you want to learn how to mod games.
9. Very simple map editor.
 



Cons:
1. Forces of Corruption isn't balanced. (Not even close)
2. The Campaign's for Empire at War aren't the best and can get boring. (My Opinion)
3. Multiplayer no longer works without 3rd party software such as GameRanger.
4. Multiplayer can be very buggy and cause a lot of Synchronization Errors. (Via GameRanger)
5. If you attempt to play Forces of Corruption online with another player with the Steam version then he must also have the Steam version. Steam players can't play with Retail Forces of Corruption players due to a version mismatch. (Does not effect regular Empire at War)
6. The EaW AI is very dumb, the FoC AI is slightly better but still isn't that great. (AI Improvement mods do exist) 


If you are interested in playing the game online I truly suggest you download GameRanger at www.gameranger.com Official online servers were shut down due to GameSpy shutting down.

It was hard to not give this game a 'not recommend' because of nostalgia and the fact that it is an okay game, that being said there are quite a few problems with it. Mostly they are just balencing issues with some of the units being far too overpowered or weak. The biggest issues are in the conquest mode with the Zann Consortimum being unbalenced ("Your structure on Coruscant has been destroyed! Your structure on Kessel has been destroyed! Your structure on..." so on and so forth), you can hear enemy fleets approaching because of the massive alert it gives you but you can't see where they are moving or where they are attacking just that they are attacking so most battles end up like 1 battlestation and a frigate against an entire fleet (IT ENDS PRETTY FAST) also the "autoresolve" function hates you if you have a army (or fleet) that is one of everything you will win most battles by autoresolving because of a countering system that the autoresolve goes through, on the other side of that though if you just spam only fighters like the A wing prepare your anus (Brother made 500 A-wings I was it was stupid he kills entire fleets with them, I stand corrected apparently it was genius). But for a game it's really fun it is, and the space battles have the cool function of shooting at specfic parts of ships which makes for interesting gameplay. The conquest and land battles are fairly bland though as nothing much happens other than those small fast ending battles and land battles are just... well boring. But it is definatly fun to play and I remember why I enjoyed it as a little one.

Rating : 11/10

Excluding the expansion, I've always like this game, however, there are some weird qualities this game has that will leave your head scratching, but before I get to that, lets look at the positives.
Single player modes, there are quite a few, but you either play as the rebels or empire, for an RTS game that kinda sucks because most RTS have multiple factions, but this is star wars so whatever, each side has their own story in their respective campaign modes, they follow the story but as soon as you get farther into the campaign the less the story matters.  As far as timeline is concerned it's more along the lines of A New Hope than any other point.  Anyway, what's nice about this game is that there's space combat and ground combat, and the campaigns dive into both.  You build an army, send it to a planet, space combat if necessary, then land on the planet for a ground assault.  Simple, effective, and fun.
There's Galactic Conquest which follows the same type of gameplay as the main campaign but a more do at your own pace and strategy.  This is where balance imo becomes more lopsided.  After playing a few rounds with either side, I've come to this conclusion.  The Rebels ARE FAR stronger than the Empire in terms of Navy and Army.  Empire have certain units that are most definitely stronger, IE Star Destroyers and AT-AT's, but as a unit the Rebels just kick so much ass, even the heroes are more than a match for Empire heroes.  Each side also has special abilities, Empire can build a deathstar and instant blow up planets and systems, while the Rebels can sneak attack a planet they deem weak enough to liberate under the Empire's noses.
Every planet is different however, some side with Rebels making it harder to win for Empire and vice versa.  Some can't have speeders on the planet, so yes, strategy abounds in this game.

Then there's the skirmish mode, it's so weird.  You don't have to build any main buildings (like a barrecks), they're already prebuilt, you just upgrade your soldiers, build mines/turrets, summon soldiers, and that's it, but this is where my biggest gripe comes in.

The enemy players regardless of difficulty, WILL BUM RUSH YOU!  They will send every available soldier they have straight to your base, so if you don't build anti-infantry turrets right away, you're going to have a bad time, seriously.  What's more annoying is that even if you build turrents, they will try to run straight past them straight for a target at your base.  The ai logic is piss poor to the max.  It's also randomized so sometimes games will be harder than others, again regardless of difficulty.  All in all, the game has held up for quite a while as it came out almost 10 years ago, but the poor ai logic can sometimes just kill the game.  I give it a solid 8/10, great game, shitty ai

A good bundle and a good set of games, with one serious flaw....

The Forces of Corruption mission to Saleucami is corrupted, this has been a known issue since 2006. There is a work around, you must choose to corrupt the planet via the option that DOES NOT require the hero Urai Fen. Using him will cause him to glitch out and he will be unusable for the rest of the game, which is a game breaking glitch. You will either have to start all over or load an earlier save.

Other than this serious glitch, the game is very fun, both the original game and the expansion. The original game has no glitch that i have experienced.

Star Wars: Empire at War Gold is the definition of a classic sci-fi 4x-strategy game where players explore, expand, exploit and exterminate their foes. It offers turn-based gameplay with real-time battles. One of the coolest parts of the game is that it allows for the ability to fight in space and on the surface of a planet, something no other game in this genre currently offers! Another cool aspect of the game is that the various space and land enviroments really come into play. For example, whlie battling in space players can use things like nebulas to cloak their ships from enemy sensors to launch a surpise attack just after the enemy flies by. On land, if the planet you are battling on is covered in lava then you will want to use mainly vehicles or find some serious cover like a bunker so your troops don't melt. Furthermore, players can also use their capital fleets and any orbiting bombers to aid them in their land battles using tactics such as oribital bombardments and bombing runs. Moreover, the ability to target specific systems of the enemy's larger ships and space stations for destruction as well as various special abilities for units really makes the game feel incredible. That, combined with the ability to acquire Star Wars hero or villain units, depending on your faction, really makes the game feel alive. Thus, Star Wars: Empire at War Gold is superbly polished from start to finish and any fan of the 4x-strategy genre or Star Wars will surely appreciate all that this game has to offer. Therefore, I most definitely recommend this game! It is the definition of a classic sci-fi 4x-strategy game and is a timeless masterpiece.

In FOC you are a third factor, the pirates of the Zann Consortium, and the time line is from some time before Return of the jedi and beyond.

There are still some bugs in there, and if you want a competive RTS there are better options due to bad game balance. In particular this is a problem in the expansion where the Zann Consortium are ridiculously powerful. But if you are a Star Wars fan you will love this game and spend many hours in single player mode.

Oh Lucasarts where did you go?

This game, which is basically a spiritual successor to Star Wars Rebellion (which I unfortunately have never played because it apparently doesn't work on Windows 7...) is probably my favorite Star Wars game and definitely one of my favorite real time strategies too.

This thing has got EVERYTHING, and if you get ANY of the decent mods, the quality goes up through the roof (it already was touching the ceiling with having all the lovely super weapons the empire can build, like the Super Star Destroyer and the 2nd Death Star) - only for Forces of Corruption though.

The original is still great though. The ability to play both the Rebels AND the Empire and even start before the Battle of Yavin is amazing, and in fully voice-acted and fleshed out campaigns too? As M. Bison would say: YES! YES!

The ground combat is kinda silly, but it's epic. Darth Vader, Luke, Obi-Wan, Yoda (yes Yoda) and the Emperor himself can lead swarms of rebel troopers, AT-ATs and everything else in between in huge clashes that take place on many different worlds, most of which are actually from the Expanded Universe (but don't worry, the originals like Hoth, Tatooine, Endor and Naboo are still there and even have the proper indigenous peoples as well).

The Space Combat is where this game really shines though. Despite the lack of "technically" 3-D combat, it still manages to hold up really well after 10 or so years.

The Death Star II has a big role to play in the space combat by the way (I think you can probably guess how).

I didn't even mention the Zann Consortium did I?

The Zann Consortium is only available in Forces of Corruption, but they have their own campaign (which has some ups and downs and kind of a meh ending, but is still fun) and basically are the cooler version of the Black Sun Pirates (yes even Xizor makes an appearance from Shadows of the Empire). So does Thrawn...and IG-88...and Bossk...and Jabba the Hutt.

White-haired Tyber Zann and his wannabe Jedi (but not really) alien partner Urai Fen try to build up their criminal enterprise after losing virtually everything when Tyber gets captured in the tutorial, and they do this through two ways: One, the conventional way, CONQUERING EVERYTHING IN SIGHT, and Two, the more interesting way, Corruption.

The way this new game mechanic works is that it will basically "corrupt" the planet that it is executed on (which usually involves doing a specialized ground or space mission) and give you extra special bonuses from holding the planet.

This can come in the form of just extra credits, or even being able to build ships that the faction's planet that you corrupted build!

I'm not sure if you can build Star Destroyers because that would be a little OP, but considering that the ENTIRE CONSORTIUM is OP, from their massive canderous death tanks that slaughter AT-ATs to their Mandalorian capital ships and specialized capital ships that shoot GIANT BEAMS OF DEATH, getting the half-finished Eclipse at the end just seals the deal.

By the way, the Eclipse had a scaled down superlaser, that was a little less powerful than the Death Star's.

On the other hand, it shoots faster, and kills any ship it hits instantly (just like the Death Star II), so that's always a nice plus.

10/10

P.S. I know you're probably getting tired of seeing these P.S.'s but I'm DOING EM ANYWAY.

Anyway, the P.S. I had to say here is that if we ever get an RTS that is star-wars themed, you should always think of this before you make the decision of whether to buy it or not. If it's not any better than this, don't bother. Just play this. The modding community is VERY active.

Some mods I recommend (mostly for Forces of Corruption):

Ultimate Empire at War (it's inactive, but a lot of work was done on it and it's a solid mod)
Thrawn's Revenge (haven't actually played this one, but it looks very, very good)
Awakening of the Rebellion (made by a German team oddly enough, has had a lot of updates and even has some story to it - unfortunately the voice acting's only in German, but it's great, and the combat is vastly improved on the realism front).

The first paragraph is my story of experiences with the game, and the second is akin to an actual review.

I first learned about the game when I was like 7 and I was watching the Bonus Features disc for Revenge of the Sith and I saw the trailer. I instantly fell in love with the idea of a Star Wars strategy game. I got on my mother's computer, downloaded the demo, and played all the tutorials and the 3 planet Galactic Conquest. I begged my mom to buy the game for me, but she said no so I did the most logical thing for a young kid to do. I got on my mom's computer, went to Amazon where she was already logged in, and bought the Star Wars Best of PC Collection, which came with Empire at War, Knights of the Old Republic, Battlefront, Jedi Outcast, and Republic Commando (the last 4 being stories for other reviews). I was mainly interested in Empire at War though. I chose One-Day shipping so the next day when I got home from school, I saw a package a the front door. I grapped it, ripped it open, installed EaW, and played the Empire Campaign non-stop. The next night, I here my mother screaming at me, "WHAT AMAZON.COM ORDER?!?!" I told her about it, said that I was sorry and begged her not to tell my father, and I got grounded for the first time in my life. She ended up letting me keep it though, but I had to pay her the $60 it cost plus the shipping, so I was out of money for a while. For like my 9th birthday, I asked my grandmother if she could buy me the Empire at War Gold Pack at Walmart, (which I had just discovered) and I got it. I played through the new campaign, but soon delved into Galactic Conquest as the Empire. I wondered why I didn't have Vader as a hero like in the original game, and then I saw he could be constructed for 12500 credits. I did it, brought him into battle, saw the Executor, and then I truly fell in love with the game. If Steam counted the hours I had on my cd copies, I might even be into the thousands in all honesty.

Onto an actual review though, Empire at War is a Real Time Strategy game set in the Star Wars galaxy. You can choose from either the Empire or Rebellion (or the Zann Consortium, a criminal empire with many unique gameplay elements in the Forces of Corruption expansion) in either story driven campaigns, galaxy wide Galactic Conquests, or small skirmish battles. Once you've familiarized yourself the game however, I would reccomend delving into the huge modding community for this game. There are many great mods such as Thrawn's Revenge (Setsthe game after Return of the Jedi with new factions, planets, mechanics, and a more accurate Galaxy map), Republic at War (Take a guess), and Awakening of the Rebellion (Which gives the Galactic Conquest much more depth, rebalances everything so the Empire is a hulking behemoth of a war machine and the Rebellion is just a ragtag group of freedom fighters, and just adds to the overall feel of the original Galactic Civil War Era). Even without these mods though, Empire at War is still a great game and is definitely worth your money.

The expansion pack to this game, Forces of Corruption has containd a game breaking bug since it was initially released; to this date it has not been fixed.  The issues is noticed during the main campaign of the FoC; where, if a player corrupts a planet that one of the main characters is suppose to do a campaign mission on, then there is a chance that the character will become stuck on that planet, invisible.  The player will have no way to interact with the character or start the mission.  How you will notice, is that the character will suddenly vanish off of the map after completing the corruption mission.  No matter where you look, it won't be visible.  If you click on it's icon in the upper corner, it will direct you to the planet where the character was suppose to do the mission.  The reason is, because that character is stuck on the planet; just invisible.  This breaks the game.  The only thing you can do is return to an older save and avoid using corruption when you last did it.

The fact that such an aggrivating bug exists in a released product, is enough to earn it a poor rating.

Edit: I deleted some comments due to fallacies.  Just because you never experience a problem with a product; doesn't mean no problems exist.  You can go to the Star Wars wikipage for FoC and see the campaign bug mentioned on the page.  Granted it says that it was patched; but, obviously it wasn't done so effectively if it still persists for players.  There is literally a recent steam community discussion you can look up, where someone is describing the exact issue and multiple other members are trying to help them trouble shoot the issue.  The final concensus was: you guessed it, restart the campaign.

I have only played this game for a little while after buying it, and I can say that it is good. Though, there are a couple downsides to it. Heres a list of Pros and Cons.

Pros:
-Game is fun, and plenty of strategies to experiment with.
-Moding community is amazing.
-Really is worth the money, with the free "Force of Corruption" Expantion.
-3 factions to experiment and play with.
-Real ships and vehicles from the movies (Including a couple that aren't).
-Balancing is great, depends how you look on it though.
-Maps that you can re-inact your favorite battles with.
-You can build the Deathstar. 'Nuff said.

Cons:
-Gameplay is fairly limited.
-Units are fairly limited.
-Ground Battles aren't exactly bad, but they aren't great either.
-Multiplayer servers shut down. (You can download third party programs to get multiplayer, though I havn't tried this yet).
-No workshop. (Mod installing isn't as easy as it could be).

So, these are my thoughts on this game. Buy it, it's definently worth it. I may edit this if I find anything in the future.

Star Wars: Empire at War is not the greatest RTS I've ever played. Actually if this wasn't Star Wars related I'd probably not recommend this game. Empire at War is a game about conquering the galaxy as either the Empire or the Rebellion. Or some third party faction.

Ground combat is not the best, I actually autoresolve most ground battles because the real fun is in the space combat commanding mighty Imperial II Class Star Destroyers and tearing through Rebel Escort Frigates.

If you get this game I strongly encourage you to check out the two major mods for this game: Republic at War or Thrawn's Revenge. Repubic at War is a full conversion to be all about the Clone Wars and features characters from the TV show. I've never played it but I've heard good things about it. The other, Thrawn's Revenge is based on the expanded universe novels set after Return of the Jedi and it is a lot of fun. Thrawn's Revenge will add a lot more ships and unit types and heroes spanning the events from just after the Battle of Endor, through Grand Admiral Thrawn's Campaign, the reborn Emperor and that crisis, into Admiral Daala's time in command, the Black Fleet Crisis, and ends with the events of the Hand of Thrawn books covering about the 15-20 years between Return of the Jedi and the Pellaeon-Gavrisom Treaty.

Jedi can be killed. Same with Sith. Just send in some tanks. A lot of them. You know what? Forget it, it'd take too long to raise the funds to kill one Jedi. That's what I learned. Playing as the Consortium made me feel bad for all those faceless, nameless, untrained bad guys I killed in KOTOR 2. That sense of hopelessness that you cannot kill a Jedi, no matter what you did. Overall, 8.9/10. This game is great but the replay-ability is kind of whack after conquering the Galaxy 6 times, corrupting over 90 planets. At least I killed Luke 2 times, Vader 3 times (once in the Bespin level), and the Emperor 17 times. Obi-Wan, why must you always run away?

Wonderful game; one of my favorite RTS.  Pick a side, whether it be the Galactic Empire, Rebel Alliance, or Zann Consortium (an assortment of the underworld's baddest scum united together).

The content in this game is mind-blowing; the creators obviously spent a hefty amount of their time researching into what Star Wars has to offer (including EU content).

Land battles are fun, though not visually impressive.  Compared to other RTS games, land battles are certainly lacking.

Space battles are where the game shines the brightest.  Battles are gorgeous, the ships are gorgeous, and the cinematic camera view is certainly entertaining.

The game is fun, especially if you play as Tyber Zann, because it introduces a new concept to Star Wars games: CRIME. The Zann Consortium is infinitely more interesting than most Star Wars factions, at least to me.

Simply put, the only issue with the game is repetition. The game itself really only offers 2 single player modes: campaign and conquest. The former has a short storyline that you can beat in a couple of hours (if you take your time) and conquest is just capturing planets, over and over again. This is essentially the same for multiplayer.

The bottom line: If this game is on sale for a few bucks, I'd say it's worth it but I wouldn't suggest spending 20 bucks on it. It simply doesn't provide enough replay value, unless you reinstall it once a year or so.

It's a very interesting game, you have elements of a 4x4 game, a normal RTS game, and capture point RTS.

Simple explantion of a game: Many planets, some have perks. You first sent your fleet over, than you attack it and take control. You have pre-made units that you deploy to the plant. Than you build on the planet whatever you want. 

I enjoyed the concept that you need more than one fleet to protect choke point planets and sometimes you need a ground presence, but generally if your fleet is destroyed and your planted is invaded it's not going to be much of a battle because you can only keep "X" amount of units actually on a planet. 

The game starts to go wrong half way through the game:

1. Space battles. As the Empire you can not build normal tie fighters, they come from your crusiers. The Empire does feel stronger in space when you are the rebels, but when you play them they are capped at 20 compared to Rebels being caped at 25. Which would be fine, but you're two major big ships cost more points compared to the Rebels big ships. 

Overall the space battles are interesting but at the same time you're fleet doesn't seem to respond very well to what you want them to do. More so when you hit a ships special ability. 

2. Ground battles 

When you play as the rebels your missle soilders are a key fuction, they deal a great deal of damage to vehicels. When you play as the Empire they seem to do even more against you. Which is fine in the long run, yet as the Empire you don't have any missle toting storm troopers. 

Vehicles are too easily defeated, they seem to die quicker than soilders. More so they don't seem to deal a lot of damage, even the big ATT shots at the rebels soilders and the damage isn't near what you would think it would be. Yet somehow you need them.

The speeder bikes for the Empire are sort of pointless. They are suppose to drop a little bomb, but by the time you click on it your bike is blown apart, and your lone storm trooper is doomed. They are meant for exploring and doing quick bombing runs but it never works out. You don't need to scout...You know there are a ton of baddies (or goodies-depends how you feel about the rebels) in the location where you are sending them.

The Rebels assult speeder is basically untouchable, nothing the rebels have can really damage it. It's not like they do a lot of damage, but they can bring down your ATT with the cable lines. Since none of their soilders or tech have something to bring a flying unit down you have to hope there is a pod where you can build a missle bay. Even than your range is very limited. 

The main isssue is the balance, there is not a lot of countering. Your standard battle is mostly about getting another capture point to bring in more units, and getting close enough to do a bombing run which destroys a building in one shot along with anything around it.  It's pretty much a pissing contest latter in the game and you fighting till you can bomb again, 2-3 bombing and a capture point is how you win.  Strategy goes out the window. 

With that said it's a fun game and even when the game isn't on sale it's worth playing. This is one of the games where it's not a thumbs up or a thumbs down, it's just OKAY. Hardcore Star war fans will probably love it, but it just seems like they could have done a lot more with the game.

The best Star Wars strategy game you will find. Galactic conquest mode is great, allowing for battles across land and space of 50+ planets as any of the game's three factions. Bonuses gained while occupying planets diversify it quite a bit and sometimes makes you want to keep the planet rather than blow it up with the Death Star. Don't look for great depth in this game. You have money that is given on a regular interval, which is determined by planets controlled and mining facilities built on them. Use this money To build units or buildings. Diversify units to counter enemy units well.Conquer the galaxy.

The space battles are amazing and what really make this game great. Being able to target specific functions on larger ships (smaller ones like a Nebulon B Frigate, up to a Star Destroyer or Mon Calamari Cruiser, even to a Super Star Destroyer) serves great purpose. The ability to send bombers in to take down shields with proton torpedoes, for example, is a great use of this as it disables the shields on the ships and makes them vulnerable to laser fire. Units  are well balanced, Empire may get the Executor or Death Star to conquer space and destroy planets, but Rebels get Garm Bel Iblis who can sneak past fleets and invade the ground with his powerful shielded tank- capable of winning over many planet systems.

Overall, a great game. I mostly played this as a child when I had it on CD and played a ton, but I do not regret buying this again. However, if you are looking simply for a RTS there are better ones out there (Age of Empires 2, for example). Get this for the impressive Star Wars universe.
A fun way to kill some time, especially if you are a Star Wars fan.  Blowing up a planet with the Death Star is as satisfying as you would expect it to be.

Let me start by saying this game is not flawless by any means. It can be a bit simple, especially compared to other RTS games like Starcraft. However, the voice acting, character design, references to the explanded universe, and multitude of units make this game a ton of fun for a seasoned star wars veteran, and nothing beats getting into a space battle and bringing in the Executor, Vader's mammoth star destroyer, and ripping your enemies in two. Similiarly the ground battles are a ton of fun. My main complaint with this game is in its expansion, Forces of Corruption. It adds another faction to the mix, that in my opinion is incredibly unbalanced, particularly in Galaxy Conquest where their use of Defilers can constantly destroy building, requiring you to clear the corruption with either Thrawn, Vader or the Emporer. Overall a great game, witha few nagging problems.

On Steam it says I've barely played this game, but I played a TON of it when it first came out and didn't have it on Steam. Anyways, it's an old game, and I HATE to say it, but it has not aged well. At all. In fact, if I ever play it again, it will be entirely for nostalgia's sake, unfortunately. The problem is the balance, especially in land battles. 

The way everything is set up just feels weird. It feels like vehicles can die too easily, the Empire infantry weirdly stack up into box formations that just doesn't really fit with the Star Wars atmosphere, and the rocket artillery on the Rebel's side is RETARDEDLY overpowered, to the point where they can almost take out your entire military force at the beginning of a match (yet when you use them, they don't feel nearly as powerful). It's just kind of a weird game, and yes, the space battles are cool, but they have also aged to the point where unfortunately, it's just not worth it anymore. The meta game  (galactic conquest or whatever it's called) is also weird. A lot of time there are strangely fast time limits to win the game, which annoys me because it gives little time to really develop a nice army and tech that can really do damage. And since it's all in real time, it sometimes devolves into a game of tag, where each side has their core planets, and then all the outlying planets are taken by one side, then taken by another, and so on and so forth, and this is due to the unit cap, which restricts you from truly building a large enough force to take over the empire. There's so many connections to all of the planets that it's not easy to actually form a stronghold, and while there is strategy in that, the game isn't quite good enough to compell you to want to develop the skills to master that strategy. I don't think I ever finished a single galactic conquest map. I ended up just reverting to multiplayer (which I can only assume is dead now).

If you played the game before, and just want nostalgia to kick in, maybe pick it up on a sale, but if you've never played it before, I'd say move on to better RTS games.

Honestly, it doesn't seem like this game came out 5 years ago. This is one of my favorite RTS's of all time, right next to AoE. The dual plane RTS mechanic is what makes this game a great balance between combat and building your empire. I have yet to replay  through the story, but I recall it being really fun and quite long (If you consider the different story lines just one campaign, it is even longer). Also, being able to refine and hone in your ground combat skills in the skirmish mode is very helpful, since you don't have to initiate an extensive galactic conquest match. Since I don't want to have a wall of text, nor feel like making an in depth review, just buy this game. Here is a synopsis of why you should:

+ Star Wars
+ Really great space battles
+ Fun ground battles
+Great sounds and sound track
+ A good learning curve; this game can appeal to casual gamers as well as hardend RTS players. It just depends on how much time you want to put into the game, and if you want a challenge (the CPU opponents can get pretty feisty lol)
+ A plethora of units from the entire Star Wars galaxy 
+ The cinematic view is cool
+ Space battles in particular are super fun to just sit back and watch. Something about them lasers...

Really the only con(s) would be
- Price. But the game gives you so much content for a fraction of the cost of a big name companies would charge. That said, I'd suggest getting it on sale if you still have reservations about buying it
- Graphics. The game is 5 years old, what do you expect? Even so, it really isn't that bad maxed out, it actually looks quite good for its age! 

All in all, great game. I have yet to find anything bad/wrong about the game. 10/10

EDIT:
I've since played throught the campaign, and its really fun. Not necessarily note worthy story telling, and there isn't much of a plot, but I still found it entertaining to play through. It isn't as long as I recalled, being that it took me ~5hrs and I was purposely taking my time.
