The game was first released in 2006, and the graphics are very much of that time.  But the gameplay is still a classic in terms of strategy base-building games.  There is a narrative to the game but that is mainly to flesh out a plot for you for to build an army and to attack and invade planets.  Ground warfare consists of taking landing zones to gain not only a foothold on the planet, however, it is also to increase the size of your army due to the cap level placed, and as your tech upgrades furthers your army's capabilities, so does it make your space fleet stronger, and space is the gem of where this game is at.  Corruption brings to bear all that is shown in Star Wars VI: The Return of the Jedi, employing everything from X Wing and Tie fights, to superstar destroyers and death stars.  Quite simply, this game is brilliant, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking to play a simple build and conquer game.
A must for any Star Wars or RTS fan

Love it.

The concept of this game is pretty fantasitc. Other RTS's, such as: Warcraft III and Starcraft and Command and Conqore with Red Alert as well, you build your base and then your army, and then you attack/defend. This game you build your base  on other planets, then your army, then you take your army and attack the enemy base which is on another planet. The ideal behind this is the person playing defense has the advantage. They have factories that will constantly put out troops, while you are limited to the troops that you brought. You attack their space station and their defenses, while they continually get backup. So you have to work quick to bring them down. Making this a unique and interesting approach to the classic RTS
However this game is not without its quirks. It is starting to show age and some of the units are not fully balanced. But since the multiplayer really never kicked off, they didnt keep messing with it. Yet this doesnt take away from the fact that it is a fun game to play, especially when you are with your buddies/roomies and just have a lan party for an hour or so, or just play single player. The skirmish battles with a hard AI is quite the challenge.
So dispite its setbacks, this game still pleases, even after all these years.

The game has good graphics (for its age), lots of strategies to try and many different worlds, vehicles and military units with unique traits to discover. While it has a few flaws (the expansion bugs sometimes and the AI is way too predictable when you know how to play), they're not likely to disturb the gameplay too much.

Honestly, I think this is an excellent game that is definetly worth trying.

I used to play this game back in my college days, and when it went on sale on Steam, I got it for nostalgic value. Playing through it again, it reminded me of all the faults and all the pros of the game.

"Empire at War" is kind of like the Command and Conquer games, but placed in the Star Wars universe. You have a map of the Star Wars galaxy, and can choose to play the Empire or the Rebellion (I never played the expansion). The universe map is semi-real time, with the clock ticking while you choose to raise units and build structures on various planets to either gain resources, research better technology, be able to build more units, etc. You can move ships from planet to planet, and in the case of battles, there are two: space battles, just above the planet surface; and land battles, after you've secured the space above the planet and have troops available to attack.

Sometimes space battles can be boring. If you have the upper edge, you can pretty much just sit there and stare at the screen while the enemy is obliterated. That being said, if there's a decent fleet facing you, things can get exciting. It's also exciting if you're outnumbered: there were a couple of good fights where I had nothing but a space station and a few regular ships up against a much larger fleet, and managed to come out victorious. This is where micromanaging (a dreaded word to some) comes in really handy.

Land battles can be more engaging. One thing I must recommend in battle: USE THE SPECIAL SKILLS OF YOUR UNITS - A LOT! Not even just your hero units, but you're regular units as well. If you try to play this game with the units as is, you're going to lose every time. Trust me - I know it might sound weird, but unless you really put time and effort into your micromanaging, you're going to get overrun. When I first started playing again, I didn't do this, and got frustrated when I kept losing. When I started to use the special abilities for even foot soldiers, things turned around. The only other complaint I might have about land battles is the drop point limitation can be annoying sometimes; on some planets, you can only land three or four units, and then you need to really push and use your strategy to obtain other drop points in order to increase your army. If you're not careful, one of the annoying default units of the planet will swipe in and steal your drop point. In fact, the default (or "native") units on planets will be especially annoying given how quickly they spawn. However, this doesn't make land battles IMPOSSIBLE - you just need to be wiser and keep these things in mind.

Perhaps the saddest part about this game is the cinematic camera option. Basically, in the midst of a battle, you can choose to have the camera look at the scene from various angles, as if you're watching a movie. The problem is how the game decides to put the camera is peculiar. You could have a massive battle like the opening of Episode III...and the camera chooses to focus on a giant rock floating off to the side. What?! Sometimes it will shoot at a random part of the space station completely untouched by the battle. Again, not sure how they developed the camera system, but it's disappointing how lacking it is in delivery.

Overall, this game is a fun way to past the time, if you want a strategy game set in the Star Wars universe. It's not the greatest strategy game ever, but it can be one of those games you install and play every now and then. With Star Wars fandom picking up again, probably worth a try.
If this game works for you than congrats! It is a fun game and is worth every penny. Just be wary though, for it might not work for you.

Some reasons this game is so good:
[list]
[*]Easy for a complete noob (i.e. me) to start playing.
[*]Has solid multiplayer (with the help of Evolve or other similar software).
[*]Is the only game that allows full immersion in Star Wars battles on such a grand scale.
[*]As of this moment, I have barely touched on the Galactic Conquest gamemode. But if you play smart, you can amass a colossal fleet of Star Destroyers and cripple everyone, which is amazing to watch.
[/list]

Some interesting things that have happened so far:
[list]
[*]My friend had a full population of B1 Battle Droids, I had an orbital strike and annihilated said Droids.
[*]In a 2v2 game: Other team attack all our mining facilities, they lose to teammates Acclamators.
He attacks their base, a solid stalemate. I then send in the 6 Venators I've been stockpiling. Win.
[*]I start my first Galactic Conquest game. 5 minutes later. Alderaan is being attacked. I have 2 Venators and a couple of other ships defending it. Droids have 13 of their biggest cruisers. I lose.
[/list]

In short AI > friends.

Personally, as a casual strategist, I think that this is a really great and fun game. Overall, most of the controls and mechanics are solid, and of course it doesn't look fabulous, but the graphics are not bad and, to me, the game looks fine. Besides, a little less graphical quality helps it run better on non-dedicated gaming machines. The AI in the game are not super hard, and you will find things about bad ground AI, but to me the AI in ground battles has been fine, and the space battle AI is still good. Really huge Star Wars fans would love this game, as well as many casual strategists.

Rebel campaign, in my opinion, seems a little harder early on - you don't really have a ship equal to light Imperial cruisers, though you do have bombers.

Besides, some of the space battles can get pretty awesome, with large fleets of Star Destroyers or Mon Calamari ships.

For those who don't want to do a lengthy campaign, there is a solid skirmish mode.

Overall, a solid game that looks alright and is pretty fun for most strategists.

SIDE NOTE: One of my favorite, somewhat ridiculous battles that I had was as the empire in the campaign mode.
(LOOKS AT INCOMING FLEET) 1 missile ship, okay.
6 corellian corvettes: my Acclamators can handle them.
21 squadrons of Z-(21?)s: That's alot.
56 squadrons of X-wings: This is going to take a while.

Proceeds to epic battle as hordes of X-wings pummel helpessly at the shields of my Cruisers as they laser the Corvettes into oblivion and then slowly mop up X-wings, since they are not good anti-fighter ships.

Ignore how many hours I have logged on steam, I had this game on disc before and easily have hundreds, possibly a thousand hours unlogged on it.

Onto the review:
[h1]NOTE:[/h1]
I have only played Star Wars: Empire at War, not the Forces of Corruption expansion that also came with the Steam version, thus that makes this review for the core game itself, not the FoC expansion!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game itself is an RTS. Rebellion vs Empire in the Star Wars universe that features a galactic map system (Something people might be familiar with in the old Star Wars Battlefront games). However EAW features both land and space battles in a two-step invasion system to conquer a planet. The ultimate goal is to take control over the entire galaxy, but to achieve it smaller, and much more tedious and annoying goals must be finished. The online multiplayer last time I checked no longer functions due to gamespy shutting down their multiplayer servers (RIP). But back when it was online there were a few gamemodes, none I really played. It had a fairly sizable modding community which provided custom maps, Which I am not sure you can get anymore as they were hosted on filefront. Not to say this game is boring, but just throwing out there that there are custom maps for this game you could find.

[h1]Standard Maps[/h1]
Every planet (Excluding one, the astroid fields.) has it's own space and ground map, which will lead to hours of gameplay alone as you battle through each of them for either faction. But be aware a lot of them have native species which will either side with you, your enemy, or themselves. There are build pads scattered across the maps in key locations and choke points where you can build turrets (AA, AT, and AI), radar scanners (Sensor Nodes), or a medical station/vehicle repair station.

[h1]Misc.[/h1]
The graphics on thisgame show their date. The game itself is pretty old. But like I stated before, there are mods for that. Just use google and you can probably still find them.
This game has very few custom songs, maybe none at all from what I know. All the music I have heard in this game is recycled from the official movie's soundtracks.
I would especially recommend this game for newer players getting into the RTS genre as it is a very forgiving game on the easier difficulties. RTS veterans would still have a bit of a problem playing on the hardest difficulty as I have found the AI player does not really have many restrictions on it, meaning it will start producing units from multiple locations at the same time and have dozens of fleets moving at the same time, leaving the player at a severe disadvantage.

This game rocks. 

I've always loved rts and I've always loved star wars and this game really does a great job of combining the two. The split between empire-building by controlling and upgrading facilities on different star systems and the real time strategy of both space and land skirmishes remind me a of the Total War franchise and I like it a lot.

The real time missions though are what gets me. You can just jump right into them from the main menu without doing a campaign - a live action space or land battle at your fingertips. Did you ever have those little figurines off the millenium falcon or of some star destroyers or x-wings? I used to play with those things; flying them around and making up little battles and narratives to go with them. This game gives you what you always wanted that experience to be. Good sized fleets and armies to fight even though you'll still find yourself wanting more. There are a couple of maps that allow you to fight more than one AI but not too many. The game does allow for the play of custom maps which is really neat in concept, if a little bit of a hassle to get too for....uh. well lazy people like me when it comes to these things. 

Overall this game is great and I would definitely reccomend it. Disney, this game would make for a great sequel, especially with the great reception of the recent Total War games (once the bugs were fixed). I would love bigger maps!

A suprisingly good starwars game despite the glut of terrible ones produced by the late Lucas Arts.  It has a very strange system that I have not seen in a game that I remember.  You have the campaign map, but it is not static.  You generate money pretty quick and the enemy can attack you at anytime.  The land and space battles are similar to say what total war is on a much smaller and different scale, but there is no pause after on the campaign.  

The difference in difficulty between the rebel campaign and the imperial campaign is huge.  As the empire you should have no problem steam rolling the alliance.  Imperial ships are heavily armored, carry free tie fighters, and have more fire power than most rebel ships.  Your land units will also destroy people.  ATATs can produce squads of free storm troopers meaning you have the best anti veicle and decent anti infantry that cost nothing.  

The alliance campaign on the other hand can be frusturating.  Get read to have the auto resolve tell you that your fleet can own 10 victory star destroyers only to play it out and be destroyed.  Because you rely on figters so much, and the Y wing is your only chance against imperial capital ships, its devastating when a Tantun cruiser kills almost all of them in 10 seconds.  Managing ships is hard.  With the empire you just send in your gugernauts and they kill everything.  With the alliance untill you get the assault frigate expect to see your capital ships blown out of orbit.  The nebulon B frigate (medical frigate) is really only good at giving Luke a robot arm and being blown to peices.  

Luckily even if you cant hold space, you can hold planet surfaces if you invest in defenses.  The battles can be tense though.  But just as shields are hard for you, they are for the enemy.  Rebel infantry are really good, just watch out for the over powered tie maulers who can just run your entire army over at 60mph.  

Still the best starwars RTS I can think of, and there are lots of mods.  I think there is even a 40k mod.

Having logged countless hours in the retail version back when retail was up-to-date, I was eager to play it again and replay an awesome RTS in the SW universe.  Now before the actual review, I would like to warn windows 8 users: MAKE SURE THAT YOU DO NOT BUY THE RETAIL VERSION!!! You will find this game super cheap on Amazon, E-Bay, etc, but they will not run correctly on win8 systems. There is an official patch to fix this, but it doesn't always fix the whole problem. However, you will not need to patch and/or modify the game on steam to work :)

 Now for the review:

Yes EaW is old, but it can compete with most current RTS games pretty well. EaW brings cool ideas to the table like space battles, hero units, and a conquest mode in which you have to conquer the galaxy!!! While EaW wasn't the first to do some of those things, they sure did them right. Ok now time for the generic Pros and Cons section:


Pros:
Doesn't feel repetitive
Has a large map variety
Explores a part of the SW timeline from an interesting new perspective
It's in the SW universe!!!
Space Battles
Balancing is ok (Aside from the Rebels and their suprise armadas out of nowhere!)
Zann Consortium adds a fun new play style



Cons
Kinda pricy for an old game
Graphics (Expected from an old game)
Battles should be bigger (There's probably a mod for that)
MP is dead :( (There are programs for running MP on Gamespy dependent games though, look up Evolve or Gameranger)
Rebels are really OP and can do massive suprise invasions



Conclusion:

If you like Star Wars, RTS games, or both, then buy this game. If you are looking for stunning graphics and scripted events every minute, then this game is not for you. If you found this review to be good, please mark it as helpful, but if not, then please mark it as not helpful so I can re-write it :)

So, what to say about this game...I can't recommend it quite enough for those into strategy games. You can play as the Empire or the Rebellion (or the Zaan Consortium, in the expansion) and battle against each other in skirmishes, campaigns or a free-for-all in galactic conquest. You manage the buildings on your planets, generating armies and navies. The ground combat is a bit lacking, but the space battles totally make up for it. Don't let my hours fool you, I used to play this game obsessively years ago, and picked it up on sale recently.

The only problem I have with the game is the balancing, in that there is none. It's actually kind of overshadows proceedings. If you want to play as the Empire, I'd give a couple run throughs of the Rebellion or Consortium first, because the Empire is severely underpowered compared to those two (until you get the Super Star Destroyer and the Death Star, which takes quite some time. Even then, they can only be in one place at a time). The Rebellion is pretty much unbeatable on the ground, having artillery that might as well just automatically win every assault, and the expansion gave them fast-moving torpedo ships that make space combat a headache. The Consortium generates credits so quickly they can just effortlessly throw massive armies and navies at you over and over until you Phyrric Victory yourself into the grave. Not to mention they've got the Canderous Assault Tank, which is so OP that ten of them can take out pretty much anything you've got. The Empire really has nothing to compare.

Still, balancing aside, it's a great strategy game, and if you love strategy games, you should definitely pick this up.

I like Star Wars Empire at War because it fun it let you think under pressure.

Don't let my time online discourage you, I've played this game to death offline.
Empire at War is a stunning Real Time Strategy revolving around the 'Rise of the Empire era' Star Wars universe. The main game allows you to take the sides of both the Galactic Empire and the Rebel Alliance across varied planets and participate in epic space battles above said planets. Famous environments such as Hoth, Endor and Coruscant return as well as lesser known planets from spin offs and extended universe canon.
Ultimately you control either faction with the goal of controlling every location in the galaxy. Along the way you will participate in skirmishes with land forces and space fleets and combat your enemies in engaging and clever ways. Land battles see you build bases and call in ground troops from your fleet in space to wipe out the enemy presence while space battles see you attacking or defending a space station with a wide range of units such as fighters, frigates and capital ships.
The expansion pack, Forces of Corruption, adds a third faction and a wide array of new locations, units, and ways to play.  You can now play as the Zahn Consortium, a group of intergalactic space pirates who want their own share of the galaxy. The new setting takes place during the galactic war and sees you entering the fight between the Rebels and the Empire.
This is an amazing RTS that really captures the feeling of being a part of the Star Wars universe. If there's only one Star Wars game you should play, this is it.

For a game as old as this one it delivers on so many aspects, and with the modding community thats built up over the years  this game is something everyone should definutely have in they're library. Its a simple strategy game where you pick your faction, manage your income(its not complex at all you get so many credits per second/day depending on what mode your playing--skirmish or a campaign), build the units you need, move whatever units, point being its all at your your control, upgrade your tech lvl to lvl 5 and conquer the galaxy or cream the AI in skirmish mode. Its all in real time but you can fast forward, pause, and play at your descretion at any time. Multiplayer is where the game just gets better, add some mods and hit repeat, this game only improves on itself. I can't wait to see any sort of sequel. 

In conclusion, I've had years of fun with this game and its one of the best space RTS games available even today, theres a reason this game is on the top ten list of the best star wars games of all time.

Had this on disc for years but time to its toll and both the expanision and base discs got damaged to the point of not being read by any drive I put them in.

After seeing this in the sale, I jumped at the chance and instantly bought it.

Empire at War is a great pick-up and go game. It's gameplay is fast enough to not get boring quickly but it still maintains the challenge and pace of a true startegy game. If you have a beefy system, I'd recommend modding the game to allow for (virtually) unlimited population caps, especially in space battles. Nothing more fun than playing with friends and having a massive battles spanning across the entire map.

Don't worry if your system isn't powerful either, my laptop (AMD E1 @ 1.35GHz) can handle pretty large battles with not a huge loss in framerate. Plus it runs it with max details and AA too so I can't complain too much.

As I'm only a user of LAN multiplayer, I cannot comment on the Online support but I believe that programs such as gameranger may help get you playing over the internet.

All in all. Do I recommend this game? Yes and no, while I find it fantastic myself, it's not going to be a showstopper for everyone. If you like Star Wars but are still unsure, wait until a sale and give it a go :)

If you like massive spacebattles in a Star Wars theme then this is one of the best games. You can play against AI or players on both the surface of many different planets or in space above them or in fields of asteroids. Empire or rebels the choice is yours, both have their own campaigns. If you add the "Republic at War" mod you may play as the Confederacy of Independent Systems or as the republic. Well, Steam has FRAK'ed US in the a** again !!!!

This , SW:EAW Gold,  is normally a great deal at $10 (Wallmart, Discount Books & Games).
Now, it went on sale this weekend .........sounds great, right??? Wrong.

First a couple of issues....if you already bought the game (on CD / retail box version) and wanted to play your friends that just got the game from steam's download.......you going to have huge problems playing them online, through steam.

Frankly, it won't happen....you will have to figure out how to play though the game's internal multi-player Internet (which will want you to make yet another account , email and password)

So, after 3 hours of frustration of the CD not wanting to update from version 1.01 to 1.5.....you desided "FRAK IT", and buy the game though steam.

Well, be prepared to kiss $8 good-bye.......because after you paided for the game, and got it installed, you will get hit with steam's Error :: Failed to Contact Key Server.

So...once again, a good running game that worked well on CD, has been turned to crap when downloaded threw steam.

Thanks alot, Steam. --Way to Go.

There are three Star Wars games that should really set the bar for any that follow them: Star Wars: Jedi Knight III: Jedi Academy, Star Wars: Battlefront II, and the one you are looking at right now, Star Wars: Empire at War.

Essentially a Total War game in the Star Wars universe, albeit with a realtime campaign map as opposed to turn-based, this game offers a deeply enjoyable RTS and Grand Strategy experience, all set in the wonderful world of Star Wars. Play the Empire and crush the rebellion with your lumbering fleets of Star Destroyers and the legendary planet-destroying planetoid, the Death Star. Alternatively, shatter the tyranny of the Empire as a fledgeling Rebel Alliance, utilizing fast and agile ships to run circles around your foe.

Ultimately, of the three gameplay modes, Space Battles are where the game design shines the most, followed closely by the campaign map, both of which overshadow, by a large degree, the lackluster ground battles. But this is not an issue. The Space Battles and Campaign map are so engrossing that you will likely get more fun and replayability out of those two modes alone, than a version of this game where more time were diverted to making better ground battles.

Ultimately, I highly recommend this classic gem of a game to Star Wars and strategy gaming fans alike!

P.S. I have probably over 200 hours in this game on the CD version, which I had since barely a month after its release!

[h1]A decent game made great by its space battles and player mods[/h1]

Plenty of bang for your buck, with three campaigns, about a dozen turn-based conquest modes, and classic skirmish battles. However, if you're an experienced RTS fan, you might find the ground battles lacking. The unit controls are imprecise, the balance questionable, and the pop limit placed painfully low. 

That said, the space battles are magnificent. Each class of ship has its place, and the pop limit gives you far more breathing room. The game just shines here.

And when vanilla bores you, check out some of the mods on moddb. I personally recommend the Revenge of Thrawn and Republic at War projects, both of which introduce a plethora of new units familiar to longtime Star Wars fans.

Star Wars Empire at War combines a great combination of ground and space combat which not only looks great but also plays well.

The game works around the idea of a galactic map with planets that you control. these create a general map that you have to conquer, each planet can change control to whoever conquers it and has two levels of defence that you can have.
Ground defence allows you to have fight in traditional RTS ways where you have to eliminate the hostile forces to capture the planet  or stop an invasion force.

Space combat allows you to bring large or small ships into combat using RTS gameplay, this creates great combat and gives you the oportunity to play as you want. there can also be a space station and defences that you can build / destroy making space combat vary in each fight.

the game in general is good fun for anyone who likes RTS games with a unique take on the genre. i find that it is enjoyable and the game has its own fan made expansion which completely overhauls the game and changes the empire and rebels to republic and federation. This allows for an entirely new type of gameplay as the new units have far more weapon spots and units which makes your screen light up with turbo lasers.

the expansion however can run a bit slugish if you go insane and spam battledroids as the game tanks and doesnt run too well.

in general i would say if you like RTS conquest games then give this a shot, its pretty cheap now and the free expansion Republic at War allows for a near whole new game.

If you like Star Wars or science fiction in general, and have an interest in real time strategy, I recommend this one. In single player there is the option to pause even during battle, so you don't have to worry about controlling all of your units with keyboard inputs.

The space battles are the highlight, I personally enjoy the ground battles as well though. I have had limited success with the multiplayer. In gameplay terms, the Empire is more about brute force, the Rebels are about smart tactics. So you can look at it and see the Empire as easy mode and the Rebels as hard mode, or being two different playstyles.

Though if you enjoy messing stuff up, play Force of Corruption and take Darth Vader into a space battle. Super Star Destroyer > All.

This game is truly a treat to strategy gamers.

I would call myself a strategy fanatic since mostly the only games I ever play are strategy, and I will easily recommend this as being one of my top five. After the Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds installments, it seemed pretty hard to be able to follow up another decent strategy without making it too modernised and missing out key elements that make true strategy games, especially a Star Wars one also. 

But I can truly say they pulled it off with this game. This game is a crystal to the RTS genre and provides players with the ability to be able to Strategically take over the Galaxy, as three different factions fight for power - you have to use all assets at your disposal to assert your faction above others. This power can be asserted by RTS space battles, in which huge fleets massacre eachother, or in RTS ground battles, where every unit has a weakness and strength, meaning that combat must be played strategically.

I recommend this game to anyone looking in the RTS genre, as even for the 20+ hours i've played it, it is a gem to the RTS genre.
This game is by far one of the greatest games of which I have played. I would highly reccomend it to those who like strategy.

This is my favorite RTS of all time. Probably because I've never played C&C but anyways this is a very simple RTS but a very fun RTS too. First, there are the Space battles which are pretty fun and can be super epic. Then there's the land battles which are pretty slow and boring, there are some cool moments that can happen but you will most likely auto-resolve. There are 3 campaigns, Many Galactic Conquest modes, and Skirmish battles. Galactic Conquest is what I think is the best mode because you can conquer more planets and choose your approach. Campaign is a simple Star Wars story and teaches you how to play the game. Skirmish battles are land/space battles where you destroy the enemy base. Unfortunatly the game's multiplayer no longer works but you can play regular Empire at War (No Forces of Corruption because Steam counts it as DLC.) with Gameranger.

What I do suggest if you get bored is that you download some mods. Some of my favorites are Republic at War, Thrawn's Revenge, and Super Star Wars: Rise of the Droid Empire. I give this game a 9/10 but I say get this game on the May 4th sale because thats the only time I've seen it on sale

Fantastic game for the most part. Typically keeps me entertained but eventually becomes painfully boring due to long hours searching for that last troop on a massive map. Also when fighters are put against one another (Like me vs NPC), the fighter icon goes next to the enemy fighter icon and nothing really happens. Also the drivers of the ships arent very smart either because they never attack or move where you want them to move.

Let me start by saying I do believe this is worth buying but I caution you if you are a fan of RTS games that this may not be what you are used to. The modding community has also done wonders with this game and for the Republic at War mod alone is worth buying the game.

The game is split into 2 distinct parts. The galaxy overview where you build bases, move your troops and play in a Risk like format. The second part is the the RTS side of the game where you control your troops directly. This is further split into space combat and ground combat. I'm going to give each a review and then add the sum for my total review.

First with the ground combat it always involves protecting or destroying the buildings. The defending side get's units through deployed troops already built and gets further free troops from buildings designed to construct units. The offensive side I find often is at a disadvantage and it becomes of game of invading with totally overwhelming numbers or playing more tactically with stealth based units. This generally ends up being long winded and downright boring battles in the later parts of the game where the combat is meant to be more fast and furious to keep a game going. For the ground combat I'd give it a 2/5.

Second the space combat. This is where the game really shines and you can recreate some of the great moments from the movies. The Rebels and the Empire both play very differently and it keeps the fights fresh each time. The Imperials go for that ovewhelming numbers and get free Tie Fighters and bombers from the capitol ships. The Rebels why they need to buy Fighters and Bombers are generally more well rounded to deal with threats. Capitol ships on both sides play fairly the same with your standard Rebel Crusiers and Star Destroyers but what makes space combat so unique is that larger ships and space stations have hardpoints to target. To many Tie fighters take out the hangar. Mon Calamari Cruiser flanking around you take out its engines and leave it stranded. This adds a whole new dimension to and RTS that I've never played before and makes it a truly tactical experience. Space combat gets a 5/5.

Finally the Galaxy Overview portion. It's fairly straightforward and just involves moving units, building bases on planets, sabatoging enemy bases and upgrading the tech tree. For players who don't want to play the battles can actually play and entire match from this screen and let the computer simulate the battles for you. It's different, it's cool, it's noting totally special but does offer a new take at strategy games. The Galaxy overview gets a 4/5.

Don't expect much difficulty from the computer. The AI is somewhat dissapointing but fear not. One of the best parts of this game is what the modders have created for it. The Republic at War mod can take the place of the expansion and allows you to play out the Republic vs. Seperatist conflict. The AI in that is tough. I'm at the point where all I play is Republic at War and it offers the challenge that I was looking for from an AI in an RTS. AI gets a 4/5.

So when you add it up the game is a 15/20. That takes into accounts both the vanilla game and the modded game. The modded version is much better and totally free so it's absolutely worth getting. Vanilla version is more for people who want to learn the game or are big Star Wars fans. In all it's not super difficult and definately different from most RTS games on the market. I definately recommend this game!

Quite an interesting RTS format, with a galaxy wide strategy mode and both space and land battles that are very exciting!

Land battles are a bit different to typical RTS games, in that there's no real base building. The units you get for a battle are all the units you brought with you for the invasion, no more no less. You start out with just a few on the board, but by capturing control points around the map you can bring down additional forces via dropship.

A few minor nitpicks: The 'accelerate game time' button (which you will use a lot, as you wait for buildings or units to be built in the galaxy overlay) isn't really that fast, and battles can feel a little sluggish at times.

Apart from that though, definitely worth a look. There are mods out there for those who prefer Clone Wars battles, too!

Decent RTS with a mixture of space and ground combat with some planetary management and heroes thrown into the mix. This game can be challenging at normal difficulty if you are like me an not a RTS master in ground combat, though space combat (what you REALLY look forward too) can be a bit too easy sometimes once you start fortifying your planets with high level space stations.

I really recommend this game if you love RTS and Star Wars games.

Simply put. The venerable "Mac Daddy" of (non story driven) Star Wars video games.
Sure theres a story but, who does that when you can conquer the Galaxy with a fleet of Imperial Star Destroyers, or crush the Imperial war effort with squadron upon squadron of X-wing fighters and Y-wing bombers, or even indulge your inner Hutt and corrupt the galaxy with slavery and intimidation.
Sure the graphics are dated and theres a limited amount of playability in the main story. But with a host of mods online ranging from simple ship re designs to full scale Clone Wars overhauls (complete with Episode 1-3 heroes and villains from tv shows and movies), The range of galactic conquest ideas goes on and on, What happens if the Imperials wiped out Dantoine and Hoths rebel bases, what if the Rebellion retook courscaunt? It's all in your hands... or steam library so go on.
Rule the Galaxy!

played this in CD version before i found it on steam, and am always enthralled everytime i play it, the ability to jump in a super star destroyer is always a must have option in a game for me :3 however, the AI doesnt always seem to think tactically, as even on hard im still finding the AI rushes my ships, oh well, if your looking for a game that has nearly all major planets, vehicles, and notable personnel, including expanded universe, this is it, the gameplay is relatively easy to grasp, theres only one resource you need, and you can even play as the underworld/black market in the corruption expansion, which unlocks more planets, more ships, more units, and a third, unique faction :3 lots of game content and worth the money i spent

I bought this game a week ago, and before I even thought of writing a review I wanted to play this game extensively. Its been eight or nine years since Empire at War was released and it still holds up as a viable and entertaining game, even though the engine is a bit outdated.
   Space Battles are superb and can mass into hundreds of ships locked in hull to hull engagements. The battles are so detailed to the point where you can order a squadron of TIE fighters or X-Wings to attack a starship using a unique hitpoint structure for the games time (We have seen it many times since). However, I have to say the space battles are the MOST impressive aspect of this game.
   Unlike the space battles which is almost unlimited on your size of the seige, the land invasions are heavily restricted on how much is on the battlefield at one time.  You land at a command point with a set number of reinforcement slots and must wisely choose what unit you want on the field. The options are massive as the Galactic Conquest mode offers forty-three planets to dominate under the Galactic Empire or the Rebel Alliance. It is an amazing sight to see five to six AT-AT's roam Hoths frozen tundra in search of the elusive Rebel Base, and you actually command them!!
   To tell you readers interested in this epic game the answer you were reading for, BUY THIS GAME!!! You will be blown away at the magnitude this game can throw at you making every unit and desicion you make a careful one! This game is easily worth the buy      9/10
          *I highly reccomend downloading the Republic at War mod from moddb.com, it's the most solid mod I've seen in years

I first played Empire at War when I was 9 and I have been hooked ever since. Now I'm 15 and I am still loving it. Although I personally never get tired of Story Mode and Galactic Conquest Mode, I occasionally look up mods (this game has some of the best mods of all time, even if you don't have the DLC expansion pack) and I love those too. I usually compare this game to Halo Wars on Xbox 360. The gameplay is very similar to upgrading buildings and telling troops where to go on the battlefield, and the space combat is exactly the same. There is an out of battle part of the gameplay (unless playing Skirmish Mode) where you send fleets and troops to other planets to attack, reinforce, or retreat. You also train troops and build ships and space stations for when you actually fight in this part of the game. There are heroes in the game you can play as (Darth Vader, Boba Fett, Han Solo, Chewbacca, Luke Skywalker (Red Squadron in base game only, Jedi Knight in DLC only), Yoda, and more). This game was a gateway drug to strategy games for me and I was obviously attracted to it as a Star Wars fanboy, but this really did get me into strategy games. The only thing I might be worried about is the fanboy level in this game. If you are not a fanboy, this game is still worth trying, but you might get bored way too early.
If you like Strategy or commanding games this is the game for you!

As RTS games go, this title isn't going to redefine the genre in any way. But that doesn't stop it from being an enjoyable enough game, especially if you're a Star Wars nut. Personally i find the space battles to be the real highlight for me, they're just so much better than ground force battles. I also must admit to having NEVER played as the rebel alliance, i always play as the Empire... purely because their ships and vehicles look so much better! For this reason i'm not sure just how balanced the gameplay is in terms of unit strength or if the number of recruitable units varies to make up for the difference in strength... after all, sure an AT-AT is going to be pretty tough to beat, but i wouldn't fancy the rebels chances if the Empire could recruit as many AT-AT's as the rebels can recruit in soldiers!

Those of you who want to play as the rebels will be at least partially pleased to hear that the AT-AT doesn't appear until VERY late in the campaign. Same applies to the vast Executioner class Star Destroyers, although those ships seem to be lacking in firepower and are little more than enormous target practice sites. The bad news for the rebels though is if the Empire manage to finish constructing the Death Star and retrieve the stolen plans, they've already as good as won. If you're playing as the Empire then consider this good news, especially as you then get to destroy 4 or 5 planets and revel in genuine global destruction.

In terms of graphics and audio, this game is fine and has stood the test of time well. In terms of gameplay it's pretty simple, bringing in little in the way of new features to the RTS genre. So if you're a fan of Star Wars and like the established RTS style of game, you're going to really enjoy this. If you're looking for something new, this will be a very shallow game indeed.

This particular ditty was released back in 2006 and at the time, I couldn’t have been more excited.  A game like this was a long time coming, as the last title to have a similar theme (“Star Wars: Rebellion”) was released back in 1998.  I won’t bother reviewing a game that is well over five years old, but I will say that it was an incredible feat and achievement.

Essentially, the player will control either the Rebels or the Imperials and attempt to wipe the other out.  Galactic Conquest mode will let you play a game similar to what you may have experienced in “Star Wars: Rebellion”.  You’ll attempt to grow your empire by capturing planets, which in turn gives you more money in which to expand further and build fleets.  Unlike “Rebellion”, you’ll be in complete control of both space and land battles, though you can automate them if you wish.  Skirmish modes are available for those who just want a quick fix, though it doesn’t do Galactic Conquest justice.
 
An expansion was released later that year (“Forces of Corruption”) that adds a third faction.  This faction resembles a pirate faction that acts very differently during Galactic Conquest mode. I honestly wasn’t very fond of this new faction, as spreading corruption around for the sake of earning credits was tedious and repetitive.  The expansion also forced all three to be played in Galactic Conquest mode, rather than allowing you to pick and choose which factions would be present.  Luckily, Steam lets me load the core game and not the expansion when I want to eliminate this faction.

Overall, still a great game after all these years.

This game is the best of all the series posted here on Steam. If your looking for a game to micro manage units, build complex bases and defence, and lots more this is the game for you. Think of it as CIV 5 , expect better in everyway. You get to move units in real time no "taking turns", if you attack a planet ( city ) you get to send in your infantry/tanks/etc giving them specific orders of where to go, and depending on that, how much damage you will do to their base. Even with a simple squad of infantry, they can sneak around and destroy a building before escaping, breaking down your enemies defences for the main armada.
The only bad thing about this game is that the developers left the game alone. And in turn  leaving the multiplayer lacking in players and "issues" take some time to fix if they do.
Overall: a great game that more developers should look up to and reach for this games level of complexity. The graphics are still pretty decent for being made around 2009 and later.. which i can't say for some of these newer games like "Rust".

This is an amazing RTS game with three main areas. Ground Strike. Space Conflict. Planetary Management.
Ground Strike is both in the main conquest modes and skirmish. It is where you take your infantry, tanks, scouts, and heavy tanks to try to destroy the enemy base or otherwise win. No battle is the same.
Space Conflict is again main conquest modes and skirmish. You take your fleets against the opposing fleets and there is usually a massive space station for one side or both.
Planetary Management is for the conquest modes and is where you decide what structures are built on each world and which units you build.
This game is incredibly addictive and has many mods for it that take literally seconds to install with ease so even if you have beatne the campaign and Galactic Conquest a dozen times for each side, just put on a mod and try it all again.

TIE Fighter, Shadows of the Empire, Dark Forces, Battlefront, and Knights of the Old Republic. What do they all have in common? References, characters, ships, you name it, Empire at War has it all. Not only from the best 6 movies, but the great random genres of the series' video games. I won't spoil much for everyone, but there will be alot of moments and others you want to recognize, and shout out "OH, that was in *other Star Wars game*!!!" 3 great awesome campaigns, of the Rebel Alliance, the Galactic Empire, and the Zann Consortium. Featuring Battlefront's infamous Galactic Conquest, and the Skirmish mode along with multiplayer, you will have hours of fun, depending on how you play: strategy or power.

Although a very very old game, it provides an excellent blend of Galactic management, ground tactical battles, and space tactical battles.

The best parts:
Interactive galactic map that, while it appears overwhleming, it actually extremely simple. Planets have space stations, ground structures, and special effects based on the specific, such as planetary weather or tactical advantages such as production discounts for specific units.
Space battle mechanics. Frigates, Cruisers, Capital ships and Space Stations have "Hardpoints" that have different functions, like torpedo launchers, turbolaser cannons, shield generators, or engines. 
The hardpoints are individually selectable as targets and can be destroyed in any order. As hardpoints are destroyed, the ship loses functions, for example destroying turbolaser cannons will silence them, destroying shield generators permanantly disables shields, and destroying engines reduce speed and manuverability.
The hardpoints also have limited firing zones. What his means, is that turrets can only engage targets in their cone of fire, so it's possible for skilled tacticians to ambush larger ships and hit them in their "Blind spots" to gain a tactical advantage.
Each factions has it's own unique line-ups of ground forces, starships, and heros. Each one is unique, and nearly all units have special abilities to exploit. All units also have carefully designed strengths and weaknesses, and using each one correctly is the key to success.  No point-and-click tank and plane wars where the bigger army wins. A small force of well-played units will trump a large force of point-and-click steamroller armies.

Of course, the game is a bit outdated. The graphics aren't up to date, and the game sacrifices intense, specific battles. It makes up by combining all 3 levels of command in a simpler way that caters to smart, creative tacticians rather than "Point-and-click steamrollers" who are used to just ordering a hundred tanks and craming them down the enemy's throat.

I have never been more addicted to a game than this one. Truely a strategy game, and not just a tactical. The scope for new tactics is huge. The Empire is a lumbering juggernaught spread defensively over its borders; the Rebels need to raid and carry out hit and run attacks to survive. Nearly a decade on and I am still finding new tricks.

Empire at War is one of the few RTSs that has kept its appeal throughout the years without having to re-release or sequelize itself every few years. The land battles have a certain something about them that makes them enjoyable, but the space battles are what really attracts one to the game. A beautifully done piece of art serves as the background for most of the space arenas and the sprites are very well drawn/animated with a good level of detail. Ship movement is fluid, and the AI seems somewhat realistic in sticking with the tactics of their respective STAR WARS sides/teams. All in all, I would recommend this game if you are a fan of STAR WARS space battles, but I would recommend something more like Supreme Commander of Planetary Annihilation for someone in the mood for a good land battle-based RTS.

Star Wars: Empire at War attempts to be to three RTS games in one, a land combat RTS, a space combat RTS and grand stratergy game. Unfortunatley the ground combat is so dull, repetitive and illogical, that I have found the only method of playing this game to be by auto-resolving every ground map. This isn't the only issue the voice acting and story are abysmal, the graphics were unimpressive even at release (Feb '06). Strange descisions were made with characters, vehicles  and abilities, controls are often unintuitive, the GUI looks like a placeholder, not to mention the problems caused with star wars canon.

But... for some reason I still really enjoy playing this game. There is something very satisfying about moving your forces around the galaxy, crushing rebel scum with a fleet of "Imperial-Class Star Destroyers", before blowing up their planet with the death star, which manages to outway the games many negatives. I really hope that one day, a sequel will be made to this game by a more competent developer.

As with most Star Wars games, the game is brimming with potential, but falls well short of the its potential.

I have played this game for over 150 hours and I still keep coming back.  I am a huge fan of RTS games and grew up on the Command and Conquer along with Starcraft and Warcraft games, and this one by and large does them justice.  What is great about this game in particular, in my opinion, is the fact that resource management is pretty much out the window.  You get planets and then you can decide what to do with them, do you want them to focus on making money or making units.  Now while some people find this task a bit arduous, by and large I find it refreshing.  

For those of you who are Star Wars fans, there are going to be some points that are going to irk you about this game when it comes to the continuity.  But as a die hard fan that  I am, I am willing to overlook this, just for the fact that I like to look at this game as a "chose your own adventure" type of game.  Is it right?  Who cares!  I am calling the shots and therefore, what I say goes.  That is all I can really say.  

Overall, if you are looking for a good solid RTS game, and are not on the hunt for badges or acheivements, then I would highly recommend this game.  However, if you are stickler for those types of games, I am sure there are others to tickle your fancy.  But, if this does go on sale, I would still pick it up.

Then there is the "Galactic Conquest" in which you control one of the factions to ultimate galactic domination, crushing, liberating or corrupting.

Well, this is all, finally, I can only say that.... 12/10.

Great game if your looking for awesome space battles!

Pros: 

- SPACE BATTELRUUUU~
- A dated game, yet explosions and ships don't imeadiately disapear, I love how the hunks of destroyed ships fall slowly into the abyss away from the field.
- Awesome spawning in system, team battles are amazing.
- Mostly balanced races for fun all around actual games!
- Mauler Mithel- I mean Darth Vader in a tie counters everything but Darth Vader in a Tie (dat XWING tmg reference)

Cons:

- LAND BATTLES D: so much potential... so much tank spam
- AT-ATs provide free supply of squads, actually very game breaking when you have enough
- Assault speeds counter everything. Harpoons in the future are the key to controling the universe apparently.
- The NINE supply... MFW
- Confusing and very annoying/frustrating when trying to build your units, why not be like the space battle and have everything built/unlocked at one key location? WHY BREAK YOUR OWN GAME!?
- The ultimates are ultimately useless until you knock out the shield generators- and even then, they really don't do that much damage, and are too slow that you literally need the force to make them connect with anything viablly tactical.

Final Review/Opinion:

Great game overall, if the supply lock wasn't so low for un-modded battles, this would be an even better game, but even with the supply locked to a default the battles are intense, and every choice or reinforcement you call in is a  carefully decided choice. Should you go for the giant capital ships, slow but powerful? Or should you field a specialized fleet of fast movers capable of dodging the fire and taking out his big supply units? Micro versus Macro, fleet ships engage with decent AI, fighter squads also engage in decent AI at a ship to ship level of combat. The ground battles are giant blobs however, whoever has the better blob wins. If you see this game on sale, buy it! a must have for every sci-fi nerd or anyone with two eyes!

History lesson:



A long long time ago in this very galaxy LucasArts made a game called "Star Wars: Rebellion". It was a RTS game that was released under Windows 95. While this game was VERY fun, it did have a lot of flaws built into it. (one example would be an overuse of windows). The fans liked the game anyways, and demanded Rebellion 2. LucasArts developed Star Wars: Empire at War (originally called Rebellion 2) 



Review:



This game is a must have for any Star Wars fan, but in reality, it is not the game that Petroglyph wanted to make. Unfortunately, LucasArts tended to be fairly impatient with the release of the games and would rush games to the stores before they were even really ready. While a lot of the errors can be seen if you know what to look for, and the AI will cheat (the higher the difficulty, the more the AI will cheat. The only real way it gets "more difficult" is by having things there is no way it should have. The tactics the computer uses aginst you is always the same), it is still a very fun game. I have spent many a hour playing this game. The graphics are good, the sound is what you would expect from a Star Wars game, and the voice acting is very good.

Land Battles aren't my thing: I'd rather just play Star Wars Battlegrounds, it's deeper and suits my turtle tactics much more. The AI is somewhat disappointing, but I suppose I've come to expect that at this point from RTS games. Haven't even tried the campaign, since a) it's Star Wars, I already know the canon and b) it just... doesn't interest me. Not a great excuse, I suppose, for leaving the game "unfinished".
If the game were exclusively "Space Battle" focused, I'd love it, but as it is, it's okay.
Dunno who thought the Proton Torpedo Spamming Frigates were a good idea, but that person needs to get kicked in the crotch... talk about OP.
Other than that, edit an .xml to boost the pop cap, make a map in the editor (downloaded seperately, google it), and have at! It can be great fun!

one of if not the best strategy game EVER!

although i should technicaly say ''games'' as this is the combination of both the original and the expansion.  this game seemlessly combines a civ builder and a strategy game together to fully emerse the player in the star wars universe WITHOUT screaming ''star wars om nom nom.  only star wars fans all others excluded''  (infact many star wars fans of other star wars games feel alienated by this game)  however for the fans they will find many of thier favorite ships aswell as some interesting new ones and allot of backstory and info they might not have nowne otherwise.  

as for the game?  its a fun ALL real time strategy/civ builder.  everything is in real time.  everything is linked together.  from strategy map> space map> ground battles> taking over planets for the strategy map in a fast paced but fun way.  of course if you simply want to see GIANT ships firing HUNDREDS of lasers at each other then you can simply jump into the battles with space and ground skirmishs.  and the expansion? no it isnt some small add on or a tiny little pack but a full new campaigne and my favorite faction.  enter the consortium, a chaotic space mafia bent on ruling the universe!(ses economy) consortion adds not just new ships but also a unique and interesting and totaly new tech level upgrade sytem... stealing.  you can even steal ship disigns from the other factions and make them your own (though technicaly... uh oh that would be a spoiler)  the multiplayer is fun though it is an old game and therefor its probably best to find a friend that plays it.  additionaly the factions arent balenced very well but the expansion does add some balancing by making the rebel faction dominate the consortiom but not to the level that the empire dominates or the consortiums pure awsomness.  a multiplayer co-op campaigne would also have been cool but alas we can only dream.  there is however, a multiplayer co-op skirmish that is an interesting take on an age old idea (by that i mean starcraft :P)

Like Star Wars? Like Command & Conquer? Remember Rise of Nations? This is a lot like that, but not turn-based. In the galaxy map strategy part of the game, you have to build all of the units you're going to use in the ground and space battle parts of the game. Aside from that, you have hero units that can be deployed in battle or sent on special missions. Smugglers, for example, can be deployed to enemy systems to steal credits, or deployed in ground battles.

There's a lot of strategy and tactics involved. Certain simple tactics (baiting/kiting) will sometimes work and sometimes not, depending on how the AI feels right then. Like any good Total War game, you have the option of just allowing the computer to calculate the results of a battle instead of playing it out yourself. And as with any good Star Wars game, the music reacts to the battle conditions.

I give it a B+. When it was first released, I would have given it a C, but patches have improved the mechanics a lot.

I personally don't care for the expansion campaign. I forget what it's called. It certainly added some cool stuff to the game, but the campaign was just a bit too... I dunno. Too freeform? It was certainly significantly more difficult than the original Rebel and Imperial campaigns.
This game is absolutely amazing. Old so graphics are naturally out dated but it is amazing. Great gameplay, Endless hours of galactic conquest, Well worth it.

The first of the Star Wars titles to enter the grand strategy genre, Empire at War was highly anticipated but failed to meet expectations. Major flaws plague every aspect of the game. The developer made the poor decision to make the strategy map run in real-time rather than in a turn-based fashion, resulting in the need for constant pauses and frantic clicking; land battles are campy and boring; and space battles leave no room for tactics, as the bigger fleet nearly always wins by default. 

This game was created with an obvious degree of laziness, and the result is a frustrating experience. One can only assume that this arose from complacency on the part of the developer; perhaps it was believed that the Star Wars factor would compensate for the game's obvious shortcomings. If so, the developer was very incorrect.

I simply wish there were more Star Wars RTS games out there like Empire at War. Don't be confused by the storyline, it's not "canon" or adheres to the lore 100% but the gameplay is what sells me. I'm a huge Star Wars nuthead but when I came across the Galactic Map and all the planets I could conquer it seemed quite daunting.

You take over worlds with 2 fleets, the first fleet is your "Space Fleet", which invades an enemy planet and initiates a space battle. Should you win this battle (and destroy the enemy space station / fleet) you can send your second fleet, namely "Ground Forces". This will initiate a tactical land battle whereby you have to destroy all the enemy structures, capture reinforcement points in order to increase you unit cap on the map (therefore more ground forces can land) and do this with every planet. 

The large amount of units to choose from, different routes to take and with the addition of the Pirate Faction in Forces of Corruption (the expansion) you'll find that you're in for a really long and great time. The AI is ruthless on harder difficulties and the game is mod compatible so do check out the Empire at War Filefront website for huge add-ons to the game. 

At this point I guess I've clocked 400+ hours on this, and that's just a small estimate, I'm certain it's a LOT more. Check the game out, see videos of it online, do what you want but I highly recommend this game.

If you are a Star Wars fan, and love RTS games, then this title does not disappoint. There is a bit of a learning curve, and I found no pdf manual in the downloaded copy I recieved, so it will take a bit for most people to get used to this title.  The campaign mode is a bit dull, and it really does feel linear which in my opinion takes away from the fun.  The conquest mode with multiple maps to choose from, maps with just a few planets to mega maps with up to 55 planets to conquer in all, is where the real meat of this game lies.  In the forces of corruption add-on there are 3 playable factions, all working against each other for control of the galaxy.  Each of these factions have their own strengths and weaknesses and have their own winning strategy for achieving total domination, so there is lots of replayability with this game.  Finally, add to all of that a robust multiplayer mode and you've got a complete package of Star Wars mayhem that will satisfy any true Star Wars fan.  Do it

As a strategy game, Empire at War delivers a true Star Wars experience. If you're into AT-ATs stomping around battlefields, Darth Vader knocking over 20 soldiers with Force push, or space battles thick with dozens of fighters swarming in between gargantuan capital ships, Empire at War will deliver all that in a fun, compelling package. You can't really lose in any game in which you can blow up a planet with the Death Star, can you? Combined with a presentation that is as epic as the films that inspired the game and a slick, dual-layered strategy design, Empire at War is easily recommendable to any strategy fan, especially those who are fond of George Lucas' space classic.

Awful ground battles, but excellent space battles. As someone who's always enjoyed massive space battles picking it up for the space battles alone is worth it (though I would recomend modding the until cap for space battles since the default is far to low).

Star Wars + real time strategy + strategic gameplay? A winning combo in my humble opinion :P In addition to fighting real time battles over planets and in space, there is a campaign mode with a map where the player can plan which planet to attack, which production structures to build, and planetary defences. Planets have natives allied to the different sides that will help that side in any battle there (Rebellion/Empire/Zhan Consortion) and also provide unique bonuses for whoever controls them.

The bundle also comes with 3 full campaigns, the third culminating in the player controlling a Eclipse-class super star destroyer complete with it's very own anti-ship superlaser. Not to mention that the Empire can build the Death Star itself and use it to destroy enemy planets.

Also, X-wings, lightsabers, and Darth Vader.
